%no~

Introduction%ha~
       The goals of this translation are as follows. First, it is to make the NT more understandable. The average reader cannot understand the NT, and much of that is because of the philosophies of translations.%nv~
       Second is to bring more detail to the surface. As many nuances in grammar and shades of meaning of words are brought out as possible, preferring to bring this out in the rendered text rather than to economize words.%nv~
       Third is to take produce a translation which is unconstrained traditional constraints. The more popular Bible translations are maintained by large committees and are built upon long traditions, and while this has its advantages, it also has its disadvantages. Since I’m an outsider who has no self-interest and no reputation to lose, I’m in a position to say things many a distinguished professor dare not for those reasons %nv~
       Fourth is to put another NT translation out in the public domain. The hope is to make it easier to disseminate this work, to weaken the landscape of copyright and other intellectual property stakes for what should be the word of God, and—if you’ll excuse the hint of arrogance—to indirectly contribute to other translations by allowing them to copy and paste should they desire.%nv~
Notes%ha~
Translation Method%hb~
       This is a translation, not a paraphrase. I used the UBS %I@G%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@ %I@N%i@e%i@w%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t 3%u@r%u@d Edition as the source, supplemented with phone apps and websites. I didn’t use copyrighted translations as a basis, and only referred to one or two now or then for confirmation, a second opinion, for comparison after the fact, or to simply quote. I never copied any copyrighted translations. Since the KJV and ASV are public domain, I referred to them when I was at my wit’s end. I relied on several commentaries and lexicons plus the occasional grammar book. Of course, I had to research specific areas.%nv~
The Usual Markups%hb~
       Verse numbers are all superscripted, along with footnote references. Any of the traditional verse numbers missing from the UBS text were footnoted. As everyone knows, no punctuation or other special formatting was put in the original manuscripts; these all originate in the translation.%nv~
Italics%hb~
       Words in italics are interpolations. Interpolations consist of words, phrases, or even entire sentences which are added which are not derived from a literal translation of the Greek text. What’s deemed an interpolation is not always cut and dry. I did not consider nuances insinuated by a verb tense or some other grammatical construct or by a shade of meaning of a word used in a particular context to be interpolations.%nv~
       Some of the text was radically modified and although the rendered version has interpolations, it was too messy to italicize, especially the places marked %i@l%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@n. These were marked and handled in footnotes.%nv~
       You cannot make sense of the NT without interpolations, as the writers purposely omitted words for the sake of brevity. Or they were just plain sloppy. Sometimes, though, the writers assumed that the readers had certain a background understanding, one which the modern reader doesn’t have. Some of the interpolations I added, especially the longer ones, are obvious additions. Because the aim of this translation is to produce something which is understandable by the average person, such additions are crucial at times.%nv~
       Of course, all interpolations are subjective, and as such are a source of disagreement. The reason why they’re set off in italics is to alert the reader that they are additions and should be received as such. Since I plan to publish both an abridged and a unabridged version, the unabridged will have the interpolations left in but their italics removed (and I never used italics for anything other than an interpolation).%nv~
Footnotes%hb~
       Footnotes are noted with both capital and small letters formatted in superset and enclosed in brackets. The small-letter footnotes are, for the most part, comments on the translation or are short general comments. Capital-letter footnotes are long small-letter comments, are explanations about what some difficult verses and passages mean, or are just random comments about the passage.%nv~
       The footnotes supplement the translation where the translation fails to do justice to the text, or where there’s extra detail which the curious reader may glean: nuances or other shades of meaning that weren’t thoroughly captured in the translation, as it would be too wordy. In the course of this work, I eventually settled on a set of rules for footnoting. %nv~
       I footnote to express uncertainty; to list alternatives when uncertain; to reveal a lack of justice with which even my best intentions can do to the underlying text; to add insight that would otherwise clutter the translation; to give apology for the choices I’ve made.%nv~
       The word %i@o%i@r%i@ suffixed by a colon is an alternative, and indicates uncertainty as to how something should be translated from Greek into English. The alternative may be an improvement, it many not. The word %i@a%i@l%i@s%i@o%i@ is a supplement to what’s in the translation, an alternative rendering. What’s after %i@a%i@l%i@s%i@o%i@ should agree with what was translated, and offer a better explanation, more insight, or just help the reader understand what was translated better. Unlike %i@o%i@r, %i@a%i@l%i@s%i@o%i@ does not convey uncertainty.%nv~
       The word %I@L%i@i%i@t%i@.%i@ (short for %i@l%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y) is what a literal word-for-word translation of the Greek into English would look like. It is the literal wording that the text in the beginning of the footnote was derived from. The literal wording is added for the following reasons. First, so the reader can see the difference between the final translation and what the word-for-word translation would’ve looked like. Though there are several word-for-word translations available, there are times when the such translations are incomplete, inaccurate, or misleading. Second reason to add the literal wording is when the final translation doesn’t do justice to the literal wording, or when I think there may be value in the reader comparing the translation with the literal wording. Third, the literal wording is many times rich in figures of speech, or prose, or some poetic aesthetic and is a shame to deny the curious reader that richness. Fourth, when the footnote addresses some of the finer or more complicated details of the text, many times I must rely on the literal wording and not on the actual translation. Fifth, in the instances where I’m not certain of something, or when the passage is controversial, I’m supplying the curious reader the wherewithal to make the decision for himself. I attempt to convey what the underlying Greek is saying, and sometimes what the experts say about it, what my opinion of this is based on my own understanding of Greek, and do all of these so there reader can be armed with the knowledge he needs to arrive at an informed decision on his own. I often hear Bible teachers give explanations about what a Greek word used in a particular passage means, and many times they’re incomplete or worse flat out incorrect. Taking the usual Greek courses offered in seminaries is not sufficient. Many Greek words change meanings based on context; like any other language, Greek words are paired together; prepositions in any language are idiomatic; short, commonly-used words are some of the most difficult.%nv~
       The capital-letter footnotes are longer notes, notes that explain something which isn’t obvious to one who hasn’t studied the Bible intensely for years. These footnotes therefore fill in the background. The background may consist of cultural or historical background. They give clarification and justification to some of the more irregular renderings too. These are called %i@l%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@e%i@s in the footnotes; if the translation deviates completely from the Greek text, this is a liberty. For example, “go out to the on-ramps and the off-ramps,” part of Matt. 22:8, is a liberty; there were no interstates back then, so there were no on-ramps and off-ramps. The reader will know that. But there are other liberties that he won’t know; these liberties are documented.%nv~
       Whatever collateral damage is racked up in the rendering should be cleaned up in a capital-letter footnote. And from time to time a note is added which will explains difficult or controversial passages.%nv~
       %nv~
Abbreviations%hb~
       
%I@A%i@b%i@b%i@r%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%I@M%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@gGk.GreekGTThe Greek Texti.e.In other words…that is to say…put another way.Impl.Implied by the nuances in the GT, by a figure of speech, or by symbolismKJVKing James VersionLit.The GT literally reads…LXXThe SeptuagintNASBNew American Standard BibleNIVNew International Version BibleNTNew TestamentOTOld TestamentRef.Reference; refer to       %nv~
%nv~

The Gospel of Matthew%ha~
       According to church history, Matthew was the first of the four gospels to be written. Apparently, it was commissioned by the Jewish church, those Jews who came to believe in Jesus as the Messiah and continued to hold to their Jewish ways. For this reason it is steeped in Judaism and assumes the reader is familiar with the Judaism of the Old Testament.%nv~
       Matthew, one of the twelve apostles, was a logical choice to write this book since he was an eyewitness to most of Jesus’s ministry, which is the majority of the book. It’s assumed that the parts in which he wasn’t an eye-witness, he interviewed those who lived in Israel who were themselves eyewitnesses of John’s ministry, etc.%nv~
       Church history also says that Matthew was originally written in Hebrew then translated into Gk. The GT has a simplistic and awkward feeling, the same sort you get when you follow subtitles of a foreign movie. It is apparent in the GT that Matthew was not a native Greek speaker. He does not have the command of the language which Paul and Luke have. But one thing is clear: an extensive amount of research went into the Gospel of Matthew.%nv~
       But Matthew is rich in figures of speech, rich in symbolism, and has a Semitic feel to it. This gives it a uniqueness among the NT books. The figures of speech have a richness which is difficult to follow for those not intimately familiar with the Bible and those who can’t see the figures of speech beneath the literal words. The more literal translations, the KJV in particular, preserve the colorful language at the expense of being more difficult to comprehend. In order to make it more comprehensible, much of the rich language has to be abandoned, which is a pity. To complicate matters, Matthew quotes Jesus saying things that cause one to stop and scratch his head for a while.%nv~
       So that these treasures of literature don’t completely fall through the cracks of translation, copious footnotes supplement the rendered text to point to the original, beautiful language. In addition, because Matthew is such a lively book, it merits a more lively translation. If one looks through all the layers of translations, simplicity of language, myriads of OT references, one sees that Jesus was a colorful speaker, much like those simple ministers who can break a congregation out into laughter and a moment later bring them to tears. Of interest, also, is that there are a couple of parables which are told like an ordinary story, no surprises. An interesting story, but one which, part way through, ceases to be an ordinary story and goes off the rail into something bizarre. Examples are the parable of the wheat and the tares (Math. 13), parable of the vineyard day-laborers (Matt. 20). %nv~
%i@%sb~
Matthew Chapter 1%hb~
%u@1A Genealogical Record%u@[%U@A%u@] of Jesus Christ, Descendent of David and of Abraham:%vt~
%u@2Abraham had Isaac,%vp~
Isaac had Jacob,%vp~
Jacob had Judah and his brothers,%vp~
%u@3Judah had Fares and Zara from Tamar%u@[%U@B%u@], %vp~
Fares had Hesrom,%vp~
Hesrom had Aram,%vp~
%u@4Aram had Aminadab%vp~
Aminadab had Naasson,%vp~
Naason had Salmon,%vp~
%u@5Salmon & Rahab had Boaz,%vp~
Boaz & Ruth had Obed,%vp~
Obed had Jesse,%vp~
%u@6Jesse had King David,%vp~
David got with Urriah’s wife and had Solomon,%vp~
%u@7Solomon had Rehoboam,%vp~
Rehoboam had Abia,%vp~
Abia had Asaf,%vp~
%u@8Asaf had Jehosaphat,%vp~
Jehosaphat had Jeoram,%vp~
Jeoram had Ozias,%vp~
%u@9Ozias had Jotham,%vp~
Jotham had Ahab,%vp~
Ahab had Hezekiah,%vp~
%u@1%u@0Hezekiah had Manassah,%vp~
Manassah had Amos,%vp~
Amos had Josiah,%vp~
%u@1%u@1Josiah had Jehonias and his brothers while in captivity in Babylon,%vp~
%u@1%u@2After the Babylonian captivity, Jehonias had Salathial,%vp~
Salathial had Zerubabel,%vp~
%u@1%u@3Zerubabel had Abioud,%vp~
Abiod had Eliakim,%vp~
Eliakim had Azor,%vp~
%u@1%u@4Azor had Zadok,%vp~
Zadok had Achim,%vp~
Achim had Eliud,%vp~
%u@1%u@5Eliud had Eleazar,%vp~
Eleazar had Matthan,%vp~
Matthan had Jacob,%vp~
%u@1%u@6Jacob had Joseph, Mary’s husband,%vp~
…and from her was born Jesus, who’s called “the Christ.”%i@%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@7In total, there were fourteen generations from Abraham to David; there were fourteen generations from David to the Babylonian captivity; there were fourteen generations from the Babylonian captivity to Jesus.%vn~
%u@1%u@8The Way Jesus’s Birth Was%vt~
      After Mary was engaged but before she was officially married%u@[%U@C%u@] to Joseph—and before she was intimate%u@[%U@D%u@] with him—she found that she was pregnant, and that it was from the Holy Spirit. %u@1%u@9Her husband Joseph, being someone who always did the right thing and not wanting to disgrace Mary, decided to himself that he’d quietly break up with her. %u@2%u@0After he talked himself into doing this—of all things—an angel sent from the Lord appeared to him in a dream and said,%vn~
      “Joseph, you marvelous godsend%u@[%u@a%u@], don’t be afraid to keep Mary as your wife; what she’s conceived in fact came from the Holy Spirit. %u@2%u@1She’ll give birth to a son, and you’re going to name him ‘Jesus’%u@[%u@b%u@], since he will indeed deliver the people from their sins.” %u@2%u@2All of this has happened in order to fulfill the prophecy%u@[%u@c%u@] which came through the Prophet Isaiah, which says,%vn~
%si~
%u@2%u@3Check this out! Our virgin here will get pregnant and give birth to a son,%vp~
And they’ll call him Emmanuel (which translated means “God with us”)%vp~
%si~
%u@2%u@4Joseph woke up from the dream and did just as he was told to do by the angel sent from God and kept Mary as his wife %u@2%u@5and didn’t sleep%u@[%U@D%u@] with her until after she’d given birth to the son, whom he named Jesus.%nn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@d%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@d…Lit: %I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@D%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@.%i@ Ref. note of Matt. 12:23.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s…The name %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s in Hebrew means %i@d%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@r or %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@u%i@e%i@r%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@c%i@y…Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@A%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@o%i@g%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d…It begs the question, “Just why does the NT begin with a genealogy?” It’s because all OT characters of any significance have their genealogy enumerated, which is important as Matthew was written for a Jewish audience. It’s to show that Jesus fulfills the promises and prophecies repeated throughout the ages. It establishes Jesus’s pedigree, which while not important to us today was important in OT times. It shows the mercy of God and providence of God as Jesus descended from less-than-perfect humans.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@F%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@Z%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m %I@T%i@a%i@m%i@a%i@r…Some liberties taken with translating the names. Attempt made to render well-known names as they appear in most English Bibles, but no attempt was made to do all of them; some are as-is from the GT.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@e%i@n%i@g%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o…In Jewish culture, Mary’s engagement to Joseph was just a step shy of a real marriage, certainly stronger than what we consider to be an engagement. To break such an engagement constituted a divorce.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r; %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@l%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ (v.25)…Lit: %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@k%i@n%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r.%i@ These are biblical euphemisms for sex. Of note is that the verb tense in v.18 %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ specifies a one-time event.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Matthew Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1Now after Jesus was born in Bethlehem, in the province of Judea, during the days of King Herod, out of nowhere these gurus called “magii”%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@ who came from the East%u@[%U@B%u@] and showed up in Jerusalem %u@2going about saying, “Where’s that child-king of the Jews? The fact is, we saw his star while over in the East and came to worship him.”%vn~
          %u@3Hearing about this made King Herod queasy, along with everyone else in Jerusalem. %u@4So he gathered the chief priests and the designated teachers called scribes%u@[%U@C%u@] and quizzed them to find out exactly where the Messiah%u@[%U@D%u@] would be born. %u@5They told him, “In Bethlehem, Judea, since it’s been written about by the Prophet %I@M%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@h:%vn~
%si~
%u@6”And for you, Bethlehem, Judea, by no means%vp~
Do you come in last place%vp~
In the Judean power rankings;%vp~
For out of you will come a ruler who’ll lead my people Israel”%vp~
%si~
          %u@7Then Herod stealthily summoned the magii and ascertained from them the time of the star’s appearance, %u@8and sent them to Bethlehem telling them, “Go ask around and gather all the facts you can about this child. Then after you find him, come tell me so that I can come and worship him too.” %u@9Having heard this from the king, they went out and—just like that—the same star which they saw back east took the lead in front of them until it reached the place where the child was and then stood still up over that place. %u@1%u@0Seeing what the star had done, they got really excited%u@[%u@a%u@]. %u@1%u@1They went into the house and saw the child with his mother Mary and fell flat on their faces and worshipped him. Then they opened their chests and delivered gifts to him, gold, frankincense, and myrrh. %u@1%u@2And having received a divine instruction given through a dream to not return to Herod but instead to take another way out, they left to go back to their homeland.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Now after they had departed, just like that an angel appeared in a dream to Joseph telling him, “Get up, grab the child and his mother, and run for your life to Egypt. Stay there until I tell you. Herod, you see, is going about seeking to eliminate the child.” %u@1%u@4So he got up, took the child and his mother, and left for Egypt under the cover of darkness. %u@1%u@5And he stayed there until Herod passed away, in order that the prophet Hosea’s prophecy%u@[%u@b%u@] would be fulfilled, which says, “From out of Egypt I summoned my son.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@6Now when Herod realized that he’d been tricked by the magii, he got really angry and had all the children in Bethlehem and all the surrounding areas eliminated, from two and under, consistent with the time which he’d ascertained from the magii. %u@1%u@7It was then that the prophet Jeremiah’s prophecy was fulfilled, which says,%vn~
%si~
%u@1%u@8A sound was heard in Ramah%u@[%U@E%u@]—%vp~
Weeping and wailing—%vp~
Rachel%u@[%U@E%u@] crying over her children%vp~
And she wasn’t wanting to be comforted,%vp~
Since they’re gone for good%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@9After Herod died—just like that—an angel sent from the Lord appeared in a dream to Joseph while in Egypt %u@2%u@0saying,%vn~
      “Get up and take the child and his mother and go to Israel, now that those who’ve been craving to snuff out the child’s life are finally dead.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@1So he got up and took the child and his mother and entered the country of Israel. %u@2%u@2But since he heard that Archelaos had replaced his father as king of Judea, he was afraid to go over there. Getting instructions through a dream, he detoured over to the Galilean area, %u@2%u@3and when he got there, he settled in a city called Nazareth, in order that what the prophets had prophesied would be fulfilled, that he would be considered to be a Nazarene.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%I@S%i@e%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@d…Lit: %I@S%i@e%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@j%i@o%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@j%i@o%i@y%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@y. The repetition of %i@j%i@o%i@y%i@ here is a figure of speech. Also ref. Mark 5:42.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@c%i@y…Lit: %I@W%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@c%i@y…Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@m%i@a%i@g%i@i%i@i%i@…The magii were spiritualists who were genuinely seeking after the One True God. They interpreted astrological signs as from God. They didn’t worship the stars above but nevertheless expected God to use them—which in both the OT and NT, God at times does use astrological signs to communicate with man.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@E%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@…Literal rendering of the GT. Just as we might say that those folks out West do such-and-such, and things are done different down South, so the East in the Bible has connotations of its own (Gen. 2:8, 3:24, 4:16 for some) as being a mystical, spiritual place.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@C%i@h%i@i%i@e%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %I@S%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s…these are the elites of the religious class. The chief priest held the power while the scribes had the utmost knowledge and expertise, called on to settle disputes.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@M%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@a%i@h%i@…Lit: %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@. The Jews have always believed that the Scripture speaks of a messianic person, whom is named the %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t, which is equivalent to the %I@M%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@a%i@h.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%I@R%i@a%i@m%i@a%i@h%i@…%I@R%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@l%i@…The place %I@R%i@a%i@m%i@a%i@h%i@ and the name %I@R%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@l%i@ are metonymies . Ramah is a suburb of Jerusalem to the north, so Ramah is a metonymy of the greater metropolitan area of Jerusalem extending out to remote suburbs. Remote, because Bethlehem is a suburb south of Jerusalem, whereas Ramah is a suburb to the north, making their distance even greater. Rachel is an ancestor of the Benjamites who lived there. Hence Rachel, assumed to be a common woman’s name, is a metonymy for the typical, child-bearing woman who lives in Jerusalem and in its far-reaching suburbs. As such she personifies the suffering of the average woman who lived anywhere near Jerusalem and who had infants at that time. To put these metonymies in terms that the contemporary generation understands, the name %I@R%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@l is a meme like the name %I@K%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@ is a meme for the Gen-Z’ers. To be clear, Rachel is not a Karen—i.e. both are memes but characterize entirely different types of women. Since %I@R%i@a%i@m%i@a%i@h%i@ is so far from Bethlehem, it can be viewed as a metonymy similar to the metonymy %I@T%i@i%i@m%i@b%i@u%i@k%i@t%i@u. %fn~
%i@%sb~
Matthew Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1Now back in those days, John the Baptist appeared on the scene in the Judean countryside%u@[%u@a%u@] %u@2saying, “Straighten up and change your ways%u@[%u@b%u@], since God’s involvement with mankind (the kingdom of heaven) just got here! %u@3You see, what’s taking place here is the prophecy from Isaiah which says,%vn~
%si~
The sound of shouting in the countryside:%vp~
“Block off the road the Lord will take!%vp~
Barricade the streets he’ll be on!%u@[%u@c%u@]”%u@%vp~
%si~
          %u@4John dressed himself in a camel-hair outfit wrapped in a leather belt, and his diet consisted of grasshoppers%u@[%u@d%u@] and wild honey.%u@[%U@A%u@] %u@5At that time everybody%u@[%U@B%u@] in Jerusalem and Judea and everybody from around the Jordan kept coming out to see him. %u@6And they were %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r being baptized in the Jordan River by him while pouring their hearts out in confessing their sins out loud.%vn~
          %u@7Seeing that many of the Pharisees and Sadducees were showing up at his baptism, he said to them, “You nest%u@[%U@C%u@] of vipers, who convinced you to run for your lives because of the coming wrath? %u@8Have the change in lifestyle%u@[%u@e%u@] which goes hand-in-hand with%i@ the commitment to a change in ways%u@[%u@f%u@]. %u@9And while discussing this among yourselves, don’t say, ‘We’re descendants of Abraham.’%u@[%U@D%u@] Oh yes—I tell you, God is able to turn these stones%u@[%U@E%u@] here into descendants%u@[%u@g%u@] of Abraham. %u@1%u@0The axe is lying next to the tree trunk%u@[%U@F%u@] %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@e%i@d: Every tree which isn’t yielding good fruit will be chopped down and tossed into a fire. %u@1%u@1Me—I baptize in water towards the goal of repentance, but the one who’ll come after me is greater%u@[%u@h%u@] than me; I’m not worthy enough to carry him around by the soles of his shoes.%u@[%U@G%u@] But him—he’ll baptize in a fiery manifestation of the Holy Spirit%u@[%U@H%u@]—%i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e; %u@1%u@2with the winnowing fork in his hand, he’ll clear everything off his threshing floor too. He’ll store his wheat in the silo but will burn up the chaff with a fire that will never be put out.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Then Jesus appeared on the scene in the Jordan region, %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g from Galilee, to get with John, to be baptized by him. %u@1%u@4But John brushed him off saying, “It’s me who needs to be baptized by you, but you’re approaching me instead?” %u@1%u@5Jesus formulated a reply and said, %r@“%R@L%r@e%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@.%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %R@T%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@u%r@b%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@u%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@q%r@u%r@i%r@r%r@e%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@u%r@l%r@f%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@”%r@ He then permitted it. %u@1%u@6While he was being baptized, he came straight up out of the water, and—of all things—the sky opened up, and he saw the Spirit of God coming down like a dove upon him. %u@1%u@7And—of all things—a voice spoke from the sky saying, “This one here is my Beloved Son, and I’m quite pleased with him.”%vn~

%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@S%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@B%i@l%i@o%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@a%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@!%i@ %I@B%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n!…Lit: %I@P%i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@a%i@d%i@!%i@ %I@S%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@s%i@!%i@ Some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@g%i@r%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@h%i@o%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@l%i@o%i@c%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@y%i@l%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@u%i@i%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@g%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@…Lit: is %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@g%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@…Lit: %i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@i%i@e%i@r%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%I@L%i@e%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@t…Lit: %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@w%i@.%i@ This is echoed at the end of v.15, where it lit. says, %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@.%i@%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@J%i@o%i@h%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@-%i@h%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@f%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@h%i@o%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@y…His clothing was uncomfortable, ungainly, and unattractive; his food did not taste good and was inconvenient to procure.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@…The word %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y here is a figure of speech (a type of Synecdoche), and does not actually mean every single person. It’s like if we were to say, “Everybody was at the Christmas party last week.”%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@t…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@o%i@d%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%I@W%i@e%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@A%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@…Lit: %I@W%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %I@A%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r, implying that God approves of their lives because of their pedigree%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@…Here and in other places, the NT hints that stones are symbolic of the masses of mankind%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@x%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@x%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@n%i@k…Also: %I@S%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@m%i@m%i@e%i@r%i@.%i@ Note the word %i@l%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ means %i@p%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@,%i@ same as in Phil. 1:16.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@y%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@y%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@e. In the Bible, putting somebody “under your feet” is to put him in subjection to you. Bearing someone by the sole of his shoe is an act of servitude and humility akin to a servant would wash his master’s feet.%fn~
%u@[%U@H%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@.%i@ This is a figure of speech called a %i@h%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@s. There is no actual baptism in fire; it means that Holy Spirit will manifest himself in a fiery way. This figure of speech also appears in John 4:23,24, %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@.%i@ In both cases, the hendiadys is indicates something which can hardly be put in words but has to be experienced; hence the additional words %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@.%i@ It is also used in Mk. 11:24; John 10:1. Most/all the hendiadyses which occur in the Gospels share something in common: they all describe a spiritual experience or a spiritual being, and being spiritual in nature transcend human comprehension, thus the use of the hendiadys.%fn~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 4%hb~
          %u@1Then Jesus was guided by the Spirit into the countryside%u@[%u@a%u@] to be tempted%u@[%U@A%u@] by the devil. %u@2After fasting for forty days and nights, he finally became hungry, %u@3and the Tempter came by and said,%vn~
      “If your position is %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@e%i@d Son of God, speak so that these stones become bread.”%vn~
       %u@4But he answered him, %r@“%R@I%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@,%vn~
%si~
%R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@”%vp~
%si~
          %u@5So the devil then took him to the holy city, and placed him on the battlements on the temple roof%u@[%U@B%u@]. %u@6He turned and, in continuation, said,%vn~
      “If you’re %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@e%i@d God’s son, jump off. %I@I%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@a%i@n, it’s written,%vn~
%si~
Where you are concerned,%vp~
He’ll issue orders for His angels to follow.%vp~
They’ll even lift you up by putting you on their hands,%vp~
Lest your foot impact a stone.”%vp~
%si~
          %u@7Jesus declared to him, %r@“%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@v%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@p%r@l%r@y%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %R@H%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@l%r@s%r@.%r@’%r@”%vn~
          %u@8So again the devil took him to a really high mountain and shows him all the kingdoms of the world and their glory. %u@9And he said, “All of these I’ll give to you, if you would fall and worship me.” %u@1%u@0Then Jesus, finishing the conversation, said, %r@“%R@D%r@e%r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@,%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@!%r@ %R@I%r@n%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@g%r@a%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@,%vn~
%si~
%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@s%r@h%r@i%r@p%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@%vp~
%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@u%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@r%r@v%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %R@H%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@”%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@1Then the devil left him, and—then and there—some angels came and attended to him.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Once he heard that John had been taken into custody, he withdrew to Galilee. %u@1%u@3After leaving Nazareth for good, he took up residence in Capernaum-on-the-Sea in the region of Zebulon and Naphtali, %u@1%u@4so that Isaiah’s prophecy%u@[%u@b%u@] might be fulfilled, which says,%vn~
%si~
%u@1%u@5In the land of Zebulon and in the land of Naphtali%vp~
On the road leading to the sea, on the other side of the Jordan%vp~
In the region of Galilee—%vp~
%u@1%u@6The folk sitting in darkness saw a great light,%vp~
And for the ones sitting in a region %i@%vp~
%I@W%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e under the shadow of death%u@[%U@C%u@]%vp~
A light shined on them%vp~
%si~
%u@1%u@7Starting then, Jesus began to go about and proclaim openly,%nn~
%si~
%R@S%r@t%r@r%r@a%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@S%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@v%r@o%r@l%r@v%r@e%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@(%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@)%r@%vp~
%R@J%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@!%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@8While sauntering down the Sea of Galilee coastline, he saw two brothers, Simon, whom they call Peter, and Andrew his brother, casting fishing nets into the sea, since they were fishermen. %u@1%u@9He said to them, %r@“%R@B%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@c%r@i%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@,%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@D%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@” %u@2%u@0Right away they quit being fishermen%u@[%U@E%u@] and became his disciples%u@[%u@d%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@1Continuing on from there, he saw another pair%u@[%u@e%u@] of brothers, James son of Zebedee and John his brother, in the boat with their father Zebedee mending their fishing nets. He called them. %u@2%u@2Right away they left the boat and their father and became his disciples%u@[%u@f%u@]. %u@2%u@3He began to go about the entire region of Galilee teaching in the%u@[%u@g%u@] synagogues and proclaiming the good news%u@[%u@h%u@] of the kingdom and treating%u@[%U@F%u@]%u@ any kind of and all sorts of diseases and any kind of and all sorts of maladies%u@[%U@G%u@] among the people. %u@2%u@4News of him spread throughout the whole region of Syria. They brought to him all kinds of people%u@[%u@i%u@] having something wrong with them…various kinds of sicknesses, those suffering or in pain%u@[%u@j%u@], the demon-possessed, epileptics, paralytics…and he treated everyone. %u@2%u@5Large crowds from Galilee, Decapolis, Jerusalem, the Jordan, and from the other side of the Jordan followed him around.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@I%i@s%i@a%i@i%i@a%i@h%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@c%i@y%i@…Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@a%i@i%i@a%i@h%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@. Of note is the difference in verb tense between this and Mark 14:13, where Jesus said, %I@F%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. In 14:13, following is a one-time event. Here in Matthew, it’s an unbounded action.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@p%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@w%i@o%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@n%i@a%i@g%i@o%i@g%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@n%i@a%i@g%i@o%i@g%i@u%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@g%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@.%i@ This is a figure of speech called a synecdoche.%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@s%i@u%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@e%i@d…In the GT, %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ here%i@ implies having to pass a series or a program of trials, tests, and temptations, loosely analogous to a ship which must pass sea trials before it can be certified as fit for use%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@o%i@f%i@…The temple complex sits on a hilltop in the center of Jerusalem, the highest point in the city central. The temple reaches high in the sky and overlooks the temple mount and its courtyard bustling with crowds. The temple is crowned with a golden, decorative, pointy battlement around the perimeter of its roof. The GT refers to this battlement in v. 5, and its perch would’ve allowed one to see a panorama of the temple, the city, and the surroundings of Jerusalem. %fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@g%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@…Lit: %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@g%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@.%i@ A figure of speech enhancing the metaphor rendered %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%I@B%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@s…in the GT literally reads %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@e, and is normally translated %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@m%i@e. This phrase in the GT is close in wording to Matt. 16:23, %I@G%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@e; both imply subordination.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@q%i@u%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@.%i@ The Gk. word for %i@n%i@e%i@t%i@s in v. 20 is a different word than what is used for %i@n%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ in v. 18. The %i@n%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ in v.18 describe a specific type of fishing net; the %i@n%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ in v. 20 is the general word for any kind of net. The word %i@n%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ as used in v. 20 is a figure of speech meaning that Peter and Andrew retired from fishing. A contemporary figure of speech in the setting of a western novel would be that of a sheriff who “hangs up his gun”—he retires from being sheriff. Likewise t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ implies that they hung them up, never to take them down again. In any case, it doesn’t necessarily mean that Jesus shouted to them and they literally dropped the nets they had been casting in v. 18.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%I@T%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@…in the Gk. NT means healing, casting out demons, or what-not—doing whatever it takes to remedy the patient%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%I@M%i@a%i@l%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@…this word is typically translated %i@i%i@n%i@f%i@i%i@r%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ or %i@a%i@f%i@f%i@l%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s. It’s a strange or unknown or lingering type of sickness. With modern medicine, we’re accustomed to root-causing and thereby categorizing any kind of disease, but in ancient times, people became sick for no apparent reason. This kind of sickness is a %i@m%i@a%i@l%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@.%i@%fn~
%i@%sb~
Matthew Chapter 5%hb~
          %u@1Now seeing the crowds, he hiked up the mountains%u@[%u@a%u@], and upon seating himself, his disciples came to him. %u@2He opened his mouth and proceeded to teach them %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@,%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@m%i@o%i@n%u@[%u@b%u@]:%vn~
%si~
%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@B%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@o%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@u%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@y%r@-%r@s%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@A%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@%vp~
%R@S%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@.%r@%vp~
%r@%si~
%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@B%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@B%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@S%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@%vp~
%r@%si~
%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@B%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@l%r@f%r@-%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@r%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@f%r@t%r@-%r@s%r@p%r@o%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@C%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@S%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@g%r@i%r@t%r@i%r@m%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@a%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@%vp~
%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@D%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@%vp~
%r@%si~
%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@B%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@r%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@e%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@S%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@s%r@f%r@i%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@%vp~

%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@p%i@a%i@y%i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@…Lit: %i@w%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@s%fn~

%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@P%i@o%i@o%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@-%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ (Lit: %i@p%i@o%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t) is one who does not think himself or herself to have enough of God, to have a close enough relationship with Jesus, to have enough of the presence of the Holy Spirit, to name a few%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@M%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s…In this context they are those who have a deep sorrow, to the point of grief—the same grief experienced when a loved-one passes away—when they do wrong; when they want more of God; when they intercede for others who’re away from God; when they pray for those in authority, knowing the troubles that are in the world; for their own complacency; for their own callousness; the list goes on…%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@-%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@f%i@t%i@-%i@s%i@p%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@;%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@;%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@e%i@k. %I@M%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@ appears in the KJV; modern translations prefer %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@.%i@ When Matthew quoting Jesus wrote “the meek shall inherit the earth,” the GT which Matthew wrote is a near-verbatim copy of the GT of Ps. 37:11 in the LXX. Studying the context surrounding Ps. 37:11 gives the interested party a broader understanding of what Jesus had in mind when he spoke those words. In any event, meekness can be described as the absence of the pushiness, the obnoxious attitudes, the belligerency, the quickness to retaliate, the harsh words and sharpness of tongue, the carnal loudness, the eagerness to step on others in order to promote self, etc. In the absence of these emerges that gentle demeanor called %i@m%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@.%i@%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@l%i@e%i@g%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@a%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@t. Ref. note of Luke 10:25.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@u%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@…Lit: %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@o%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n. This%i@ is a NT idiom meaning %i@m%i@i%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m. Ref. Matt. 7:6; Luke 21:24; Rev. 11:2.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@…Lit:%i@ %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@.%i@ The literal reading from the GT is what they called the Old Testament in Jesus’s day%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@u%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@o%i@t%i@a%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@-%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@n. The Greek letter %i@i%i@o%i@t%i@a%i@ (the smallest Gk. Letter)%i@ is a proxy for the Hebrew letter %i@y%i@o%i@d (י‎), which is a small letter resembling a backwards apostrophe, much smaller than any of the other letters of the Hebrew alphabet. The Gk. word %i@l%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@-%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@ is derived from the Gk. word for %i@h%i@o%i@r%i@n, perhaps a diminutive. When applied to the alphabet, the closest English equivalent is %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@f, but that doesn’t do the word justice, as there are several sets of letters in the Hebrew alphabet which are indistinguishable except for a short stroke of the pen, a small protrusion—a little horn. Here’s some pairs of Hebrew letters which are only distinguished by a short stroke of the pen: gimel and nun (ג vs. נ‎); bet and kaph (ב vs. כ‎); dalet and rhesh (ד vs. ר). There are other pairs. So Jesus is saying that there’ll be no small stroke of the pen which will delete the letter yod or swap a letter for its similar-looking twin. Since written Hebrew doesn’t normally use vowels, the changing of a single letter could more easily change an entire word than a single change of a letter in English could. And, of course, a change in word could change the meaning of a verse entirely. So Jesus is saying there’ll be no small stroke of the pen changes to the Law which would result in profound changes to the meaning of a verse in the Law.%fn~
%u@[%U@H%u@]%i@i%i@d%i@i%i@o%i@t…Lit: %i@r%i@a%i@k%i@a. One of the few Aramaic words appearing in the NT. It borders on cursing.%fn~
%u@[%U@I%u@]%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@…Liberties taken in the translation to make it more relevant; vv. 23,4 actually read, %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@t%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@m%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@,%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@t%i@a%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g. Over the course of the year, Jews were required to journey to the temple in Jerusalem and offer up a sacrifice of various kinds at the altar on the temple premises. The trip to Jerusalem could take a few days, unlike going down the street a few blocks to get to church.%fn~
%u@[%U@J%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@…Liberties taken in the translation to make it more relevant; vv. 25,26 actually read, %I@M%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@a%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@q%i@u%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@l%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@a%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@f%i@f%i@ [%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t]%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@j%i@a%i@i%i@l%i@.%i@ %I@V%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@f%i@y%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@,%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@e%i@n%i@t. This describes a civil action decided by a judge with no jury. Back then, those who didn’t have the money to pay the entire settlement the judge determined would be thrown into jail immediately.%fn~
%u@[%U@K%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@…A misunderstood verse, easily clarified when a bit of common sense is applied. In no way is staring carnally at another woman equivalent to or as morally wrong as having sex with her. The point Jesus is making is that both the ogler and the adulterer are transgressors of the law; committing either breaks a stainless record. But the difference between the two is like the difference between a light misdemeanor and a high class felony—and distinctions in the severity of transgressions is a concept adhered to elsewhere in the Bible.%fn~
%u@[%U@L%u@]%i@i%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@y%i@e%i@/%i@i%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@…In the Bible, eyes are symbolic of the heart’s desire and hands are symbolic of actions you take. The right eye is the principal desire of the heart, and the right hand is the most important thing that you do. This passage, symbolic and not literal, means to aggressively and decisively eradicate any bad desires in your heart or eliminate any habits, actions, involvements, etc. if any of these is a principal cause of you committing sin.%fn~
%u@[%U@M%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@q%i@u%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@v%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@…Under OT Law/the Law of Moses, as quoted here, divorce was permitted. By law, the husband could (but the wife could not) initiate the legal proceedings for the divorce and, if approved, was required to supply her with a divorce certificate to protect her reputation, her legal, and her moral standing. In this day and age, the laws for divorce are applied equally to husbands and wives, therefore Jesus’s commandment applies equally to both sexes as well. So in v. 32, which reads, %i@d%i@i%i@v%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@x%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@m%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@o%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@v%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@r, the case of the husband is treated differently than the case of the wife, as the husband was permitted by law to initiate a marriage and to initiate a divorce. The wife could only ascent to it or acquiesce to it. Therefore, their situations are different, and Jesus speaks to both separately. In modern times, we would simply say, %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@v%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@(%i@e%i@x%i@c%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@x%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@m%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@)%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@y.%fn~
%u@[%U@N%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@l%i@a%i@p%i@s%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@s%i@o %i@(%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@t%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@)%i@…”An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth” was OT law; the same was also embedded in Hammurabi’s law code. If someone wrongs you, you have the legal right of retaliation, the right to get even. For mankind, this is natural law; “turning the other cheek” is therefore a point of contention for many. A couple things to consider. First, the point Jesus was making is that you don’t have to retaliate when you’re wronged. He didn’t mean that you shouldn’t protect yourself against those who try to harm you. Second, read Acts 23:1-10, where Paul was actually slapped on the cheek, and ask yourself, “Did Paul turn the other cheek?” Same thing for Acts 16:37: when Paul, a Roman citizen, had been illegally beaten, he demanded his rights. Also see Acts 22:25.%fn~
Turning the other cheek is to present the same “face”—the same disposition—which you presented previously. Don’t change your disposition based on the way people treat you. For example, an employee is working at a retailer. While the employee is politely explaining a company policy, the customer behaves rudely. The employee turns the cheek when he continues to show politeness after the customer behaves badly. An example of turning the other cheek is when Joseph decided to divorce Mary (Matt. 1:19): he chose to do it quietly rather than to retaliate by making a stink about it.%fn~
Turning the other cheek is not as extreme and uncommon as it appears. In fact, even non-Christians turn the other cheek from time to time. Waitresses who are treated rudely by their customers but continue to be polite to them are turning the other cheek.%fn~
%u@[%U@O%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@p%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@w%i@o%i@…By law, if a Roman soldier passed one going the opposite direction, by law he was permitted to force him to carry his pack for him for a mile.%fn~
%u@[%U@P%u@]%i@d%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@l%i@f%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@e%i@c%i@t. %I@P%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ is also translated %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@t%i@e or %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@d; a complete person fulfills the full intention of God’s laws and not just the letter of it, what appears on the surface, or what is left over when corners are cut. %I@P%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ is used in v. 48 here the same way it’s used in James 1:4.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Matthew Chapter 6%hb~
          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@”%R@D%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@A%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@;%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@w%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@n%r@e%r@f%r@i%r@t%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@ %u@[%u@i%u@]%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@u%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@…Impl: accumulate spiritual material, not natural%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@f%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@i%i@s %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@d%i@a%i@r%i@k%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@a%i@r%i@…Lit: %i@m%i@a%i@m%i@m%i@o%i@n, Aramaic for %i@m%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@y%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@t%i@…Some manuscripts add, %I@O%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k, some don’t%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@c%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@…Lit: %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@a%i@ cubit[a%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@o%i@t%i@/%i@3%i@0%i@ %i@c%i@m]%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@-%i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@…Lit: %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@…Lit. %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@.%i@ Implied that it’s the observance of a prescribed religious act, the religion in this case specified by the Law of Moses%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@U%i@p%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@,%i@ an abstract place somewhere up the sky and beyond. God is up there, somewhere, not exactly sure where, but He’s up there%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@v%i@o%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@(%I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@)%i@…%I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@(%I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@)…Your kingdom, the kingdom of God, enter God’s kingdom, or some other variation of the same is an idiom first promulgated by Jesus himself. Some confusion arises if we simply take the phrase at face-value instead of taking it as an idiom. The face-value meaning steers us in the direction of a person either becoming a Christian or not; either gaining access to heaven in the afterlife or not; etc. The meaning of this idiom is understood by studying the usages in the NT, since it is used copiously. One example is Acts 14:22, …%i@s%i@u%i@c%i@c%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@(%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@). Notice how Acts 14:22 is encouraging those who are already believers to enter the kingdom of God.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@m%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@d%i@a%i@y%i@…Lit: %I@S%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ [%i@a%i@t%i@-%i@e%i@x%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e]%i@ %I@B%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@.%i@ Note the Gk. word for %i@s%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ namely %i@e%i@p%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@s (ἐπιούσιος/Strong’s 1967) only appears in the NT here and in Luke 11:3. According to Origen, this word was coined by Matthew and Luke; tradition maintains that it means “necessary for existence.” The root %i@o%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@a (οὐσία/Strong’s 3776) means “substance, state, condition, being, essence”; although the prefix %i@e%i@p%i@i (ἐπί/Strong’s 1909) can mean several things, it’s assumed to mean “at” in this word. (Gk. prefixes do not always modify the meaning of the root word in a predictable way.) But it’s entirely plausible that %i@a%i@t%i@-%i@e%i@x%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ is more precisely rendered %i@s%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@,%i@ which is the meaning of %i@e%i@p%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@s%i@ passed down by tradition. %I@B%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ is a synecdoche for food in general, as, up until the last century or so, the majority of caloric intake of the average person came from starches—bread, rice, potatoes.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%I@T%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o….from the GT, the picture of us being on a bus or something and God is the bus driver, and He takes us wherever. The word %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ refers to temptation as we know it but also refers to tests and trials that could break us.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%I@B%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@u%i@f%i@f…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@.%i@ Refers to all of the wrong, all of the bad, and all of the evil that goes on in this world.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%I@R%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@u%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@…Some early manuscripts of Matthew were corrupted with the insertion of the phrase, %I@F%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@.%i@ %I@A%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@.%i@(%I@K%I@J%I@V%i@), which is called the Lord’s Prayer Doxology, and is apparently a reference to 1 Chron. 29:10–13. This is a spurious addition; Jesus never said this.%fn~
%u@[%U@H%u@]%i@p%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@.%i@ In the OT and in ancient times in general, people applied oil to their bodies as an ointment, a protective lotion, as a soap-like cleanser, or as a skin enhancer. This is what %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ refers to%i@.%i@ Also, the head and the face have symbolic meanings. The head refers to what you’re thinking and the face refers to your disposition and attitude.%fn~
%u@[%U@I%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@y%i@e%i@ %i@(%i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@x%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@)%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@(%i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@u%i@i%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@)%i@,%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@m%i@p%i@…In ancient Israel, in the average home there was a single room where the inhabitants gathered when it got too dark to see. In that room, they illuminated a single lamp or candle and placed it on a lampstand in a central location, where it effectively filled the entire house with light. In addition, in the Bible the eye symbolizes one’s fascinations, desires, meditations, fixations, thoughts, etc. In English, we speak symbolically too, in statements like, “I’ve got my eye on that new Escalade®.” Furthermore, in the NT, the body refers to not just the physical body but can also refer to the physical appetites and the physical actions we take. Together, these explain what Jesus meant in this passage. Also, ref. John 11:9,10.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Matthew Chapter 7%hb~
          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@”%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@d%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@(%r@i%r@.%r@e%r@.%r@,%r@ %r@d%r@r%r@a%r@w%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@n%r@c%r@l%r@u%r@s%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@I%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@d%r@g%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@d%r@g%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@d%r@g%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@B%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@W%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@r%r@a%r@d%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@e%r@y%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@w%r@n%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@P%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@r%r@a%r@d%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@H%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@y%r@e%r@,%r@’%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@—%r@h%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@—%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@y%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@H%r@e%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@y%r@p%r@o%r@c%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@r%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@w%r@n%r@           %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@”%R@S%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@s%r@           %u@2%u@8After Jesus finished this sermon, the crowds were just amazed at the way he had taught%u@[%u@j%u@]: %u@2%u@9For he taught in a captivating manner%u@[%U@F%u@] and not like their designated teachers%u@[%U@G%u@].%vn~
