%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@’%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@’%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g %i@l%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@,%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@,%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@k…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%u@%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@B%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@P%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@…Lit: dressed%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n…Lit: %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o. This is an idiom; ref. note of Acts 19:8.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@n%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@q%i@u%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@…Lit: %i@n%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@k%i@n%i@e%i@w%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@c%i@k%i@…Lit: %i@o%i@n %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@c%i@k%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@c%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@n%i@k%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@s%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@n%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@d%i@r%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@…Lit: %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e. (Also, ref. note of Luke 6:37.) The word %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@ as used in the Bible means one of the following: ascertaining guilt or innocence, in or out of an actual courtroom; the verdict reached from such deliberation; the resulting sentence; a combination of these. This is evident upon examining how the word is used in both the OT and NT. In the case of 7:1 here, judging refers to the verdict reached from deliberation but does not refer to the ascertaining of guilt or innocence; hence, the misunderstanding of what Jesus is saying here. Many who read “don’t judge” here in 7:1 understand it to mean that Christians should refrain from ascertaining guilt or innocence, i.e. they shouldn’t decide whether another person’s deeds are moral or immoral, and to make such decisions brings judgment upon ourselves. Not only does this contradict common sense but it’s not consistent with other teaching of the NT. It’s the case of building a doctrine on one verse of Scripture and not taking all of Scripture into consideration. Those who wrote the NT lived in the times of Jesus and were either spent much time around him (and conversed in the same native language), were taught directly by him, or had contact with those who did. Had Jesus meant that Christians shouldn’t ascertain moral guilt or innocence of others, then their writers would reflect that. But their writings do not. In other words, Paul’s epistles violate the notion that “don’t judge” means one shouldn’t look at another Christian and decide if what they’re doing is right or wrong. For example, Paul wrote these statements in 1 Cor. 5, %I@F%i@o%i@r%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@e%i@d (v. 3)…%I@I%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@p%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@ (v. 9)…%I@B%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@w%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@i%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@t%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@d%i@o%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@u%i@n%i@k%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@;%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@(%i@v%i@.%i@ %i@1%i@1%i@)%i@…%I@F%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@?%i@ %I@D%i@o%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@?%i@ (v. 12)…%I@B%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@.%i@ %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ (v. 13). Paul also wrote %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@b%i@u%i@k%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ (2 Tim. 4:2). Paul rebuked Peter (Gal. 2:11–21).%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@…The GT reads %i@k%i@r%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@ %i@k%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ā%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@h%i@e, (κρίματι κρίνετε κριθήσεσθε) which has a ring to it, like something you might see written on a church billboard…“Get all you can, and can all you get”…“Get right or get left.” Jesus uses humor instead of a scolding in this verse and in the verses which follow.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m…Lit: %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@.%i@ This is an expression in the Bible (ref. note of Matt. 5:14; Luke 21:24) which means to treat with contempt. In the mind of ancient Jews, dogs were dishonorable animals; pigs were filthy and disgusting, designated as unclean by the Law of Moses. Verse 6 is telling us not to give what we treasure most to filthy, unworthy people. They’ll just have contempt for it, then, knowing you’ve entrusted them with something you shouldn’t have, use it to turn on you.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@f%i@…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@.%i@ %I@I%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ is a phrase in the NT which means, %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u or %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ or %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@v%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ (ref. Acts 4:17–20).%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@u%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n…Lit.: %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@w%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@.%i@ Though lawlessness comes in many shapes and forms, Jesus views lawlessness here as though it originates from the same source, and, when you get right down to it, it is all really the same thing. When the NT refers to a person who’s lawless, it means one who’s unrestrained by the law of the land; by restrictions specified in the Bible; by godly rules of conduct; by accepted moral practices; by common decency. This covers a wide swath of peoples …pirates who sailed in hunt of prey…philosophers who spread contempt for Christian morals…those who drive like maniacs all the time…drug addicts who leave syringes on the street.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%I@F%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@…Lit: %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y. It means that Jesus took command of their attention and that the minds of those in the crowd weren’t wandering. He kept their attention with commanding rhetoric, with persuasiveness, with humor, with rhetorical questions that pierce the heart, with the right mix of sternness and gentleness, with colorful figures of speech, by the use of imaginative allegories and examples.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s. As the Scribes were the OT experts, they were tasked with delivering sermons to the large audiences. As experts in the Law, they decided matters of doctrine.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Matthew Chapter 8%hb~
          %u@1After he came down out of the mountain, large crowds followed him. %u@2Out of nowhere, a leper came up to him and started groveling in front of him,%vn~
      “Sir%u@[%U@A%u@], if you so desire, you can clear me up%u@[%U@B%u@].”%vn~
          %u@3He stretched out his hand and touched him saying, %r@“%R@I%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@i%r@r%r@e%r@;%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@”%vn~
Immediately his leprosy cleared up. %u@4Jesus then said to him, %r@“%R@S%r@e%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@r%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@m%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@a%r@w%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@M%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@b%r@m%r@i%r@s%r@s%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@c%r@e%r@r%r@t%r@i%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@r%r@o%r@s%r@y%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@.%r@”%nn~
          %u@5After he entered Capernaum, an army captain came up to him pleading with him,%vn~
          %u@6“Lord, my servant is bedfast, suffering terribly of paralysis.”%vn~
          %u@7On top of the situation, Jesus said, %r@“%R@I%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@8The captain then replied, “Lord, I’m not worthy for you to set foot in my house. Just give the word, and my servant will be healed. %u@9You see, I’m a man who’s %i@u%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g under authority, having soldiers under my command. I say to this one ‘Come here!’ and he comes; I tell my servant ‘Do this!’ and he does it.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@0Once he heard this, Jesus was just amazed, and said to his followers, %r@“%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@r%r@a%r@e%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%R@I%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@l%r@k%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@ %R@A%r@b%r@r%r@a%r@h%r@a%r@m%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@a%r@a%r@c%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@J%r@a%r@c%r@o%r@b%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@m%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@y%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%R@I%r@@%R@I%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@O%r@u%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %R@D%r@a%r@r%r@k%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@—%r@a%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@n%r@a%r@s%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@C%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Jesus said to the captain, %r@“%R@G%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@;%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@4Jesus entered Peter’s house and saw his mother-in-law bedfast with a high fever. %u@1%u@5He touched her hand and the fever left her. %u@1%u@6When evening arrived, they brought to him many demon-possessed, and he cast the spirits out with a few words, and he treated many who had something wrong with them%u@[%u@e%u@], %u@1%u@7in order that the Prophet Isaiah’s prophecy would be fulfilled,%vn~
%si~
He himself took our weaknesses%vp~
And bore our diseases%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@8Now Jesus, seeing a crowd surrounding him, gave a command to hike up the mountain. %u@1%u@9One of the designated teachers%u@[%u@f%u@] came and said to him,%vn~
      “Teacher, I’ll follow you wherever you happen to go.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Jesus, following up the statement, said, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@x%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@i%r@r%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@D%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@(%r@i%r@.%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@)%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@g%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@2%u@1Another, who was one of his disciples, said, “Let me go from here and bury my father%u@[%U@E%u@] first.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Jesus, following up that statement, said, %r@“%R@F%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@;%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@.%r@”%u@%vn~
          %u@2%u@3Then he got into a boat and his disciples followed him in. %u@2%u@4And—like that—the sea broke into a great commotion, to the extent that the boat was overshadowed by waves. All the while, he was still asleep. %u@2%u@5They came over and roused him from his sleep saying,%vn~
      “Lord—Help! We’re dying here!”%vn~
          %u@2%u@6He said to them, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@n%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@l%r@e%r@-%r@f%r@a%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@-%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@,%r@”%vn~
He then got up and rebuked the winds and the sea, and a great calm came over the water. %u@2%u@7The men were amazed and said, “Just what kind of guy is this, that even the wind and the sea obey him?”%nn~
          %u@2%u@8After he arrived on the other side, in the Gadarene region, he was accosted by two demon-possessed men coming out of the tombs—really dangerous men—so much so that no one was tough%u@[%u@h%u@] enough to pass through on that road. %u@2%u@9Out of nowhere, they cried out, “We have no beef with you%u@[%U@F%u@], Son of God—have you come here before the appointed time to torment us%u@[%u@i%u@]?” %u@3%u@0Now off in the distance, a large herd of pigs was feeding. %u@3%u@1The demons begged him, “If you’re going to cast us out, send us into the herd of pigs.” %u@3%u@2He said to them, %r@“%R@P%r@r%r@o%r@c%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@”%r@ So they exited the men, went out and entered the pigs. Like that, the whole herd stampeded over the cliff and into the sea and died in the water. %u@3%u@3All the herdsmen began to flee, and when they got to the city, they spread the word about everything that happened, including what happened to the demon-possessed men. %u@3%u@4Then and there—the whole city came out to meet up with Jesus %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@l%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m, and seeing him, they pleaded with him to leave the area%u@[%u@j%u@].%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@m%i@i%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@…Lit: %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@E%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@W%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@r%i@o%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ [%i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@e]%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@,%i@ i.e., the Israelites%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@…Lit: %i@m%i@a%i@l%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@…Lit: %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@…The verb tense in the word %i@t%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t here implies a one-time act of torment, not the start of a never-ending or eternal torment.%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@…Impl: %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@x%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@t%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@S%i@i%i@r%i@…Also: %i@l%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@.%i@ The word %i@l%i@o%i@r%i@d here does not refer to the lordship of Jesus Christ the Son of God, but is a term of respect used when addressing nobility or when addressing someone with authority who has no formal title or if their specific title is unknown.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@…Lit: %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@.%i@ According to OT law, if anyone showed any signs of leprosy, they were designated unclean. The word %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ derives its meaning from the OT concepts of clean and unclean, which besides being applicable to leprosy applies to many hygienic, etc. conditions. In the NT, the concepts of clean and unclean are extended to spiritual conditions. But in this passage, the leper must be certified (the certification additionally requiring a sacrificial offering) as clean by a priest in order to be readmitted back into society. Should he have but a little leprosy, he’ll fail certification; the leper is therefore asking for a total removal of the leprosy.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@W%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@g%i@n%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@…a biblical phrase, partly to be taken literal, partly not.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n%i@…Lit: %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n%i@.%i@ This is a phrase that has its origins in the OT, particularly Ezekiel. The Bible embeds family members into phrases, like %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n, %i@f%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@e%i@s, %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@s%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r, etc. In the Bible the phrase %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f means someone who’s a perfect example, who faithfully personifies, or who’s the epitome or the total embodiment of a concept, ideal, or state of being. %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n means several things. It means the perfect man; one who has the full spectrum of human qualities alive and fully functioning in himself; a sort of Renaissance man; a single specimen who’s the most suitable representative for the human race; a person who stands in proxy for all human beings; a person of character and ability; and in this context, the Man. All these describe Jesus.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@b%i@u%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@…this%i@ is likely an expression and a hyperbole, and means that you have urgent business to attend to, but not to be taken literally that your father just died. (Some say it instead means that that your father is still alive and you have to wait for how many years for him to pass away.) After all, one of the Ten Commandments is to honor your mother and father, and Jesus would not tell the disciple to violate a commandment of that magnitude, and one is applicable in NT times as well. If %i@b%i@u%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ is an expression indeed, then Jesus’s reply %I@L%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ is a play on that expression. The “dead” Jesus refers to are the spiritually dead; the expression therefore means, “Let the spiritually dead take care of their own pressing matters.”%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%I@W%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@…Also:%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@?; %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@ne…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u? A NT phrase, also found in Mark 1:24; Luke 4:34, 8:28; John 2:4.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Matthew Chapter 9%hb~
          %u@1He got into the boat, crossed over, and arrived at his hometown. %u@2Momentarily, they brought him a paralytic laid up on a cot. Jesus, seeing their faith, said to the paralytic, %r@“%R@C%r@h%r@e%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@3Then and there, some of the designated teachers%u@[%u@a%u@] said among themselves, “This guy’s blaspheming.” %u@4Reading their lips%u@[%u@b%u@], Jesus said to them, %r@“%R@J%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@e%r@w%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@i%r@l%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@s%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@s%r@i%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@’%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@‘%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@l%r@k%r@’%r@?%r@…%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@”—He then turns and says to the paralytic, %r@“%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@7So he got up and went back home. %u@8Seeing this, a solemn reverence%u@[%u@e%u@] came over the crowd, and they glorified the God who gives authority such as this to mankind.%vn~
          %u@9Now as Jesus continued on from there, he saw a man sitting at the customs table named Matthew and said, %r@“%R@F%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@” And he got up and followed him. %u@1%u@0And when he happened to be lounging at the dinner table%u@[%U@A%u@], out of nowhere several tax collectors and %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ sinners came and joined Jesus and his disciples at the table. %u@1%u@1The Pharisees, seeing this, proceeded to say to his disciples,%vn~
      “Just why does your teacher eat with tax collectors and %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ sinners?”%vn~
          %u@1%u@2He heard it and said%r@,%r@ %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@c%r@t%r@o%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@w%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@F%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@a%r@n%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@:%r@ %r@‘%R@I%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@r%r@c%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@c%r@r%r@i%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@.%r@’%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@m%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@e%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@n%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@4Then John’s disciples came to him, “Just why do we and the Pharisees fast all the time, but your disciples don’t fast?” %u@1%u@5Jesus said, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@u%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@g%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@.%r@ %R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@N%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@a%r@r%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@-%r@s%r@h%r@r%r@u%r@n%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@a%r@r%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@f%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@N%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@h%r@l%r@y%r@-%r@s%r@q%r@u%r@e%r@e%r@z%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@;%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@w%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@u%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@ %R@I%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@.%r@”%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@B%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%vn~
          %u@1%u@8While saying these things, out of nowhere a synagogue head came and began pleading with him saying, “My daughter just passed away—but now, if you come and lay your hand on her, she’ll live again.” %u@1%u@9Jesus and his disciples got up and followed him. %u@2%u@0And, quite abruptly, a woman who had a hemorrhage for twelve years came up behind him and touched the hem of his garment; %u@2%u@1for she kept saying to herself, “If I could just touch his outer garment, I’ll get better.” %u@2%u@2So Jesus turned, looked at her, and said, %r@“%R@C%r@h%r@e%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@’%r@a%r@m%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@:%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@s%r@c%r@u%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@”%r@ And the woman was delivered%u@[%u@j%u@] %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@l%i@l%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s that moment.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3After Jesus came to the synagogue head’s house and saw the flute players and the wailing crowd, %u@2%u@4he went %i@a%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e saying, %r@“%R@L%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@.%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@r%r@l%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@—%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@l%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@.%r@” %u@2%u@5When the crowd was thrown out, he went in and took hold of her hand, and the girl%u@[%u@k%u@] got up. %u@2%u@6And his fame spread throughout the entire surrounding area%u@[%u@l%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@7Continuing on from there, two blind men followed Jesus, crying out, “Have pity on us, you wonderful godsend%u@[%u@m%u@].” %u@2%u@8Arriving at the house, the blind men approached him, and Jesus said to them, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@?%r@”%r@ They %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ say to him, “Yes sir.” %u@2%u@9Then he touched their eyes while saying, %r@“%R@I%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@c%r@c%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@a%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@s%r@s%r@,%r@” %u@3%u@0and they regained their sight. Jesus firmly charged them, “Don’t let anyone know,” %u@3%u@1but they left from there and talked all about it in the entire surrounding area.%vn~
          %u@3%u@2While they were heading out, they brought to him a deaf, demon-possessed man. %u@3%u@3After the demon had been cast out, the deaf man spoke. As the crowd was amazed, the rumor kept on being repeated, “This has never been seen before in Israel.” %u@3%u@4But the Pharisees went around saying, “It’s by means of the head demon that he casts out demons.”%vn~
          %u@3%u@5Jesus went about to all the cities and towns, teaching in the local synagogues and proclaiming the good news%u@[%u@n%u@] of the kingdom and healing all kinds of diseases and all kinds of infirmities. %u@3%u@6Seeing the crowds, he felt deeply sorry for them because they were beaten down and defeated, like sheep that have no shepherd. %u@3%u@7In line with this, he then said to his disciples, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@r%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@i%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@k%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@S%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@k%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@H%r@a%r@r%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %R@C%r@h%r@i%r@e%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@k%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@r%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@.%r@”%vn~
%sf~

%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@l%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e. In the next sentence%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@x%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@j%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e…Liberties taken. People back then laid on couches in a circle while eating a meal, and took their time at it. There was actually no dinner table as we know it.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@b%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@…In the examples of the patch and the wineskins, Jesus says that you must match the one to the other, the patch to the cloth, or the wine to the wineskins. A mismatch won’t work. Jesus’s ministry was, before the cross, a time of joy and of celebration for the human race. It was appropriate for his disciples to match this with joy and partying of their own. On the other hand, John’s ministry was one of austerity, and it was appropriate for his disciples to follow suit.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Matthew Chapter 10%hb~
%u@1…And%u@[%U@A%u@] summoning his twelve disciples, he gave them authority over filthy, disgusting%u@[%u@a%u@] spirits, so that they would cast them out and go about healing all sorts of sicknesses and all sorts of infirmities. %u@2The names of the twelve missionaries%u@[%u@b%u@] are: first and foremost Simon, who’s called Peter, and his brother Andrew; James the son of Zebedee and his brother John; %u@3Phillip and Bartholomew; Thomas and the tax collector Matthew; James the son of Alpheus; Thaddeus; %u@4Simon the Cananaean%u@[%U@B%u@]%u@ (Cananaeans are also called “the Zealots”); and Judas Iscariot, the one who’ll betray him.%nn~
          %u@5Jesus sent out these twelve telling them, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %u@[%u@e%u@]%i@c%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@…Lit: %i@g%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@w%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@m%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@t%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%I@S%i@o%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@w%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@l%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@i%i@t%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@o%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@s%i@ (etc)…Lit: %I@N%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@.%i@ %I@A%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@.%i@ %I@B%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u. Multiple figures of speech used in this passage. The word %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ has a similar, idiomatic type of usage in Acts 15:33; Heb. 11:31; James 2:16.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@n%i@o%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@v%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@u%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@/%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@.%i@ Note that the Gk. word %i@s%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@ (used for %i@w%i@i%i@s%i@e) (σοφός/Strong’s 4680)%i@ isn’t used here, as %i@s%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@ also means cunning.%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%I@B%i@e%i@w%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@…Impl. also: %i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n;%i@ also means: society, body politic%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@j%i@u%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l…lit: %I@S%i@a%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@r%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n%i@.%i@ Ref. note in Matt. 8:20.%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@,%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%i@a%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@r%i@m%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@f%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@d%i@i%i@s%i@a%i@v%i@o%i@w%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@d%i@e%i@n%i@i%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@s%u@]%i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@:%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@,%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@t%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@…Also: %i@r%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@u%u@]%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@…Also: %i@d%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@e%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@A%i@n%i@d%i@…Chapter 10 is a continuation in the narrative from chapter 9. Jesus sends the twelve out because of the compassion he felt and said in 9:36,37%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@C%i@a%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@a%i@e%i@a%i@n…Also called the Zealots. These were a sect of Jewish partisans and revolutionaries.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@D%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@m%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@…Jesus’s mandate was only for the nation of Israel. Post-crucifixion, that mandate was expanded to include every human being on the planet. The reason God limited Jesus’s mandate to Israel only is that it was the most he could do at the time.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@…It was only a few years ago that, if a worker came to work at your house for the day, he didn’t bring his own lunch because he and any other workers would expect to be provided lunch. As refrigerator, preservatives, packaging, etc. only came into being in the last several decades, prior to this it was a necessity to partake in the large-scale meal preparation of a household you visited as a worker.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@t%i@t%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@…The significance to the Jews of wiping the dirt off your feet is that you are clean and they are unclean and that the OT Law prohibits you from having any contact with that which is unclean. You therefore mark them unclean. Ref. Mark 6:11; Acts 13:51; Acts 18:6.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d. The word %i@s%i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ in the NT has a few similar but nevertheless distinct meanings, depending on the context. In this context, it means violence, but it’s a metaphor to physical violence and not the solicitation of such violence per se.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%i@l%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@…The word used for %i@l%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@ here is %i@p%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ō%i@ (φιλέω/Strong’s 5368), not %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@p%i@a%i@ō%i@ (ἀγαπάω/Strong’s 25)%i@.%i@ Phileo is a high degree of comradery, an enjoyment of another’s fellowship. The command is to not have greater phileo for your family, not %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@p%i@ā%i@ (ἀγάπη/Strong’s 26).%fn~
%u@[%U@H%u@]%I@H%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ (etc.)…Lit: %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@g%i@e. Just as Jesus commands his disciples in this chapter to go about from place to place and to have their material needs met at the places they visited, those who itinerate in this manner—prophets in this case—are also expected to live off the generosity and patronage of those in the cities who welcomed them. The word %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ used here refers to those who take in and shelter such a prophet, provide him with meals while he’s stays with them, and clothe him, if necessary. These gifts of food, shelter, and clothing are the prophet’s “wages” referred to in this passage. What it means to receive a prophet in the name of a prophet is to welcome and support that prophet simply out of respect for his calling and his ministry and not because of his charisma, his personality, a personal like or dislike of the prophet himself, or other such reasons. Those who provide this sustenance will themselves receive back a “prophet’s wage”: a payback blessing from God in the form of material goods in this lifetime and, in addition, of spiritual rewards in the life to come. %fn~
%i@%sb~
Matthew Chapter 11%hb~
          %u@1When Jesus had finished commissioning his twelve disciples, he went about from there teaching and proclaiming in the neighboring cities. %u@2When John, %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ in jail, heard about Jesus’s doings, he sent word to Jesus by way of some of his disciples, %u@3asking,%vn~
      ”Are you the Coming One, or shall we wait for somebody else?”%vn~
          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@J%r@e%r@s%r@u%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@s%r@w%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@p%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@“%R@G%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %R@J%r@o%r@h%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@:%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@r%r@i%r@p%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@l%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@r%r@o%r@s%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@s%r@u%r@r%r@r%r@e%r@c%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@c%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@a%r@g%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@A%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@g%r@a%r@r%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@A%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@7While these disciples were on their way back to John, Jesus began to talk to the crowds about John, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@t%r@r%r@y%r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@?%r@ %R@A%r@ %r@t%r@w%r@i%r@g%r@ %r@f%r@l%r@u%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@e%r@z%r@e%r@?%r@—%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@N%r@o%r@.%r@ %R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@?%r@ %R@A%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@c%r@k%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@i%r@t%r@?%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@—%R@L%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@—%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@‘%r@b%r@e%r@a%r@u%r@t%r@i%r@f%r@u%r@l%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@’%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@t%r@z%r@y%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@B%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@N%r@o%r@,%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@ %R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@—%r@a%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@?%r@ %R@Y%r@e%r@s%r@—%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@—%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@v%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@0%R@H%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@v%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@l%r@k%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@,%r@%vn~

          %u@2%u@0He then began to rip on the cities that had had the most miracles, because they didn’t repent. %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@”%R@B%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@,%r@ %R@C%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@a%r@z%r@i%r@n%r@!%r@ %R@B%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@,%r@ %R@B%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@s%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@a%r@!%r@ %R@B%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %R@T%r@y%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@S%r@i%r@d%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@i%r@r%r@a%r@c%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@n%r@d%r@u%r@c%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@r%r@l%r@a%r@p%r@-%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@-%r@a%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@-%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@J%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@B%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@D%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@J%r@u%r@d%r@g%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@s%r@i%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %R@T%r@y%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@S%r@i%r@d%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %R@C%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@r%r@n%r@a%r@u%r@m%r@…%r@%vn~

%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@l%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@c%i@k%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@i%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@d%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@a%i@g%i@g%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@k%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@u%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@;%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g. An idiom; ref. note of Luke 16:16.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@g%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@k%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@P%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%I@Z%i@e%i@i%i@t%i@g%i@e%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n. A %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ in this context refers to a Zeitgeist or a class of people or a clique who are of the same mindset. It does not specify a span of time per se, as those who are like-minded may span multiple human generations.%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%I@J%i@o%i@h%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@…Lit: %I@J%i@o%i@h%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n%i@…%I@L%i@i%i@t%i@:%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n%i@.%i@ Ref .note of Matt. 8:20.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@—%i@a%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@u%i@t%i@t%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@u%i@n%i@k%i@a%i@r%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@e%i@y%i@e%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@G%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@g%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@e…Or: %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@t%i@u%i@m%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@. In the Bible, to stumble is an idiom which points to and identifies the root-cause of making a mistake (whether the mistake is intentional or unintentional is irrelevant) and thereby committing a sin; to do wrong; to fall short of the mark; or to be offended by what’s right.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@z%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@—%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@f%i@t%i@ [%i@c%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g]%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s. Some liberty taken here and in v.8 to make the passage more relevant to modern times.%i@%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@s%i@u%i@b%i@j%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@g%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@k%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@…Lit: %i@s%i@u%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ only partly refers to physical violence, but only partly. In the NT, the violence is not so much physical—except for the persecution aspect. Other aspects of this violence are alluded to in the previous chapter when Jesus said that he didn’t come to sprinkle peace but to bring a sword (Matt. 10:34), and that parents will be set against their children, etc. The kingdom of heaven suffers violence not only at the hands of unbelievers but suffers violence at the hands of believers, those believers who by radical conversions, strong convictions, disregard for their own self, who pray fervently and endlessly, who give until it hurts, who forgive even when it hurts—those are the violent ones who are seizing it.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@…Lit: %I@A%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@c%i@e. See the scrutiny this passage has been subjected to, the justification for tacking the words %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ onto this literal translation here is that the infinitive %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ in this verse is an aorist infinitive. By default, infinitives are usually present tense, so Matthew added some additional nuance in flipping this infinitive from present to aorist before committing it to writing.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %I@E%i@l%i@i%i@j%i@a%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e…there’s heated debate over whether Jesus is saying in this verse that John the Baptist is Elijah reincarnated or not. I do not have a dog in this fight. However, it cannot be overstated just how important John the Baptist’s ministry was. Furthermore, Elijah personifies prophecy in the face of apostasy. John raises that to a higher level. The apostasy by the Jewish leadership at the time of Christ was at an all-time high. Judgment followed soon after.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%I@A%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@…Lit: %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r. It means: you who are willing to take heed, pay attention or you’ll miss something.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@b%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@…Mothers bring their children along to the marketplace, and as the mothers are busy looking over the produce, or perhaps catching up on the latest news, the children wander off a bit, sit and wait for their mothers. The children congregate in groups and, as time passes, grow bored and restless and want to play a game of some sort to entertain themselves and pass the time. The more children who play, the more fun the game, so the first group of children tries to recruit the second in their frivolities. But the second group is not interested in playing. The first group, desperate to break the monotony, seeks to entice the second group with something—anything—which appeals to them, so long as they’ll get up and start to play with them. They attempt two opposite games that appeal to two opposite moods, figuring that one of them will be appealing to the second group.%fn~
%u@[%U@H%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@i%i@l%i@…Jesus quotes what the first group of children says to the second after the second refused all their attempts to get up and play with them. Both of the games were emotional and exhilarating. The first game was a dance: someone would play the flute and everybody would dance. The second game was a sad song: someone would sing a dirge and everybody would pretend that they’re at a funeral. At first, this seems to be an unusual game to play, one that would be no fun at all. This is not the case; extreme emotions are entertaining regardless how morbid they may be. This is the same reason why teens like horror movies and zombie apocalypse movies, or movies with a lot of bloodshed. They cover their eyes during the gory scenes, but peak a bit. By the same measure, sad movies and sad songs—though not as popular as they used to be—are also entertaining. Years ago, teenage girls used to bring a box of tissues with them for when they cried through a sad movie. %fn~
%u@[%U@I%u@]%I@W%i@i%i@s%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@—%i@w%i@i%i@s%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@—%i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@ %i@…Lit:%i@ %I@W%i@i%i@s%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@s. It means that you can tell if something was a smart thing to do or a smart way of living by the end-result of theory put into practice.%fn~
%u@[%U@J%u@]%i@b%i@u%i@r%i@l%i@a%i@p%i@-%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@-%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@…In the OT, those who repented showed their sincerity by the self-abasement of dressing in sackcloth, which is similar to burlap, and by sitting in ashes. They did this for days at a time.%fn~
%u@[%U@K%u@]%I@T%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@o%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@-%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@f%i@t%i@-%i@s%i@p%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@-%i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@.%i@ %I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@s%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@l%i@d…Lit: %I@T%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@.%i@ %I@F%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@s%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t. The metaphor is to oxen pulling a load. (Also ref. note of Matt. 5:5 for definition of %i@m%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@.) Oxen have the strength to pull heavy loads but can only pull such loads if a yoke is properly fitted and placed on them. An analogy for us is moving furniture which is difficult to move. Though the furniture is heavy, the problem with moving it has more to do with the difficult shape and size of the furniture, the inability to get a good grip on it, the amount of twisting and turning necessary—all these more so than the weight itself.%fn~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 12%hb~
          %u@1During that period of time, Jesus walked through the fields on Sabbath days. The disciples were hungry and began to go through and strip kernels off%u@[%U@A%u@] the wheat heads and eat them. %u@2But the Pharisees, seeing what was happening, said to him,%vn~
      “See, look what your disciples are doing. This isn’t allowed on the Sabbath.”%vn~
          %u@3And he said to them, %r@“%R@D%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@v%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@D%r@a%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@—%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@—%r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@r%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@h%r@o%r@w%r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@B%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@b%r@i%r@d%r@d%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@—%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@c%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@—%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@t%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@O%r@l%r@d%r@ %R@T%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@m%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@v%r@i%r@o%r@l%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@w%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@m%r@p%r@o%r@r%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@m%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@m%r@i%r@l%r@i%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@a%r@n%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@I%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@r%r@c%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@c%r@r%r@i%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@,%r@’%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@m%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@n%r@o%r@c%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@T%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@9After he left from there, he went into one of the local synagogues. %u@1%u@0There happened to be a man there with a shriveled-up%u@[%U@C%u@] hand, so they asked him, “Are we allowed to perform healings on the Sabbath?”, in order to find something to accuse him of.%u@[%U@D%u@] %u@1%u@1He answered, %r@“%R@I%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@b%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@S%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@v%r@a%r@l%r@u%r@a%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@?%r@—%r@%%R@I%r@@%R@W%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%R@I%r@@%R@I%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@’%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@v%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@i%r@s%r@s%r@i%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@o%r@i%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@” %u@1%u@3He then turned to the man and said, “Stretch your hand out.” He stretched his hand out, and it was restored to a state of well-being like the other hand. %u@1%u@4After the Pharisees left, they convened a meeting about how they proposed to eliminate him. %vn~
          %u@1%u@5After Jesus made that known, he left from there. Many followed him, and he healed all of them. %u@1%u@6He charged them to not let the word out about him, %u@1%u@7so that Isaiah’s prophecy would be fulfilled,%vn~
%si~
%u@1%u@8Look! My chosen child,%vp~
My beloved in whom My soul is pleased.%vp~
I’ll put My Spirit upon him%vp~
And announce justice to the nations.%vp~
%u@1%u@9He’ll neither squabble nor scream%vp~
Nor will anyone hear his voice in the town square.%vp~
%u@2%u@0He won’t break a damaged twig,%vp~
He won’t extinguish a wick%vp~
Until he brings about a victory for justice,%vp~
%u@2%u@1And those far off%u@[%u@d%u@] will have hope through him%u@[%u@e%u@].%vp~
%si~
          %u@2%u@2Then they brought to him a blind, mute, demon-possessed man, and he treated%u@[%u@f%u@] him, resulting in the mute man talking and seeing. %u@2%u@3The entire crowd was amazed and was going about saying, ”Isn’t this fellow the marvelous godsend we’ve been waiting for all these years%u@[%u@g%u@]?” %u@2%u@4But when the Pharisees heard about this, they said, “This guy can’t cast out demons except through %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@l%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f the demon chief Beelzebub.” %u@2%u@5Knowing what they were really thinking, he said, %r@“%R@E%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@c%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@I%r@f%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@.%r@ %R@S%r@o%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@l%r@p%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@B%r@e%r@e%r@l%r@z%r@e%r@b%r@u%r@b%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@l%r@p%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@m%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@é%r@g%r@é%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@j%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@m%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@o%r@r%r@c%r@i%r@s%r@m%r@s%r@?%r@ %R@B%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@é%r@g%r@é%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@k%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@l%r@p%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@(%R@G%r@o%r@d%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@)%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@r%r@a%r@s%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@P%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@           %u@3%u@8Then some of the designated teachers%u@[%u@u%u@] addressed him, and Pharisees too, “Teacher, we want you to perform a spectacular miracle%u@[%u@v%u@].” %u@3%u@9Jesus replied,           %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@”%R@N%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@i%r@c%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@i%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@s%r@—%r@m%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@           %u@4%u@6While he was in the middle of telling the crowds this, his mother and his brothers showed up standing outside wanting to have a word with him. %u@4%u@7Someone told him, “Your mother and your brothers are standing outside wanting to have a word with you.”%u@[%U@H%u@] %u@4%u@8He answered the fellow who told him this, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@?%r@” %u@4%u@9He put his hand out on his disciples and said, %r@“%R@T%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@—%r@m%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@0%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@%%R@C%r@@%R@H%r@%%R@C%r@@%R@E%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@”%vn~

%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e %i@m%i@a%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@d%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@’%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@D%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@.%i@ %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@D%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@ is an idiom meaning %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@d%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@.%i@ %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@D%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@ means that and also refers to the one who’s been prophesied to come.%fn~
