%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@…Lit: %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@…The thirty silver coins here are equivalent to $10,000 in today’s dollars. Ref. note in Matt 26:15.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@…Lit: %I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d. Same phrase as used in Matt. 26:64; ref. note there.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%I@W%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@…Lit: %I@W%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%I@D%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@x%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@-%i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@…Lit: %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n. Same expression used in John 2:4.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@w…This is the same phrase used in v. 4, %I@T%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@m. The phrase literally reads, %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e, short for, %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@i%i@t.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%I@L%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@!…Lit: %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@.%i@ Also, by implication, %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@ here means %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@.%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@…Probably a rod made of reeds or some similar plant, something more substantial than a simple reed, which is the common translation of this word, so it would be more like a cane.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%I@D%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@d %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u…Same phrase that Judas spoke to Jesus when he met him in Gethsemane in Matt. 26:49%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@x%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@…The %i@b%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@ is likely myrrh. Ref. note of Mark 15:23.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@r%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@t%i@s%i@.%i@ Ref. note of Mark 15:24.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@u%i@g%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@r%i@o%i@b%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@g%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@.%i@ English expression derived from KJV rendering of Matt. 27:50, %i@y%i@i%i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@.%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@l%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%I@A%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d…ref. note of Mark 15:39%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@n%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@x%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y. The Jewish day starts at sundown.%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y…Lit: %i@h%i@i%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@s%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t. A figure of speech.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@x%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@u%i@n%i@d…Lit: %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@e%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e…Assumption is that the word %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ here is short for %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@o%i@r%i@b%i@a%i@n, which is the temple fund. The word %i@k%i@o%i@r%i@b%i@a%i@n%i@ is used in v.6. Implication is that he indicated one way or another that money to go to the temple fund. He may have indicated through some gesture or some other means that the money be designated for the temple fund, then threw it on the floor in their sight. The details are not specified.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@e%i@l%i@d%i@…The impression from the GT is that the “potter’s field” was a well-known location in the first century.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@l%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@s…In the GT, the word %i@p%i@a%i@y%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ in various forms is repeated four times in the quotation from Jeremiah used here. Using the same word, it reads, %I@A%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@y%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@.%i@ Such repetition is a figure of speech. Furthermore, the %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@ is also a figure of speech that can be rendered a number of ways: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@l%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@s, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@e%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@s, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s, %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@o%i@t%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@p%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@s.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%I@E%i@l%i@i%i@,%i@ %I@E%i@l%i@i%i@,%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@m%i@a%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@b%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@t%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@i…This is one of the places in the NT where a Hebrew phrase is quoted verbatim. In Matthew, most other foreign words are in Aramaic, not Hebrew, since Aramaic was their common tongue, not Hebrew. Hebrew is the language of Judaism, and Jesus is clearly quoting the beginning of Psalm 22. Those who do not receive Jesus are fond of quoting %i@m%i@y%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@e as Jesus’s great moment of doubt and regret. It is neither. Jesus is asking a fair question to God, one which he completely knows the answer to, but asks it nevertheless. It is a figure of speech; what Jesus is really saying is, “I’m innocent, I don’t deserve this.”%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@g%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@n%i@e…This was wine which had gone sour and turned into vinegar. It was a common drink of soldiers and was actually was refreshing for those who were working hard. In addition, drinking wine mixed with water, whether the wine has soured into vinegar or not, was commonplace in ancient times, for the practical reason of eliminating bacteria from the water. However, in Luke’s account (Luke 23:36), the soldiers mock him by giving him such a poor drink; doing so is also prophesied in the OT.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@u%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@…Within the temple there is a chamber called the Holy Place, and the Holy Place is divided into two sub-chambers separated by a veil. Behind this veil is the Holy of Holies. This the %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@u%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n referred to in v. 51. The Holy of Holies is the most sacred place in all of ancient Judaism, the place where God dwells. When the temple curtain was torn in two, God’s presence departed from the Holy of Holies, never to return.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@m%i@b%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@s%i@e%i@p%i@u%i@l%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s. Ref. Matt. 23:29. These are above-ground tombs, and it’s likely that those who were dead who were resurrected had died recently and their body hadn’t decayed much yet.%fn~
%u@[%U@H%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@a%i@l%i@…In addition to Saturdays being Sabbath days, Jewish religious holidays were also Sabbaths, and the restrictions covering the Sabbath applied to these holy days as well. This meant that no work could be done on the Passover, being a Sabbath. Therefore, duties such as meals had to be completed the day before. Such a day is designated “a day of preparation.”%fn~
%i@%sb~
Matthew Chapter 28%hb~
          %u@1After the %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@-%i@t%i@o%i@-%i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k Sabbaths had ended,%u@[%U@A%u@] at the first light of day on Sunday, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary came to take a look at the tomb. %u@2Wouldn’t you know—a huge convulsion had occurred; in fact, an angel sent from the Lord descended from out of the sky, went over to the stone, rolled it away, and sat down on top of it. %u@3His appearance resembled lightning, and his outerwear was as white as snow. %u@4Terrified of him, those keeping guard trembled violently until %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y becoming as stiff as the dead, laid out on the ground%u@[%u@a%u@]. %u@5The angel summed the situation up and said to the women, “Don’t be afraid, since I know that you’re looking for Jesus, the one who was crucified. %u@6He’s not here, since he was resurrected just like he said he would be: go look at the place where he was laid to rest. %u@7And—quickly now—go tell his disciples that he’s been resurrected from the dead, and in the meantime he’ll be heading out to Galilee ahead of you; you’ll see him there.”%vn~
          %u@8Quickly, and in a state of great fear and joy, they left the tomb and raced to tell his disciples. %u@9And out of nowhere, Jesus interrupted them saying, “Delighted %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%u@[%u@b%u@]” They went to him and grabbed ahold of his feet, having prostrated themselves in worship before him. %u@1%u@0Then Jesus, getting to the point, said to them, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@f%r@r%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@.%r@ %R@C%r@o%r@n%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@u%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@r%r@a%r@d%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %R@G%r@a%r@l%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@1While they were on their way, another thing was afoot—some of the guards went into the city to tell the chief priests everything that had happened. %u@1%u@2They gathered the councilmen%u@[%u@c%u@] and met with them, and then they got a sizeable amount of cash to give to the soldiers %u@1%u@3saying, “Say that his disciples came during the night and stole him while you were sleeping. %u@1%u@4If this gets reported to the governor, we personally will smooth things over with him and fix it so that you won’t have anything to worry about.” %u@1%u@5They took the cash and did as they were coached to do. And this account has been circulated among the Jews until the present day.%vn~
          %u@1%u@6The eleven disciples went to Galilee, to the mountain which Jesus told them %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@o, %u@1%u@7and when they saw him, they bowed before him in worship—but they just couldn’t believe it%u@[%U@B%u@]. %u@1%u@8Jesus came over to them and had a talk with them, %r@“%R@A%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@c%r@i%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@l%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@p%r@t%r@i%r@z%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@H%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@S%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@0%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@r%r@u%r@c%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@b%r@s%r@e%r@r%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@m%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@.%r@ %R@A%r@n%r@d%r@—%r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@—%R@I%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@t%r@i%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@r%r@a%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@”%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@b%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@D%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@…Lit: %i@j%i@o%i@y. Ref. note in Matt. 26:49%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@…Also: %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%I@I%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u…Lit: %I@I%i@ %i@a%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@r%i@a%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p…Lit: %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@u%i@m%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@e. Ref. Matt. 13:39%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@A%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@-%i@t%i@o%i@-%i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@…Lit: %I@W%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@s%i@.%i@ As the Jewish day begins at sundown, dawn is “well after” a Sabbath. The %I@S%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@s%i@ in v. 1 is plural, but idiomatically using the plural for the singular when referring to days of the week occurs a few times in the NT (putting aside this verse and the parallel ones in Mark 16:2, Luke 24:1, John 20:1, John 20:19, this idiomatic form is found in Luke 4:16; Acts 16:13; Acts 20:7). But there were, in fact, two consecutive Sabbaths, the Passover and a Saturday, not just a single Sabbath. This helps with the math of reconciling Jesus being supposedly crucified on a Friday and raised from the dead on a Sunday; how does that add up to three days? Nor does this account for the three day and three night duration called out in Matt. 12:40. To achieve a span of three days and three nights, Jesus would’ve been crucified on a Wednesday, the day of preparation (Matt. 27:62), and the three days and three nights consisted of Wed. night, Thurs. day, Thurs. night, Fri. day, Fri. night, Fri. day. And he was resurrected on Saturday evening, while several hours later, early Sunday morning, the women discovered that he’d already been resurrected.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@u%i@b%i@t%i@e%i@d. This is partly a figure of speech and partly true; they didn’t actually doubt that Jesus was there, but it’s like we say when we unexpectedly meet a friend somewhere whom you haven’t seen in a long time, “I still can’t believe that you’re here,” or, “I just can’t believe I’m talking to you after all of these years.” You know that they’re there, but the unexpectedness of it all has left you in a somewhat bewildered, excited state. On the other hand, they didn’t know what or if they should even believe it at all, as further detail is revealed in Luke 24:41–43.
The Gospel of Mark%ha~
       According to church tradition, Mark is the one referred to as John-Mark, son of Mary, in Acts 15:37, to whose house Peter went after the angel freed him from the prison in Jerusalem. John-Mark is also the cousin of Barnabas. Some believe that his mother Mary is the one who furnished the upper room used for the Last Supper and also used on the day of Pentecost. Some believe that the “young man” whom Mark refers to in Mark 14:51,52 is none other than himself, corroborating the theories. But most agree that the “Mark my son” whom Peter refers to in 1 Pet. 5:13 is the same John-Mark and is the author of the Gospel of Mark.%nv~
       Mark was not actually Peter’s son, but he was a close enough companion and brother that Peter claims him as his figurative son, not only a son in the faith but a son in relation. Church tradition says that Mark was Peter’s interpreter, likely interpreting Aramaic into Greek as Peter itinerated throughout the Roman Empire. Serving as Peter’s interpreter, Mark would re-tell the same stories over and over again. He also spent a lot of time with Peter, everything from travelling to dining. No doubt, Mark spoke to Peter a lot and asked many questions about the missing details of the life of Jesus.%nv~
       Also according to church tradition, Peter was martyred in Rome. Mark was there at that time, and the brethren asked him to commit all of what Peter had told him over the years to a book. This book is the Gospel of Mark. Mark’s gospel is written to a Roman audience, so it does not dwell on things that would be interesting to a Jewish believer of the day who believed in the Messiah. Mark’s gospel is full of drama, action, encounters, confrontation. The teachings it contains are more down-to-earth than Matthew or Luke, though they are wrapped in analogy (parable) as Jesus taught them.%nv~
       Mark’s Greek is simple. He does not have the command of the language that Luke and Paul do, and his Gospel makes repeated use of simple words rather than drawing on less common, more specific words. There’s rich detail in the description of characters that looks like it came straight from the mouth of Peter. It vividly paints a familiarity with the character. For example, the story of the woman with the hemorrhage, which begins in Mark 5:25. The details give us a clear picture of this woman’s ordeal:%nv~
       A woman who had a hemorrhage for twelve years, having suffered a great deal at the hands of many doctors, spending everything she had—and nothing was helping but instead things were trending more to the worse…%ni~
       The details about the length of her affliction and how she had spent everything she had trying to find a cure leaves a stronger impression than if Mark had simply wrote, “there was a woman who had a really bad hemorrhage…”%nv~
       Another example comes from the story of Herod and John the Baptist. Herod kept John locked up in jail, and with detail Mark supplies about Herod (Mark 6:19,20), one acquires a familiarity with Herod:%nv~
       So Herodias maintained a grudge against him and was wanting to kill him, and wasn’t yet able to do so, since, throughout, Herod had a reverential awe of John, knowing him to be an upstanding man, right in the eyes of God and holy, and was keeping him safe. After listening to him many times, he became conflicted, yet still enjoyed listening to him.%ni~
       …the story continues after Herod’s stepdaughter finishes her dance. The silly girl “rejoined the party with hasty eagerness”; one can feel the glee coursing through her cruel, juvenile head.%nv~
       He swore up and down to her multiple times, “Whatever you ask me for, I’ll give it to you—anything you want—anything at all.” She excused herself and said to her mother, “What should I ask for?” Her mother said, “John the Baptist’s head.” Straightaway she rejoined the party and with hasty eagerness said, “I want you to give me John the Baptist’s head on a platter—right now.”%ni~
       On the other hand, Mark is loud, clumsy, and careless as a writer, in spite of apparently having a scribe work with him to proof-read his Greek and to translate words for obscure objects and the like. In spite of his simple use of Greek, the translator must pause and think what Mark meant to say. He over-uses the imperfect and present subjunctive tenses for effect. He uses %i@a%i@n%i@d when he should use %i@o%i@r and vice-versa (ex: Mark 11:28). He gets some simple events out of sequence, like Mark 12:8, where it literally reads, “They took him, killed him, and drove him outside of the vineyard.” As correlated with Matt. 21:39, he means, “They took him, drove him some place outside of the vineyard, and killed him there.” In other words, they first drove him out of the vineyard then killed him, not the other way around.%i@%nv~
       Modern criticism asserts that Mark wrote his Gospel first, then it became the basis for Matthew and Luke. The critics are quick to dismiss reports from early church witnesses who contradict this theory, and are slow to propose theories of how the commonality could have come about.%nv~
       Another point of contention is the ending of Mark’s gospel, Mark 16:9–20. A footnote in a contemporary translation such as the NASB states that this ending is missing from two of the oldest manuscripts. Modern critics claim that the ending of Mark has been lost for all time, seizing upon this in their eagerness to poke holes in the integrity of the Scriptures. We do not have the detail of information we would like to solve this mystery, however there are enough fragments scattered over time to postulate a likely scenario. This is analogous to how the NTSB determines causes of crashes in smaller aircraft: they sift through the evidence and eliminate possibilities until they’re left with the “likely” cause of the crash. They cannot say with absolute certainty what caused the crash, but they can state with confidence what likely caused the accident.%nv~
       In this train of thought, the mystery of the ending of Mark is likely explained in this way: the ending was intentionally truncated from certain manuscripts in the late third or early fourth centuries by order of one in authority, perhaps even Eusebius of Caesarea himself. The reason this person did so was because he refused to believe what was written in Mark 16:16-19. Ironically, these manuscripts, which are called the %I@A%i@l%i@e%i@x%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@r%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@x%i@t%i@-%i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e, are the most accurate in most every other respect to the originals, as the editors who produced them made a concerted effort to eradicate the false emendations (mostly insertions) which had accumulated over time in manuscripts everywhere, most likely in the second and third centuries, and they predate any false changes made in the fourth century and onwards. To a large extent, scholars in the 19%u@t%u@h and 20%u@t%u@h centuries, observing the faithfulness and accuracy of the hand of correction which guided the Alexandrian manuscripts, could not fathom that the same party who had corrected so many verses in the NT would be the one most instrumental in trashing the largest and most important disputed passage in the NT—but this is precisely what they did.%nv~
%i@%sb~
Mark Chapter 1%hb~
%u@1The Beginning of the Good News%u@[%u@a%u@] of Jesus Christ, Son of God%vt~
%u@2…Just as it had been written by the Prophet Isaiah:%nn~
%si~
      See here—I will send my messenger%vn~
      To where your attention is fixated%u@[%u@b%u@],%vn~
      Who’ll prepare your way%vn~
%si~
          %u@3The sound of shouting in the countryside%u@[%u@d%u@]:%vn~
“Block off the road the Lord will take!%vp~
      Barricade the streets he’ll be on!”%u@[%u@c%u@]%u@%vn~
%si~
          %u@4John the Baptist came on the scene in the countryside%u@[%u@d%u@] preaching a baptism—a water immersion-type of initiation ceremony—signifying a total commitment to a change in conduct to live the right way %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@i%i@f%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ into %i@a forgiveness of sins.%u@[%u@e%u@] %u@5All%u@[%u@f%u@] of the Judean region and everyone in Jerusalem were coming out and were being baptized by him in the Jordan River, one after another, while pouring their hearts out in confessing their sins out loud. %u@6John dressed himself in a camel hair outfit wrapped in a leather belt and for food ate grasshoppers and wild honey.%u@[%u@g%u@] %u@7He preached, “One’s coming after me who’s greater than me, for whom I’m not worthy of bending over and unfastening one of the straps on his sandals. %u@8Me—I baptize in water, but he—he’ll baptize you in the Holy Spirit.”%vn~
          %u@9Jesus of Nazareth, Galilee came on the scene in those days and was baptized by John. %u@1%u@0As he came straight up out of the water, he saw the sky parting and the Spirit descending upon him like a dove.%u@[%U@A%u@] %u@1%u@1A voice spoke from out of the sky, “You are my Beloved Son. I’m quite pleased with you.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Immediately the Spirit drove him into the countryside%u@[%u@d%u@]. %u@1%u@3He was out there in the middle of nowhere%u@[%u@d%u@] for forty days, being tempted%u@[%U@B%u@] by Satan. He was fighting for his life,%u@[%U@C%u@] and all the while the angels were attending to him.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4After John had been taken into custody, Jesus came to Galilee preaching God’s message of good news%u@[%u@h%u@], %u@1%u@5and saying that the time had arrived%u@[%u@i%u@] and that God’s involvement with you (God’s kingdom) had drawn near; %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g, %r@“%R@G%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@g%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@j%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %R@N%r@e%r@w%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@6While passing by the Sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and his brother Andrew casting a net%u@[%u@k%u@], seeing that they were fishermen. %u@1%u@7Jesus said to them, %r@“%R@C%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@” %u@1%u@8Right away they left their nets and followed him. %u@1%u@9He continued onwards a bit further and saw James, son of Zebedee, and his brother John, while they were in the boat mending the nets. %u@2%u@0Right away he called out to them, and they left their father Zebedee in the boat with the hired hands and departed to be his followers.%vn~
          %u@2%u@1They came to Capernaum, and without delay he started teaching in the synagogue there on the Sabbaths. %u@2%u@2They were amazed at his teaching, since he was teaching in a captivating manner%u@[%u@l%u@], and not like their designated teachers, the Scribes. %u@2%u@3In an instant, there was a man %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e in their synagogue with a demonic spirit%u@[%u@m%u@], and he screamed, %u@2%u@4”We have no beef with you,%u@[%u@n%u@] Jesus of Nazareth; did you come to annihilate us? I know who you are: %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e the Holy One of God.” %u@2%u@5Jesus %i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@l%i@y took charge over him saying, %r@“%R@S%r@h%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@!%r@”%r@ %u@2%u@6The demonic spirit%u@[%u@m%u@] shook him real good, cried out in a loud voice, and then exited him. %u@2%u@7Everyone was amazed, to the extent that they began to discuss and argue among themselves, “%I@J%i@u%i@s%i@t who is this guy?…Fresh teaching delivered in a captivating manner…He even takes charge over demonic spirits, and they obey him.” %u@2%u@8Immediately, the news about him spread to everyone in the entire area surrounding Galilee.%vn~
          %u@2%u@9Right after leaving the synagogue, they went with James and John to Simon and Andrew’s house. %u@3%u@0Simon’s mother-in-law was laid out with a fever, and immediately they spoke to %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s about her. %u@3%u@1He went over to her, took her hand, pulled her up, and the fever left, and she began to attend to their needs. %u@3%u@2When it was late in the day and the sun was setting, they began to bring him all those having something wrong with them%u@[%u@o%u@] and the demon-possessed. %u@3%u@3The whole city gathered at the door, %u@3%u@4and he healed many of those who had something wrong with them consisting of a disease of one kind or another, and cast out many demons, and %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ wasn’t letting the demons say anything, because they knew who he was.%vn~
          %u@3%u@5Early in the morning, before daybreak, he left and went out to a place where nobody was around and prayed and prayed there. %u@3%u@6Simon and those with him went out to hunt him down. %u@3%u@7They found him and, engaging him in conversation, said, “Everyone’s looking for you.” %u@3%u@8Continuing the conversation, he said, %r@“%R@L%r@e%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@l%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@v%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@y%r@.%r@” %u@3%u@9They went throughout all of Galilee preaching in the synagogues there and casting out demons.%vn~
          %u@4%u@0A leper approached him%u@[%u@p%u@], pleading with him, “If you so desire, you can purge this disease from me%u@[%u@q%u@].” %u@4%u@1He had pity on him, extended his hand, touched him, and pronounces, %r@“%R@I%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@i%r@r%r@e%r@;%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@r%r@g%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@a%r@s%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@4%u@2Immediately it left him; he was purged of the disease. %u@4%u@3Without wasting any time, he sternly and with an inner indignation%u@[%u@r%u@] gave him specific instructions and %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n cut him loose%u@[%u@s%u@], %u@4%u@4telling him, %r@“%R@M%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@O%r@l%r@d%r@ %R@T%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@m%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@b%r@m%r@i%r@s%r@s%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@e%r@r%r@t%r@i%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@a%r@s%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@4%u@5But he departed and began going around enthusiastically telling lots of people what had happened and spreading the story and its acclamation around, resulting in him no longer being able to enter a city, but instead having to stay outside in the countryside.%vn~
      And they began to come to him from every direction.%i@%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@S%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@—%I@I%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@x%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@…Lit: %I@L%i@o%i@,%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@B%i@l%i@o%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@!%i@ %I@B%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@!%i@…Ref. Matt. 3:3%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@m%i@—%i@a%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@m%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@-%i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@y%i@—%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@i%i@f%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@t%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@i%i@f%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@s…Lit: %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@c%i@l%i@a%i@i%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ [or possibly:%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@,%i@t%i@o]%i@ %i@a [or possibly: %i@t%i@h%i@e]%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%I@A%i@l%i@l%i@…Ref. note in Matt. 3:5%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@h%i@o%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@y…Ref. Matt. 3:4%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%I@G%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@t%i@…The GT specifies that this is a circular fishing net, unlike the other word used for %i@f%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@t%i@ in the NT%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@…Ref. note of Matt. 7:29%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%I@W%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@…Ref. note of Matt. 8:29%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m…Lit: %i@b%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s. These are unexplainable illnesses.%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@p%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@…Some manuscripts add, %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@k%i@n%i@e%i@e%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%i@p%i@u%i@r%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n. Ref. note of Matt. 8:10%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@…The Gk. word here means that he was vexed and indignant, like a horse snorting%fn~
%u@[%u@s%u@]%i@c%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@t%u@]%I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@…Lit: %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s. This is short for %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@k%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@v%i@e…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@k%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. The comparison of the Spirit to a dove is misunderstood. The Spirit descended the same way a dove would descend, but the Spirit himself is not like a dove. Pigeons are similar to doves, and are birds we are more familiar with. A pigeon flutters and flaps its wings as it lands on a spot in the park, but once it has landed, all the flapping and fluttering immediately ceases, and the pigeon then begins to walk slowly looking for food. So it was when the Spirit descended: a lot of activity and commotion, but once the Spirit came to rest on Jesus, the commotion ceased. But like the pigeon, the Spirit remained.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@…The implication of the word %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@e%i@d here is that Satan was trying to break him.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@H%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@s. This is an idiom used in both the OT and NT (Ref. Ps. 22:12,13, 1 Cor. 15:32), and means, %I@I%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@,%i@ or, %I@I%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@,%i@ or, %I@I%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@t%i@w%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@o%i@t%i@.%i@%fn~
%i@%sb~
Mark Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1Several days after entering Capernaum, word got out that he was staying in a house %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e. %u@2Many converged on it, to the extent that nobody could get in or out of the door anymore, and he kept on speaking the word %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d to them. %u@3Four men arrived carrying a stretcher that had someone who was paralyzed on it. %u@4Not being able to carry him through the crowd, they pulled away the roof where he was and dug out a hole in order to lower the stretcher on which the paralyzed fellow was lying. %u@5Seeing their faith, Jesus said to the one paralyzed, %r@“%R@S%r@o%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@6Some of the designated teachers%u@[%u@a%u@] were sitting there mulling this over in their hearts, %u@7”How can he talk that way to this guy? He’s blaspheming; who’s able to forgive sins, except for the one-and-only God?” %u@8Immediately coming to the realization in his spirit exactly what they had thought up, Jesus engages them in conversation, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@k%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@s%r@i%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@r%r@a%r@l%r@y%r@z%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@,%r@’%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@r%r@e%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@l%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@’%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@0%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@…%r@”%r@ he %i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d speaks to the paralyzed fellow, %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@”%r@…%R@I%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@p%r@i%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@r%r@e%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@1%u@2And in front of everybody he got up, without delay picked up his stretcher, and left, to everyone’s amazement and to their glorification of God saying, “We’ve never seen anything like this before.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Again, he ventured out near the sea. Everyone in the crowd started coming to him, and he began teaching them. %u@1%u@4As he was passing through, he saw Levi %i@s%i@o%i@n of Alphaeus sitting at the customs table%u@[%U@A%u@], and tells him directly, “Be my follower.%u@[%u@c%u@]” And he got up and became his follower. %u@1%u@5As he sat down to dine%u@[%U@B%u@] at home, many tax collectors and %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ sinners gathered there to eat with Jesus. %u@1%u@6The designated teachers, the ones affiliated with%i@ the Pharisees, observing that he takes meals with sinners and tax collectors, were saying to his disciples, “How is it that he dines with the tax collectors and %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r sinners?” %u@1%u@7Jesus heard %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s and said to them, %r@“%R@H%r@e%r@a%r@l%r@t%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@c%r@t%r@o%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@.%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@r%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@n%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@8John’s disciples and the Pharisees were fasting, and they approached him with a question, “What’s the reason that John’s disciples fast and the Pharisees’ disciples fast, but your disciples don’t fast?” %u@1%u@9Jesus said, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@y%r@?%r@ %R@A%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@0%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@m%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@a%r@p%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@h%r@l%r@y%r@-%r@s%r@q%r@u%r@e%r@e%r@z%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@C%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@;%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@w%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@u%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@ %R@R%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@g%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@2%u@3He happened to be passing through the grain fields on days which were Sabbath days, and his disciples began to make their way through the fields stripping the grain off the heads of the stalks%u@[%U@D%u@]. %u@2%u@4The Pharisees proceeded to say to him, “%I@T%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a look—they’re doing what’s forbidden on the Sabbath.” %u@2%u@5Looking deeper at the situation, he said to them, %r@“%R@D%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@D%r@a%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@r%r@y%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@—%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@H%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %R@A%r@b%r@i%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@E%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@c%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@—%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@—%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@?%r@” %u@2%u@7He summarized, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %u@[%u@a%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@…Lit: %I@S%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n. Ref. note in Matt. 8:20.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@B%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@…Lit: %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@m%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%I@B%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%i@…Lit: %I@B%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@n%i@g%i@r%i@y%i@…Impl: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@n%i@g%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t, or, %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@n%i@g%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@c%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@m%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@…Also: %i@c%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e,%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@e, or %i@t%i@a%i@x%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@e. Nowadays, we visit places like tag agencies or license plate offices. The concept is similar, the details vastly different, of course.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@s%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@…Lit: %I@A%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e. They reclined to partake of the meal, taking their time at it and enjoying the company of those dining them. Also, the GT insinuates that, once the sinners heard that Jesus had reclined for a meal, they came and joined him at the meal.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@f%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@h%i@l%i@y%i@-%i@s%i@q%i@u%i@e%i@e%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@n%i@e%i@w%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@n%i@e. The Gk. word for wine means either grape juice (no preservatives, of course) or wine. The distinction in ancient times is that grape juice is simply wine which hasn’t fermented yet; freshly-squeezed grape juice will invariably ferment into wine (or vinegar if not done properly). The fermentation of the juice into wine yields gases, and since the skins are sealed shut, such gases cause an increase in pressure, which causes a new skin to stretch, and therefore the total volume in the sealed container to increase, thereby reducing the pressure. Old skins, those which have been used once already for making wine, have been stretched fully and do not shrink after the wine has been poured out of them. When grape juice is fermented in them a second time, since they have already been stretched to their maximum extent, and are not capable of stretching any more, the pressure buildup from the second fermentation cannot be relieved and causes the skins to burst.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@p%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@l%i@k%i@s…Walking through the fields and eating the heads of wheat, barley, etc.; this is permitted under OT law (ref. Lev. 19:9-10, Deut. 24:19-21, and others).%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@…The %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d here is the showbread. This is bread which was placed on a table and was always present in the Temple in Jerusalem, as required by the OT (ref. Exod. 25:30, Matt. 12:4).%fn~
%i@%sb~
Mark Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1Yet again he introduced himself to those in the synagogue and attended a meeting%u@[%u@a%u@]. There was a man there with a shriveled-up%u@[%u@b%u@] hand, %u@2and they were watching him closely, to see if he was going to heal him on the Sabbath, so that they’d have something to accuse him of. %u@3He addressed the man with the shriveled-up hand, %r@“%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@” %u@4He challenged them, %r@“%R@I%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@i%r@s%r@s%r@i%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@f%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@?%r@”%r@ They remained silent. %u@5He looked all around, staring at them in fury, being deeply grieved over the callousness of their hearts, and said to the man intently, %r@“%R@S%r@t%r@r%r@e%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@.%r@”%r@ He stretched it out, and his hand was restored. %u@6After the Pharisees departed, they wasted no time in meeting with the Herodians about him, %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@g%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t how they could kill him.%vn~
          %u@7Jesus, accompanied by his disciples, ventured over to the sea, and a great many followed him from Galilee, and from Judea, %u@8and from Jerusalem, and from Idumea, and from the other side of the Jordan %I@R%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@r, and from %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@s around Tyre and Sidon—a great many, hearing about how much he was doing, went to him. %u@9And because of the crowd, he spoke to his disciples about getting a boat, so that they wouldn’t press in on him. %u@1%u@0Indeed, he treated many, resulting in them mobbing him%u@[%u@c%u@] in order that they might receive a touch from him, whoever was getting the tar beaten out of him by disease or whatnot%u@[%u@d%u@]. %u@1%u@1And, time and time again, the demonic spirits%u@[%u@e%u@], when they saw him, prostrated themselves before him in homage and screamed out, “You are the Son of God!” %u@1%u@2And, time and time again, he was sternly silencing them so they would not cause him to be plainly known %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@c%i@h.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3He hiked up a mountain and summoned those whom he had been wanting %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@s, and they came to him. %u@1%u@4He made twelve%u@[%U@A%u@], %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m so that they would be with him and so that he could send them out to preach %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e %u@1%u@5and to have authority to cast out demons%u@[%U@B%u@]. %u@1%u@6%u@[%U@A%u@]He assigned the name “Peter%u@[%U@C%u@]” to Simon, %u@1%u@7and %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s James son of Zebedee and his brother John, to whom he assigned the name “Sons of Thunder%u@[%u@f%u@],” %u@1%u@8Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, Thaddeus, Simon the Canaaanite (i.e., Zealot), %u@1%u@9and Judas Iscariot, his betrayer.%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Now he came to a house. Once again, the crowd converged on it, resulting in them not being able to get a bite%u@[%u@g%u@] to eat. %u@2%u@1When the neighbors%u@[%u@h%u@] caught wind of this, they came out to get him under control%u@[%u@i%u@], since they had been saying %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g that he’s lost his mind. %u@2%u@2And the designated teachers, the Scribes, made the journey from Jerusalem%i@ and had been saying that he’s possessed by the Chief Demon%u@[%u@j%u@] himself, and that, by means of the chief, he casts out the underling-demons. %u@2%u@3He called them over and began to teach them by using analogies%u@[%u@k%u@]: %r@“%R@H%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@I%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@w%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@g%r@a%r@n%r@i%r@z%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@t%r@—%r@n%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@ %r@g%r@u%r@y%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@u%r@y%r@.%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@D%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@I%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@n%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@l%r@k%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@a%r@s%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@u%r@r%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@a%r@s%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@H%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@S%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@E%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@—%r@h%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@u%r@i%r@l%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@e%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@.%r@” %u@3%u@0%I@H%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ because they were going about saying, “He has a demonic spirit%u@[%u@d%u@].”%vn~
          %u@3%u@1His mother and brothers came and were standing outside and sent him word, calling on him. %u@3%u@2Seated around him was a crowd, and they said to him, “Hey, your mother and your brothers are outside looking for you.” %u@3%u@3Surprisingly, he replied, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@?%r@” %u@3%u@4He looked around at those sitting in a circle around him and said, %r@“%R@T%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@—%r@m%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@.%r@”%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@W%r@h%r@o%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@”%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@n%i@a%i@g%i@o%i@g%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@n%i@a%i@g%i@o%i@g%i@u%i@e. Ref. note of Acts 19:8.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@s%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@-%i@u%i@p%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@…Ref. note of Matt. 12:10%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@m%i@o%i@b%i@b%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@…Lit: %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%I@G%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@n%i@o%i@t…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@o%i@g%i@g%i@e%i@d. This word means a scourge, a plague, a judgment (perceived at least) from God.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@(%i@s%i@)%i@…Lit: %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@(%i@s%i@)%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%I@S%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@T%i@h%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@…means %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@b%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@n%i@e%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@b%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. Surmising that “those with him” are his neighbors, since it says later in v. 21 that %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t: assuming that this means they were not in the same house Jesus was in. Some, however, think that “those with him” refers to Jesus’s family members.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@l%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%I@C%i@h%i@i%i@e%i@f%i@ %I@D%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@…Lit: %I@B%i@e%i@e%i@l%i@z%i@e%i@b%i@u%i@b. The ancient Jews believed he was the ruler of the demons.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@o%i@g%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%I@H%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@?…Lit: %I@H%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@t%i@a%i@n? The demons under Satan at times go by the name of Satan himself, as they do his bidding.%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@…Lit: %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@…Lit: %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@d%i@.%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@k%i@…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@a%i@s%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@u%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@…Lit: …%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@a%i@s%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@a%i@s%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@e. The wording is a figure of speech.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@H%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@w%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@…Some manuscripts include the phrase, %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@s%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@“%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@”%i@ (i.e. apostles) in v. 14 and the phrase, %I@A%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@w%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e, in v. 16, but there is not strong evidence whether this is genuine or not. The assumption is that it is not genuine.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@s. In classical Gk., this phrase meant %i@d%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@,%i@ and referred to special talents or powers that select folks had, and also came to mean an inferior race of divine beings. As this evolved in time, it is used in the NT to refer to an evil race of divine beings. This is the meaning Mark selected to use here, by choosing the phrase %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@s, which is not used much in the NT,%i@ instead of the usual phrase %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@s. Mark emphasizes that these evil spirits are an entire supernatural race of a sort. The phrase %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ emphasizes the vile, unnatural, and evil nature of these beings; the phrase %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ emphasizes that these beings are a supernatural race.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@P%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r…The name comes from a Gk. word means %i@r%i@o%i@c%i@k. Jesus is not only assigning him this name but declaring that Simon has the characteristics of this new name. Although many interpret %i@r%i@o%i@c%i@k%i@ to mean stability, the meaning of %i@r%i@o%i@c%i@k%i@ as revealed in the NT (ref. Matt 16:18, Eph. 2:20) is a foundation to build upon, which specifically points to a foundational leadership position in the Church. This list of apostles here in Mark 3 ranks them according to the preeminence Jesus assigns to them. Therefore, in listing Peter first and giving him the name Peter (”the rock”), Jesus has made Peter the first among his disciples and the one who’ll lead the early church after his ascension.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%I@N%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@g%i@u%i@y…Jesus stated this in the context of the way Satan and his demons operate. This verse is one of the most important rules for understanding how demons take hold of people. What Jesus is saying is that it is not possible for demons to simply approach someone and take control of them, believers and unbelievers alike. In order for evil spirits to get any sort of control over a person, they must break that person’s will first. Breaking their will is “binding the strong man.” Only then, can they “enter the strong man’s house.” A person who is fully demon-possessed has had his willpower systematically broken, and for this reason, someone must cast the demon out of him, since he has not the willpower to do it himself. However, any believer can simply exercise his will and authority in Christ and drive any demonic influence from himself.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@b%i@l%i@a%i@s%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@…Jesus says that this one sin called “the blasphemy of the Holy Spirit” is unforgiveable. Jesus spoke of the same thing in Matt. 12:32 (ref. note there). What exactly, then, is the blasphemy of the Holy Spirit? The answer is in plain sight, as Jesus was insinuating that the Scribes had committed this sin, and what the Scribes did is specified in v.30. Here the Scribes could see the miracles of Jesus, and they attributed them to the devil. Believing in miracles does not require the amount of faith as believing in something which is unseen does. The hardness of heart that denies the undeniable will never turn to God and will therefore never receive forgiveness, ever.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Mark Chapter 4%hb~
          %u@1On another occasion, he began to teach near the sea. A huge crowd gathered around him, causing him to have to get in a boat and sit %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ in the sea; everyone in the crowd %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@y%i@e%i@d on dry land %i@a%i@n%i@d %i@s%i@q%i@u%i@e%i@e%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n as close as they could to the shoreline. %u@2He began to teach them by means of analogy%u@[%u@a%u@], telling many. In one of his sermons he was telling them this: %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@”%R@L%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@!%r@ %R@T%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@r%r@m%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@w%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@W%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@w%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@i%r@r%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%r@w%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@c%r@k%r@y%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@i%r@l%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@i%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@m%r@m%r@e%r@d%r@i%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@n%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@c%r@o%r@r%r@c%r@h%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@d%r@u%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@e%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@b%r@l%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@o%r@t%r@s%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@Y%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@r%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@g%r@u%r@l%r@f%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@o%r@k%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@i%r@e%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@d%r@u%r@c%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@N%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@m%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@w%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@i%r@e%r@l%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@d%r@u%r@c%r@e%r@:%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@i%r@e%r@l%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@3%r@0%r@-%r@t%r@o%r@-%r@1%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@6%r@0%r@-%r@t%r@o%r@-%r@1%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@1%r@0%r@0%r@-%r@t%r@o%r@-%r@1%r@.%r@” %u@9And he kept telling them, %r@“%R@A%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@f%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@.%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@A%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@0When they got together by themselves, those around him, along with the Twelve, asked him about the analogies. %u@1%u@1He began by saying, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@’%r@s%r@ %R@I%r@n%r@v%r@o%r@l%r@v%r@e%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@(%R@G%r@o%r@d%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@)%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@(%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@.%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@.%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@w%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%R@I%r@@%R@G%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@’%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@k%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@g%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@m%r@)%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@j%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@o%r@g%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@,%r@%vn~
%r@%si~
%r@“%R@W%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@%vp~
%r@(%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@.%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@.%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@,%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@y%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@’%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@w%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@,%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@y%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@’%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@g%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@)%r@,%r@%vp~

%r@(%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@.%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@.%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@,%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@g%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@x%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@)%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@L%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@”%r@%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@3He said, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@o%r@g%r@y%r@?%r@ %R@H%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@
