%u@[%u@u%u@]%I@T%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@…Lit: %I@R%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@i. Using the affectionate form (ref. Mark 10:51) for the word %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r, this could more accurately be rendered, %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@.%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@v%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@y%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@…Ref. note of Matt 26:59%fn~
%u@[%u@w%u@]%I@I%i@ %i@a%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@-%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@o%i@n%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@…Lit: %I@I%i@ %i@a%i@m%i@.%i@ Ref. Mark 13:5%fn~
%u@[%u@x%u@]%I@I%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@-%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n…Lit: %I@S%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@-%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@y%u@]%i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@u%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s…Lit: %I@S%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@a%i@k. Some liberties taken; Ref. note of Matt. 26:65.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@c%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@e%i@d%i@…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@k; %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r; %i@c%i@r%i@u%i@s%i@h. What Mark is conveying is the tearing or breaking of an expensive seal, elaborate packaging, or a one-time breaking of some sort of container. Just as it is today, expensive items back then came with elaborate seals, not just simple lids. The manufacturer of an expensive item will purposely intend the breaking open of such a container to become a pleasing ritual and a means of fueling the hype and anticipation of discovering its contents.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@a%i@s%i@t…Lit: %i@d%i@i%i@p%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@e. Some liberties taken; ref. note of Matt. 26:23.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@a%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@k%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t…Breaking of bread was a ritual; ref. note of Matt. 14:19.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@t…Some of the older manuscripts have an alternate reading, %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@t, while others read, %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@w%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@t. The evidence for the accepted reading is sufficient to accept what’s rendered here as genuine. It remains for us to accept what Jesus said at face value.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@s%i@l%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@;%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@k%i@n%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@y%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@g%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %I@A%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@s%i@l%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@y%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@g%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@k%i@n%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. They were sleeping because they didn’t know how to reply to Jesus?—An example of Mark’s clumsy writing.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@](V.48) %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@y…(v.50) %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m (v.48); %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m (v.50). It’s known by the context what the antecedent of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ is in both cases, but the potential for ambiguity would otherwise exist. Another example of Mark’s clumsy writing.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%I@A%i@ %i@c%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@…Some assert that the “certain young man” referred to in v.51 is none other than Mark himself. At a minimum, Mark’s book is worded in such a way that the reader would understand who he was talking about. Patching together NT verses here and there and also church tradition, Mark was the son of Mary, who owned the upper room where the Last Supper was held. Mark wasn’t one of Jesus’s disciples, either because he was too young to be so, didn’t know him until the Passover week, or both; but he followed Jesus and the Twelve Disciples after they left the upper room to Gethsemane.%fn~
%u@[%U@H%u@]%i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@r%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@d%i@…From the sounds of it, when those in the party tried to grab ahold of the young man, they could just barely get ahold of him. They weren’t able to arms, legs, neck, or grab him around his waist; all they could do is get a hand on his linen garment. He squirmed, the loin cloth came off, and he continued to bolt. This probably would’ve taken place in just a few seconds.%fn~
%u@[%U@I%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@d%i@ (v.68)…%i@a%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@d %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e (v.72)…These words are missing from a few of the most reliable manuscripts. It’s possible that others added what Mark in his clumsiness neglected. %fn~
%u@[%U@J%u@]%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@s%i@…Lit: %I@H%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g. The single Gk. word %i@e%i@p%i@i%i@b%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ō%i@ (ἐπιβάλλω /Strong’s 1911). Apparently an idiom of some sort; it’s not entirely certain what the exact meaning of this is when used as an idiom. Some translators render it, %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@d.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Mark Chapter 15%hb~
          %u@1Without delay, late in the night the chief priests, along with all the councilmen and the designated teachers%u@[%u@a%u@], convened a meeting, bound Jesus, carried him away, and delivered him into Pilate’s custody. %u@2Pilate asked him, “You’re the king of the Jews?” He answered him, “Whatever you say%u@[%u@b%u@].” %u@3The chief priests accused him of many things. %u@4Again, Pilate asked him, “You’re not going to say anything in response? Take a look at how many accusations they’ve leveled against you.” %u@5But to Pilate’s astonishment, Jesus didn’t have anything more to say.%vn~
          %u@6He had an ongoing %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n, done at each festival, of releasing one prisoner for them, whomever they’d ask for. %u@7There was one called Barabbas who had been imprisoned along with the revolutionaries%u@[%U@A%u@], %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@r those who had committed murder during the insurrection%u@[%U@A%u@]. %u@8The crowd came over and initiated making the request, in accordance with his usual practice. %u@9Pilate responded to them, “Do you want me to set the king of the Jews free?”, %u@1%u@0since he was aware that the chief priests had him arrested out of envy. %u@1%u@1Now, the chief priests had whipped the crowd into a frenzy, in order that their preference would be to release Barabbas.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Again, Pilate responded to them,%vn~
      “So now, what do you want me to do with the one who’s called the King of the Jews?”%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Again, they shouted, “Crucify him!”%vn~
          %u@1%u@4Pilate said to them multiple times, “…Because he’s done what wrong?”%vn~
      But they shouted all the more, “Crucify him!”%vn~
          %u@1%u@5Intending to placate the crowd, Pilate set Barabbas free and handed over Jesus, after%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m flogged, to be crucified.%vn~
          %u@1%u@6The soldiers led him away to a courtyard inside %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d, the one used by the governor’s security guards%u@[%u@c%u@], and called over the entire company of guards. %u@1%u@7They clothed him in a robe a nobleman would wear%u@[%U@B%u@] and placed on%u@[%u@d%u@] him a crown, a wreath woven from thorns. %u@1%u@8They began to go about greeting him, “Pleased %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%u@[%u@e%u@] King of the Jews.” %u@1%u@9They kept on hitting him on the head with a rod, spitting on him, and getting on their knees in an act of subservience to him. %u@2%u@0When they finished ridiculing him, they took the robe off and put his clothes back on him, and they led him away to be crucified%u@[%u@f%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@1They pressed into service a random passerby, Simon of Cyrene (%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ father of Alexander and Rufus), who %i@h%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e coming in from %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n the fields, to carry%u@[%u@g%u@] his cross. %u@2%u@2They brought him %i@u%i@p %i@o%i@n %i@t%i@o%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%u@[%u@h%u@] the place called Golgotha, which translated means “Skull Place.” %u@2%u@3They kept on %i@t%i@r%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o give him spiced%u@[%U@C%u@] wine, but he wouldn’t take it. %u@2%u@4They crucified him and divvied up his clothing, rolling dice%u@[%u@i%u@] to see who was going %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t to take it away. %vn~
          %u@2%u@5Now it was mid-morning%u@[%U@D%u@] when they performed the crucifixion on him.%u@[%u@j%u@] %u@2%u@6There was a sign stating the reason %i@w%i@h%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@e%i@d, and it read, “The king of the Jews.” %u@2%u@7They crucified two thugs with him, together as a group, one to the left of him and one to the right of him%u@[%u@k%u@]. %u@2%u@8%u@[%u@l%u@] %u@2%u@9Those who passed by reviled him, nodding their heads %i@l%i@e%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t saying, “Ah! The one who’ll %i@s%i@u%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@l%i@y destroy the temple and rebuild it in three days— %u@3%u@0Save yourself: come down off that cross.” %u@3%u@1In the same way, the chief priests and the designated teachers%u@[%u@m%u@], going back and forth with each other making fun of him, in the midst of that were saying, “He %i@w%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d rescued others, but he cannot save himself. %u@3%u@2The Messiah, the Christ, the King of Israel: let him come down from the cross now, so that we would see and believe.” Even his fellow crucifixion-mates kept on taunting him.%vn~
          %u@3%u@3When it got to be noon%u@[%U@D%u@], darkness appeared over the entire planet until late afternoon%u@[%U@D%u@], %u@3%u@4and in the late afternoon%u@[%U@D%u@], Jesus shouted in a loud voice, %r@“%R@E%r@l%r@o%r@i%r@,%r@ %r@e%r@l%r@o%r@i%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@m%r@a%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@b%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@i%r@?%r@”, which is translated, %r@“%R@M%r@y%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@?%r@”%r@ %u@3%u@5Some of the bystanders heard this and started saying, “Look, he’s calling on Elijah.” %u@3%u@6Someone ran and soaked a sponge in a mixture of water and vinegar that the soldiers commonly drank, put it on a rod, and proceeded to %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@t to him to drink, saying, “Let’s see if Elijah comes and takes him down from off the cross,” %u@3%u@7but Jesus let out a great cry and passed away%u@[%u@n%u@], %u@3%u@8and the temple curtain%u@[%u@o%u@] was torn in two from top to bottom. %u@3%u@9Seeing this, the army captain standing across from him said, “This man really was the embodiment of a son%u@[%u@p%u@] of God.” %u@4%u@0Now there were also women watching at a distance, among whom were%u@[%u@q%u@] Mary Magdalene, Mary mother of James the younger and of Joses, and Salome, %u@4%u@1those women who were ever his followers and were constantly attending to his needs when he was in Galilee, and many other women who accompanied him to Jerusalem.%vn~
          %u@4%u@2It had gotten to be late, and since it was a preparatory day (that is, a pre-feast day or pre-Sabbath %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%u@[%U@E%u@]), %u@4%u@3Joseph of Arimathea, an influential councilman, who also was himself a true believer,%u@[%u@r%u@] got up the courage, entered %I@P%i@i%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d, and went up to Pilate and asked for Jesus’s body. %u@4%u@4But Pilate wondered if he had %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@t died already, and summoned the captain and asked him if it had been a while since he died%u@[%u@s%u@]. %u@4%u@5Getting up to speed with the captain, he presented the body to Joseph as a gift, %u@4%u@6and Joseph purchased a cloth sheet made of linen and used for wrapping, took him down, rolled him up in the sheet, put him in a tomb, one which had been hewn out of a rock %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n, and rolled a stone over the tomb’s entrance. %u@4%u@7Now Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses were monitoring where he was being placed.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@W%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@…Lit:%i@ %I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@c%i@u%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@g%i@u%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@a%i@n. Similar to the Roman Praetorian Guard but applied to the governor’s (Pilate’s) palace.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@…Lit: %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. The use of the word %i@a%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ instead of %i@o%i@n%i@,%i@ and the fact that the word for %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ here is something similar to a Roman laurel wreath indicates that the crown indeed was just like we see in the pictures and movies about Jesus.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%I@P%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@,%i@ %I@K%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@…Lit: %I@J%i@o%i@y%i@,%i@ %I@K%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@i%i@f%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@y%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p. The Gk. word rendered %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@y in v.21 is the same word used in Matt. 16:24 (%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p).%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@u%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@…Or: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f; %i@t%i@o%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@r%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@…Some liberty taken; they cast lots instead of rolling dice.%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%I@N%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@d%i@-%i@m%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@x%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m…Lit: %I@N%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. The two thoughts (#1: %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@r; #2: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m) separated by the word %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ rather than combining them is a figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m…Also: %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]Verse 28 which reads, %I@A%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@p%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@“%I@A%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@w%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@,%i@” is spurious and therefore omitted.%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@d, or, %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@u%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@…Ref. note of Matt. 27:52%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@…The rendering %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@n should not insinuate that the Son of God is one of many sons of God. The GT does not say that.%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%i@a%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@…The GT includes a leading %i@a%i@n%i@d to the list of women, and this %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@,%i@ though omitted in the rendering, seems to imply that all the women who were watching from a distance are listed in vv.40,41; that there were no other women present.%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@s%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@s%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@s%u@]%i@i%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@e%i@d…some of the older manuscripts instead read, %i@i%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@e%i@d.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@v%i@o%i@l%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@…%i@d%i@u%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@…As v.8 is worded in the GT, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@v%i@o%i@l%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@s and %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n refer to a specific group of insurgents and a specific rebellion, lost to history perhaps, but known to Mark’s readers.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@a%i@r…The Gk. word %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@y%i@r%i@a%i@ (πορφύρα/Strong’s 4209)%i@.%i@ It means two things: it means %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@p%i@l%i@e and it also refers to the Murex snail from which purple dye is extracted. In modern times, dyes are synthesized at a low cost from chemical compounds, and so there is an abundance of cheap, multi-colored clothing. In ancient times only by harvesting Murex snails from the ocean could one produce a purple dye, so the clothing made from this dye was expensive. Since only the wealthy nobles could afford it, purple coloring was associated with nobility.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@s%i@p%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@m%i@y%i@r%i@r%i@h%i@-%i@m%i@i%i@x%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@n%i@e. Also ref. Matt. 27:34, Ps. 69:21. Roman soldiers normally drank a wine which was at least partly vinegar; the sour taste helped quench one’s thirst, something like putting a slice of lemon in a glass of iced tea. Obviously, however, too much vinegar would make the drink unpalatable, and apparently they mixed myrrh to limit the extent to which the wine degraded into vinegar, as it would naturally do so when exposed to the air. But the myrrh was also slightly narcotic, and Jesus apparently refuses it so that the wine won’t ameliorate his suffering.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@m%i@i%i@d%i@-%i@m%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@…%i@n%i@o%i@o%i@n%i@…%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@o%i@o%i@n%i@…%I@M%i@i%i@d%i@-%i@m%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g in the GT is the third hour. The Jewish regular hours of prayer and of sacrifices instituted the third, sixth, and ninth hours of the day. Out of this, the third, sixth, and ninth hours became the way of specifying approximate points during the day (ref. Matt. 20:1–17), and they correspond to what we call mid-morning, noon, middle of the afternoon, and late afternoon. In spite of the fact that they are numerical values in a twelve hour day, they are not as exact as their nominal values suggest.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@a %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@-%I@S%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y…The Sabbath here could be either a Saturday or a feast day. Naturally, one would want to remove dead bodies immediately; furthermore, dead bodies should not remain on the Sabbath. Work was forbidden on the Sabbath, not to mention the aversion and restrictions the Jews had concerning dead bodies.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Mark Chapter 16%hb~
          %u@1After sundown, just after the Sabbath %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s came to a close%u@[%u@a%u@], Mary Magdalene, Mary %i@m%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r of James, and Salome bought fragrant spices in order to go and apply to his body, covering it all over. %u@2Very early on Sunday morning%u@[%u@b%u@], when the sun had just risen, they went to the tomb. %u@3They were repeatedly saying amongst themselves, “Who’s going to roll the stone back away from the entrance of the tomb?”, %u@4and they all at once looked up and observed that the stone had been rolled away (it was simply enormous, you see). %u@5They came to the tomb and saw a man who looked to be in his late teens or early twenties sitting off to the right wearing a long white robe, and they were startled out of their wits. %u@6But he %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ tells them, “Don’t be startled. Jesus of Nazareth who had been crucified has been resurrected; he’s not here—take a look at the place where they put him. %u@7In any event, go your way and tell his disciples—and Peter%u@[%U@A%u@]—that he’s heading out before them to Galilee. They’ll see him there, just like he told them %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d.” %u@8They exited the tomb and began to run away like mad, since they were in a state of shock and were shaking all over. They didn’t say anything to anyone, since they were still too terrified to do so.%vn~
          %u@9%u@[%U@B%u@]After he had been resurrected early Sunday morning, he appeared first to Mary Magdalene, whom he had cast out seven demons out of. %u@1%u@0That lady went and told the news to those who had been mourning and weeping with her, %u@1%u@1and those who heard that he’s alive and that he had been seen by her refused to believe it%u@[%u@c%u@].%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Now after these %i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@s, he appeared in a different form to two of them while they were going out to the countryside, %u@1%u@3and those %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e went away and told everyone else—they didn’t believe those people either.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4Now last of all he appeared to the Eleven while they were relaxing taking a meal, and he chewed them out for their refusal to believe%u@[%u@c%u@] and for their hardness of heart, because they didn’t believe those who had beheld him resurrected. %u@1%u@5He said to them, %r@“%R@G%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@h%r@a%r@b%r@i%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@l%r@d%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@m%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %R@N%r@e%r@w%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@w%r@o%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@g%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@g%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@H%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@p%r@t%r@i%r@z%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@r%r@u%r@c%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@f%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@m%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@p%r@e%r@r%r@n%r@a%r@t%r@u%r@r%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@g%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@c%r@c%r@o%r@m%r@p%r@a%r@n%r@y%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@:%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@j%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@;%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@u%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@-%r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@d%r@-%r@b%r@e%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@n%r@g%r@u%r@a%r@g%r@e%r@s%r@;%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@r%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@;%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@k%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@k%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@i%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@e%r@r%r@t%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@r%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@;%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@c%r@k%r@l%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@9So then the Lord Jesus, after speaking to them, was taken up into the sky and assumed his position as God’s chief executive%u@[%u@l%u@]. %u@2%u@0But those %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@s went out and preached everywhere, the Lord working alongside and cooperating with them like a fellow-worker, and the message kept on being confirmed, established, and made certain by means of the supernatural signs following %i@h%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ right there on the spot, right on their heels.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@s%i@e…The Jewish day ended at sundown, so the Sabbath ended at sundown. Once the Sabbath was over, the women could conduct business.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@V%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@r%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %I@S%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@…Lit: %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@r%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@s%i@ (v.2). Ref. Matt. 28:1 for “Sabbaths” use in plural. The “first of the Sabbaths” is a Sunday; also ref. John 2:1; Acts 20:7 Related to this, v.9 reads lit.: %i@n%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@r%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@a%i@t%i@h…%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@f%i@u%i@s%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e…%i@r%i@e%i@f%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e…Lit: %i@u%i@n%i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@a%i@b%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@l%i@d%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@l%i@d%i@.%i@ Refers to the people who live on the earth, rather than the earth per se.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d…This is the word %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ in the aorist tense, not the expected present tense. The use of aorist over present tense views the proclamation of the gospel as a one-time event, rather than a never-ending series of proclamations. The one-time preaching of the gospel views takes all the individual proclamations and views them as a single set. In other words, make sure everyone gets to hear it at least once.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %I@N%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@w%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@g%i@s…Lit: %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n. This is a figure of speech, as Jesus isn’t commanding the disciples to preach to dogs or mountains or such.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@k%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@…Lit: %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@b%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@.%i@ Ref. note of Acts 4:7.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y…Also: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s. Some manuscripts read, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s, appending the words %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@. The word used for %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@p here is translated various ways depending on context.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@u%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@e%i@f%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@e%i@c%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@P%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r…If there’s any doubt that Mark was close to Peter, remarks such as these should lay that doubt to rest. In multiple places Mark points Peter out, mentioning what he’s doing. Furthermore, he often uses the name %I@P%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r, the one given to him by Jesus,%i@ instead of ones that others called him, %I@S%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n or %I@C%i@e%i@p%i@h%i@a%i@s.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]Those who deny that vv. 9–20 are genuine build their argument not on the manuscript evidence (which is certainly not in their favor) but instead on “internal” evidence, i.e. whether they think these verses fit Mark’s style of writing and his use of vocabulary. Their claims:%fn~
(a) %I@M%i@a%i@r%i@y%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@g%i@d%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@s (v.9). They claim that the writer is introducing Mary Magdalene here, noting the demons cast out of her, but in fact she had been referred to just a few times in the preceding verses and chapters.%fn~
(b) Some words occur in this passage that Mark doesn’t use anywhere else%fn~
(c) The writing is simply not Mark’s style%fn~
Let us look at these claims in detail.%fn~
First, Mark mentions that Mary Magdalene had had seven demons cast out of her. Any forger would know that Mary Magdalene was brought up in v.1 and would’ve written accordingly. But the extra statement of her having demons cast out is not an introduction but a reminder of the grace she had received, resulting in a tender heart which caused her to be the first to believe when the others wouldn’t. To emphasize this, Mark, when he said %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t, chose to use the Gk. perfect tense over the aorist for emphasis. In support of this, v.10 begins with the words %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@d%i@y, which invites the reader to detach himself and ponder her history. The other women weren’t address in that fashion.%fn~
Second, there are a few words which Mark uses in this passage that don’t appear elsewhere in his book (never mind the fact that every chapter of Mark has unique words used in its chapter which Mark uses nowhere else). Let us look at these words:%fn~
(i) %I@A%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@y (v.17). This is a more specific word that pre-pends the word %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ to %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@.%i@ Certainly Mark knew the meaning of this word.%fn~
(ii) %I@S%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t (v.18). A common word.%fn~
(iii) %I@H%i@u%i@r%i@t (v.18). Ranks 2808%u@t%u@h out of 5394, where 1 is most common and 5394 is least. This word is uncommon.%fn~
(iv) %I@P%i@o%i@i%i@s%i@o%i@n (v.18). Derived from a very common root.%fn~
(v) The phrase %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n (v. 19). Two extremely common words used as a phrase. Mark certainly knew the meaning of the phrase, but didn’t use it anywhere else.%fn~
(vi) %I@W%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e (v.20). This is the verb form of the commonly-used noun %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@-%i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@e%i@r%i@.%fn~
(vii) %I@C%i@o%i@n%i@f%i@i%i@r%i@m (v.20). Appears as 2803%u@r%u@d out of 5394. This word is uncommon and is not derived from a commonly used root.%fn~
We can strike serpent, hurt, and poison from the list, since there are no alternatives for these words; Mark would’ve asked the scribe who was doing the actual writing to supply these words had he not known them and when he had need of them. This leaves four words, three of which are common, and Mark certainly knew, but he hadn’t used before. The list of uncommon words is whittled down to the single word %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@f%i@i%i@r%i@m%i@.%i@%fn~
As far as the style is concerned—and this is quite open-ended—true, Mark shifts his preference in verb tenses around, but this passage has little story-telling narrative. Another thing to note are the figures of speech used in vv.15,16. Would a forgerer risk using a figure or speech? Would a forgerer dwell on the disciples not believing when they should have (vv.13,14). While all these things with style are debatable, they are not definitive in determining whether the long ending of vv.9–20 is spurious or not.%fn~

The Gospel of Luke%ha~
       Luke, the beloved physician (Col . 4:14), the faithful companion of Paul, is the author of one of the four officially-sponsored Gospels. We assume that Paul authorized Luke to write it, and since it was associated with Paul, it’s target audience was the gentile church, more specifically the Christians planted by Paul’s ministry. Evidence points to Luke being a slave or a freedman, serving or having served one Theophilus, for whose benefit he writes not only the Gospel of Luke but its sequel, the Book of Acts.%nv~
       The facts Luke recorded in his Gospel were obtained from him conducting first-hand interviews (he says this in 1:2) with many eyewitnesses to the ministry of Jesus. To do this, Luke would have had to have spent a few months in Israel, and would have spoken directly with Mary the mother of Jesus and recorded her very words in order to obtain such precise details of Jesus’s birth. The likely time of his doing these interviews would have been around AD 55, when Paul was in Israel during his third missionary journey. Had it been any later than this, these eyewitnesses would have been deceased already, not to speak of the sack of Jerusalem in AD 70.%nv~
       Luke was thorough and meticulous. He was likely a native Greek speaker; his command of Greek surpasses Matthew’s, Mark’s, and John’s by a large measure, and is only rivaled by Paul’s and by those who wrote the epistles of Jude and Hebrews. Luke has full command of the nuanced richness of the Greek language, and he can capture in a word or a word inflection something which takes an entire phrase to render in English.%nv~
       Though Luke has the education and intelligence to write complex, sophisticated passages—which he does in Luke 1:1–4—he refrains from doing so and writes in a down-to-earth manner throughout his book. From time to time, he dresses up a sentence or two, using colorful wording where more straightforward wording would suffice. An example is Luke 7:1; another example is Luke 8:15 “beautiful and morally good;” another example is the simile of Luke 22:44, where Luke compares Jesus sweat to drops of blood. But throughout the book, he is mindful of detail and correctness, as what he writes must reflect what the eyewitnesses told him in face-to-face interviews. In the example of the Pharisee and the tax collector praying at the temple (Luke 18:11,13), Luke says that both stood, but uses a different form of the same verb %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@,%i@ subtlety conveying the difference in their standing postures. Moreover in 18:13, Luke’s prose garnishes the story beautifully (literal rendering): “But the tax collector standing at a distance was not wanting neither to lift up the eyes to heaven.” Luke is sparing in his use of special forms and expressions, but by being sparing when he does use special forms, his usage is more effective. For example, in Luke 17:37, Luke uses the present tense to mean the past tense—he does not do that often, like in the other Gospels.%nv~
       Of the four Gospels, Luke captures the most sober and chilling warnings of the judgment to come: do the right thing or pay for it later, even if the payment might be deferred to the life to come. Some examples of this are as follows. Luke 12:20: “Fool—the Grim Reaper is coming for you this very night. Now everything you saved away: who’s it going to go to?” Luke 13:8,9: “The gardener considered things and replied, ‘Boss, leave it be this year as well; meanwhile, I’ll dig around it and put down fertilizer, and we’ll see if it produces figs in the coming year. But if it doesn’t, you can cut it down.” Luke 13:27,28: “Get away from me, the lot of you, practitioners of wrong-doing.’ There will be the weeping and the gnashing of teeth, at that time when Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and all the prophets connected with God’s involvement with mankind (God’s kingdom) will be seen. Those people, though, get the boot.” Luke 14:24: “I’ll tell you this much: not a single one of those people who were invited will taste even a morsel of my dinner.” The rich man and Lazarus (Luke 16). Luke 19:27: “However, my enemies, those who didn’t want me to rule over them as their king, bring them here and slay them right in front of me.”%nv~
%i@%sb~
Luke Chapter 1%hb~
          %u@1In light of the fact that many have attempted%u@[%U@A%u@] to compose a narrative concerning the deeds which have been carried out to fulfillment among us, %u@2and to record it%i@ in the same way that they—those from the get-go who became eye-witnesses and custodians of the entire affair—delivered and entrusted it to us, %u@3it seemed like a good idea for me to follow up after them and write something%i@ for you, something that starts from the very beginning and which is completely accurate and in sequential order, Lord Theophilus%u@[%U@B%u@], %u@4so that you would become %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@l%i@y acquainted with the affairs which you’ve learned by word of mouth, and that you would know them with certainty.%vn~
          %u@5It came to pass in the days of Herod, king of the Jews, that there was a certain priest named Zechariah, from the Order of Abijah, and he had a wife who was of the priestly caste%u@[%U@C%u@]—and her name was Elizabeth. %u@6Both of them were righteous in the sight of God, their conduct, from God’s perspective, was that they complied with%u@[%u@a%u@] all the commandments and %i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f correct %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@o%i@r. %u@7They had no children, because Elizabeth%u@[%U@C%u@] couldn’t have any children, and both were now elderly.%vn~
          %u@8Now during his %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@l%i@y order’s timeslot in the rotation schedule, he happened to be %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e performing the priestly duties in the %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y presence of God%u@[%U@D%u@] %u@9(%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d according to the priests’ tradition of rolling dice%u@[%u@b%u@]), having entered into the temple sanctuary %i@i%i@t%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%u@[%U@D%u@] to light the incense; %u@1%u@0and everyone who was in the multitude, a multitude of the folk-people, was outside praying during the hour of the incense lighting ritual. %u@1%u@1So now, an angel sent from the Lord appeared to him standing to the right of the Altar of Incense. %u@1%u@2Looking %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l, Zechariah became disturbed, and fear fell upon him. %u@1%u@3The angel said to him, “Don’t be afraid, Zechariah; you see, your prayer has been taken to heart, and your wife Elizabeth shall bear you a son, and you’ll name him John. %u@1%u@4He’ll be a cause of joy and exultation for you, and many will rejoice at his birth. %u@1%u@5Indeed, he’ll be used mightily by the Lord%u@[%u@c%u@] and won’t drink wine or liquor—absolutely won’t—and he’ll be filled with the Holy Spirit while still in his mother’s womb, %u@1%u@6and many native Israelites will heed%u@[%u@d%u@] the Lord their God. %u@1%u@7The Lord will use him as a herald in a spirit and power the likeness of which Elijah had%u@[%U@E%u@], to soften%u@[%u@e%u@] the hearts of the fathers towards the children, and the skeptics and the disobedient%u@[%u@f%u@] to the sensibility of the ways of the righteous, to bring about a fully-refined people for the Lord%u@[%u@g%u@].” %u@1%u@8Zechariah said to the angel, “Just how will the realization of these things come to me? The fact is, I’m old, and my wife is well-past her prime.” %u@1%u@9The angel replied, “I am %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@-%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l Gabriel: the one who stands in the presence of God. Concerning these things, He sent me to speak to you and deliver the good news. %u@2%u@0See here now—you will remain silent, unable to speak, until the time comes that these things come to pass, as a consequence of you not having believed my words, which will be fulfilled in the course of good time.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@1The people were expecting Zechariah %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@ and were baffled at how long a time he was spending in the temple. %u@2%u@2When he came out, he was unable to speak to them, and they realized that he’d seen a vision while inside the temple. He was gesturing to them, all the while remaining mute. %u@2%u@3When his %i@o%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@’%i@s %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@s%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r priestly service was up, he left to go back home. %u@2%u@4Some time afterwards, his wife Elizabeth conceived, and during the five months that she was keeping herself in seclusion, she kept on saying, %u@2%u@5”%I@A%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ because%i@ the Lord %i@w%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d things to turn out for me in a way that would remove my shame in the eyes of others%u@[%U@F%u@].”%vn~
          %u@2%u@6Now in the sixth month %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@E%i@l%i@i%i@z%i@a%i@b%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@y%u@[%u@h%u@], God sent the angel Gabriel to a city in Galilee called Nazareth, %u@2%u@7to a young, never-married woman%u@[%u@i%u@] engaged to a man named Joseph, who was a direct descendant of David—and the name of this young woman was Mary. %u@2%u@8He entered %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@h%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@l%i@d%i@ right in front of her and said, %vn~
      “Greetings%u@[%u@j%u@], favored-one%u@[%u@k%u@], the Lord %i@b%i@e with you.” %u@2%u@9Now she was deeply disturbed at the remark and was trying to figure out what the nature of the visit would be. %u@3%u@0The angel said to her, “Don’t be afraid, Mary; the fact is, you’ve found favor with God. %u@3%u@1See here now—you’ll conceive and give birth to a son, and you’ll name him ‘Jesus.’ %u@3%u@2He’ll be capable, noteworthy, and accomplished%u@[%u@l%u@] and will be called a son%u@[%u@m%u@] of the Most High. The Lord God will give him the throne of his ancestor David, %u@3%u@3and he’ll reign forever over the Israeli people, and his kingdom will never come to an end.” %vn~
          %u@3%u@4Mary said to the angel, “How will this come about, since I don’t have a husband with whom to be intimate?”%vn~
       %u@3%u@5The angel answered, “The Holy Spirit will come over you, and the miraculous power of the Most High will engulf you. For this reason, the one you’re giving birth to is holy, and he’ll be called a son of God. %u@3%u@6Take a look—in her old age, your relative Elizabeth—even she—is pregnant with a son; the one everyone took for granted was infertile%u@[%u@n%u@]—this is her sixth month of pregnancy. %u@3%u@7You see, with God, all things are possible%u@[%u@o%u@].”%vn~
          %u@3%u@8Mary said, “I present myself as the servant of the Lord. Let things come to pass with regard to me according to your word.” And the angel departed from her.%vn~
          %u@3%u@9During this time, Mary took a trip into the hill country, to a town in Judea. %u@4%u@0She entered Zechariah’s house and was welcomed enthusiastically by Elizabeth. %u@4%u@1It so happened that when Elizabeth heard Mary’s greeting, the baby leaped in her womb; Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit, %u@4%u@2and with a great cry uttered back, “You %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@r among women %i@b%i@e blessed, (%i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@i%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s); and blessed be, (%i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@, %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r),%i@ the produce of your womb. %u@4%u@3How did I get such an honor, that the mother of my Lord would come to %i@v%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@t me? %u@4%u@4In fact—get this—the moment the sound of your greeting entered my ear, the baby I’m carrying leaped in exultation. %u@4%u@5She who believed is blessed, because it will be a realization of those things which have been spoken to her %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ from the Lord.”%vn~
          %u@4%u@6And Mary said,%vn~
%sp~
%u@4%u@7”My life-being%u@[%u@p%u@] extols the Lord%vp~
And my spirit has heaped exultation upon God my Savior%u@[%U@G%u@]%vp~
%u@4%u@8Because He took interest in the abasement of his slave.%vp~
Yes indeed—and—hey—from now on%vp~
All generations will call me blessed%vp~
%u@4%u@9Because he has done great things for me, the Capable One,%vp~
And holy is His name%u@[%U@G%u@],%vp~
%u@5%u@0And His mercy %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%u@[%U@G%u@]%i@ towards those%vp~
Who have a deep reverence%u@[%u@q%u@] for Him.%vp~
For generation upon generation%vp~
%u@5%u@1The One exuding power intervened%vp~
In the affairs of man%u@[%U@G%u@] and did this:%vp~
He%u@[%U@G%u@] routed%u@[%U@G%u@]%u@[%u@r%u@] those who are high-and-mighty%vp~
Where the intention of their heart is concerned%u@[%U@G%u@].%vp~
%u@5%u@2He pulled down rulers from %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ thrones%vp~
And exalted the abased.%vp~
%u@5%u@3From out of good things He filled the hungry up,%vp~
And He punted the rich,%vp~
Sending them away empty-handed.%i@%vp~
%u@5%u@4He took the responsibility of caring for Israel, his child,%vp~
To %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ remember mercy,%vp~
%u@5%u@5In accordance to what he said to our ancestors,%vp~
To Abraham and to his descendants until the end of time.”%vp~
%sp~
          %u@5%u@6Mary remained with her for three months and set out for the return trip back home. %u@5%u@7Now Elizabeth’s due-date arrived, and she gave birth to a son. %u@5%u@8Her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord showered tremendous mercy on her and rejoiced with her joy and congratulated her. %u@5%u@9When the eighth day %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@ came, they went to circumcise the child, and they were thinking of naming him after his father Zechariah. %u@6%u@0His mother spoke up and said,%vn~
      “No—he’ll be named John instead.”%vn~
          %u@6%u@1They told her, “You don’t have any relatives who go by that name.”%vn~
          %u@6%u@2They started gesturing to his father what he might possibly%i@ want to name him. %u@6%u@3He asked for a chalkboard%u@[%u@r%u@] and wrote, “His name will be%u@[%u@s%u@] John.”%vn~
      Everyone was taken back: %u@6%u@4he immediately regained his ability to talk, and he began speaking, uttering praises to God. %u@6%u@5A deep reverence came over all his neighbors, and the whole hill country of Judea kept on talking about all these matters; %u@6%u@6the reports settled %i@d%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ in the heart of everyone who heard them: they were saying, “What will come of this child as a result?” The fact is, God was directing the course of his life.%u@[%u@t%u@]%vn~
          %u@6%u@7Zechariah, his father, was filled with%u@[%u@u%u@] the Holy Spirit and prophesied,%vn~
%si~
%u@6%u@8Blessed %i@i%i@s%i@ the Lord God of Israel,%vp~
Because He showed up and did a spiritual service for His people%vp~
%u@6%u@9And got a horn ready, a horn%vp~
Which signals security and the end to our misery%u@[%u@v%u@],%vp~
Ready to blow, to be a cue for us%vp~
By means of the lineage of David, His son%vp~
%u@7%u@0In accordance to what He spoke%vp~
Through the mouth of the holy people %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@o%vp~
Prophesying about him from the beginning of time:%vp~
%si~
%u@7%u@1”Security and the end to our misery from our enemies%vp~
And from the ability of those who hate us to do us harm:%vp~
%u@7%u@2To perform an act of mercy in the company of our ancestors%vp~
And to remember His holy covenant,%vp~
%u@7%u@3An oath which He swore to our ancestor Abraham:%vp~
%u@7%u@4%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@s%i@e to grant us bold raid-and-rescue %i@o%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@%vp~
To get us out from the clutches%u@[%u@w%u@] of our enemies;%vp~
To be continuously holding %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p services dedicated to Him%vp~
%u@7%u@5In piety, holiness, and correctness%vp~
In His midst for all the days of our lives.”%vp~
%si~
%u@7%u@6Now you, child, will be called a prophet of the Most High%vp~
You see, you’re %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d to be a trailblazer for the Lord%vp~
To prepare the road that he’ll take%vp~
%u@7%u@7To impart to his people%vp~
The comprehension of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ security and of an end to their misery%vp~
By means of the forgiveness of their sins%vp~
%u@7%u@8Through deep, heartfelt mercies from our God,%vp~
By which mercies a sunrise to noon%i@-%i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@p%i@o%i@c%i@h will come visit us,%vp~
%u@7%u@9To shine upon those in darkness,%vp~
Upon those sitting under a death-shadow%u@[%u@x%u@],%vp~
To put us on the path to peace%u@[%u@y%u@].%vp~
%si~
          %u@8%u@0The child grew and grew and became stronger and stronger in spirit, and he stayed out in the wilderness until the time came for his public appearance to the nation of Israel.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@…Lit: %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@l%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@.%i@ This sort of wording is commonplace in the OT.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@r%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@…Lit: %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@t%i@s. Ref. note of Mark 15:24.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n; %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@k%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@o%i@b%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@…Also: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r; %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@u%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@u%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@-%i@r%i@e%i@f%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@q%i@u%i@i%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@d%i@ [%i@f%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@d]%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@s%i@i%i@x%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@E%i@l%i@i%i@z%i@a%i@b%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@y…Could possibly mean,%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@x%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@e%i@a%i@r, which in the Jewish calendar is the month of Elul, which is August or September.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@g%i@,%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@-%i@m%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n…Lit: %i@v%i@i%i@r%i@g%i@i%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%I@G%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s…Lit: %i@j%i@o%i@y. The simple word %i@j%i@o%i@y%i@ is used as a salutation in Gk. and is the same greeting used in Matt 26:49, Mark 15:8, Acts 23:26.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@f%i@a%i@v%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@-%i@o%i@n%i@e…The verb tense insinuates one who has received God’s favor after much deliberation or approval of her conduct, works, and lifestyle.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@c%i@a%i@p%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@e%i@w%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@d…lit: %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@n…ref. note of Mark 15:39%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@‘%i@b%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@’%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@.%i@ The double-negative is a figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@-%i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e…Lit: %i@f%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@c%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@k%i@b%i@o%i@a%i@r%i@d…Lit: %i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@t. Liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@s%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e…Lit: %i@i%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@t%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e…Lit: %I@F%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@u%u@]%i@f%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h…Lit: %i@f%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@v%u@]%i@s%i@e%i@c%i@u%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@y…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@l%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@w%u@]%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@u%i@t%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@…Lit: %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@x%u@]%I@T%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@r%i@k%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@-%i@s%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@o%i@w…Lit: %I@T%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@r%i@k%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h. A figure of speech: the joining of two redundant clauses, and the joining of them with the conjunction %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@.%i@ Also, ref. Matt. 4:16.%fn~
%u@[%u@y%u@]%I@T%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@e…Lit: %I@T%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@e. A biblical idiom.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@e%i@d…In these first few verses, Luke alludes to the fact that many have attempted to create a written record of the life of Jesus but did a mediocre job of it. He’s not referring to the Gnostic Gospels or some other heretical works, but to a few Christians who made early attempts to create what we now know as the Gospels but whose workmanship was a failure. Luke says here that he’ll correctly the problem and write his account accurately. Luke, the man of learning that he was, was versed in the correct method of writing history, the theory of which had been formulated by the first century. This passage gives us valuable insight into the formation of the four Gospels. None of the four were haphazardly written, all four gained the approval of the church leadership, and the “many” that Luke refers to in v.1 were rejected because they didn’t live up the standards set by the four that have been handed down through the ages. The four gospels were sponsored, by the church, approved by the church, and propagated by the church.%fn~
To achieve the self-set goals Luke stated in vv3,4, in addition to fulfilling the requirements for writing proper history, Luke had to have conducted direct, meticulous interviews with the eyewitnesses of what he wrote about. From the content in the first few chapters of his Gospel, he certainly would’ve had to interview Mary mother or Jesus, or perhaps (and this is a stretch) one of Jesus’s siblings, at a minimum, the shepherds who were there at his birth, etc. Conducting these interviews and documenting them would’ve taken a few months, would’ve had to have taken place in Israel, and would’ve had to have taken place in the lifetime of all the witnesses. The timeframe which fits these criteria is Paul’s second and third missionary journeys, in particular his third, which was around A.D. 55. This would’ve been the latest date for the composition of Luke’s Gospel, as beyond that the eyewitnesses of Jesus’s birth would’ve died of old age.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@u%i@s…Lit: %I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %I@E%i@x%i@c%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@y%i@ %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@u%i@s. Luke addresses Theophilus like he’s an aristocrat or that he had authority over him or both. This evidence has led scholars to conjecture that Luke was either a freedman, once a slave to Theophilus, or perhaps still a slave. But Theophilus had assigned him to be an assistant to Paul, donating Luke to Paul’s ministry like someone would donate a car to a charity. This might explain why Luke was the only person still with Paul at the time of his death (2 Tim. 4:11)—he had no choice but to stick with him. In any event, slaves in ancient Rome were often educated, and Luke certainly was. In addition, the name Theophilus means God-friend. We’ll assume that his name’s not a coincidence, that he wasn’t born with the name but changed it or acquired it when he became a Christian. In any event, both his name and the interest he has in the events surrounding Jesus’s life indicate that he devoted his life to his faith.%fn~
It might seem remarkable to us, living in modern times, that a slave or former slave such as Luke could write a great work of theology, humanity, and literature, but Epictetus, the Greek stoic philosopher, was born a slave. Two great books were written by his student-followers: %I@D%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@s and %I@E%i@n%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@d%i@i%i@o%i@n.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e…Lit: %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@A%i@a%i@r%i@o%i@n. The priesthood was a hereditary caste consisting of males who descended from Aaron, brother of Moses, of the tribe of Levi. The priests were not required to marry women from within that caste. Luke goes out of his way to mention the fact that Elizabeth was in the Aaronic lineage even before giving her name. This emphasizes the purity of John the Baptist’s parents’ pedigree, the level of sanctity, consecration, and cleanness, the Old Testament prerequisites for holiness. These John inherited as a result. The extreme degree to which the couple were sanctified to God would only magnify the intensity of the view that God was punishing Zechariah and Elisabeth by not providing them with a son (v. 7), one who would propagate the priesthood on their behalf. As there was no sin that Zechariah and Elisabeth were culpable of, whereby they would’ve received God’s disfavor and reproach, it must’ve been a mystery to the people why God would not give them a son.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ (v. 8)…%i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ (v. 9)%i@…This the first chamber inside the temple edifice, accessible only to priest. In OT times, God’s presence dwelled in the Holy of Holies, the hidden chamber behind the temple sanctuary. To a lesser extent, God’s presence was also in the sanctuary. The duties of the priests included entering the temple sanctuary on a regular basis to replenish the incense, which must burn at all times, and to switch out the showbread.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %I@E%i@l%i@i%i@j%i@a%i@h %i@h%i@a%i@d…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ [%i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@r%i@u%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r]%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@E%i@l%i@i%i@j%i@a%i@h. Coming back to a city after victory on the battlefield, conquering commanders sent out forerunners to the towns they’d pass through to announce their imminent arrival, to stir up the people to gather in a large, enthusiastic crowd when the commander passed through. Also, see note of 1 Cor. 16:6 for %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@ and apply that to %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@r%i@u%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@ here.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%i@s%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@y%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s…As the ancients didn’t have a scientific understanding of medicine, they generally assumed that it a couple couldn’t have a child, somehow it was because of the woman. In Elizabeth’s case, they assumed God despised her, perhaps even that she had sinned. Her experience was much like Job’s.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]In this passage of vv. 47-55, Mary breaks into a poetic discourse, which is comprised of these literary elements:%fn~
v. 47: The two clauses in this verse constitute a figure of speech, one which consists of the repetition of two clauses, both of which in essence express the same thought.%fn~
v. 49: Tacking on %I@A%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ (Lit: %I@A%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e) as a clause instead of as a clause offset by a relative pronoun, i.e. instead of saying %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@C%i@a%i@p%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@.%i@%fn~
v. 49: The omission of the word %i@i%i@s%i@ before %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ gives this more of a poetic ring.%fn~
v. 50: Like in v. 49, the omission of %i@i%i@s%i@ or %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d is poetic.%fn~
v. 51: %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@.%i@ This is a metaphor, a comparison to an army sounding defeating another army, in the same way that %i@s%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ is used in Psalm 68:1, causing the enemy to break ranks and run in a disorderly retreat.%fn~
v. 51: %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@n%i@e%i@ %I@E%i@x%i@u%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@…Lit: %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@u%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@m. The “arm of the Lord” or a variation of this (like in v. 51) is a Heb. idiom used throughout the Old Testament. It refers to God’s ability to intervene in the affairs of mankind, and the strength and finality by which he does so.%fn~
v. 51: Breaking a single thought into two clauses is a figure of speech. In other words, saying, %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@u%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s: %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e…instead of saying, %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@u%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e…%fn~
v. 51: %i@h%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@-%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@h%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@-%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@s. Making %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@s%i@ an appositive of %i@h%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@-%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@y%i@ and tweaking the literal meaning is a figure of speech.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Luke Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1Around that time, an edict from Caesar Augustus was issued to the entire civilized world.%u@ %u@2This edict was a census%u@[%u@a%u@], and this census was the first one issued during the tenure of Quirinius, the ruler of %i@t%i@h%i@e %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ Syria. %u@3Everyone was either coming or going to be registered, each to the city he belonged to. %u@4So Joseph went from the city of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to the city of David, which is called “Bethlehem,” on account of him being of the lineage of and being a descendant of David, %u@5to be registered for the census along with his fiancée Mary, who was expecting. %u@6While they were there, her due-date arrived, %u@7and she gave birth to a son, her firstborn, wrapped him in a blanket, and laid him in a manger, since there wasn’t any room for them in the upstairs floor of the house they were at%u@[%U@A%u@].%vn~
          %u@8Nearby in the same area, there were shepherds working the night shift outdoors, keeping an eye on their sheep. %u@9An angel sent from the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shined all around them, and they became very frightened. %u@1%u@0The angel said to them, “Don’t be afraid, since I’m here, you see, to announce to you something good, a message about the tremendous grace which will be %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n to all the people, %u@1%u@1since this day a savior, who is Christ the Lord, was born in your midst in the city of David. %u@1%u@2This is the way you’ll spot him: you’ll find a baby all wrapped up lying in a manger.” %u@1%u@3And suddenly a multitude of troops%u@[%u@b%u@] from %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ heaven appeared together with the angel praising God, saying %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r,%vn~
%si~
%u@1%u@4Glory to God to the max,%vp~
And peace %i@b%i@e upon the Earth among men of good intent%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@5When the angels departed from them back to heaven, the shepherds began saying to one another, “Let’s go from one end of Bethlehem to the other, right this moment, until we get to look into this situation, this thing that the Lord informed us of.” %u@1%u@6They left in a hurry and discovered it: Mary, Joseph, and the baby lying in the manger. %u@1%u@7While looking %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r, they made known the details of the message spoken to them in regard to this very child. %u@1%u@8Many of those who had heard what was said were amazed at what the shepherds were telling them; %u@1%u@9Mary latched on to all these words while they were being deposited into her heart and collected there. %u@2%u@0The shepherds returned glorifying and praising God for everything they heard about and saw, %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@t just like it had been spoken to them.%vn~
          %u@2%u@1When the eighth day, the day for him to be circumcised, rolled around, they named him “Jesus,” the name given by the angel before he was conceived. %u@2%u@2And when the purification time, the span of time in accordance with the Old Testament%u@[%u@c%u@] statute, had expired, they took him over to Jerusalem to be presented to the Lord, %u@2%u@3just as it’s written in the Old Testament%u@[%u@c%u@], “Every man-child who is a mother’s first delivery shall be designated as set aside for the Lord%u@[%u@d%u@],” %u@2%u@4and to offer up a sacrifice according to the commandment in the Old Testament%u@[%u@c%u@], “a pair of turtledoves or two young doves.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@5Now, you see, there was a man in Jerusalem named Simeon, and this fellow was righteous and devout, awaiting Israel’s consolation%u@[%u@e%u@], and the Holy Spirit was upon him. %u@2%u@6He had been informed in a consultation by the Holy Spirit that he won’t encounter death before seeing Christ the Lord. %u@2%u@7By the Spirit, he went to the temple and to the parents %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e presenting the child Jesus, carrying out the Old Testament%u@[%u@c%u@] ritual concerning him, %u@2%u@8and he himself took him into his arms, gave a blessing to God, and said,%vn~
%si~
%u@2%u@9”At this time You’re releasing Your servant%vp~
From his service in peace, Master,%vp~
%I@J%i@u%i@s%i@t like You said you would,%vp~
%u@3%u@0Because my eyes have seen Your rescue program%u@[%u@f%u@],%vp~
%u@3%u@1That which You’ve prepared in accordance with%vp~
The disposition of the people%u@[%u@g%u@]:%vp~
%u@3%u@2A light resulting in a revelation for the nations%vp~
And resulting in your people Israel’s high regard%u@[%u@h%u@].”%vp~
%si~
          %u@3%u@3His father and mother were surprised by what was spoken about him. %u@3%u@4Simeon pronounced a blessing on them and said to Mary, “You see, this fellow is destined to be %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f the downfall and rejuvenation%u@[%u@i%u@] of many in Israel and to be a portent%u@[%u@j%u@] spoken against them. %u@3%u@5And for you—your very life-being%u@[%u@k%u@] will be gone through with a sword, pierced from end to end, so that from out of many hearts, contemplations and reasonings would be revealed.”%vn~
          %u@3%u@6There was a prophetess %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ Anna, daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Asher. She was up there in years, having married as a young woman, her marriage lasting for seven years, %u@3%u@7and after that being a widow for 84 years, during which time she hadn’t been absent from the temple, fasting and praying day and night in service %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d. %u@3%u@8At the same time %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@n, she %i@w%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r and stood by %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e, all the while professing affirmations in acknowledgement to God and speaking about Him to all those in Jerusalem awaiting the rectification of their dire straits%u@[%u@l%u@].%vn~
          %u@3%u@9When all the rituals prescribed by the Old Testament%u@[%u@c%u@] were concluded, they left for Galilee, to their hometown of Nazareth. %u@4%u@0Now the child kept on growing and kept on getting stronger, while being filled with wisdom, and God’s favor%u@[%u@m%u@] was upon him.%vn~
          %u@4%u@1Year after year, his parents kept going %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k to Jerusalem, to the Passover festival, %u@4%u@2and when he was twelve years old, they went to Jerusalem according to festival custom. %u@4%u@3When the festival, which lasted a few days, was over, as they were departing, the child Jesus remained in Jerusalem, but his parents were unaware. %u@4%u@4Having assumed that he was somewhere in the caravan, they were on the road a few days and began searching for him among their relatives and acquaintances, %u@4%u@5but they weren’t able to find him. They returned to Jerusalem in search of him.%vn~
          %u@4%u@6It so happened that after three days they found him in the temple sitting in the middle of the teachers, listening to them and asking them questions. %u@4%u@7All of those who were listening to him were amazed at his understanding—his ability to put things together—and at his answers. %u@4%u@8%I@U%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ seeing this, %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ were taken aback, and his mother said to him, “Child, why have you treated us this way? Look—your father and I have been pulling our hair out looking for you.” %u@4%u@9He said to them, “Just why now were you searching for me? Didn’t you know that I had to be in the midst of my Father’s interests%u@[%u@n%u@]?” %u@5%u@0They didn’t put all the pieces together from the remark that was spoken to them. %u@5%u@1He left with them and went to Nazareth, and he was staying in submission to their authority. His mother in her heart latched on%u@[%u@o%u@] to all these incidences, one after another; %u@5%u@2and Jesus continued forging ahead%u@[%u@p%u@] in wisdom, stature, and in God’s and in peoples’ favor.%vn~
