%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@o%i@p%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@i%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s (v. 22); %i@l%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d (v. 23); %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w (vv. 24, 27, 39)%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@a%i@w%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@o%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@…Or: %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@ (which uses the more common definitions of the words therein)%i@…Or: %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@m%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@v%i@o%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ [%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@l%i@p%i@e%i@r]%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@ (which is more literal). Note that v. 38 repeats the word %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@;%i@ the two instances of this word are connected.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@g%i@r%i@a%i@m…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@l%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e…lit: %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@h%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@g%i@a%i@r%i@d…Lit: %i@g%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@y%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@j%i@u%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@-%i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@a%i@w%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@s…Lit: %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g %i@r%i@e%i@d%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@f%i@a%i@v%i@o%i@r…Lit: %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@d%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %I@F%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@s…KJV: %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %I@F%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@n…Same word used in v. 19 and has the same meaning%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@w%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@.%i@ This Gk. word describes someone who’s chopping down brush, trees, or other obstacles—even enemy soldiers—in front of oneself, in order to move forward. This is the means by which Jesus grew in wisdom, stature, and the favor of God and of man; the implication is that life was not handed to him on a silver platter.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@…Or:%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@n…Lit: %i@u%i@n%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g. The word refers to the unharnessing of horses, hence the derivation of the meaning %i@i%i@n%i@n%i@.%i@ There is some uncertainty as to what the true meaning of this word is as used by Luke; the word means %i@i%i@n%i@n%i@ but it also means %i@u%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@o%i@m%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@o%i@m%i@,%i@ %i@g%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@o%i@m%i@.%i@ The word is used elsewhere in the NT (Mark 14:14; Luke 22:11) to refer to the upper room, where the Last Supper was held, which is assumed to be the same upper room as was occupied on the day of Pentecost. Some claim that this is an upper room of a house. Houses in those days were split-level, and often the downstairs was used to house the animals. The upper room was the main domicile. This could mean that Mary and Joseph were staying at the lower level of a friend or a distant relative’s house, and “there wasn’t any room for them in the inn” simply means that the upstairs was already filled. This is more plausible than %i@i%i@n%i@n.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Luke Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1In the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, while Pontius Pilate was governor of Judea, and Herod the ruler%u@[%u@a%u@] in Galilee (his brother Philip, though, was the ruler%u@[%u@a%u@] of the regions Iturea and Traconitis, and Lysanias the ruler%u@[%u@a%u@] of Abiline), %u@2during the tenure of the high priests Annas and Caiaphas, the word of the Lord (%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e) came%u@[%U@A%u@] to John son of Zechariah while in the countryside%u@[%u@b%u@]%u@[%u@c%u@]. %u@3He went into all the surrounding regions of the Jordan preaching a baptism—a water immersion-type of initiation ceremony—signifying a total commitment to a change in conduct to live the right way %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g into %i@a forgiveness of sins.%u@[%u@d%u@], %u@4as it’s been written in the Book of Isaiah, the prophet:%vn~
%sp~
The sound of shouting in the countryside:%vp~
“Block off the road the Lord will take!%vp~
Barricade the streets he’ll be on!” %vp~
%u@5All valleys will be filled in%vp~
And all hills will be leveled;%vp~
All the windy roads will get straightened out%vp~
And all the rough roads will be resurfaced%u@[%U@B%u@];%vp~
%u@6Every living being will witness God’s rescue program%u@[%u@e%u@].”%vp~
%si~
          %u@7Accordingly, he went on and on saying to the crowd coming out to be baptized by him, “You offspring of vipers, who convinced you to run for your lives because of the coming wrath? %u@8In line with this, produce the corresponding actions on par with a change for the better%u@[%u@f%u@]—and don’t start in %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@l%i@k%i@, saying among yourselves, ‘%I@W%i@e%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e we’re descendants of Abraham.%u@[%u@g%u@]’ Let me tell you what—the fact is, God can create from scratch and establish descendants for Abraham from out of these stones%u@[%U@C%u@]. %u@9The axe is already lying next to the tree trunk %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n; in line with this, all trees not producing good fruit will be hacked out and cast into a fire.” %u@1%u@0The crowd %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n asked him,%vn~
      “How then are we supposed to conduct our lives?”%vn~
          %u@1%u@1He replied to them by saying, “Whoever has two shirts%u@[%u@h%u@], give one to him who doesn’t have any, and the one who has food do the same.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Tax collectors%u@[%U@D%u@] also came to be baptized and said, “Teacher, how are we supposed to conduct our lives?”%vn~
          %u@1%u@3He said, “Don’t take anything more than what the quotas and tax rates mandate.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@4Soldiers also were questioning him, “How are we too supposed to act?”, and he said to them,%vn~
      “Don’t shake people down for money or take bribes from racketeers, and be content with your wages.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@5While the people were in a state of anticipation, everybody was thinking the circumstances concerning John over in their heart, going back and forth, trying to decide whether he was the Messiah—the Christ—or not. %u@1%u@6John declared to them all, “Me—I baptize in water. But one’s coming who’s greater than me, one whom I’m not worthy enough to carry around by the soles of his shoes.%u@[%u@i%u@] He, for his part, will baptize you in a fiery manifestation of the Holy Spirit.%u@[%u@i%u@] %u@1%u@7One who, with the winnowing fork in his hand, will clear everything off his threshing floor and will gather the wheat into his silo, but will burn up the chaff with a fire that will never be put out.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@8So then, at many times and in many different ways exhorting, instructing, appealing to, and pleading with the people, again and again he made the good news known. %u@1%u@9But now, for the ruler Herod, being called out by him in regard to his brother’s wife Herodias and in regard to all the wickedness that he, Herod, did, %u@2%u@0this was the last straw%u@[%u@j%u@], and he locked him up in jail.%vn~
          %u@2%u@1In the course of baptizing all the people, including Jesus, while he was being baptized and was praying, the sky opened up, %u@2%u@2the Holy Spirit came down in bodily form upon him, appearing like a dove%u@[%u@k%u@], and out of the sky a voice said, “You are my Beloved Son, with whom I’m pleased.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3Now Jesus himself was around thirty years old, considered to be the son of Joseph, who’s the son of Heli, %u@2%u@4the son of Matthat, of Levi, of Melki, of Jannai, of Joseph, %u@2%u@5of Mattathias, of Amos, of Nahum, of Esli, of Naggai, %u@2%u@6of Maath, of Mattathias, of Semein, of Josek, of Joda, %u@2%u@7of Joanan, of Rhesa, of Zerubbabel, of Shelatiel, of Neri, %u@2%u@8of Melki, of Addi, of Cosam, of Elmadam, of Er, %u@2%u@9of Joshua, or Eliezer, of Jorim, of Matthat, of Levi, %u@3%u@0of Simeon, of Judah, of Joseph, of Jonam, of Eliakim, %u@3%u@1of Melea, of Menna, of Mattatha, of Nathan, of David, %u@3%u@2of Jesse, of Obed, of Boaz, of Salmon, of Nahshon, %u@3%u@3of Amminadab, of Ram, of Hezron, of Perez, of Judah, %u@3%u@4of Jacob, of Isaac, of Abraham, of Terah, of Nahor, %u@3%u@5of Serug, of Reu, of Peleg, of Eber, of Shelah, %u@3%u@6of Cainan, of Arphaxad, of Shem, of Noah, of Lamech, %u@3%u@7of Methuselah, of Enoch, of Jared, of Mahalalel, of Kenan, %u@3%u@8of Enosh, of Seth, of Adam, of God.%vn~

%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@r%i@u%i@l%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@t%i@e%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@r%i@c%i@h (a four-part governorship)%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]The passage of vv. 1,2 are worded like something out of the OT%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@s…Ref. note of Mark 1:4%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@g%i@r%i@a%i@m…Lit: %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@l%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d. The phrase %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@h%i@ is an idiom used throughout the Bible.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@u%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%I@W%i@e%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@A%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@h%i@a%i@m…Lit: %I@W%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@—%I@A%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@h%i@a%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@u%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@…Ref. notes of Matt. 3:11%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@w…Lit: %i@a%i@d%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@v%i@e…Ref. note of Mark 1:10%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@(%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@)%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e…This introductory phrase appears throughout the OT, appearing as the lead-in to a prophecy.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@a%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@…The quotation from Isaiah up to this point is a series of metaphors, the things described compared to people. The valleys are those who are in despair; the hills are those who are haughty; the windy roads are those who are confused or are in error; the rough roads are those encumbered by sin.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %I@A%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s…In the mindset of some of the religious Jews of the time, God had chosen the descendants of Abraham to be his people, and His election was final. Jesus is saying that that is not the case; if a people whom God has chosen persist in disobeying him, God will oust them and replace them. %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s in this verse symbolize the random, unknown, and insignificant mass of humanity throughout the world. In this light, Jesus is insinuating that God will replace the disobedient Jews with obedient Gentiles, should the Jews persist in their disobedience.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@t%i@a%i@x%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@…In the Gospels, tax collectors, since they were involved in so much fraud, are generally assumed to be sinners. The expression %i@t%i@a%i@x%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ is found in various places in the Gospels.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Luke Chapter 4%hb~
          %u@1Now Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, withdrew from the Jordan %i@r%i@e%i@g%i@i%i@o%i@n and proceeded to be led by the Spirit in the wilderness%u@[%U@A%u@], %u@2while for forty days the devil kept trying to break him using trials and temptations. He wasn’t eating anything during those days, and as %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e was drawing to its conclusion, he was famished. %u@3So the devil said to him, “If you enjoy the status of Son of God, speak to this rock here so that it becomes bread.” %u@4Jesus answered back to him, %r@“%R@I%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%R@I%r@@%R@S%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@.%r@’%r@” %u@5He took him up and showed him in a brief moment all the kingdoms of the inhabited world, %u@6and the devil said to him, “I will give you the authority over all of these and all the wonderful things in them%u@[%u@a%u@], since it was granted to me and to whomever I might desire to give it. %u@7So now, if you pay homage to me in obeisance, all of this will be yours.” %u@8Jesus’s reply to him was, %r@“%R@I%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%R@I%r@@%R@S%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@,%r@”%r@%vn~
%r@%si~
%r@“%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@m%r@a%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@%vp~
%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %R@H%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@i%r@t%r@u%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@s%r@h%r@i%r@p%r@”%r@%vp~
%si~
%u@9He led him to Jerusalem and stood him on top of the battlements of the temple roof and said to him, “If you enjoy the status of Son of God, jump down from here; %u@1%u@0you see, it’s been written %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@S%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@p%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@e,”%nn~
%si~
“Concerning you, His angels are commanded%vp~
To keep a close eye on you and protect you%vp~
%si~
%u@1%u@1”…and, you see,”%nn~
%si~
“They’ll snatch you out of the way with their bare%i@ hands%u@[%u@b%u@]%vp~
To prevent your foot from impacting a stone”%vp~
%si~
%u@1%u@2And Jesus’s reply to him was, %r@“%R@I%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@ %R@H%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@l%r@s%r@.%r@’%r@”%r@ %u@1%u@3And the devil, having run through his list of temptations%u@[%u@d%u@], departed from him for the time being.%nn~
          %u@1%u@4Jesus returned to Galilee in the miracle-working power of the Spirit. His renown spread throughout the surrounding area. %u@1%u@5He began to go about teaching in their synagogues, while being hailed and applauded%u@[%u@e%u@] by many.%vn~
          %u@1%u@6He went to Nazareth, where he was raised, and introduced himself to those in the synagogue and attended their meeting as he was in the habit of doing on days which were Sabbaths. He stood up %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@w%i@a%i@r%i@d to do a reading.%u@[%U@B%u@] %u@1%u@7A scroll was handed to him, the Book of Isaiah (the prophet), and he opened the book and found the place where it’s written,%vn~
%si~
%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@%vp~
%r@%%R@I%r@@%R@A%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%R@I%r@@%R@H%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@’%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@m%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@%vp~
%R@H%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@c%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@s%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@%vp~
%R@O%r@f%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@v%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@r%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@C%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@%vp~
%R@T%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@i%r@t%r@u%r@t%r@e%r@.%r@%vp~
%R@H%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@c%r@l%r@a%r@i%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@%vp~
%R@T%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@p%r@t%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@l%r@e%r@a%r@s%r@e%r@%vp~
%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@o%r@r%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@;%r@%vp~
%R@T%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@t%r@r%r@o%r@d%r@d%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@v%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@D%r@i%r@s%r@c%r@h%r@a%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@a%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@l%r@e%r@a%r@s%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@m%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%vp~

%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@T%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@c%r@l%r@a%r@i%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@%vp~

%si~
%u@2%u@0Once he rolled the scroll back up, packed it way, and gave it to the attendant, he seated himself %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e; everyone in the synagogue had their eyes fixed on him. %u@2%u@1He proceeded to speak, telling them that, this day, their own ears have witnessed the fulfillment of this very Scripture. %u@2%u@2Everyone was caught up in taking note of him and in being amazed at the eloquence of what flowed out of his mouth, and were saying, “Isn’t this guy Joseph’s son?”—%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@c%i@t. %u@2%u@3He said to them, %r@“%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@P%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@E%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@—%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@C%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@r%r@n%r@a%r@u%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@f%r@o%r@l%r@k%r@.%r@’%r@”%r@ %u@2%u@4%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@n he said, %r@“%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@:%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@l%r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@f%r@o%r@l%r@k%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@o%r@t%r@-%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@r%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@—%r@b%r@a%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@E%r@l%r@i%r@j%r@a%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@d%r@o%r@w%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@r%r@a%r@e%r@l%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@v%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@g%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@r%r@e%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@l%r@f%r@ %r@y%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@h%r@u%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@E%r@l%r@i%r@j%r@a%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@c%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@m%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@Z%r@a%r@r%r@e%r@p%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@S%r@i%r@d%r@o%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@d%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@r%r@a%r@e%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@ %R@E%r@l%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@a%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@r%r@o%r@s%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@r%r@g%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@c%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@y%r@r%r@i%r@a%r@n%r@ %R@N%r@a%r@a%r@m%r@a%r@n%r@.%r@”%nn~
          %u@2%u@8Hearing this, everyone in the synagogue was filled with rage, %u@2%u@9and they rose to their feet, kicked him out of the city, and forced him along until they got to the crest of the large hill%u@[%u@f%u@] upon which their city had been built, in order to toss him down over the edge. %u@3%u@0He, though, having wriggled his way out of their clutches%u@[%U@F%u@], went his way.%vn~
          %u@3%u@1He went over to Capernaum, a city in Galilee, and was teaching them on the Sabbaths. %u@3%u@2They were time and again amazed at his instruction, since his message was captivating and commanding. %u@3%u@3Now, there was a man in the synagogue who had a vile-and-disgusting, assigned-to-harass%u@[%U@G%u@]%u@ spirit, and he yelled out in a loud voice, %u@3%u@4“Hey! We have no beef with you%u@[%u@g%u@], Jesus of Nazareth! Have you come to annihilate us? I know who you are—you’re God’s Holy One!” %u@3%u@5Jesus shut him down saying, %r@“%R@S%r@h%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@!%r@” In front of everyone, the demon slammed him to the ground and came out of him, never to harm him again. %u@3%u@6An uproar came upon everyone, and they started saying to each other, “What system of belief%u@[%u@h%u@]%u@ this is, that he commands the vile-and-disgusting spirits in an authoritative and powerful manner, and they depart.” %u@3%u@7News concerning him propagated throughout the entire surrounding area.%vn~
          %u@3%u@8He got up from the synagogue and went to Simon’s (%I@P%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@’%i@s%u@[%U@H%u@]) house. Simon’s mother-in-law was running a high fever, and they asked %i@i%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g for her. %u@3%u@9He stood over her, rebuked the fever, and it left her. Immediately she got up and started waiting on them. %u@4%u@0While the sun was waning, they brought him everyone and anyone at all who was unwell%u@[%u@i%u@] with various diseases. He kept healing each one of them when he laid his hands on them. %u@4%u@1Demons also were coming out of many, and on their way out were crying out, “You are the Son of God!” He was sternly taking charge over them, forbidding them to speak, since they knew that he was the Christ, the Messiah.%vn~
          %u@4%u@2Now when the day had wound down, he left and went to a place which was uninhabited. The crowd proceeded to look for him and came over to where he was at and kept trying to detain him so that he wouldn’t leave them. %u@4%u@3He told them that he had to deliver the good news of God’s involvement with mankind (God’s kingdom) to the other cities too, since this was the reason he had been sent. %u@4%u@4And he kept preaching %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@ in the Judean synagogues.%vn~
%sf~

%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@r%i@u%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s…Lit: %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@u%i@d%i@e%i@d %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n. A figure of speech.%fn~

%u@[%u@g%u@]%I@W%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@f%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@e?…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@? Ref. note of Matt. 8:29.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@s%i@y%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@f%i@…Also: %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@;%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@c%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@;%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@;%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@g%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@u%i@n%i@w%i@e%i@l%i@l…Lit: %i@w%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@l%i@y.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s…Also: %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e. The same word is translated %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@ in prior verses. The Judean wilderness is harsh, uninhabitable, and rocky.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@H%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@w%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d. Unlike churches today, synagogues back then allowed ordinary Israelites to read from the OT and deliver a homily on what they read. Also, ref. note of Acts 19:8.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@v%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@e. At various times in the OT, God conferred special favor and granted special abilities to select individuals for specific purposes, usually to the benefit of Israel. This favor and these abilities were conferred in a ceremony where a priest or the like would cover (%i@a%i@n%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t) in oil the one upon whom the favor and abilities were conferred, while making a pronouncement to that effect. An example of this can be found in 1 Sam. 16:12–13.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%I@A%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@-%i@c%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d…Lit: %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d. A “year of the Lord” refers to the OT Year of Jubilee, which the Law of Moses commands that Israel hold once every fifty years. There were laws specific to a Jubilee year, and these laws involved things like the freeing of slaves and the cancellation of debts. In the same way, this %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ is a Jubilee-like occasion, as described in the previous verses, where the captives are set free, the blind regain their sight, the downtrodden are released.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@p%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@p…Lit: %i@d%i@o%i@c%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f…Some liberties taken. An idiom assumed to be a common expression of the time.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%I@H%i@e%i@,%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@,%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@g%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@u%i@t%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@s…Lit: %I@B%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@,%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@d%i@s%i@t. Some indications in the GT here hint that Jesus didn’t conjure up a miracle that would placate the angry mob, thus allowing him to walk away, but that’s not what happened. He had to exercise a measure of force and recalcitrance on his part to escape their clutches. The evidence in the GT is that, first, Luke uses an explicit personal pronoun for %i@h%i@e, which has connotations apart from the face-value meaning of the word %i@h%i@e%i@.%i@ Luke is telling us something by choosing this pronoun; he’s telling us that Jesus himself was taking some action when leaving the mob. Second, Luke chooses the verb %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ rather than %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f, the latter form being expected had no force been involved. %I@G%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h emphasizes the opposition he faced, while %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f would have deemphasized that opposition.%fn~
Not only this, but the phrase used in v. 30 %i@d%i@i%i@a%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@o%i@u%i@ [%i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@d%i@s%i@t, διὰ μέσου, (διὰ /Strong’s 1223),( μέσου/Strong’s 3319)] is almost identical in wording to the Gk. idiom %i@e%i@k%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@o%i@u%i@ [%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@d%i@s%i@t%i@,%i@ ἐκ μέσου) (ἐκ /Strong’s 1537), (μέσου/Strong’s 3319)], and should be considered to be another idiom of similar or same meaning. %I@E%i@k%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@o%i@u (ref. 2 Thess. 2:7, Matt. 13:49; Acts 17:33; Acts 23:10; 1 Cor. 5:2; 2 Cor. 6:17; Col 2:14) “is a Greek idiom for being out of the way, and always implies decisive action, either of the person’s own will or of force on the part of others,” %I@F%i@i%i@g%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@e%i@e%i@c%i@h%i@ %I@U%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@B%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@e, E.W. Bullinger, p. 838.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@-%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@d%i@i%i@s%i@g%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@-%i@t%i@o%i@-%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t…Lit: %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@c %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n. In the GT, the noun %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ is listed first followed by the adjectives%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n. The adjective %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@ comes from the root verb %i@d%i@a%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@o%i@ (δαιμονάω/no Strong’s number)%i@,%i@ which has the primary meaning %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@j%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@.%i@ %I@D%i@a%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@o is rooted in Greek mythology, where a person lost favor with one of the gods, and that god sent a lesser god or some other supernatural creature to torment said person. Also related to %i@d%i@a%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@o%i@ is the Gk. verb %i@d%i@a%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@z%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@i%i@ (δαιμονίζομαι/Strong’s 1139)%i@,%i@ which has a primary definition %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@.%i@ In the case of %i@d%i@a%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@z%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@i%i@,%i@ it’s as though a god of mythology choose to use his or her supernatural power against a mortal being, and the person, being mortal, is trapped in the bonds of a superior, supernatural being, and therefore locked into the fate dictated by the god. Related to the use of these two words, Paul’s thorn in the flesh (2 Cor. 12:6–7) is actually that: a %i@d%i@a%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ (δαιμόνιον/Strong’s 1140): a spirit assigned to him. Therefore, in a biblical context, the word %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@ means %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e. The other adjective, the word %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@,%i@ is used throughout the OT for things forbidden by the Law of Moses to be touched, handled, things which are impure, unholy, and must be altogether shunned. These three words, %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@,%i@ construct a different meaning to what was tormenting this man in the synagogue. First, %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ means that it wasn’t a natural creature but a supernatural one. Second, %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@ means that the evil spirit is given a specific assignment to torment a person. Third, %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ means that the spirit is all-around disgusting in its evil, irredeemably so.%fn~
%u@[%U@H%u@]%I@S%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@(%I@P%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@)…The GT does not say %I@P%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@.%i@ In the NT, Peter has multiple names, the name %I@P%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ added to clarify what might otherwise be confusing.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Luke Chapter 5%hb~
          %u@1Now %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y there happened to be a crowd situated in close proximity to him, listening to the word of God; he, though, had taken a place standing on the shoreline of the lake, Lake Gennesaret. %u@2He saw two boats docked on the lake’s shore. Now the fishermen who manned these boats had disembarked and were scrubbing their fishing nets. %u@3But one of them—and this was Simon—was %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ onboard one of the boats. He asked him to cast the boat out a bit from the shore, and he, having taken a seat %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@a%i@t, began to teach the crowd from the boat. %u@4Now as he wrapped up his talk, he said to Simon,%vn~
       %r@“%R@T%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@o%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@w%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@u%r@l%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@5Simon answered back, “We’ve been at it all night working and haven’t gotten a thing; but since you said so, I’ll cast the nets.”%vn~
          %u@6And when they’d done this, they entrapped a huge swarm of fish, to the point where it was beginning to break their nets. %u@7They motioned to their partners in the other boat to come help%i@ haul the fish in, and they came and filled both boats to their sinking thresholds. %u@8Simon Peter, having witnessed this, fell to his knees before Jesus saying, “Leave me, sir, since I’m a sinful man.” %u@9You see, those surrounding him and all those who were a part of his company were amazed at the take of fish being hauled in. %u@1%u@0In the same way, so were the sons of Zebedee, James and John, Simon’s coworkers. Jesus said to Simon, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@f%r@r%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@:%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@A%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@” %u@1%u@1And after the boats returned to shore, they all left and became his followers.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2While he happened to %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@l be in one of the boats, a man with a full-blown case of leprosy appeared out of nowhere. Seeing Jesus, he fell on his face and begged him, “Sir, should you desire to do so, you can purge %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@s%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m me.” %u@1%u@3He stretched out his hand and touched him saying, %r@“%R@I%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@i%r@r%r@e%r@:%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@r%r@g%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@”%r@ Immediately, the leprosy departed from him. %u@1%u@4He, though, told him sternly and in no uncertain terms to not tell anyone, but instead to go and show himself to the priest and to bring him that which the Old Testament%u@[%u@a%u@] commanded, in order that the evidence %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@f%i@i%i@r%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@e%u@[%u@b%u@].%vn~
          %u@1%u@5But to an even greater extent, information concerning him spread through and throughout, and huge crowds kept gathering together to listen and to be treated and healed of everything that was dragging them down, physically%u@[%u@c%u@]. %u@1%u@6As far as his own self was concerned, he kept stealing away to various places out in the countryside, alone, praying continually.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7He happened to be teaching one day, and in attendance, paying attention, were Pharisees and instructors%u@[%u@d%u@] in the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s, who had come from all of the towns of Galilee, Judea, and Jerusalem. There was a supernatural power of the Lord %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t for him to perform healing%i@.%i@ %u@1%u@8Just like that, %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f men showed up carrying a person who was paralyzed on a cot, and they were trying to bring him in and place him in front him, %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. %u@1%u@9Since they weren’t able to find any way to bring him in on account of the crowd, they climbed up and got on the rooftop patio, and they lowered him down through the roof itself and put him together with his cot right smack in front of Jesus. %u@2%u@0Seeing their faith, he said, %r@“%R@F%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@2%u@1The designated teachers and the Pharisees proceeded to mull this over,%vn~
      “%I@J%i@u%i@s%i@t who is this guy, who speaks blasphemies? Who, except for God alone, has the ability to forgive sins?”%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Now Jesus, aware of what they’d been mulling over, responded to them by saying, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@s%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@s%r@i%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@’%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@l%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@’%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@m%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %R@P%r@l%r@a%r@n%r@e%r@t%r@ %R@E%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@…%r@“%r@ He addressed the paralytic, %r@“%r@…%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@:%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@2%u@5Immediately and in front of everyone, he got up from that which he’d been %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r lying upon and left for home, glorifying God. %u@2%u@6Everyone became ecstatic%u@[%u@f%u@] and began to glorify God, and they were filled with deep reverence, saying, “We witnessed an incredible miracle.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@7After this he departed. He saw a tax collector named Levi sitting at the tax booth, and he said to him, %r@“%R@B%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@2%u@8He left everything behind, got up, and became one of his followers. %u@2%u@9Levi threw a huge party%u@[%u@g%u@] for him at his house. A large crowd of tax collectors was there and others were there with them seated around the table%u@[%u@h%u@]. %u@3%u@0The Pharisees and their designated teachers%u@[%u@i%u@]%u@[%U@B%u@] started to grumble to his disciples, “Why do you live it up%u@[%u@j%u@] with the tax collectors and sinners?” %u@3%u@1Jesus replied to them, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@l%r@t%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@c%r@t%r@o%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@I%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@m%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@f%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@r%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@m%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@n%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@f%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@.%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@k%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@3%u@3His disciples said to him, “John fasts day and night, and so do the Pharisees, but your clique%u@[%u@l%u@] parties%u@[%u@j%u@].” %u@3%u@4Jesus said, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@m%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@g%r@a%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@3%u@6He then proceeded to tell them an analogy. %r@“%R@N%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@u%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@j%r@a%r@c%r@k%r@e%r@t%r@.%r@ %R@S%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@s%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@m%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@.%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@b%r@o%r@d%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@h%r@l%r@y%r@-%r@s%r@q%r@u%r@e%r@e%r@z%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@.%r@ %R@S%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %u@[%u@i%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %I@S%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@p…Lit: %i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@.%i@ An idiom.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%I@I%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@m%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@m%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d…Lit: %I@I%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e. Mixing up the word order, namely stating, %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@,%i@ instead of, %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@,%i@ is a figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@i%i@q%i@u%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@g%i@r%i@o%i@o%i@m%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@o%i@m%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e…Lit: the single Gk. word %i@z%i@ō%i@g%i@r%i@e%i@ō%i@ (ζωγρέω/Strong’s 2221).%i@ This refers to capturing prisoners of war in combat. In this passage, the fish were hauled in alive and not dead, and Jesus is making an analogy to this. In the same way, people who receive word of God are “captured alive” in a sense; once captured they continue to live. They are like prisoners of war in that their life changes: they are interned, they work in captivity, but are also cared for in captivity. Those who do the capturing must make provide for those captured; this is what Jesus is also hinting at—not only will Peter capture men, but he’ll have to have some sort of plan for them after they’re captured: a plan of discipleship.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: (the same). It’s unclear what exactly %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ means in this verse, but it seems to indicate that the Pharisees were subordinate to the Scribes, or at least held them in high esteem.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@P%i@l%i@u%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@w%i@;%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@‘%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@u%i@f%i@f%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@.%i@’%i@”…A few of the principal manuscripts have omitted v. 39, and one might speculate that this was done because the verse is awkward and enigmatic. Verse 39 describes a person who, while in the act of drinking the older wine, claims that he prefers the older to the newer, without giving due consideration to the new. While drinking the old, his heightened awareness of its subtle, unique flavor causes him to lose any objectivity to the different qualities that the new will possess. His fondness for the wine at the moment produces a reaction which rejects any substitute—even to his detriment, as he may thoroughly enjoy the new wine also, were he to just give it a chance.%fn~
And it reminds me of an old company in the landscape of corporate America which has an excellent product—be it an aircraft, a soft drink, what have you—and management in their hubris (or under pressure from the stockholders) thinks they can tinker with it and either to improve it or to shave a few pennies off its cost. But the old product is better. Or, don’t you miss the way they built such-and-such a few decades ago?—You have to pay top dollar on the used market to get one, because they’re not made anymore.%fn~
These analogies are relevant to this passage. There were movements of God going on at the time, one of austerity (John the Baptist) and one of celebration (Jesus). Both are very different from one another. When one is caught up in the one, he becomes so enthralled with it that he will not see the value in the other. Jesus says that both are necessary and that there’s a time and place for both. Another application is that the old-timers had a more powerful presence of the Holy Spirit in their services than we do today.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Luke Chapter 6%hb~
          %u@1He happened to be going through a grain field on the Sabbath, and his disciples were plucking off the heads of the stalks and eating them, stripping them of their grain with their hands. %u@2Some of the Pharisees said, “Why are you doing what’s forbidden on the Sabbath?” %u@3Jesus shot back, %r@“%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@D%r@a%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@r%r@y%r@—%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@—%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@—%r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@b%r@o%r@d%r@y%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@c%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@—%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@w%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@?%r@”%r@ %u@5He proceeded to tell them, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@6On another Sabbath, he introduced himself to those in the synagogue and was teaching there. There was a man there whose right hand was all shriveled up.%u@[%u@c%u@] %u@7The designated teachers%u@[%u@d%u@] and the Pharisees were keeping a close eye on him, to see if he would heal on the Sabbath, so they’d be able to find some %i@v%i@i%i@o%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s to accuse him of %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e. %u@8He, though, knew what they were mulling over on the inside and what their intentions were, so he said to the man with the shriveled-up hand, %r@“%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@”%r@ He got up and stood %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o. %u@9Jesus said to them, %r@“%R@Q%r@u%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@:%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@g%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@g%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%R@I%r@@%R@L%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@w%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%R@I%r@@%R@M%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@f%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@n%r@i%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@?%r@”%r@ %u@1%u@0He looked around at everyone and said to him, %r@“%R@S%r@t%r@r%r@e%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@.%r@”%r@ He did, and his hand was restored to its original form. %u@1%u@1They, though, had lost their wits filled with rage and began to talk things over with one another, about what they would do to Jesus %i@i%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2One day back then, he withdrew to a mountain to pray and was praying continuously to God all night long. %u@1%u@3When daylight came, he called his disciples to gather around, and chose twelve from among them, which twelve are also called “missionaries%u@[%u@f%u@]”: %u@1%u@4Simon, who was renamed Peter, his brother Andrew, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew, %u@1%u@5Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alpheus, Simon the insurrectionist, %u@1%u@6Judas son of James, and Judas Iscariot, the one who became a traitor.%u@[%U@A%u@]%vn~
          %u@1%u@7He descended with them and stopped when the ground leveled off, and %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e %i@w%i@a%i@s %i@g%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ a large crowd of his disciples, and a great many of the people were from all over Judea, Jerusalem, and Tyre and Sidon, which are on the coast. %u@1%u@8They came to listen to what he had to say and to be healed from their diseases. Those tormented by vile, disgusting%u@[%u@g%u@] spirits were being treated, one after another, %u@1%u@9and all the while the entire crowd sought to be touched by him, since the supernatural power that accompanied him kept on issuing out %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m and healing everyone.%vn~
          %u@2%u@0He, for his part, directed his attention to%u@[%u@h%u@] his disciples and proceeded to say,%vn~
%si~
%r@“%R@B%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@o%r@r%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@S%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@(%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@)%r@.%r@%vp~
%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%R@B%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@,%r@%vp~
      %R@S%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@%vn~
%R@B%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@S%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@.%r@%vp~
%r@%si~
          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@”%R@B%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@o%r@s%r@t%r@r%r@a%r@c%r@i%r@z%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@f%r@u%r@l%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@a%r@p%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@o%r@r%r@m%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~

%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d…This is what we call the %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@.%i@ Ref. note of Mark 2:26%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p…Lit: %I@A%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p. The literal wording of the GT is a figure of speech. The figure of speech is breaking the two connected thoughts into two loosely connected clauses separated by the conjunction %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@.%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %I@S%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@d%i@s%i@t%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]”%i@m%i@i%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@s”…Lit: %i@a%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@.%i@ Translated means %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@. J.B. Phillip’s translation translates apostle as %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@r%i@.%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@g%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@d%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o…Lit: %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@y%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o. Lift up the eyes or is an expression used throughout the Bible. It means to stop focusing narrowly on one thing or one task and look at things more broadly, whether to look at matters in a broader perspective, or (in this case) consider all the people and not just a few.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@c%i@h%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@g%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r…Also: %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@k%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@u%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@—%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@—%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@u%i@r%i@b%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@t…Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@s…Lit: %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@o%i@t%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@p%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@t…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@p%i@u%i@t…%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@c%i@k%i@e%i@t…Lit: %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e…%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@s%i@o%i@m. %I@B%i@o%i@s%i@o%i@m in this context refers to the fold of clothing near your body where cash and other items are carried. “Giving to your bosom” is a figure of speech called a %i@m%i@e%i@t%i@o%i@n%i@y%i@m%i@y; the items will actually be given to you, not given to your bosom.%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@b%i@u%i@d%i@d%i@y%i@’%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@g%i@e…Or: %i@t%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@’%i@s…Or: his%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@’%I@B%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@,%i@ %I@B%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@!’…Or, ‘%I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@,%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@!’…Also: ‘%I@M%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@!’. Using the word %I@B%i@o%i@s%i@s over %I@M%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r or %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d, because Jesus is talking about a servant or slave replying to his employer or master.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@…The twelve apostles are listed here in order of their importance, from greatest to least, with a couple of exceptions. Andrew is listed after Peter because he’s his brother; James is listed before John because he’s his older brother, but John was actually the more important of the two. Judas Iscariot takes last place in the list. Bartholomew is the same as Nathanael . %I@S%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@s%i@t in the GT reads %I@S%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@Z%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@o%i@t, as the Zealots were insurrectionists.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@l%i@a%i@p%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@—%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@o…Ref. note of Matt. 5:39%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@d%i@r%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s…%i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f…Lit: %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e…%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@m%i@n. To begin to understand what Jesus means by judging and condemning, one should first learn from other Scriptures what it is not. It is not taking no account of what others do (one example: “Know them which labor among you,” 1 Thess. 5:12). In the NT, if someone who claimed to be a Christian conducted himself in an immoral manner, this person was to be treated like an infidel. But ascertaining such behavior is not judging. Judging is drawing conclusions, based on a person’s history, concluding what their fate or destiny must be. Condemning a person is determining that a person who has guilt due to sin will never be able to escape it, that part or all of their life is irredeemable—Even though it may in fact be irredeemable. To judge someone is to weigh them by their motives and not by their actions. To condemn someone is to assign them consequences. Concerning judging, ref. note of Matt. 7:1 also.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Luke Chapter 7%hb~
          %u@1Since he finished going through all of his material with those listening—a bunch of ordinary folk%u@[%u@a%u@]—he entered Capernaum. %u@2Now there was this centurion’s servant, whom the centurion%u@[%U@A%u@] held in high esteem, who was sick and about to pass away. %u@3Having heard about Jesus, he sent distinguished, respected Jewish citizens to him, asking him if he would come and resuscitate his servant. %u@4Approaching Jesus, they asked him—begged him—to hurry up, saying that this particular individual is worth him going out of his way to help, %u@5since he loves and values our people, and that he single-handedly built us a synagogue. %u@6So Jesus proceeded to go with them.%vn~
      They had already made it to where they were not too far from his house, when the centurion sent some of his close friends telling him, “Sir, don’t put yourself out; you see, it’s not appropriate for you to set foot in my house for a visit%u@[%u@b%u@], %u@7seeing that I’m not considered worthy of you associating with me%u@[%u@c%u@]. Instead, just say the word and have my servant receive healing%u@[%U@B%u@]. %u@8You see, I too am a man who’s under chain-of-command-structured authority%u@[%u@d%u@], having soldiers under me. I tell this one, ‘Have him go %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h,’ and he goes, and tell someone else, ‘Come %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e’ and he comes, and tell%i@ my servant, ‘Do this %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g,’ and he does it.” %u@9Jesus heard these things and was amazed at him and turned to the crowd following him and said, %r@“%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@r%r@u%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@c%r@r%r@o%r@s%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@y%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@w%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@r%r@a%r@e%r@l%r@.%r@” %u@1%u@0When they got back home, those who were dispatched found the servant in good health.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1The next thing that happened was that he went to a city called Nain, accompanied by his disciples and by a large crowd. %u@1%u@2As he neared the city gate, he ran across a dead man being carried out, his mother’s only son (and she herself was a widow%u@[%U@C%u@]); a sizable crowd from the city was accompanying her. %u@1%u@3Upon seeing her, the Lord felt compassion deep in his heart for her and said, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@r%r@y%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@1%u@4He went over and touched the open coffin%u@[%u@e%u@]; the pallbearers came to a halt and stood still. He said, %r@“%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@—%r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@!%r@” %u@1%u@5The dead person sat up and began talking, and they handed him over to his mother. %u@1%u@6A deep reverence came upon everyone%u@[%u@f%u@], and they glorified God saying that a great prophet had been brought to prominence%u@[%u@g%u@] among them, and that God has paid a visit to His people. %u@1%u@7The news of this affair propagated throughout the entire region of Judea and all the surrounding area.%vn~
          %u@1%u@8His disciples told John about all of these things, and John summoned two of his disciples %u@1%u@9and sent them to the Lord saying, “Are you the One-Who-Is-To-Come%u@[%u@h%u@], or should we wait for someone else?” %u@2%u@0These men met with him and said, “John the Baptist sent us to you to say, ‘Are you the One-Who-Is-To-Come, or should we wait for someone else?’” %u@2%u@1During the last couple of hours just then, he had treated many people of diseases, of whatever bad thing happened to be beating the tar out of them%u@[%u@i%u@], and of evil spirits, and he graciously granted many who were blind the gift of sight. %u@2%u@2He replied to them, %r@“%R@G%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %R@J%r@o%r@h%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@w%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@d%r@:%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@l%r@k%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@r%r@g%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@r%r@o%r@s%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@s%r@u%r@r%r@r%r@e%r@c%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@i%r@t%r@u%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@s%r@—%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@j%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@2%u@4So John’s messengers left, and he proceeded to speak to the crowd about John, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@t%r@r%r@y%r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@D%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@?%r@ %R@A%r@ %r@t%r@w%r@i%r@g%r@ %r@f%r@l%r@u%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@e%r@z%r@e%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@I%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@c%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@p%r@a%r@r%r@e%r@l%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@k%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@?%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@j%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@-%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@-%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@-%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@m%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@T%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@“%R@S%r@e%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@n%r@g%r@e%r@r%r@%vp~
%R@T%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@x%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@%vp~

%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%r@”%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@b%r@o%r@d%r@y%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@o%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@n%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %R@J%r@o%r@h%r@n%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@g%r@n%r@i%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@v%r@o%r@l%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@(%r@i%r@n%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@)%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@2%u@9Everyone %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@d%i@ who was listening—ordinary folk including tax collectors—had affirmed God, making Him the right choice, having been baptized in John’s baptism. %u@3%u@0But the Pharisees and the Old Testament%u@[%u@m%u@] experts disavowed God’s will, plan, and purpose for their own selves, not being baptized by him.%nn~
          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@“%R@F%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@o%r@g%r@y%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@d%r@r%r@a%r@w%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@p%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@d%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@-%r@d%r@a%r@y%r@ %R@Z%r@e%r@i%r@t%r@g%r@e%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@p%r@a%r@r%r@a%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@d%r@r%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@r%r@k%r@e%r@t%r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@,%r@%vn~
%r@%sp~
      %r@“%R@W%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@y%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@l%r@u%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@;%r@%vn~
      %R@W%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@r%r@g%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@w%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@E%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@%vn~

%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@”%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@,%r@ %R@J%r@o%r@h%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@B%r@a%r@p%r@t%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@g%r@u%r@y%r@—%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@x%r@
