%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g…%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y…%i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n…Lit: %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e…%i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s…%i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f. Ref. notes of vv. 7,10.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@—%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@u%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@e%i@p…Lit: %i@n%i@e%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@u%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r [%i@a%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d] %i@n%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k. A figure of speech, a hendiadys of a sort.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n. An expression; also used in John 1:11.%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@a%i@n%i@t…Or: %i@b%i@o%i@y. Ref. Acts 3:13.%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@t…In regard to the usage of this word, quoting Max & Mary: “properly of prancing and whinnying of high-spirited horses”%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@l…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e…Lit: %i@e%i@x%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@s%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@c%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p…Lit: %i@p%i@u%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g [%i@i%i@t] %i@n%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@s. A NT idiom, one which is a variation of the expression found in Eph. 1:22.%fn~
%u@[%u@t%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@p%i@i%i@t%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f. Expression used throughout the Bible. Also, ref. note of Matt. 8:20.%fn~
%u@[%u@u%u@]%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@r%i@g%i@y%i@m%i@a%i@n…Lit: %I@L%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@t%i@e. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@y…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s. The phrase %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ or something akin to it is used throughout the NT, and this occurrence here in vv. 7 and 9 provide one of the best examples of what the phrase means. To do something in the name of someone else means one or several of the following: To do something at one’s bidding or command; to do something as one authorized by another, using delegated authority which the other grants; to acquire the right to do something that one naturally has no right to do, only because of the reputation or authority of the one whose name is invoked. Related to %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e, ref. notes of Matt. 21:9; Mark 9:41; Mark 16:17; Rom. 2:24.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@d%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@e%i@d…Ref. note of Acts 2:35%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@v%i@o%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@r…The well-known Gk. word %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@k%i@l%i@ā%i@t%i@o%i@s%i@ (παράκλητος/Strong’s 3875) is used here, and the word has several meanings. The specific meaning of %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@k%i@l%i@ā%i@t%i@o%i@s%i@ which best applies to Barnabas, however, can be discovered by studying what Barnabas did through the Book of Acts (Acts 11:23–26, for example) and drawing conclusions based on that. Barnabas assisted Paul in his missionary journeys, but also advocated for Mark, thereby causing a dispute between him and Paul. In the end, though, Barnabas’s judge of Mark’s character was vindicated by Mark’s maturity.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 5%hb~
          %u@1Now a certain man named Ananias sold a piece of property in conjunction with his wife Sapphira %u@2and withheld—appropriated—part of the proceeds, keeping the money for himself (his wife was in on it too) and gave a certain amount to the apostles, placing it under their care and ownership%u@[%u@a%u@]. %u@3Peter told him,%vn~
      “Ananias, how is it%u@[%u@b%u@] that Satan filled your heart causing you to lie %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f the Holy Spirit and appropriate some of the sales price from the sale of the property? %u@4While you still had it, wasn’t it yours to keep%u@[%U@A%u@], and after it was sold, didn’t you have the right to retain control %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@c%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@s? How did this whole affair get lodged in your heart? You didn’t lie to human beings but to God.”%vn~
          %u@5While Ananias was listening to these words, he dropped dead. An enormous sense of awe and reverence—downright fear—came over%u@[%u@c%u@] all those who were listening. %u@6The older teens and younger men wrapped his body up, carried him out, and buried him.%vn~
          %u@7About three hours went by and his wife came in, unaware of what had happened. %u@8Peter reacted to her %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e,%vn~
      “Tell me: did you sell the property for X amount of dollars?”%vn~
      She said, “Yes, for X dollars.”%vn~
          %u@9Peter %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ to her, “Why did you %i@t%i@w%i@o conspire to try to pull a fast one on%u@[%U@B%u@] the Spirit of the Lord? Take a look at the feet%u@[%U@C%u@] of those who buried your husband at the door%u@[%U@D%u@]—and they’re going to carry you out as well.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@0She immediately dropped dead alongside his feet. The older teens and younger men came in, checked that she was dead, and took her and buried her next to her husband. %u@1%u@1A sense of awe and reverence—downright fear—came upon the entire community of believers and upon those who heard what happened. %vn~
          %u@1%u@2Lots of miracles, all kinds of them%u@[%u@d%u@], occurred among the folk-people. Everyone was on the same page, sharing the same heartfelt passion, %i@m%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@x%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ Solomon’s Colonnade. %u@1%u@3As far as everyone else was concerned, no one was daring enough to join them, but apart from that, the people thought they were awesome. %u@1%u@4More and more kept being added %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@y%i@,%i@ those who believe in the Lord that is, and not only men but women too, %u@1%u@5to the point that they were even bringing out into the streets those with maladies of one sort or another, physical problems that were dragging them down%u@[%u@e%u@], and placing them upon single-person dining couches%u@[%u@f%u@] and cots, so that when Peter came %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h he might possibly peer down and check in on%u@[%U@E%u@] any one of them %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g. %u@1%u@6Swaths of people in the vicinity of Jerusalem began to gather, bringing those with maladies and those inflicted by dirty, disgusting%u@[%u@g%u@] spirits, all of whom kept on getting healed or otherwise treated %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7The High Priest and all those associated with him (those who belong to the Sadducees sect) were stirred to action%u@[%u@h%u@] by a competitive, passionate zeal, %u@1%u@8and they apprehended%u@[%u@i%u@] the apostles and put them in the city jail. %u@1%u@9But some time during the night, an angel%u@[%U@F%u@] unlocked the cell door and lead them out, and said, %u@2%u@0”Go stand in the temple %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@x%i@ and tell all the short messages—the accounts, stories, sayings, and anecdotes—of this %i@n%i@e%i@w%i@ life %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t, and do this over and over again.” %u@2%u@1Once they heard this, they entered the temple at the crack of dawn and proceeded to teach.%vn~
      Now the chief priest came over while leading his entourage of associates—the Council with all of the councilmen%u@[%u@j%u@]—and they sent %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ to the city %i@j%i@a%i@i%i@l to retrieve them. %u@2%u@2But when the attendants got there, they didn’t find that they were in the jail, so they turned around, went back, and reported it, %u@2%u@3saying, “We found that the city jail was firmly locked down and found the prison guards standing %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@s at all of the doors. After they opened %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@o%i@r %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ in, we discovered that no one was there.” %vn~
          %u@2%u@4As they heard these words, both the commander %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@u%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@ and the high priests were perplexed over how this could’ve happened. %u@2%u@5Someone showed up and reported to them, “Check this out—the men whom you put in jail are standing in the temple %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@x teaching the folk-people.” %u@2%u@6Then the commander with a party of attendants attached to him proceeded to %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d take them away—%i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ not by employing violent force, since they were wary and fearful of the people, lest they be pelted with stones.%vn~
          %u@2%u@7After they brought them %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@b%i@e%i@r, they were made to stand before the Council. The High Priest questioned them, %u@2%u@8”Didn’t I absolutely and emphatically command%u@[%u@k%u@] you not to teach basing your authority to speak on this %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%u@[%u@l%u@]? See here now—Jerusalem’s been filled with your teaching, and you want to blame us and have us assume the guilt and consequences for this man’s death%u@[%u@m%u@].”%vn~
          %u@2%u@9Peter and the apostles replied, “We must obey God over obeying people. %u@3%u@0God our Father resurrected Jesus, whom you got your %i@g%i@r%i@u%i@b%i@b%i@y hands on and killed, having hung %i@h%i@i%i@m on a wooden %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@-%i@b%i@e%i@a%i@m%u@[%U@G%u@]. %u@3%u@1God exalted this person, this number-one leader and savior, to the position of chief executive officer, to be His right-hand man%u@[%u@n%u@], to grant a change of heart and of ways%u@[%u@o%u@] to Israel and a forgiveness of sins. %u@3%u@2You personally are first-hand witnesses of these affairs and of the Holy Spirit whom God gave to those who obey Him.”%vn~
          %u@3%u@3This hit a real sore spot with those who heard this, and they became infuriated and were wanting to kill them. %u@3%u@4A Pharisee named Gamaliel, a teacher of the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ who was well-respected by all the folk-people, got up in the council and ordered the men out for a short while %u@3%u@5and said to them, “Men, Israelites%u@[%u@p%u@], stop, take a look at yourselves, and think for a moment about what you’re about to do to these men. %u@3%u@6The fact is, a good while ago, Theudas came to prominence, claiming to be someone special, and four hundred men joined up with him. Everyone who believed in his cause%u@[%u@q%u@] disbanded, and %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ amounted to nothing. %u@3%u@7After this, Judas the Galilean came to prominence during the time that the census was being taken, and he led a group of people away in apostasy. And that guy perished too, and everyone who believed in his cause%u@[%u@q%u@] dispersed.%vn~
          %u@3%u@8”With that in mind, at this point in time I’m telling you to walk away from these men and leave them alone, because if %i@e%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ the intentions themselves or this cause as a whole happens to be man-made, it will be demolished. %u@3%u@9But if it originates from God, you won’t be able to wipe them out—lest it become self-evident%u@[%u@r%u@] that you’re fighting against God.”%vn~
      They were persuaded by him, %u@4%u@0and they summoned the men, beat them, and commanded them not to speak based on Jesus’s authority%u@[%u@l%u@] and set them free. %u@4%u@1They therefore proceeded to go their way rejoicing after facing the Council because they had been deemed worthy to be dishonored on behalf of %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@’%i@s authority %u@4%u@2and didn’t stop meeting in the temple %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@x%i@ and from house to house every day, teaching and proclaiming the good news—the Gospel—of Christ Jesus.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@s. An idiom; ref. note of Acts 4:35.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@h%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@t…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t [Usually rendered: %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t; %i@w%i@h%i@y; %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t]%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@m%i@i%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m…Lit: %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s. A biblical expression.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@p%i@h%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@m%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@a%i@g%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n…Lit: %i@w%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@ses. Ref. note of Matt. 4:23.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@e%i@-%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@s…A piece of furniture used to recline on while dining%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@d%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@g%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@r%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p. Common usage of the verb %i@r%i@i%i@s%i@e in the Bible. %fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@l%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n. A common NT phrase.%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@C%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@m%i@e%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@a%i@b%i@s%i@o%i@l%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@m%i@p%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u…Lit: %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@d. This repetition of the word %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ is a figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@b%i@a%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n…%i@b%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y…Lit: %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e…%i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s. Ref. note of Acts 4:17%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@s%i@u%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@u%i@i%i@l%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@q%i@u%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h…Lit: %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n.%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@e%i@f%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@e%i@c%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@-%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s…Lit: %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%I@M%i@e%i@n%i@,%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@s…Ref. note of Acts 1:11%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@u%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@-%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@W%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g [Gk: %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@i%i@ %i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@n%i@ (μένον σοὶ ἔμενεν), (μένον/Strong’s 3306), (σοὶ/Strong’s 4771), (ἔμενεν/Strong’s 3306)]. In the GT, the terse wording of the phrase, the repetition of the verb %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ō%i@,%i@ and the fact that this is a quotation of someone speaking and is not narrative leads to the conclusion that this is an expression, and therefore has a meaning beyond the face-value word-for-word transliteration. The bottom line is that an equivalent English expression for this Gk. expression would be, “what’s yours is yours.”%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@s%i@t; %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t. The context of the usage of the Gk. word %i@p%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@z%i@ō%i@ (πειράζω/Strong’s 3958) used here in v. 9 sheds light on the meaning of this multi-faceted word, aiding in one’s understanding of how it’s used in other passages, Matt. 4:7, 1 Cor. 10:9 for example.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@T%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@e%i@t…Of course, Peter meant %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ instead. The word %i@f%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ is a synecdoche for the young men themselves. Throughout the Bible, the word %i@f%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ is symbolic of what a person does at a high-level, or the things a person does which are more involved than simple actions. The word %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ is for simple actions, but %i@f%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ is symbolic of something which requires a sequence of actions to complete. In this verse here, Peter’s synecdoche indicates what the young men are about to do. Of particular interest is how deeply rooted such figures of speech were in the Israelis of that time, that they were used in impromptu, conversational speech such as this. We can assume that Jesus talked the same way; passages such as Matt. 18:8, though they sound out of place to the modern ear, were commonplace remarks for the time and place. %fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@o%i@r…One possible reason that those who carried off Ananias where standing at the doorway instead of being in the building could be because, having handled a dead body, they were unclean according to Jewish purity law and therefore were banned from rejoining the others.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@p%i@e%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@e%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@n [or %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@o%i@w] %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m. Not absolutely certain, but this appears to be an idiom/expression. This phrase paints a picture of someone sitting or lying on the ground when the sun’s shining, and someone else walks up to this person stands near them in such a way as to block the sun. Sometimes movies, especially Westerns, have scenes like this where a stronger person approaches a weaker person and blocks the sun when close. The weaker person squints up until when the stronger person is close, and he no longer needs to squint because of the shadow provided by the stronger person. The stronger person has come by to have an encounter of some sort with the weaker person—in this case, for Peter the stronger, the one standing, to heal the weaker one, who’s sitting or lying due to his weakness.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l…Lit: %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d. At times the NT uses the phrase %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d instead of simply %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l (Luke 2:9 for example) to clarify any ambiguity as to the meaning of %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l, specifying the angelic being as opposed to a human being. Since the word %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@ is rendered a couple different ways into English, once in English there’s no need to retain the words %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ as the ambiguity has been stripped. Also, ref. usage in Rev. 1:20.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@-%i@b%i@e%i@a%i@m…A figure of speech—a synecdoche—where instead of using the obvious words %i@c%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@i%i@f%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@,%i@ etc.%i@,%i@ which the listener normally hears used, the act of crucifixion is described in more detailed, graphical terms. To illustrate by analogy, if we were to describe someone being executed by electrocution in the following way: “We shaved his head, strapped him in a chair, put electrodes on his head and legs, and jolted him with electricity,” instead of simply saying, “We electrocuted him,” which every listener would understand. The point of such figures of speech is to illustrate how barbaric the act was, as the well-known words, being overly used, desensitizes one to the reality of what was perpetrated. %fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 6%hb~
          %u@1Now during this timeframe when the number of disciples was expanding, a complaint originated from the Greek-speaking Jews against the native Israeli Jews, that their widows%u@[%U@A%u@] were being overlooked in the Daily %I@M%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@ Service. %u@2So the twelve summoned the bulk of the disciples and said, “We’re not happy about neglecting the teaching of God’s word by being restaurant waiters%u@[%u@a%u@]. %u@3Look into %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r, comrades, %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h seven men from among you that it’s been observed%u@[%u@b%u@] %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ are full of spirit%u@[%U@B%u@] and wisdom, whom we might put in charge of this matter%u@[%U@C%u@]. %u@4We, though, will devote ourselves to prayer and to the ministry of the word %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d.”%vn~
          %u@5The reasoning put forth was agreeable in the view of the large group assembled, and Stephen, a man full of faith and the Holy Spirit, Philip, Procorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolas, who was a convert to Judaism from Antioch, were chosen. %u@6They stood %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ before the apostles, and after they prayed for them, they laid %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ hands on them. %u@7And the word of God kept on being proclaimed, being received, and producing results%u@[%u@c%u@], and the number of disciples in Jerusalem continued to grow at a high rate, and a bunch of the priests began to obey %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ in the faith.%vn~
          %u@8Now Stephen, full of grace—God’s favor and His willingness to work through him—and miracle-working capability, began to perform tremendous miracles%u@[%u@d%u@] among the people. %u@9Some people from the synagogue of those who are said to be Freedmen, Cyrenians, Alexandrians, and those from Cilicia and %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %I@P%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ Asia asserted themselves, arguing with Stephen, %u@1%u@0and didn’t have the strength %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s%i@ to withstand the wisdom and the spirit with which he continuously spoke. %u@1%u@1Then they got men to claim that, “While he was speaking, we %i@d%i@e%i@f%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@y heard him make a blasphemous remark against the Bible%u@[%u@e%u@] and God,” %u@1%u@2and stirred up the folk-people, the councilmen, and the designated teachers%u@[%u@f%u@] and descended on him all of a sudden, apprehended him, and brought him into the Council %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@. %u@1%u@3From there, the phony witnesses produced testimony saying, “This man won’t stop uttering remarks against this Holy Place and the Bible%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@.%i@ %u@1%u@4The fact is, we %i@d%i@e%i@f%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@y heard him saying that this Jesus-of-Nazareth-%i@g%i@u%i@y%i@ will destroy this place and alter the traditions which Moses passed down to us.” %u@1%u@5The panel of councilmen fixed their eyes upon him and looked at his face and saw that his countenance was like the countenance of an angel.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@b%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@s …Lit: to %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@s. Some liberties taken. %I@S%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@ is more a figure of speech akin to hyperbole than a completely accurate description of what the apostles were doing.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@b%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@k%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@c%i@l%i@a%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@s…Lit: %i@k%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@m%i@i%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@B%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@e…Lit: %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@E%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@s…Widows were the poorest in society, since they had no one to care for them and no way to earn a substantial living. Ref. note of Mark 12:40.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t…In this context, the word %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t means %i@d%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@l%i@y%i@-%i@r%i@o%i@o%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@o%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@e%i@t%i@c. It is listed as a personal quality just as %i@w%i@i%i@s%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@ is listed as such%i@.%i@ It does not mean %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@,%i@ in spite of other translations rendering this %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t, short for %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t. In the Bible the word %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ has multiple meanings; sometimes it means %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t, sometimes it means a person’s spirit, sometimes it refers to a deeply-rooted disposition of one sort or another (example of that is 2 Tim. 1:7). The NT writers understood the potential for ambiguity, and if, when writing, they were referring to the Holy Spirit, they added qualifiers to the word %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ where ambiguity might exist. (Or they added qualifiers for emphasis.) The qualifiers consist of adding an article, adding the word %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y, or%i@ forming a full predicative construct. So in v. 5, such a qualifier is added, as Stephen is %i@f%i@u%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t, not %i@f%i@u%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t. But the usage in v. 3 has no qualifiers, is paired with another personal quality %i@w%i@i%i@s%i@d%i@o%i@m, so therefore does not refer to the Holy Spirit.%i@%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@p%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r…This key phrase indicates why the seven—the first church deacons—had to be filled with spirit and wisdom in order to do their job. They were put in charge of the food distribution in order to ensure that it was being done fairly, that widows were not being overlooked because of their ethnicity. This required spirit and wisdom. But it is not a necessary prerequisite for the ordinary church worker to be filled with spirit and wisdom in order to do the simple, mundane labor that all churches require (such as being an usher, a greeter, etc.). Faithfulness and a willingness to work with others is about all such a worker needs. Furthermore, the takeaway from this passage is that a deacon is an overseer, one who can oversee an area of responsibility which is fraught with moral challenges; the run-of-the-mill church worker is not a deacon. If the qualification for every church worker was that he had to be filled with spirit and wisdom (in addition to being faithful and getting along with others), then there would be very few church workers, and much work would remain undone. Also, see description of %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@ in note of 1 Cor. 15:24.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 7%hb~
          %u@1So the high priest said, “Is this so?”%vn~
          %u@2He began to speak and said, “Men, comrades, and patriarchs: listen %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@.%i@ The%i@ God of Glory appeared to our ancestral patriarch Abraham while he was living in Mesopotamia, prior to him getting settled in Harran, %u@3and told him, ‘Leave your homeland and your relatives and go to a country which I will point out to you at some point.’ %u@4He then left the country of Chaldea and settled in Harran. After his father died, from there he relocated to this country, to where we live now, %u@5and he wasn’t given a tract of land in %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@,%i@ one that he and his descendants would own in perpetuity—not even a tiny plot that would’ve been barely big enough to get by on%u@[%u@a%u@]—And he had been promised that, ‘%I@T%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@ be granted to him, given to him for him to own, he and his descendants—his progeny%u@[%U@A%u@]—after him,’ while not having a son %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e. %u@6Here’s what God had to say to him: ‘This is what’s going to happen: his descendants—his progeny%u@[%U@A%u@]—will be foreigners and outsiders in another country, and %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@ will enslave them and mistreat them for four hundred years. %u@7And I will judge the nation (%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g) who made the decision to enslave you…,’ God said, ‘…and after these things have occurred, they will leave and %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ to this place here and%i@ continuously offer up worship by attending to an ongoing service of rituals.’%vn~
          %u@8”And He imparted to him a covenant comprised of circumcision. According to this set of instructions, he sired Isaac and circumcised him on the eighth day %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@h, and Isaac %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ Jacob, and Jacob to the twelve patriarchs, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@w%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l.%vn~
          %u@9”But the patriarchs were jealous of Joseph and handed him over to be put in the custody of some Egyptians; but God was with him, %u@1%u@0and delivered him out of all of his tribulations and gave him favor and wisdom in the presence of the king of Egypt, %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ Pharaoh, and he was put in charge over Egypt and over his (%I@P%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@o%i@a%i@h%i@’%i@s) entire %i@r%i@u%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g clan and staff. %u@1%u@1Now a famine came out of nowhere and oppressed%u@[%u@b%u@] Egypt and Canaan causing a terrible ordeal, and our %i@e%i@l%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@a%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@ ancestors weren’t able to find enough food to eat. %u@1%u@2Jacob heard that there was wheat in Egypt and sent out our ancestors as envoys to make the initial contact. %u@1%u@3Second time around Joseph made himself known to his brothers, and Joseph’s birth, lineage, and ethnicity were made apparent to Pharaoh. %u@1%u@4Joseph sent a message and summoned Jacob his father to his side and all the relatives, a total of seventy-five individuals, %u@1%u@5and Jacob went down to Egypt. He died and so did our %i@t%i@w%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@ ancestors, %u@1%u@6they relocated to Shechem, and he was placed in the tomb which Abraham bought (paying in cash%u@[%u@c%u@]) from the sons of Hamor in Shechem.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7”Just as the time %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@u%i@l%i@f%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f the promise which God promised to Abraham got closer, the %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@ people grew and multiplied in Egypt, %u@1%u@8until ‘…Another king ascended to power over Egypt, one who wasn’t affiliated with %i@t%i@h%i@e Israeli %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e.’ %u@1%u@9This fellow used cunning, Machiavellian techniques against our people and mistreated our ancestors going so far as to expose their babies %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@e%i@l%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ to where they wouldn’t survive. %u@2%u@0That was the timeframe in which Moses was born, and he was polished, charming, courteous, polite, witty, and elegant to the highest degree%u@[%u@d%u@]—he who had spent three months being raised in momma’s house%u@[%u@e%u@]. %u@2%u@1While he was exposed %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@e%i@l%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ to die%i@,%i@ Pharaoh’s daughter adopted him as her own son %u@2%u@2and trained and disciplined Moses in every sort of Egyptian wisdom and sophistication; he was formidable in speech, ability, and actions.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3”Now as he reached the age of forty, he felt an urging%u@[%u@f%u@] to visit his kinsmen, the Israelites. %u@2%u@4While seeing someone being ill-treated, he came to his defense and took vengeance on the one being oppressed and struck down the Egyptian %i@o%i@p%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@o%i@r. %u@2%u@5Now he was assuming that his brethren would understand that, through his abilities and actions%u@[%u@g%u@], God was coming to their rescue%u@[%u@h%u@], but they didn’t understand, %u@2%u@6and the following day he appeared to some men as they were fighting and tried to get them to reconcile with one another and said, ‘Men, you’re kinsmen, why are you hurting each other?’ %u@2%u@7But one who was harming his acquaintance%u@[%u@i%u@] spurned him and said, ‘Who appointed you to be a ruler and a judge over us? %u@2%u@8%I@I%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e you don’t want to eliminate me the same way you eliminated the Egyptian yesterday.’ %u@2%u@9Moses fled at this remark, and became a stranger and a foreigner in the land of Midian, where he gave birth to a couple of sons.%vn~
          %u@3%u@0”When forty years were completed, ‘…An angel appeared to him in the Mt. Sinai wilderness in the flame of a burning bush.’ %u@3%u@1Seeing this, Moses was captivated by such a sight. While approaching it, a commanding voice appeared, %u@3%u@2’I am the God of your forefathers, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.’ Moses became terrified and dared not try to wrap his head around the whole thing. %u@3%u@3’The Lord said to him, “Take your sandals off; the place on which you’ve come to stand is holy ground. %u@3%u@4I’ve seen%u@[%u@j%u@] the mistreatment of My people in Egypt and have heeded their groaning and have come down to deliver them. Go now: I’m sending you to Egypt.”’%vn~
          %u@3%u@5“This Moses whom they spurned by saying, ‘Who appointed you ruler and judge?’—this is the ruler and deliverer God sent with the assistance of an angel that was seen by him in the bush. %u@3%u@6This person led them out %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@E%i@g%i@y%i@p%i@t%i@ and performed spectacular miracles%u@[%u@k%u@] for forty years in the country of Egypt, in the Red Sea, and in the wilderness. %u@3%u@7This person is Moses who said to the Israelites, ‘God will bring to prominence in your midst a prophet like me from among your kinsmen.’%vn~
          %u@3%u@8”This is the fellow who was present in the gathering in the wilderness, along with the angel which spoke to him on Mt. Sinai and with our ancestors, %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ who was shown living words to give to us, %u@3%u@9whom our ancestors didn’t want to become subordinate to, but instead rejected and in their hearts turned %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ to Egypt, %u@4%u@0having told Aaron, ‘Make us gods that will be our banner on the march and in battle, ensuring success at every turn%u@[%U@B%u@]. The fact is, this Moses-fellow who led us out of Egypt—we don’t know what’s become of him.’ %u@4%u@1During that timeframe they did the calf-making-thing and proceeded to offer up sacrifices to the idol and to rejoice in what their hands had wrought. %u@4%u@2So God turned %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m and let them have their own way in enacting worship to the vast array of planets and stars in the sky%u@[%u@l%u@], just like it’s written in the prophet-section of the Old Testament%u@[%u@m%u@],%vn~
%si~
“‘You didn’t bring Me offerings and sacrifices%vp~
%I@W%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ in the wilderness for forty years,%vp~
%I@N%i@o%i@w %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u house of Israel?%vp~
%u@4%u@3But you applied yourselves to Molok’s house of worship%u@[%u@n%u@]%vp~
And to your star-god Rephan%vp~
And to the idols which you created%vp~
For the purpose of worshipping them.%vp~
%I@B%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ I will exile you%vp~
%I@T%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e out beyond Babylon%u@[%U@C%u@].’%vp~
%si~
          %u@4%u@4”The tabernacle of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@k%i@ %i@o%i@f the covenant existed with our ancestors in the wilderness just the way the end-to-end specifications were dictated to Moses to be built according to the blueprint he got to see; %u@4%u@5%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@a%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@ which our ancestors took turns entering while%u@[%u@o%u@] Joshua %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ taking possession of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y foreign nations, nations which God drove out by the onslaught%u@[%u@p%u@]%u@ of our ancestors up until the timeframe of David, %u@4%u@6who found favor in the eyes of God, and he begged %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@d%i@ to come up with a %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ tabernacle for the lineage of Jacob. %u@4%u@7But %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ Solomon built Him a building—a home— %u@4%u@8but no—the Most High doesn’t reside in man-made structures, just like the prophet says,%vn~
%si~
%u@4%u@9“’To Me, the heavens %i@a%i@r%i@e a throne%vp~
And the earth is a stool that I use to rest My feet on.%vp~
What sort of house will you make for me,’ says the Lord,%vp~
‘Or what %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ the%i@ place which I rest?%vp~
%u@5%u@0Has not My hand made all of these things?’%vp~
%si~
          %u@5%u@1”Unyielding and unchanged in hearts and ears%u@[%U@D%u@], you always resist%u@[%u@q%u@] the Holy Spirit; you’re just like your ancestors. %u@5%u@2%I@T%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@m%i@e—which prophet did your ancestors not persecute? Which one? They killed those who announced ahead of time things associated with the coming of the Righteous %I@M%i@a%i@n, whom you’ve become traitors to and murderers of— %u@5%u@3you the very people who received the Law of Moses, taking it to be an angelic ordinance, but didn’t keep it.”%vn~
          %u@5%u@4Having heard these things, they were piqued and went into a rage of fury%u@[%u@r%u@] and proceeded to grit their teeth, biting down hard, gnashing them%u@[%u@s%u@] against him. %u@5%u@5Being full of the Holy Spirit, he gazed up into the sky, to where heaven is, and saw God’s glorious magnificence and Jesus standing at God’s right hand (%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@i%i@f%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@e%i@c%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@s) %u@5%u@6and said, “Check this out—I see the sky up to heaven opened up and the Man%u@[%u@t%u@] standing at God’s right hand.” %u@5%u@7They screamed with their ears covered tightly, rushed him in unison, %u@5%u@8took him out of the city and proceeded to stone him to death. And the witnesses (%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@) %i@t%i@o%i@o%i@k their jackets%u@[%u@u%u@] %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d set them next to %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g young man named Saul%u@[%U@E%u@]. %u@5%u@9As they were stoning Stephen he invokes %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ saying,%vn~
      “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.”%vn~
          %u@6%u@0He dropped to his knees and loudly shouted out, “Lord, may you not hold them accountable for%u@[%u@v%u@] this sin.”%vn~
      Having said this, he went to sleep (%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r).%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@e%i@t%i@u%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@—%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@’%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@g%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@o%i@t%fn~

%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@s%i@l%i@a%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t…Lit: %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@t…Lit: %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@.%i@ The word %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ can be taken to mean %i@a%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@.%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@i%i@q%i@u%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@u%i@r%i@y…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@s%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@c%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@,%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@g%i@n%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m…Lit: %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@c%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@n%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. This is a NT expression (Matt. 8:12; 13:42,50; 24:51; 25:30; Luke 13:28) typically describing agony.%fn~
%u@[%u@t%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n…Lit: %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@a%i@n. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.%fn~
%u@[%u@u%u@]%i@j%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@e%i@t%i@s…Lit: %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@a%i@k%i@s. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@v%u@]%i@m%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r…Lit: %i@m%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@—%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@g%i@e%i@n%i@y…Lit: %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@d. This is actually singular, not plural, but the meaning is plural. However, in Gal. 3:16, Paul, using the same word, emphasizes that this is not plural but singular, singular referring to Christ.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@b%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@c%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n…Lit: %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s. Images of gods were put on carts which preceded those going into battle or those on the march, just as a strong warrior preceded the host.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@I%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@B%i@a%i@b%i@y%i@l%i@o%i@n…As it says in Ps. 37:29, “The righteous shall inherit the land, and dwell therein forever.” Going back to Genesis, God promised the land which is Israel to the Israelites. If they obeyed, God would have them live in the land. If they disobeyed, they would eventually be driven out. %I@O%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@B%i@a%i@b%i@y%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@ shows how far away they’ll be removed from the promised land.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@u%i@n%i@y%i@i%i@e%i@l%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@f%i@-%i@n%i@e%i@c%i@k%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@m%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@r%i@s. The words/phrases %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@f%i@-%i@n%i@e%i@c%i@k%i@e%i@d and %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@m%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@d %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t are OT expressions (Exod. 32:9, Deut. 10:16). Stiff-necked means a person won’t bend his head either downwards in contrition or upwards in hope and faith. Circumcision is the OT pact, the acceptance of and entry into God’s covenant. Also, the removal of the foreskin in the circumcision ceremony symbolizes the peeling away and discarding of a hardened outer layer surrounding the heart (Deut. 10:16).%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@j%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@x%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@u%i@l…The removal of the jackets (cloaks actually) was done so that the witnesses would be able to move about more freely when casting the stones. It’s also a gesture of intent, analogous to high school boys who are about to get into a fight and taking off their jackets and showing how tough they are while doing so. Once the high school boy takes off his jacket, he turns a person next to him and hands him his jacket for safekeeping. Now the boy who’s about to get into a fight would’ve been flanked by his close friends, so the person he hands his jacket to is a close friend. All of this paints a picture of who Saul was; he was standing next to the witnesses, so he was part of the inner clique, someone who was trusted, someone who, though younger, was permitted to tag along closely with the high-priest-caste. When the witnesses put their jackets next to Saul, the assumption was that Saul was responsible for their safekeeping. As the witnesses quickly scanned their throng looking for someone to entrust their jackets to, Paul was the logical choice because of his trustworthiness, his close proximity to the witnesses (indicating his zeal), and his youth (indicating that he was the younger among elders). It’s more appropriate to give a young man menial duties than someone who’s older and more senior.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 8%hb~
          %u@1Now Saul whole-heartedly agreed with eliminating %I@S%i@t%i@e%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@n.%vn~
      On that day a terrible persecution broke out against the church—the gathering %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s—in Jerusalem. Everyone scattered over the Judean and Samarian countryside except for the apostles. %u@2Devout men buried Stephen and mourned greatly for him during the period of mourning held for him. %u@3Saul proceeded to go from house to house ravaging the church, barging in%u@[%u@a%u@] and dragging off men and women, arresting them and putting them in jail.%vn~
          %u@4Those who were scattering %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@ were announcing the good news message—proclaiming the Gospel, the good news of the Word. %u@5Philip went over to a Samaritan city and proceeded to preach Christ to them. %u@6The crowds eagerly took in the various statements made by Philip, united in one heart and mind in their listening and in their watching miracles that he performed. %u@7The fact is, many filthy, disgusting spirits were being cast out%u@[%u@b%u@] one after another, crying out in a loud voice %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@f%i@t. Many paralyzed and lame were being healed. %u@8Much joy took place in that city.%vn~
          %u@9Now a certain man named Simon used to awe the Samaritans in the city by practicing magic, claiming to be someone special%u@[%u@c%u@], %u@1%u@0a person who captivated everyone’s attention, from the insignificant to the important, what they were describing as, “God’s miracle-working power: the Bomb.%u@[%u@d%u@]” %u@1%u@1They kept paying attention to him for a long time, dazzled by the works of magic. %u@1%u@2But when they believed Philip proclaiming the good news of God’s kingdom and proclaiming the authority vested in Jesus Christ and what he’s all about%u@[%u@e%u@], they proceeded to be baptized, men and women both. %u@1%u@3Simon himself also believed and, once baptized, while sticking like glue to%u@[%u@f%u@] Philip and seeing spectacular miracles%u@[%u@g%u@] and tremendous miracle-working abilities, kept on becoming more and more enchanted by having been dazzled over and over again.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4Now once the apostles in Jerusalem heard that Samaria had whole-heartedly embraced and acted upon%u@[%u@h%u@] God’s word, they sent them Peter and John, %u@1%u@5such individuals who%u@[%u@i%u@] would go over and pray for them so that they would receive %i@t%i@h%i@e Holy Spirit%u@[%U@A%u@]: %u@1%u@6for he (%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@)%i@ had not yet fallen%u@[%U@B%u@] upon any one of them, but they only existed in a state where they had been baptized%u@[%U@C%u@] into all that the Lord Jesus stands for%u@[%u@j%u@]. %u@1%u@7Then they laid hands on them and they began receiving the Holy Spirit. %u@1%u@8Simon, seeing the Spirit given through the apostles’ laying on of hands, offered them money %u@1%u@9saying,%vn~
      “Give me this ability too, so that the person I lay my hands on%i@ would receive the Holy Spirit.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@0But Peter said to him, “Get lost—I hope you die—you and your money along with you%u@[%u@k%u@]—since you assumed you could acquire God’s offering%u@[%U@D%u@] %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d through cash. %u@2%u@1You don’t get to participate in this business—not even a bit%u@[%u@l%u@], seeing that your heart is not right in God’s sight%u@[%u@m%u@]. %u@2%u@2So abandon%u@[%u@n%u@] this wickedness and beg the Lord if he would somehow possibly forgive your heart’s intention; %u@2%u@3the fact is, I see that you’re coughing up bitterness and are handcuffed by unrighteousness.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@4In response, Simon said, “You all pray to the Lord on my behalf, so that I won’t be afflicted by what you’ve said%u@[%u@o%u@].”%vn~
          %u@2%u@5So then they thoroughly presented and spoke about the concept of the Lord and returned to Jerusalem, and many Samaritan towns began to have the good news proclaimed in them.%vn~
          %u@2%u@6Now an angel spoke to Philip, “Head on out south on the road which runs from Jerusalem to Gaza, the one that nobody uses.” %u@2%u@7He got going. Out of nowhere an Ethiopian man appeared, a eunuch who had control over the Queen of Ethiopia’s entire treasury, one who had gone to Jerusalem to worship %u@2%u@8and was on the return trip sitting on his chariot and reading out of the prophet Isaiah. %u@2%u@9The Spirit said to Philip, “Go up to him and join his chariot.” %u@3%u@0Philip ran over to him and heard him reading%u@[%U@E%u@] out of the prophet Isaiah, and said, “Hmm…do you really understand what you’re reading?” %u@3%u@1He said, “Ya, about that. How would I be able to unless someone walks me through it?”, and he asked Philip to climb aboard the chariot, sit down together with him, and help him out. %u@3%u@2The passage of Scripture which he was in the middle of reading was this:%vn~
%si~
Like a sheep led to slaughter%vp~
And like a lamb speechless before the shearer:%vp~
In the same way he won’t open his mouth.%vp~
%u@3%u@3In his self-abasement his justice has been stripped %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@.%vp~
How can anyone %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@y describe%vp~
The prevailing Zeitgeist of his time%u@[%u@p%u@],%vp~
Since his life has been wiped off the face of the Earth%u@[%u@q%u@]?%vp~
%si~
          %u@3%u@4Upon reflection the eunuch said to Philip, “Can I ask you whom the prophet’s talking about here? Is he talking about himself or about someone else?” %u@3%u@5Philip opened his mouth and, from this passage of Scripture, began to tell him all about the good news of Jesus. %u@3%u@6As they were going down the road, they stumbled across some water, and the eunuch said, “Look—water: what’s stopping me from getting baptized?” %u@3%u@7%u@[%U@F%u@] %u@3%u@8He ordered his chariot to come to a halt, and both of them—Philip and the eunuch—got off %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@t%i@ and went into the water, and %I@P%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@p baptized him. %u@3%u@9When they got out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord took hold of Philip and redirected him%u@[%u@r%u@], and the eunuch didn’t see him anymore; you see, he was going his way rejoicing. %u@4%u@0Philip wound up in Azotus, and while travelling through there kept on proclaiming the good news to all of the cities all the way to Caesarea.%vn~

%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@b%i@a%i@r%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n…Lit: %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t…Lit: %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@-%i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@:%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@B%i@o%i@m%i@b…Lit: %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s [%i@m%i@i%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@-%i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g] %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t. This sentence is assumed to be conversational in nature, like a slang expression.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o…Or: %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@;%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@f%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@;%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@a%i@c%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@-%i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@e%i@m%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@s%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o…Or: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o. Same word and inflection used in 7:53. Max & Mary say that in 7:53 they mean %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@.%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%I@G%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@—%I@I%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@e%i@—%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u…Lit: %I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n [%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@h]. %fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@—%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@t…Lit: %I@I%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@t [%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n] %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d [%i@a%i@f%i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r]. %I@A%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@t is an expression.%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t…Lit: %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@a%i@b%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%I@I%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@f%i@l%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d…Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%I@H%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@v%i@a%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %I@Z%i@e%i@i%i@t%i@g%i@e%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n. %I@W%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@ is a figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@p%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@E%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@h…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@E%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@h%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@P%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@p%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m…Or: %i@s%i@e%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d [%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y]%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t…the definite article (%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@)%i@ isn’t in the GT, but in Acts 5:3 the definite article is present in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@.%i@ Although there are several reasons for inclusion or exclusion of the definite article, it appears that the inclusion of the article in Acts 5:3 emphasizes the Holy Spirit as a person, whereas the exclusion here in v. 15 emphasizes the effects that the Holy Spirit has after coming upon a person.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@n…There is a distinction between the Holy Spirit being in a person and the Holy Spirit falling upon a person. The Holy Spirit went into the eleven when Jesus breathed on them in John 20:22. Later, the Holy Spirit fell on the eleven (plus one) on Pentecost.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d…%I@E%i@x%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@e is the Gk. word %i@h%i@u%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@ō%i@ (ὑπάρχω/Strong’s 5225), and the words %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ reflect the Gk. perfect participle %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d. This adds clarity to the fact that they had become believers and were baptized in water but that the Holy Spirit had not come upon them. It is the rule and not the exception that the Holy Spirit comes upon a person a span of time after he becomes a believer.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g…Or: %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@f%i@t. The Gk. word for %i@g%i@i%i@f%i@t%i@ here (%i@d%i@ō%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@n), (δωρεάν/Strong’s 1432)%i@ is not the same word for %i@g%i@i%i@f%i@t%i@ used in 1 Cor. 12:4 (%i@c%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@m%i@a), (χάρισμα/Strong’s 5486); the word %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@m%i@a%i@ is expected. A %i@d%i@ō%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ is a gift brought and offered to another, like the offerings of the OT Mosaic Law. A dōrean is also a gift that the recipient has earned or deserves, whereas a charisma is a gift a person hasn’t earned. Charisma comes from %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@ (grace), (χάρις/Strong’s 5485); ref. note of Rom. 12:6). Therefore, the gift (%i@d%i@ō%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@n) of the Holy Spirit is something that God brings to mankind and presents as a gift, as an offering.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g…In ancient times, those who could read always read aloud and never silently to themselves, even when alone.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]vs. 37 would read: %I@P%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@p%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@“%I@I%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@y%i@.%i@”%i@ %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@“%I@I%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@.%i@” This verse is not to be found in almost all of the best manuscripts, and is therefore a spurious addition. Verse 37 is instructive of text added years after Luke wrote Acts. Rather than attempting to propagate a lie, it attempts to embellish the text.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 9%hb~
          %u@1Saul, still huffing murderous threats%u@[%u@a%u@] at the Lord’s disciples, went to the high priest %u@2and asked—begged—for letters %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@z%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ from him to present to the synagogues in Damascus, so that if he were to find anyone belonging to “the Way”%u@[%U@A%u@], either man or woman, once they’re %i@c%i@a%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ tied %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@p%i@e%i@,%i@ he would lead them to Jerusalem. %u@3While travelling he was nearing Damascus and suddenly a light from up in the sky—from out of heaven—flashed around him, %u@4and he fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to him,%vn~
      %r@“%R@S%r@a%r@u%r@l%r@,%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@u%r@l%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@c%r@u%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@?%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@5He said, “Who are you, sir?”%vn~
      %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %R@J%r@e%r@s%r@u%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@c%r@u%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@—%r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@7His fellow travellers stood speechless, without doubt hearing the voice but not seeing anyone. %u@8Saul got up off the ground, and when his eyes were opened, he couldn’t see a thing; he entered Damascus being led by the hand. %u@9For three days he had no sight and didn’t eat or drink anything.%vn~
          %u@1%u@0Now there was a certain disciple in Damascus named Ananias. The Lord spoke to him in a dream,%vn~
      %r@“%R@A%r@n%r@a%r@n%r@i%r@a%r@s%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
      He said, “I’m here, Lord.%u@[%u@b%u@]”%vn~
          %u@1%u@1The Lord told him, %r@“%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@f%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %R@S%r@t%r@r%r@a%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %R@S%r@t%r@r%r@e%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@J%r@u%r@d%r@a%r@s%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@n%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@d%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@u%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %R@T%r@a%r@r%r@s%r@u%r@s%r@;%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@a%r@y%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@w%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@n%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@d%r@ %R@A%r@n%r@a%r@n%r@i%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@c%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Ananias replied, “Lord, a lot of people have told me about this man%u@[%u@d%u@], about how much harm he’s done to the set-apart-people%u@[%u@e%u@] in Jerusalem— %u@1%u@4and he has the backing%u@[%u@f%u@] of the high priest to %i@c%i@a%i@t%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d tie up anyone in this location who’s inviting you into his life%u@[%u@g%u@].”%vn~
          %u@1%u@5The Lord said to him, %r@“%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@c%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@y%r@-%r@c%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@r%r@u%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@—%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@—%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@w%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@g%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@ %r@n%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@g%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@n%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@r%r@a%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@c%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@B%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@I%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@f%r@f%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@h%r@a%r@l%r@f%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@c%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@p%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@1%u@7So Ananias left and entered the house, laid his hands upon him, and said, “Saul, fellow comrade%u@[%U@C%u@], the Lord sent me—Jesus, the one who appeared to you while you were on the way %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e—in order that you would regain your sight would be filled with%u@[%u@i%u@] the Holy Spirit.” %u@1%u@8And without delay something akin to fish scales fell away from his eyes, and he regained his sight. He took the initiative and was baptized. %u@1%u@9Once he got something to eat, he was invigorated.%vn~
      He spent several days with the Damascus disciples. %u@2%u@0He straightaway proceeded to preach Jesus—that this person is the Son of God—in the synagogues. %u@2%u@1Again and again everyone who heard him was amazed, and they started saying, “Isn’t this the guy who’s wreaking havoc on those in Jerusalem who’ve invited Jesus into their lives%u@[%u@g%u@]? Hasn’t he come here for the same reason%i@,%i@ so that he could take the ones%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@,%i@ tie them up, and bring them right to the high priest?” %u@2%u@2But Saul proceeded to become all the more forceful and confounded the Jews living in Damascus, demonstrating through proofs that this %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y person %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ is the Messiah, the Christ.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3As a good many days had gone by and things were coming to a head, the Jews conspired to eliminate him, %u@2%u@4but their plot became known to Saul. They even started monitoring the gates closely, not just by day but by night too, so that they could eliminate him, %u@2%u@5but %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ disciples took him one night and put him all the way through the %i@c%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ wall and lowered him down in a large basket.%vn~
          %u@2%u@6After arriving in Jerusalem, he kept attempting to join up with the disciples, but a lot of them kept on being afraid of him, not believing that he %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ was a disciple. %u@2%u@7So Barnabas got ahold of him and brought him to the apostles and told them all about him: how he was on the road and saw the Lord, and that %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d spoke to him…how in Damascus he was speaking out on behalf of Jesus and all that he stands for%u@[%u@j%u@]. %u@2%u@8He accompanied them while entering and leaving Jerusalem, %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@r%i@u%i@s%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@m, speaking out on behalf of the Lord and all that he stands for, %u@2%u@9and he proceeded to speak to and to have discussions—to the point of arguing—with the Greek-speaking Jews, but they tried to apprehend him in order to eliminate him. %u@3%u@0The comrades%u@[%u@k%u@] recognized %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@m and brought him over to Caesarea and sent him away to Tarsus.%vn~
          %u@3%u@1So now the church up and down the entire stretch of Judea, Galilee, and Samaria experienced peace, being edified and conducting their lives%u@[%u@l%u@] in the deep reverence—the fear—of the Lord, and with the assistance and comfort of the Holy Spirit, they were growing and growing.%vn~
          %u@3%u@2While Peter happened to be travelling all throughout %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@,%i@ he also went over to the-set-apart-ones%u@[%u@e%u@] living in Lydda. %u@3%u@3He found a man there, a certain person named Aeneas, %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ bedfast for the last eight years, a person who had become paralyzed. %u@3%u@4Peter told him, “Aeneas, Jesus Christ is healing you: get up and make your bed.” Immediately he got up. %u@3%u@5Everyone living in Lydda and Sharon saw him; those very people turned to the Lord.%vn~
          %u@3%u@6Now in Joppa there was a certain disciple named Tabitha, which translated means “Dorcas.” She was teeming in good works and in donations to the poor%u@[%u@m%u@], which she was constantly contributing. %u@3%u@7During that timeframe she happened to get run-down with an illness, becoming sick to the point of death and eventually dying. They bathed her and put her in the top floor of a building. %u@3%u@8Lydda being close to Joppa, the disciples heard that Peter was over there and sent two men to him asking him earnestly—begging him, “Hurry up! Come over to our place!” %vn~
          %u@3%u@9Peter got up and went with them and, once he arrived, was ushered up to the upper floor. All the widows stood next to him crying and showing the oh-so-many tunics and cloaks which she was in the habit of making%u@[%U@D%u@] while she was with them. %u@4%u@0Peter pushed everyone out %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@o%i@m, and got on his knees and prayed and turned to the body and said, “Tabitha, get up!” She opened her eyes and, seeing Peter, sat up. %u@4%u@1He gave her a hand and got her up. He called for the set-apart-people%u@[%u@e%u@] and presented her alive %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d. %u@4%u@2What happened became known up and down the entire Joppa %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@e%i@t%i@c%i@h, and many believed in the Lord. %u@4%u@3As it turned out, he remained a good amount of time in Joppa with one Simon Tanner%u@[%u@n%u@].%vn~
