          %u@1A few key people came over from Judea and proceeded to tell them how things ought to be done, instructing%u@[%U@A%u@] the comrades%u@[%u@a%u@] that you’ve got to be circumcised in Moses (%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@w%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@b%i@e%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s), or else you can’t be saved (%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@l%i@k%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m). %u@2No small disagreement and debate occurred between Paul and Barnabas on one side and them on the other, and they arranged for Paul, Barnabas, and certain others from among them to go to the apostles and the presiding board%u@[%u@b%u@] in Jerusalem in regard to this debate. %u@3So then those sent forth by the church kept creating tremendous joy among the comrades as they were passing through Phoenicia and Samaria recounting the Gentiles’ conversion. %u@4Arriving in Jerusalem, they were welcomed by the church, the apostles, and the presiding board, and reported what God was doing in conjunction with them.%vn~
          %u@5Now a few who belonged to the Pharisee-sect and who had become believers stood up to speak and said that %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s must be circumcised (%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@J%i@u%i@d%i@a%i@i%i@s%i@m) and be ordered to adhere to the Law of Moses, %u@6and the apostles and the presiding board got together to look into this matter. %u@7After much debate took place, Peter stood up and told them:%vn~
      “Men, comrades: you understand that from the very start (our start that is), God chose that the Gentiles hear the Gospel through my mouth and become believers. %u@8God, the Knower-Of-The-Heart, went on record and told them that He would give them the %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Holy Spirit just like He gave it to us. %u@9After their hearts were cleansed by faith, no one discriminated against them%u@[%u@c%u@]. %u@1%u@0So at this point in time, you’re trying God’s patience (testing God) by placing an %i@u%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@r%i@y burden on the disciples (putting a yoke on the disciples’ necks), one which neither our ancestors nor we were strong enough to bear. %u@1%u@1No—%i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ through the grace of the Lord Jesus that one exercises faith to be saved %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n following the same pattern as those people did.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@2The whole lot of them fell silent and began to listen to Barnabas and Paul explain the miracles%u@[%u@d%u@] that God did among the Gentiles through them. %u@1%u@3After their silence, James%u@[%U@B%u@] responded, “Men, comrades, listen to me. %u@1%u@4Simon explained the way that, for the first time, God paid a visit—a caring, helping type of visit—in order to form a %i@u%i@n%i@i%i@q%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ people from out of the Gentiles, a people consecrated to everything He represents%u@[%U@C%u@]. %u@1%u@5The words of the prophets agree with this, as it’s written:%vn~
%si~
%u@1%u@6”’After this %i@o%i@c%i@c%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@, I will return%vp~
And rebuild David’s fallen condo%u@[%u@e%u@]%vp~
And rebuild what remains of it%vp~
And restore it,%vp~
%u@1%u@7So that what’s left of the people%vp~
%I@J%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ might seek out the Lord,%vp~
Plus all of the Gentiles upon whom%vp~
My mark of ownership%u@[%u@f%u@] was assigned to,’%vp~
Says the Lord who’s doing this%vp~
%u@1%u@8%i@a%i@n%i@d %I@W%i@h%i@o%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s known from eternity %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@t%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@.%vp~
%si~
%u@1%u@9”Therefore I decided not to bother those who are of Gentile origin who are turning to God, %u@2%u@0but instead to write them letters %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m to abstain %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@b%i@i%i@d%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s: from things polluted by idols, from %i@b%i@i%i@z%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@e sexual immorality%u@[%U@D%u@], and from %i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ blood remaining in the body %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ killed by having its neck broken%u@[%U@E%u@]. %u@2%u@1You see, going back to ancient times, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ Moses has %i@a%i@l%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ those who preach it, as it’s being read aloud in the synagogues in city after city, Sabbath after Sabbath.”%nn~
          %u@2%u@2Then the apostles and the presiding board in conjunction with the entire church decided what was best to do%u@[%u@h%u@] and chose men from among them to send with Paul and Barnabas to Antioch, %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@y Judas, who goes by Barsabbas, and Silas, men who were leaders among %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r comrades, %u@2%u@3and wrote a certified letter so there would be no doubt of its authenticity%u@[%U@F%u@],%vn~
      “The apostles and the presiding board, comrades: to the comrades up and down Antioch, Syria, and Cilicia, those who are of Gentile origin. Greetings%u@[%u@i%u@]! %u@2%u@4Because we heard that some of our own people have %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ ventured out and troubled you with remarks unsettling to your mind%u@[%u@j%u@], people who have not been issued instructions %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@o, %u@2%u@5all of us were in agreement in deciding what was best to do and chose comrades to send you who will accompany our beloved Barnabas and Paul, %u@2%u@6men who have dedicated their lives to%u@[%u@k%u@] to all that our Lord Jesus Christ stands for%u@[%u@l%u@]. %u@2%u@7So we have sent Judas and Silas, and they will report the same %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ through word-of-mouth. %u@2%u@8The fact is, the Holy Spirit and we thought it best not to make you shoulder any more burden%u@[%u@m%u@] than these %i@i%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@s %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e, which are %i@a%i@b%i@s%i@o%i@l%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@y necessary: %u@2%u@9abstain from food sacrificed to idols, from slaughtering an animal with the intent of drinking its blood, and from %i@b%i@i%i@z%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@e sexual immorality.”%vn~
          %u@3%u@0So then, once they were released%u@[%U@G%u@], they went up to Antioch, gathered the community %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ together%i@,%i@ and gave %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ the letter. %u@3%u@1After it was read they rejoiced at the advice, exhortation, and encouragement. %u@3%u@2Judas and Silas as well exhorted and encouraged the comrades by means of many short %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@i%i@c messages%u@[%u@n%u@] (they being prophets in their own right) and put them on a firm footing%u@[%u@o%u@]. %u@3%u@3After putting in time there, they were released%u@[%U@G%u@] in good standing%u@[%U@H%u@] from the comrades %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ to the ones who sent them.%u@3%u@4%u@[%U@I%u@] %u@3%u@5Paul and Barnabas continued on in Antioch teaching and evangelizing the Word of the Lord, and many others did too.%vn~
          %u@3%u@6After some days Paul said to Barnabas, “Let’s return to the cities in which we proclaimed the word of the Lord and go from city to city visiting the comrades there and see how they’re getting on %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h.” %u@3%u@7Now Barnabas was wanting to take Mark (i.e. John who goes by Mark) along with them too, %u@3%u@8but Paul was thinking it fitting not to take Mark along, the guy who deserted them, leaving them at Pamphylia and ceasing to accompany them on their mission. %u@3%u@9A sharp disagreement took place to the point where they parted ways from each other, and Barnabas took Mark and sailed for Cyprus. %u@4%u@0Paul called on Silas %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m and left, after being handed over to the Lord’s grace %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@f%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ by the comrades. %u@4%u@1He went on and on passing through Syria putting the churches on a firm footing%u@[%u@o%u@].%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@a%i@r%i@d…Lit: %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@n%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m…Lit: %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@t%i@w%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m, or, %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@t%i@w%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@m%i@i%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@o…Lit: %i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t [%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@a%i@c%i@l%i@e]. Liberties taken. Ref. note of Luke 16:9.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%I@M%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@r%i@k%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p…Lit: %I@M%i@y%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e. Similar to, “And I will write my God’s name upon him,” from Rev. 3:12.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@d %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s %i@k%i@n%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@y %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@t…The principle manuscripts differ for this verse.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t [%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t]%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%I@G%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s…Lit: %I@T%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@j%i@o%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@n%i@g. Standard introductory remark for letters back then.%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@d…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o…Lit: %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@n…Lit: %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@c%i@k. The metaphor of placing a yoke, and thereby a load to pull, on an oxen. This metaphor is used here and there throughout the NT, and in fact is used in v. 10.%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@s%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s. The usage of %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s in v. 32 should be applied to understanding what %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ means in the phrases %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@s%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@k%i@n%i@o%i@w%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@,%i@ and %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@c%i@y%i@ found in 1 Cor. 12:8.%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@p%i@u%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@m%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@o%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g…Same Gk. word used in Acts. 14:22 (ref. note there), which is rendered %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@.%i@%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h [Gk: %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@a%i@s%i@k%i@ō%i@ (διδάσκω/Strong’s 1321)]. %I@D%i@i%i@d%i@a%i@s%i@k%i@ō%i@,%i@ while normally translated %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@,%i@ has the additional meaning of instructing a person on how he should conduct his life, as it does in v. 1 here, and also in 1 Tim. 2:12, where Paul says that a woman shouldn’t teach a man (i.e., tell a man how to conduct his life).%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@J%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@s…Verse 13 quietly introduces James the brother of Jesus, the context insinuating that he’s the head of the church in Jerusalem and also that the Jerusalem church consists solely of practicing Jews who believe in Jesus.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@,%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@—%i@a%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@,%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@l%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@—%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@i%i@q%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@c%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s…Lit: %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@s. The wording that James speaks with here in v. 14 are phrases, expressions, idioms, etc. plucked out of the OT. Since this is a snippet of conversational speech and is impromptu, we deduce that James spoke this way all the time, his speech heavily seasoned with OT phraseology. Since he grew up with Jesus, Jesus spoke the same way also. Or perhaps he picked up the habit from Jesus himself.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@b%i@i%i@z%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@x%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@m%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@y…Lit: %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n. This is a reference to the prohibitions in Lev. 18:6–23, sexual practices that even the world, jaded as it sometimes is, generally disdains. Both the usage of the word %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ here and the usage in 1 Cor. 5:1 refer to extreme practices. In the NT, the Gk. word for %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@ is the female form of %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@,%i@ and keep in mind that a lot, if not most, prostitutes were temple prostitutes and fornication was combined with the pagan cult rituals. A preponderance of evidence indicates that the NT word for fornication implies something more severe than simply shacking up with your fiancée a few months before getting married, which is commonplace in the West nowadays.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d. A figure of speech, apparently: an expression built out of a hendiadys. This apparently refers to the practice of slaughtering an animal in such a way that no blood is spilled, so none of the blood is spilled and wasted, preserving more blood to be drunk.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%i@c%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@u%i@b%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@t%i@y…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@s. This appears to be an idiom. The idiom helps explain Gal. 6:11.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@d…One might have expected the word %i@d%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ to be used instead of %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@d, a word which is used twice, once in v. 30 and again in v. 33. The context together with the choice of this word seems to insinuate that Paul and Barnabas’s bed and board was provided by some other party, whoever was hosting them at the moment. When they were “released,” the hosts were relieved of the responsibility of providing for them. In v. 33, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@,%i@ means that the ones who sent them were to start providing meals for them. Here and there in his epistles, Paul addresses the support which he receives (or doesn’t receive) from his hosts; 1 Cor. 9:11 is one example. The support of ministers of the Gospel has been a thorny issue from the inception of Christianity, and not only that but in the OT as well in regard to Priests and Levites. Suffice to say that congregations, like the example in vv. 30,33 here, should assume the responsibility of providing for the pastor or pastors who lead their congregation and furthermore for the itinerating speakers who speak at their church. Like this passage here in Acts, congregations should take ownership of that responsibility rather than the pastor having to force the issue.%fn~
%u@[%U@H%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@e. The word %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ in this context has an idiomatic meaning. Ref. usage of %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ in Matt. 10:12,13. The word %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ here means not only that they left in good standing but the folks they were visiting weren’t anxious to get rid of them because they were annoying, nettlesome, or a burden, but rather felt sorry when they left.%fn~
%u@[%U@I%u@]Verse 34 missing from the better manuscripts%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 16%hb~
          %u@1%I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@ arrived in Derbe and then in Lystra and stumbled across a particular disciple there named Timothy, the son of a Jewish woman who was a believer %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ but whose father was a Greek-speaking westerner, %u@2whose %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@u%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ was attested to by the comrades%u@[%u@a%u@] in Lystra and Iconium. %u@3Paul wanted this fellow to leave with him, and took him to get circumcised (%i@s%i@y%i@m%i@b%i@o%i@l%i@i%i@z%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@J%i@u%i@d%i@a%i@i%i@s%i@m %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@b%i@e%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s) because of the Jews that were in that locale. You see, they all knew that he had a father who was a westerner. %u@4As they were travelling through the cities, they committed themselves to keeping an eye on the issues that had been decided by the apostles and the presiding board%u@[%u@b%u@] in Jerusalem. %u@5So then the churches were being strengthened in the faith and were increasing in number day by day.%vn~
          %u@6After passing through Phrygia and the province of Galatia, they were prevented from speaking%u@[%u@c%u@] the Word by the Holy Spirit in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f Asia, %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %I@P%i@h%i@r%i@y%i@g%i@i%i@a%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %I@G%i@a%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@.%i@ %u@7After they went over%u@[%u@d%u@] to Mysia, they kept on trying%u@[%u@e%u@] to go to Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus didn’t allow them to. %u@8After making an appearance in Mysia, they went over to Troas. %u@9A vision was seen by Paul over the course of a night: some Macedonian man stood planted in one place begging him, “Cut across %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@A%i@e%i@g%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ %I@S%i@e%i@a to Macedonia and help us out.” %u@1%u@0Like he saw in the vision, we%u@[%U@A%u@] immediately sought to depart for Macedonia surmising that God had summoned us there%i@ to evangelize them.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1They sailed from Troas straight to Samothrace, and the next day to Neapolis, %u@1%u@2and from there to Philippi, which is a leading colony-city in that part of Macedonia. We were keeping at it in this city for a number of days, %u@1%u@3and on the Sabbath we went out the city gates and down by the river, figuring it would be a %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e to pray. We sat down and proceeded to speak to the women who had formed a group there%u@[%U@B%u@]. %u@1%u@4A particular woman named Lydia, a dealer in luxurious cloth%u@[%u@f%u@], a Thyatirian sympathizer and near-convert to Judaism%u@[%u@g%u@], was listening and listening, as the Lord opened %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ heart to heed what was being spoken by Paul. %u@1%u@5As she was baptized (and her household was too), she asked earnestly, “If you’ve come to the conclusion that I’m faithful to the Lord, come stay at my house,” and she wouldn’t take “no” for an answer%u@[%u@h%u@].%vn~
          %u@1%u@6Now it so happened as they were going to a prayer meeting, that some teenage servant-girl who had a spirit of divination accosted them, one who brought her bosses%u@[%u@i%u@] a hefty sum of money by telling fortunes. %u@1%u@7She followed Paul around and kept on yelling, “These men are servants of the Most High God, ones who are proclaiming what you need to do to set things right %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%u@[%u@j%u@],” about them, %u@1%u@8and she kept this up for several days. Paul, exasperated%u@[%U@C%u@], turned to the spirit and said, “By the authority vested in me by Jesus Christ%u@[%u@k%u@], I command you to leave her!”—and it left her that moment. %u@1%u@9Seeing that any hope of generating income departed %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ her bosses seized Paul and Silas and dragged them to the main town square to where the rulers were. %u@2%u@0They brought them to the magistrates and said, “These here men are agitating our city, seeing that they’re Jews. %u@2%u@1They proclaim—impose upon us—sets of rules which are impermissible for us to embrace, seeing that we’re Romans.” %u@2%u@2The crowd joined in on attacking them. The magistrates flew off the handle%u@[%U@D%u@] and ordered them to be beaten %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@d%i@s, %u@2%u@3and after wounding them with many blows threw them in jail and ordered the jail keeper to lock them up tightly, %u@2%u@4who, once he received such a %i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@n order, shuttled them deep inside the jail and put their legs in stocks.%vn~
          %u@2%u@5Towards the middle of the night while Paul and Silas were praying, they kept on singing praises to God (and the prisoners kept hearing from them). %u@2%u@6A severe earthquake took place suddenly, one of such a magnitude that it shook the foundation of the jailhouse, and immediately all the doors were opened, and all of the stocks, chains, and fetters were unfastened. %u@2%u@7The jail keeper was awakened, and seeing all the jail’s doors opened, drew his sword and was about to kill himself, thinking that all the prisoners had escaped, %u@2%u@8but Paul called out to him in a loud voice, “Don’t hurt yourself; we’re all %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ here, you see.” %u@2%u@9He called for a torch, ran in, and, trembling, fell before Paul and Silas. %u@3%u@0He brought them out and said, “Sirs, what must I do to be saved %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@e%i@t%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n?” %u@3%u@1They said, “Believe in the Lord Jesus, and you and your household will be saved,” %u@3%u@2and he told him the Word of the Lord, him together with his entire household. %u@3%u@3At that moment in the middle of the night he took them into his personal care and dressed their wounds. With no further delay he was baptized, he and all who were under his authority%u@[%U@E%u@],%i@ %u@3%u@4and he brought them upstairs%u@[%U@F%u@] to his apartment and sat them down at his table and put out a spread of food. He rejoiced with his entire household, as they all arrived at the point where they had faith in God.%vn~
          %u@3%u@5Now days went by and the magistrates sent the constables saying, “Let those men out %i@n%i@o%i@w.” %u@3%u@6The jail keeper informed Paul, “The magistrates have sent %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d so that you can go free. So at this time, leave and go in peace (%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@,%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@f%i@l%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@f%i@l%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n).” %u@3%u@7Paul said to the jail keeper, “They beat us in public without a decision handed down from a court proceeding—men who are Roman citizens—threw us in jail—and now they want to kick us out %i@o%i@f %i@j%i@a%i@i%i@l in secret? No—not a chance—have them personally come over and bring us out themselves.” %u@3%u@8The constables told the magistrates these remarks; those who heard this became afraid that they’re %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ Roman citizens. %u@3%u@9They came and pleaded with them, brought them out, and kept on asking them to leave the city. %u@4%u@0After leaving the jail, they went to Lidia’s house %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e, and once they saw comrades, they comforted them, and they %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ departed.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@a%i@r%i@d…Lit: %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: to %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n. They were coming down in elevation, coming out of the mountains.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g…The word used here implies that each attempt to go into Bithynia was a trial%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@l%i@u%i@x%i@u%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@h…Lit: %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@h%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@s%i@y%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@-%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@J%i@u%i@d%i@a%i@i%i@s%i@m…Lit: %i@f%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d. Ref. note of Acts 10:2.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@“%i@n%i@o%i@”%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@s%i@w%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@u%i@r%i@g%i@e%i@d; %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@b%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@s…Or: %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s; or perhaps %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@l%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@w%i@e…First occurrence of %i@w%i@e instead of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y, as Luke joins up with Paul at Troas.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@p%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e…Many believe that this group of women were the seed out of which the church at Philippi was formed, and as a result the Philippian church—the one Paul’s epistle was addressed to—consisted entirely of women. Upon examining Paul’s epistles, the Philippian church stands out as one of the more mature and spiritual congregations written about in the NT.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@E%i@x%i@a%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d…The Gk. word %i@d%i@i%i@a%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@u%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@i%i@ (διαπονέομαι/Strong’s 1279) used twice in the NT, here and in 4:2, literally means %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@t. Though %i@e%i@x%i@a%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ is in line with 4:2, and also that the NIV renders it %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@n%i@o%i@y%i@e%i@d%i@ and the NASB %i@g%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@n%i@o%i@y%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ this context seems to insinuate something different, closer to the KJV’s rendering of %i@d%i@i%i@a%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@u%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@i%i@ as %i@g%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@.%i@ It’s as though Paul didn’t know that this woman was possessed by a demon spirit until the Holy Spirit revealed it to him instantly, at a discrete point in time. He became grieved that moment and immediately cast the spirit out of her. Paul wouldn’t have procrastinated for several days in dealing with a spirit.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@f%i@l%i@e%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@a%i@k%i@s. Some liberties taken. Ref. note of Matt. 26:65. Strange thing is that this is a Jewish practice and one would assume that the magistrates here are Gentiles. Perhaps the magistrates were Jews after all, and this would explain their animosity towards Paul and Silas. Also, in vv. 21,22 the bosses who dragged Paul and Silas before the magistrates harp on the fact that Paul and Silas are Jews encouraging Romans to adopt Jewish practices. This would mean that the bosses are painting Jews (Paul and Silas) as troublemakers in front of other Jews (the magistrates) for their own personal gain (playing the race card, as we say nowadays).%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y …Lit: %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s. Obviously, this refers to those in his household, but the literal, face-value meaning of these words insinuates anyone who’s “his,” or anyone who is under his authority, which would include any other jailers who worked under him too. Ref. note of 11:14.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%i@b%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@u%i@p. As this is rendered literally, the jailer must’ve lived in an apartment on a floor above the prison. This agrees with other details in the narrative. In v. 27, the jail keeper was awakened from his sleep by the earthquake, as he was sleeping on the upper floor of the same building which was shaken. Also, the problem of sending a message across town in the middle of the night to awaken his family and have them come to the prison (and many cities had curfews back then too) is solved. Verse 33 says that all of them were baptized %i@i%i@m%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@.%i@ So when the jail keeper took Paul and Silas and served them a meal, he took them upstairs to his apartment, never leaving the jail. Taking Paul and Silas out of the building in the middle of the night likely would’ve cost the jailer his job and probably his life too.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 17%hb~
          %u@1After travelling through Amphipolis and Apollonis, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue. %u@2For three Sabbaths Paul went to %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@n%i@a%i@g%i@o%i@g%i@u%i@e%i@ and approached those %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@n%i@a%i@g%i@o%i@g%i@u%i@e, as he was his habit of doing, and reasoned with them from the Scriptures, %u@3going through detail after detail, example after example%u@[%u@a%u@] presenting to them that the Messiah, the Christ, had to suffer and be raised from the dead and that this person Jesus is the Messiah…”The one I’m making known to you.” %u@4Some of them were persuaded and joined in with Paul and Silas, including a great many of the devout, God-fearing westerners (i.e., Greek-speaking near-Jewish converts), and no small number of the leading women.%vn~
          %u@5Overtaken by the passions of jealousy, the Jews went so far as to recruit some hooligans from the hangouts in the middle of town, formed a mob %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@,%i@ and proceeded to cause a commotion. After attacking Jason’s house, they started to try to parade them over to the rabble. %u@6Not finding them %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e, they proceeded to drag Jason and some of the comrades%u@[%u@b%u@] over to the city officials, all the while shouting, “Those guys who’ve ripped through the civilized world like a tornado%u@[%u@c%u@] have arrived here, %u@7the ones Jason has taken in as guests. All these guys engage in activities that violate Caesar’s ordinances, claiming that there’s a different king %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ Jesus.” %u@8Hearing this disturbed the crowd and the city officials, %u@9and they collected the %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@e commensurate %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@i%i@m%i@e from Jason and from the rest of them and released them.%vn~
          %u@1%u@0Wasting no time, the comrades immediately sent both Paul and Silas away to Berea during the night, who, after arriving and while being away, went to the synagogue. %u@1%u@1Now these people were more open-minded, better educated, and had more sophisticated thought processes than the Thessalonians, being individuals in particular who were totally gung-ho to embrace the Word, who day after day examined the Scriptures to see if all these things %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h %I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ were in fact true. %u@1%u@2So then, many of them believed, including many of the prominent westerner-women and men—no small number %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@t%i@a%i@l. %u@1%u@3Now as the Jews from Thessalonica became aware that the Word of God was being proclaimed in Berea, they went there as well to shake up the crowds and to cause them to feel disturbed. %u@1%u@4Immediately then the comrades sent Paul away, having him walk until he reached the ocean, while%i@ Silas and Timothy remained there. %u@1%u@5Those who escorted Paul escorted him until they got to Athens and received an order from Paul destined for Silas and Timothy that they should leave and come to him as quickly as possible.%vn~
          %u@1%u@6While Paul was waiting for them %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@,%i@ his spirit was provoked and enraged seeing the city overrun with idols; %u@1%u@7so then he kept on reasoning with and disputing with the Jews and the devout sympathizers of Judaism%u@[%u@d%u@] in the synagogue and day in, day out with whoever happened to be in the city square.%vn~
          %u@1%u@8Now some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers%u@[%u@e%u@]%u@[%U@A%u@] engaged him in a discussion; some proceeded to say, “What point is this dilettante-intellectual here trying to make%u@[%U@B%u@]?”, but others %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@,%i@ “He seems to be a preacher who preaches about weird imps%u@[%u@f%u@].” %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ because he was spreading the word about Jesus and %i@h%i@i%i@s resurrection, %u@1%u@9and they took him and brought him to a meeting of the Areopagus council on Mars Hill, saying, “May we get up to speed on what the new-fangled teaching taught by you is all about? %u@2%u@0You see, what you’re filling our heads with%u@[%u@g%u@] is strange, so we wish to understand how this fits into the big picture%u@[%u@h%u@].” %u@2%u@1(Now all Athenians and foreigners who reside %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@A%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@s have no time for anything other than talking about or hearing about something novel.)%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Paul stood %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@-%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ before everyone at the Areopagus and said, “Men, Athenians%u@[%u@i%u@], what I observe of you is that you’re exceptionally devout in every regard; %u@2%u@3you see, looking up at your objects of veneration while passing through, I ran across an elevated-altar on which is inscribed, ‘To an unknown God.’ You offer up religious devotion to that which is unknown to you, so I’ll have you know this: %u@2%u@4The God who made the world and everything in it—this sky and earth that you see all around you%u@[%u@j%u@]—is a lord who does not dwell in man-made temples, %u@2%u@5nor needs the hands-on attendance of healing treatments, %i@a%i@s He Himself gives life and breath and everything to everyone and everything, %u@2%u@6and in addition made all the nations, races, and ethnic groups that %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e living all over the planet%u@[%u@k%u@] out of one person, after delineating arranged seasons and the extent to which they linger, %u@2%u@7%i@a%i@n%i@d%u@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s to seek after God if perchance they might reach out to touch and handle Him and in so doing find Him. %u@2%u@8You see, in Him we live and are set in motion and have our existence%u@[%u@l%u@], as some of your own poets have stated too,%vn~
%si~
“For we are God’s offspring%u@[%U@C%u@] indeed%vp~
%si~
%u@2%u@9”So an offspring which gets its existence from God ought not consider the Divine Deity to be comparable to %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@g%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ with%i@ gold, silver, or stone, a craftsman’s sculpture and the reflection of a person’s conceptualization. %u@3%u@0So then, having overlooked the epochs%u@[%u@m%u@] of ignorance, at this time God is ordering all people everywhere to go about having a change of heart and of ways%u@[%u@n%u@], %u@3%u@1because a day has been marked on the calendar in which He’s going to judge the civilized world from the perspective of Him being always right and of Him expecting people to do right%u@[%u@o%u@]—%u@ judge the world by a man whom He designated, offering assurance to everyone %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ having resurrected him%u@[%u@p%u@] from the dead.”%nn~
          %u@3%u@2Once they heard “life-after-death” (i.e. the resurrection of the dead), some began to sneer, but others said, “We’d %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ hear from you on this subject again, for sure.” %u@3%u@3And with that, Paul left center-stage. %u@3%u@4Now some of the men joined up with him and became believers, among whom were Dionysius, a member of the Areopagite, and a woman named Damaris, and others with them. %vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@l%i@,%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@a%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@a%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@o%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@r%i@i%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@a%i@d%i@o…Lit: %i@r%i@a%i@v%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@a%i@b%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@l%i@d. %I@R%i@a%i@v%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@ is a hyperbole; some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@v%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@J%i@u%i@d%i@a%i@i%i@s%i@m…Lit: %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@-%i@f%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@r%i@s. Ref. note of Acts 10:2.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@E%i@p%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@S%i@t%i@o%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@p%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@o%i@s%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s…Or: %i@c%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %I@E%i@p%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@S%i@t%i@o%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@p%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@o%i@s%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@i%i@m%i@p%i@s…Something like an imp; some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g [%i@c%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o] %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@r%i@s. An expression likely.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@h%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@g%i@ %i@p%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e. An expression likely.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%I@M%i@e%i@n%i@,%i@ %I@A%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@s…Ref. note of Acts 1:11%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@k%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@k%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@h%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@t%i@h%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@p%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@n%i@e%i@t…Lit: %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@w%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@E%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@h. The face of the Earth is a well-known expression.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@r%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@e%i@p%i@o%i@c%i@h%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s…Lit: %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m…Or: %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@S%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@E%i@p%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@S%i@t%i@o%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@p%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@o%i@s%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s…Or: %i@c%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %I@E%i@p%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@S%i@t%i@o%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@p%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@o%i@s%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s. In the GT for, Luke is explicit in saying that the philosophers here were only Epicurean and Stoic, and no other kinds. As the two schools of philosophy, stoicism and epicureanism, have debated each other since their inception, Luke is insinuating that they’re wanting to see how Paul and his teaching fit into the framework of the stoicism vs. epicureanism debate.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@W%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@-%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e?…Lit: %I@W%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@g%i@i%i@c%i@-%i@d%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g? What Luke wrote here, and what was originally spoken, here and in the surrounding verses shows a marked upturn in the sophistication of the Gk. used—unlike what is found in the Gospels or other places. It demonstrates the intelligence, education, and sophistication of those speaking (as recorded by Luke), speaking in their native language. This is more on the level of something from the classical era.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@s%i@p%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@s%i@p%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ [%I@H%i@i%i@m]. This is a quotation from the Gk. poet Aratus, Paul knows those listening are familiar with the entire poem and therefore its context. We, however, receive a fragment of the poem, and the fragment taken in isolation is ambiguous. But what Paul says next in v. 29 clarifies the ambiguity and states explicitly what he meant by %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@m%i@ in Aratus’s quotation in v. 28. In v. 29, Paul says %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d, the words %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ refer to %i@o%i@f%i@ [%I@H%i@i%i@m]. %fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 18%hb~
          %u@1After this %I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@ got himself away from Athens and went to Corinth. %u@2He found a certain Jew by the name of Aquila, who grew up in Pontus but had recently come from Italy, and Priscilla his wife, %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e because of Claudius’s order to expel all the Jews from Rome, and went to them. %u@3Being of the same trade, he proceeded to take up residence near them and to start working. In this regard they were tent makers by trade. %u@4He kept on reasoning %i@a%i@n%i@d %i@t%i@r%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ in the synagogue every Sabbath, Sabbath after Sabbath, and was persuading Jews and westerners time and again.%vn~
          %u@5As they (Silas and Timothy) came over from Macedonia, Paul continued to devote himself to %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ the Word, solemnly declaring to the Jews that Jesus is the Messiah. %u@6As they were deployed against him hurling abuses, he shook out his clothing %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ and%i@ said, “You’re to blame for your own destruction%u@[%u@a%u@]! I’m wiping my hands of it%u@[%u@b%u@]! From now on, I’m going to the Gentiles.” %u@7He left there and was taken into the home of%u@[%u@c%u@] someone named Titius Justus, a pious God-worshipper, whose house was next-door to the synagogue.%vn~
          %u@8Now the synagogue head Crispus came to have faith in the Lord together with his entire household, and hearing %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s,%i@ many of the Corinthians started to have faith %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ and were being baptized. %u@9The Lord spoke to Paul at night in a dream, “Don’t fall into fear%u@[%u@d%u@]—no—keep on talking and don’t fall silent, %u@1%u@0because I am with you and no one can lay a hand on you to harm you, because a %i@d%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d group of people%u@[%u@e%u@] are with me—a great many of them—in this city.” %u@1%u@1So for a year and a half he filled the role of teacher%u@[%u@f%u@] among them, teaching them the Word of God.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2While Gallio was the %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ proconsul of Achaia, the Jews, united in heart, mind, and purpose, jumped Paul and brought him to the courtroom where %I@G%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@o sat as judge%u@[%u@g%u@], %u@1%u@3saying “This guy uses the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s to convince people to not be piously devoted to God and to not worship Him.” %u@1%u@4%I@J%i@u%i@s%i@t as Paul was about to open his mouth %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@,%i@ Gallio said to the Jews, “Oh you Jews! If this really was some wrong-doing or nefarious crime, I would’ve put up with this from you while%i@ complying with the methodology %i@o%i@f %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@t %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@c%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g. %u@1%u@5But issues concerning concepts, authority, reputations, law, %i@e%i@t%i@c%i@. that are specific to you are %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ monitored by you; I do not wish to be a judge who decides these matters,” %u@1%u@6and dismissed their case. %u@1%u@7Everyone%u@[%u@h%u@] got ahold of the synagogue head Sosthenes and began to beat him %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e in the courtroom%u@[%u@g%u@], and Gallio had no intention of doing anything about it.%vn~
          %u@1%u@8Paul continued to stay with the comrades%u@[%u@i%u@] for a good number of days more, said goodbye to them, and proceeded to sail to Syria, accompanied by Priscilla and Aquila%u@[%U@A%u@], after shaving his head in Cenchreae, since, you see, he was holding fast to %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a %I@N%i@a%i@z%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@e vow. %u@1%u@9They arrived in Ephesus, and he left those others there, but he for his part went to the synagogue and proceeded to reason with the Jews. %u@2%u@0When they asked him to stay for an even longer time, he wouldn’t acquiesce, %u@2%u@1but said goodbye instead, “If it’s God’s will, I’ll come back %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@t you again” %i@a%i@n%i@d put out to sea from Ephesus. %u@2%u@2After he went down to Caesarea and went over and greeted the church, he went down to Antioch. %u@2%u@3After spending some time %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e, he left and went through one part of Galatia after another and Phrygia too, putting the disciples on a firm footing.%vn~
          %u@2%u@4Now a certain Jew who grew up in Alexandrian named Apollos, a man who was quite the scholar, arrived in Ephesus%u@[%U@B%u@], being proficient and capable in the Scriptures. %u@2%u@5This fellow was schooled%u@[%u@j%u@] in the Way of the Lord, and as he was fervent—boiling-over really—in the Spirit, he went about speaking and kept meticulously teaching on the subject of Jesus, understanding John’s baptism only. %u@2%u@6In addition this fellow began to speak boldly and freely in the synagogue. Once Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they took him aside and correctly explained to him the Way of the Lord. %u@2%u@7As he was wanting to tour in Achaia, prompted %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ the comrades wrote a letter of recommendation to the disciples %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ to receive him%i@,%i@ who when he arrived was joined in tight unison%u@[%u@k%u@] with those who had become believers through the grace %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d. %u@2%u@8The fact is, he kept on overwhelming the Jews in public with refutations, vehemently showing with specifics through the Scriptures that Jesus is the Messiah.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d [%i@b%i@e] %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d. A biblical idiom.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@t…Lit: %I@I%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f. %I@E%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ in the context of entering someone’s house is a NT expression that means that the homeowner extended an invitation to stay for several days.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%I@D%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@a%i@r…%i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@d…%i@d%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@t. The Gk. grammar suggests that Paul was not already afraid nor was he silent; the encouragement was to stay away from fear and avoid silence, rather than to pull oneself out of one or the other or both.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e…%I@A [%i@f%i@o%i@l%i@k] %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e. The word for %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ here is the same used throughout the NT to describe the people of Israel. It means ordinary people who share a common bond, to the point of comprising a nation. The interpolation %i@d%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ is insinuated by the context.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@f%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@t. The word %i@s%i@a%i@t%i@ is similar in meaning to when we when we refer to a professorship as a chair.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e…%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@o%i@m…Lit: %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@t…%i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@t. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%I@E%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e…This is a figure of speech, a type of synecdoche, which does not literally mean everyone. Ref. note of Matt. 3:5.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@s%i@c%i@h%i@o%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@t%i@a%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@-%i@o%i@f%i@-%i@m%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@h. Probably referring to something learned in a lecture-style classroom environment, rather than self-studying books.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@j%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@i%i@s%i@o%i@n…The lectionary says this word was used for the confluence of streams or for soldiers locking their shields together during battle%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@P%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@a%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@A%i@q%i@u%i@i%i@l%i@a…Noteworthy is that Priscilla is named before Aquila, though in v. 2 Aquila is named first. This is a hint that Priscilla was of greater assistance to Paul than Aquila.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@A%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@E%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s…Rev. 2 gives hints that the Ephesian church was stamped with Apollos’s characteristics, namely his scholasticism. For more info, ref. book %I@A%i@ %I@P%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %I@R%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 19%hb~
          %u@1Now what happened when Apollos was in Corinth was that Paul passed through the highland districts and came to Ephesus. He found some disciples off to the side %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e %u@2and said,%vn~
      “Did you get the %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Holy Spirit now that you’ve become believers?”%vn~
      They replied, “Not only %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@,%i@ but we’ve not heard of there being a %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Holy Spirit.%u@[%U@A%u@]”%vn~
          %u@3And %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t Paul said, “What have you been baptized into %i@(%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@,%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@)?”%vn~
      They said, “Into John %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@B%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@’%i@s baptism.”%vn~
          %u@4Paul said, “John’s baptism was an initiation into a covenant of a change of heart and of ways%u@[%u@a%u@], while %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s telling the people %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ to the Coming-One who comes later so that they would believe in him. This person is Jesus.”%vn~
          %u@5After hearing this, they were baptized by the authority of the Lord Jesus%u@[%U@B%u@]. %u@6When Paul laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came upon them%u@[%U@C%u@] %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@,%i@ and along with that they began speaking in tongues and speaking Holy-Spirit-inspired words%u@[%u@b%u@]. %u@7All told, there were about twelve men (%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@u%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@r%i@e%i@n) there.%vn~
          %u@8After he introduced himself to the synagogue and became affiliated with the people there%u@[%U@D%u@], for three months he proceeded to openly and freely reason with and %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ convince %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@m%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ about things pertaining to God’s involvement with mankind%u@[%u@c%u@]. %u@9As some kept on getting more and more resistant%u@[%u@d%u@] and turned-off, bad-mouthing the Way in front of the majority, he parted ways with them and pulled the disciples away, while day by day reasoning in the lecture forum in Tyrannus. %u@1%u@0Now this occurred for two years, to the extent that everyone living in %i@t%i@h%i@e %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ Asia heard the Word of the Lord, both Jews and westerners, %u@1%u@1and God kept performing miracles through the hands of Paul, %u@1%u@2even to the extent that cloths, handkerchiefs, and tradesman’s aprons which he had bare-skin, physical contact with which were taken from him, and when laid over those who were run-down%u@[%u@e%u@] %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@l%i@l%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@n%i@o%i@t, the diseases left them, and the Evil Spirits went out %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@.%i@%vn~
          %u@1%u@3There were these roaming Jewish exorcists%u@[%u@f%u@] who attempted to invoke the delegated authority of%u@[%u@g%u@] the Lord Jesus Christ over people who have Evil Spirits by saying, “I exorcise%u@[%u@f%u@] you all %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ Jesus whom Paul preaches!” %u@1%u@4Now there were seven sons of a certain Jewish chief priest %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ Sceva doing this %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %I@E%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y, %u@1%u@5and the Evil Spirit replied to them, “I’m familiar with Jesus and I know about Paul, but who are you?”, %u@1%u@6and the man who had the Evil Spirit in him assaulted them and dominated and overpowered them to the extent that they fled the building half-naked%u@[%u@h%u@], bruised, and beaten.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7This became known to all the Jews who were living in Ephesus and to the westerners as well, and fear fell upon all of them, and what the Lord Jesus is all about%u@[%u@i%u@] began to be magnified, %u@1%u@8and many of those who had become believers began confessing out loud what their %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@ habits are, telling everyone about them. %u@1%u@9A sizeable number of those involved in the occult gathered their books together and burned them up in front of everyone. When they added up the cost of the books, they arrived at a figure of $6.25 million%u@[%U@F%u@].%u@ %u@2%u@0In this way—according to the Lord’s awesome power—the Word kept on growing and getting stronger.%vn~
          %u@2%u@1As these things ran their course, Paul determined by the Spirit%u@[%u@j%u@] to go through Macedonia and the Roman province of%i@ Asia in the course of going to Jerusalem, having said, “After I’ve been there, I’ve got to see Rome too.” %u@2%u@2He sent two of his helping-assistants%u@[%U@G%u@], Timothy and Erastus, on ahead, while he, on the other hand, stayed back for a period of time in Asia.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3Meanwhile, no trivial disturbance took place with regard to the Way. %u@2%u@4You see, a certain fellow by the name of Demetrius, a silversmith by trade who made silver shrines of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@d%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ Artemis which generated a not-so-insubstantial income for the guild, %u@2%u@5gathered everyone connected with this line of work together and said, “Gentlemen, you know that our well-being comes from this trade, %u@2%u@6and you see for yourself that this Paul-guy is talking a good number of people in Ephesus—and in nearly all of Asia—into disregarding and shunning %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k, claiming that man-made objects are not gods. %u@2%u@7Not only does this threaten that our profession will become disreputable, but %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ the temple of the great goddess Artemis will lose all of its prestige and %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s will wind up destroying her magnificence, she whom the entire province of Asia and the civilized world worships.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@8Once they heard this, they were filled with rage and shouted, “The Ephesians’ Artemis is awesome!%u@[%U@H%u@]” %u@2%u@9The city was filled with turmoil, and, once they caught Paul’s Macedonian travelling companions Gaius and Aristarchus, they all together rushed to the theater. %u@3%u@0Paul was wanting to engage%u@[%u@k%u@] the mob, but the disciples wouldn’t let him. %u@3%u@1Some of the public officials, being his friends, sent word to him begging him not to venture into the theater. %u@3%u@2Some kept shouting one thing, some another thing. The fact is, the throng was confused; most of them didn’t know why they’d gathered together. %vn~
          %u@3%u@3The crowd pinned %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@a%i@m%i@e on Alexander, who was pushed to the front by the Jews. Alexander motioned to the mob with his hand so that he could begin talking his way out of the situation. %u@3%u@4Recognizing that he’s a Jew, for about two hours they shouted a singular chant, “The Ephesians’ Artemis is awesome!” %u@3%u@5After hushing the crowd, the city clerk said, “Gentlemen, %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ Ephesians%u@[%u@l%u@], show me one person who doesn’t know that the Ephesians’ city is home to and protector and custodian of Artemis the Awesome, the image which fell down from Zeus. %u@3%u@6Since this is absolutely %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e, we’ve got to settle down and not do anything rash. %u@3%u@7You see, you brought these men who are neither temple-robbers nor blasphemers of our goddess %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@s. %u@3%u@8Now if Demetrius along with his fellow tradesmen really have a complaint to levy against anyone, there’s such a person called a ‘proconsul’—let them take it before him. %u@3%u@9But if that’s not good enough for you, whatever it is you’re wanting to have done will %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o be resolved through the court system. %u@4%u@0The fact is, based on what’s taken place today, we’re in jeopardy of being accused of rioting, since we have no good excuse for what we’ve done.”%vn~
          %u@4%u@1After he said this, he dismissed the throng.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%I@J%i@o%i@h%i@n%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s…Lit: %I@J%i@o%i@h%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@-%I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@-%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s…Lit: %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@d [%i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t]%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@r%i@u%i@n%i@-%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n…Lit: %i@w%i@e%i@a%i@k. Ref. note of Matt. 4:23.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%I@J%i@e%i@w%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@s…%I@I%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@e…Same base-word used for %i@e%i@x%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@s and %i@e%i@x%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@v%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@g%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@f%i@-%i@n%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@n%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@d. Assuming that “naked” means “half-naked” and not “completely naked,” same as in Matt. 25:36.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t…Lit: %I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t. The word %i@p%i@u%i@t%i@ when%i@ used concerning one’s heart is an expression. This expression appears in 5:2 also.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@e%i@n%i@g%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@b…Lit: %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@b. Same expression used in v. 8; see note there.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%I@G%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %I@E%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@s…Ref. note of Acts 1:9%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@N%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@’%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t…This sentence doesn’t lend itself to word-for-word translation; the GT reads like conversational Gk., needing interpolations, rather than written Gk. In other words, what we see in the first half of this verse is a the sort of language everyday people spoke in back then—not formal Gk.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n [%i@b%i@y] %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s. This is when they received Christ as Lord. An open question is whether they were baptized in water a second time after this, as all Christians are baptized when they believe, or whether John’s baptism sufficed. But in any case, after being “baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus” (after believing in Jesus), they were baptized in the Holy Spirit, thus demonstrating once again that, generally speaking, the baptism in the Holy Spirit happens after one accepts Christ as Savior—not at the same time.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m…The Holy Spirit coming upon a person is an expression. It does not refer to the indwelling of the Holy Spirit that a person receives as part of believing in the Lord; rather, it means that a person receives the baptism in the Holy Spirit, which is almost always an event distinct from receiving the Lord and one which occurs afterwards.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@n%i@a%i@g%i@o%i@g%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@n%i@a%i@g%i@o%i@g%i@u%i@e. This idiom is used in elsewhere in the NT, specifically in Mark 3:1; Luke 4:16; Luke 6:6, 13:14; 14:1; 17:1,2,10; 18:19; 19:30; 28:8; James 2:2. It has a few different meanings (or multiple meanings at the same time). What should be kept in mind is that a synagogue is first and foremost an assembly of people, in the same way that a church is an assembly of people, and secondly a building or some other premise. Therefore, this expression means: He introduced himself to those in the synagogue and attended one of their meetings; He became a member of the synagogue; He became affiliated with the synagogue; He visited the synagogue. It may be that this expression denotes a formal custom of introduction where a new member is greeted by those in the synagogue. As part of this, the new member’s credentials are submitted, and if he’s learned enough in the Scriptures, he’ll be given the opportunity to stand before the synagogue and teach—or at least to talk in smaller, more informal groups. This idiom is also used in phrases like “enter into the kingdom of heaven,” “enter into eternal life,” etc., as in Matt. 7:21; 19:17,23; 25:21, 26:41; Luke 11:52; 22:40,46.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@E%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m…Yet another example of disease and evil spirits lumped into the same category. If God causes disease, does He cause evil spirits to afflict people as well?%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%i@$%i@6%i@.%i@2%i@5%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@5%i@0%i@,%i@0%i@0%i@0%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@r [%i@c%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@s]. Assume that the coin is a drachma. Ref. conversion notes in Matt. 18:28 and elsewhere.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%i@t%i@w%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@l%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@-%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@w%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. The word for %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ here is translated %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@ elsewhere%i@.%i@ These were Paul’s servants, doing his bidding. Timothy started out at a young age helping Paul, and as he proved trustworthy, Paul assigned him more and more challenging tasks, as Timothy continued to prove his faithfulness and dedication, to the point where a couple of letters Paul sent him are enshrined in the NT. All of this is included in the post of NT deacon.%fn~
%u@[%U@H%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@E%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@’%i@ %I@A%i@r%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@e%i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@!…Since the same exact wording appears in v.34 and since these words are blurted repeatedly, this was likely a popular, well-known, often-repeated chant. Whenever the crowd got whipped into a frenzy, they would repeat this chant. This is like something that goes on nowadays at a sporting event, protest, or political rally.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 20%hb~
          %u@1After the riot stopped Paul sent for the disciples, and once he encouraged them and after a going-away get-together, he left for Macedonia. %u@2After passing through those parts and encouraging them with many a message, he went to Greece, %u@3and after he’d put in three months there, a plot by the Jews against him materialized while he was about to set sail for Syria; he wound up making the decision to return via Macedonia.%vn~
          %u@4Now accompanying him were Pyrrhus’s son Sopater from Berea, Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica, Gaius from Derbe, Timothy, and Tychicus and Trophimus from the Roman province of Asia. %u@5These fellows went out ahead and waited for us in Troas. %u@6We set sail from Philippi after the multi-day Feast of Unleavened Bread ended, and by the time five days or so went by met up with those in Troas, where we stayed on for seven days.%vn~
          %u@7On a Sunday%u@[%u@a%u@] when we gathered to break bread (%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@,%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@u%i@n%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@j%i@o%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@y), Paul kept on explaining to them in depth the logic behind %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t, pointing out to them the logical fallacies of the opposing points of view, and in general covering a given subject with them from top to bottom%u@[%U@A%u@]. %I@B%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ planning on leaving the next day, he was lengthening the lesson until midnight.%vn~
          %u@8Now in the upstairs room in which they were gathered, there were enough lamps %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@ a sufficient amount %i@o%i@f %i@l%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g, %u@9and there was a teenager there named Eutychus sitting on the window %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ who fell deep asleep while Paul was going into more and more explanations, and who, when he was woken up, fell out of the third floor and was pronounced dead on the spot%u@[%u@b%u@]. %u@1%u@0Paul went down, vigorously attended to him%u@[%u@c%u@], took him in his arms, and said, “Don’t make a commotion—he’s alive%u@[%u@d%u@], you see.” %u@1%u@1He went %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ up, prayed over the meal%u@[%u@e%u@], ate to his heart’s content%u@[%u@f%u@], and spoke until dawn: That’s the manner in which he departed. %u@1%u@2They took the lad away—and he was alive when they did—and were relieved in no small way.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3We went on ahead and got on the ship and sailed to Assos, intending to take on Paul there %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@r; you see, he had arranged for things to be done that way, while he himself planned to travel by foot. %u@1%u@4When he met us in Assos, he boarded, and we went to Mitylene, %u@1%u@5and from there caught an outbound wind the following day and arrived %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ across from Chios. The following day we cut across to Samos, and the day after that arrived in Miletus. %u@1%u@6You see, Paul had weighed the options and decided to sail past Ephesus, in order to not waste time in Asia; the fact is, he was in a hurry to get to Jerusalem in time for the Pentecost holiday, if possible.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7From Miletus Paul sent a message to Ephesus and summoned the church governing board%u@[%U@B%u@] together %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e. %u@1%u@8When they met up with him, he told them, “Starting with the first day I set foot in Asia, you know how I’ve spent the entire time with you, %u@1%u@9serving the Lord in total humility and self-abasement and in tears and during the hard times of the plots fomented against me by the Jews, %u@2%u@0as I did not shirk a bit in telling you the things which are a benefit to you, teaching you in public and indoors privately, %u@2%u@1solemnly declaring to both the Jews and the Gentiles a change of heart and of ways%u@[%u@g%u@] in relation to God and declaring faith in our Lord Jesus. %u@2%u@2Take note of this: I’ve been compelled%u@[%u@h%u@] by the Spirit to go to Jerusalem; what I’ll be confronted with there, I do not know. %u@2%u@3Nevertheless, in city after city the Holy Spirit solemnly goes on record to tell me that bonds and afflictions await me. %u@2%u@4But—no—I have not uttered a peep about how precious my life is to me as I finish my race and complete the ministry which I received from the Lord Jesus, to thoroughly declare the good-news-message%u@[%u@i%u@] of the grace of God.%vn~
