          %u@2%u@5”Take note of this: I know that all of you—you whom I was preaching the Kingdom %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ to while passing through %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@a—will never set eyes on me again%u@[%u@j%u@]. %u@2%u@6Therefore I’m going on record this very day to say that I can’t be blamed for the destruction of the lives of anyone%u@[%u@k%u@], %u@2%u@7for I have not shirked in telling anyone the will of our God. %u@2%u@8Be mindful of yourselves and of the entire flock %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@s%u@[%u@l%u@] whom the Holy Spirit put you as overseers%u@[%U@C%u@] (%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@o%i@p%i@s) over, leading%u@[%U@C%u@] God’s church, a church which he acquired through his very-own blood. %u@2%u@9I know that monstrous%u@[%u@m%u@] wolves will join up with you%u@[%u@n%u@] after my departure, %i@p%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@-%i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@,%i@ not sparing the flock, %u@3%u@0and men will arise from among you who speak distorted, perverted, and corrupted things, causing %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ the disciples to commit apostasy by becoming their followers%u@[%U@D%u@]. %u@3%u@1Therefore be continuously and vigilantly on the lookout, remembering that day and night for three years I did not take a break from warning every last one of you—warning you in tears.%vn~
          %u@3%u@2”At this time I commit you to God and to the concept of His grace, to be edified by the Power (the miracle-working power in fact) and for %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s end-goal plan %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%u@[%u@o%u@] to be granted among those who’ve been set apart and have been made holy%u@[%u@p%u@]. %u@3%u@3Any kind of cash, checks, or clothing%u@[%u@q%u@] I desired from no one. %u@3%u@4You’re personally acquainted with the fact that my own hands attended to my needs and subsistence. %u@3%u@5I’ve pointed all this out to you so that you participate in like manner in the toil of helping those who are weak (%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@h%i@a%i@p%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t) and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus that he himself said, ‘It is more blessed to go about giving than to go about receiving.’”%vn~
          %u@3%u@6After he said these things, he dropped to his knees to pray with all of them. %u@3%u@7A good amount of crying by everyone took place, and they wrapped their arms forcefully around Paul’s neck%u@[%u@r%u@] and kept on kissing him, %u@3%u@8in agony most of all because of the message which he spoke that they would never set eyes on him again. They then proceeded to put him on the ship and send him off.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%I@S%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@y…Lit: %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@s. Ref. note of Mark 16:2.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@o%i@t…Lit: %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d. When they got to his body, they immediately pronounced him dead and instead of trying to treat him proceeded to take away his dead body.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@v%i@i%i@g%i@o%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m…Lit: %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. The word %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ is similar to usage in the common NT expression %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n, which means to assault. %I@F%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ here has the same meaning as when paramedics attend to a person in an emergency. They are acting quickly, decisively, and aggressively, appropriate for the life-threatening situation.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e…Lit: %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@a%i@y%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@a%i@l…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@t%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@m%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t. An expression.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s…Lit: %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@b%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@-%i@n%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@-%i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@l%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@n%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@y%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n…Lit: %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e. An expression.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%I@I%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e…Lit: %I@I%i@ %i@a%i@m%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l. A biblical idiom. Ref. note of Acts 18:6%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@f%i@l%i@o%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@s…Lit: %i@f%i@l%i@o%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@e%i@e%i@p. The metaphor of shepherd as leaders and sheep as followers is extensive throughout the Bible, particularly in the NT.%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@s…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@y; metaphorically means %i@r%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e; when speaking of soldiers, it means %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@y%i@-%i@a%i@r%i@m%i@e%i@d.%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@j%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u. Similar wording as 19:8; ref. note there.%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@g%i@o%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@’%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y…Or: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%I@A%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@,%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@e%i@c%i@k%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %I@O%i@f%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g. The words %i@g%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ and %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ refer to gold and silver coins. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@w%i@r%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@m%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@e%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@c%i@k…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@c%i@k. Same expression used in Luke 15:20. %I@F%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ in other contexts means %i@a%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@;%i@ in this context it is used metaphorically to insinuate a physical—to the point of being forceful even—kind of embrace.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@k%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@p%i@l%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@g%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@g%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@e%i@w%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@j%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@p%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@t%i@t%i@o%i@m…Or: %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m. The Gk. word for %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ here is the same word used in 17:2,17; 18:4,19; 19:8,9; 20:9, and in those verses means the same thing. Paul’s epistle to the Galatians show him “reasoning” in this way, and this is what Luke says he was doing here in 20:7. Nowadays, this would fall under the category of “teaching,” but the Gk. words for reasoning and teaching don’t correspond exactly to the English words reasoning and teaching. The Gk. word for teaching implies dictating moral instruction (ref. 15:1), whereas the word for reasoning is explaining the logic behind something, the topic at times being difficult to understand.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@c%i@h%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@a%i@r%i@d…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@h. The church at Ephesus, a Gentile church, was run by elders. Later in Acts, we see churches run by bishops. Both forms of church government were in use in the NT; therefore, both forms are sanctioned.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@e%i@r%i@s…%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@b%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@o%i@p%i@s…%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g [or %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g]. This is the first occurrence of the word %i@b%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@o%i@p%i@ [%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@e%i@r] in the NT. In modern times, we often use the word %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@ when we technically-speaking mean %i@b%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@o%i@p%i@. Note that these bishops are the elders referred to in v. 17. Also, the word rendered %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ here is actually %i@s%i@h%i@e%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@d%i@ or %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@.%i@ Throughout the Bible, the word %i@s%i@h%i@e%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@d means %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@.%i@ In the NT, the word means %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@,%i@ and it is where we get the word in its modern usage.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@s%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@d%i@r%i@a%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m. The word %i@d%i@r%i@a%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ is the same base-word that is rendered %i@a%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@s%i@y in 2 Thess. 2:3. The words %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ are used throughout the NT to mean one person following another, or submitting to the will of another (same usage in Matt. 4:19; ref. note there).%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 21%hb~
          %u@1When it came time to set sail, once we were torn away from them, we set a straight course and came to Cos, and the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara. %u@2Finding a ship that was making the run straight to Phoenicia, %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@g%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@a%i@s%i@t, we boarded and sailed off. %u@3When Cyprus appeared over the horizon, we kept it on our port side and kept on sailing to Syria and docked at Tyre, seeing that the ship was destined to unload its cargo there. %u@4Seeking out and finding disciples, we stayed there for seven days. Those disciples in particular kept on telling Paul through the Spirit to not go down to Jerusalem.%vn~
          %u@5When those days were up, we left there and started walking, with everyone having a send-out for us, joined by %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ wives and children, until they got outside the city %i@w%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@s%i@.%i@ At the shore we dropped to our knees and prayed. %u@6We tore ourselves away from each other and boarded the ship, and those %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ people returned to their kinfolk and fellow citizens%u@[%u@a%u@].%vn~
          %u@7For our part, we finished taking the ship from Tyre and arrived in Ptolemais, greeted the comrades%u@[%u@b%u@] and spent a day with them. %u@8The next day we left and went to Caesarea, and were invited to stay at%u@[%u@c%u@] Philip the Evangelist’s house (Philip being one of the %i@o%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@l seven directors%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@r%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%i@s), and stayed with him as his guests. %u@9This fellow had four unmarried%u@[%u@d%u@] daughters who prophesied %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@g%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@s%i@i%i@s%u@[%U@A%u@]. %u@1%u@0While staying put there for plenty of days, a certain-someone from the Judean %i@c%i@h%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@h—a prophet named Agabus—came over %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@r%i@u%i@s%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@m%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@, %u@1%u@1approached them, took Paul’s belt off, tied his own hands and feet with it, and said, “Thus says the Holy Spirits: The Jews in Jerusalem will tie up the man who owns this belt the same way as this and hand him over to the Gentiles to be put in custody by them.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@2When we heard this, we and the locals as well advised him—begged him—not to go to Jerusalem. %u@1%u@3Paul then replied, “What are you all doing crying and breaking my heart? Fact is, I’m ready to not only be bound but also to be killed in Jerusalem, on behalf of all that the Lord Jesus stands for%u@[%u@f%u@].” %u@1%u@4Not making any progress in talking him out of it, they quieted down and said, “May the Lord’s will come to pass.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@5After this stretch of time was over, we made preparations and proceeded to go to Jerusalem. %u@1%u@6Some of the disciples from Caesarea accompanied us as well, bringing us to a certain Cyprian named Mnason, whom we were to stay with, a disciple who had been around for a long time.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7When we showed up in Jerusalem, the comrades gladly received us. %u@1%u@8The next day Paul—we—met up with James and the entire church governing board%u@[%u@g%u@]. %u@1%u@9Once greetings were exchanged, he explained down to the last detail what God had accomplished among the Gentiles through his ministry. %u@2%u@0Those who heard this glorified God and told him, “You see, comrade, how many tens of thousands there are within the Jewish community who have become believers, and all of them are zealous to be%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s. %u@2%u@1The word’s going around about you that you’re instructing all the Jews to abandon %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f Moses and live like Gentiles, telling them not to circumcise their boys %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@f%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@,%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@r%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %I@J%i@u%i@d%i@a%i@i%i@s%i@m%i@ nor to live a lifestyle of keeping%u@[%u@h%u@] the %i@a%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ traditions %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@i%i@n%i@-%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%u@[%U@B%u@]. %u@2%u@2So what’s the story here%u@[%u@i%u@]? Everyone’s going to hear that you’ve come %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@f%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@p%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@e.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3”So this is what you %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d do%u@[%u@j%u@]: There are four men who have voluntarily taken %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e %I@N%i@a%i@z%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@e vow and are partway through it%u@[%u@k%u@]. %u@2%u@4Befriend them, perform Jewish purification rituals with them as a group and pay their expenses %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@v%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ they’ll shave their heads, and everyone will know that the word-on-the-street about you is baloney%u@[%u@l%u@], and you live uprightly instead and keep the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ for your own self. %u@2%u@5Now about the Gentiles who’ve become believers: we disseminated the decision to obey %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ list of %i@r%i@u%i@l%i@e%i@s: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m food sacrificed to idols, from slaughtering an animal with the intent of drinking its blood, and from %i@b%i@i%i@z%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@e sexual immorality.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@6Paul then befriended the %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ men, and on the following day, once he was ritualistically purified, entered the temple complex with them, letting everyone know the days of ritualistic purification had been checked off, until such a time that the %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@d%i@ offering was offered by each one of them.%vn~
          %u@2%u@7As the seven days were about to come to an end, the Jews from %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f Asia saw him in the temple and proceeded to stir up everyone in the crowd, and they grabbed ahold of him, %u@2%u@8while shouting, “Men, %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w Israelites, help: this is the man who’s teaching everyone everywhere %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ in opposition to %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ the folk-people %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@ and is against the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ and this %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ place. What’s more, he brought Gentiles into the temple and defiled this holy place.” %u@2%u@9You see, they had seen the Ephesian %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ Trophimus in the city with him beforehand, and they assumed that Paul had brought him into the temple %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t.%vn~
          %u@3%u@0The entire city was perturbed, and the folk people formed a stampede, and forcibly taking hold of Paul, they proceeded to drag him outside the temple %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@x%i@, and the %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ gates were immediately shut %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m. %u@3%u@1And while trying to kill him, a report was dispatched to%u@[%u@m%u@] the colonel of the Roman garrison%u@[%u@n%u@] %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ that the entire city of Jerusalem was on the move. %u@3%u@2He immediately gathered soldiers and junior officers%u@[%u@o%u@] to his side, chased them down, and cornered them. Seeing the colonel and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul. %u@3%u@3Next, the colonel drew near, took custody of him, spoke out an order that he be tied up with two chains, and inquired who he might be and what it is that he had done. %u@3%u@4Some of the people in the crowd were shouting one thing at them, some were shouting another. Unable to understand %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@n because of the riot, he ordered that he be brought to the garrison’s base. %u@3%u@5But when they got to the stairs, they found that he was being carried by the soldiers on account of them being pressured by the crowd. %u@3%u@6You see, a multitude of the folk-people were shouting, “Get rid of him!”%vn~
          %u@3%u@7And while they were about to enter the base, Paul said to the colonel, “May I say something to you?” He said, “You know Greek? %u@3%u@8So that means that you’re not the Egyptian who a few months ago stirred up a rebellion and lead the 4,000 men from the terrorist organization out into the desert.” %u@3%u@9Paul said, “I certainly am a Jew, from Tarsus, Cilicia, a citizen of a not-so-insignificant city. I’m asking you to return me to the folk-people and speak to them.” %u@4%u@0Paul turned around, went back, stood on the stairs, and motioned with his hand for the crowd to be silent. Once the crowd was quiet, he addressed them in Aramaic…%u@[%U@C%u@]%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@f%i@o%i@l%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@n%i@s…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n. Assuming %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ refers to people; it could refer to affairs, things, etc.—or all of these.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@v%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@t…Lit: %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o. An idiom.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@u%i@n%i@m%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@v%i@i%i@r%i@g%i@i%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@r%i@u%i@s%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@m…Lit: %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n. The phrase %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ implies that he came from Jerusalem, as the GT of the NT is consistent in saying that a person “goes up” to Jerusalem or “comes down” from Jerusalem.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@c%i@h%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@a%i@r%i@d…Lit: %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@y%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g …Lit: %i@w%i@a%i@l%i@k%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@?…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@?%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@o…Lit: %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@N%i@a%i@z%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@v%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@t…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@v%i@o%i@w. Same wording as 18:18.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@y…Lit: %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@p%i@a%i@t%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@p. Here and in the next few verses, the words %i@u%i@p%i@ and %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ are used in reference to the colonel and the soldiers, as though they were stationed in a tower or something of the sort.%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@c%i@o%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@t. Around 500 soldiers.%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@j%i@u%i@n%i@i%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@c%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@g%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@s%i@i%i@s…Lit: %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g. The Gk. text does explicitly say that they were prophetesses but that they prophesied. Since prophecy by its most basic definition is speaking Holy Spirit-inspired utterance, and not necessarily foretelling the future (word of wisdom) or having supernatural revelation of something going on that you would not otherwise know (word of knowledge), it is likely that they didn’t speak words of wisdom or words of knowledge, and were therefore not technically prophetesses.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@y%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@-%i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@i%i@n%i@-%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@n%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@l%i@k%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s. The traditions were man-interpreted rules derived from the Law of Moses, with the intention of complying with the letter of the Law.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]Continues without break into the next chapter%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 22%hb~
          %u@1%u@[%U@A%u@]…”Men, %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ comrades, and patriarchs: listen to my side of the story now%u@[%u@a%u@].” %u@2Once they heard him addressing them in Aramaic, they gave him their attention all the more. He %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n %i@g%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ to say, %u@3“I am a Jew, born in Tarsus, Cilicia, raised in this city as an understudy of Gamaliel, having received tutelage down to the minutest detail from the foremost expert in the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%u@[%u@c%u@], being zealous of God in the same way that you all are today. %u@4I kept on persecuting %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ This Way%u@[%u@d%u@] to the point of death, subduing them and putting them in jail%u@[%u@e%u@], both men and women%u@[%u@f%u@] alike. %u@5As the high priest vouched for me (and every one of the councilmen%u@[%u@g%u@] too), and along with that I also received letters %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@z%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n addressed to the comrades in Damascus, I proceeded to go bring those who lived up there too to Jerusalem, all tied up, so that they would be forced into submission, thoroughly crushing their will to resist.%vn~
          %u@6”What happened to me sometime around midday while walking and approaching Damascus is that a light from out of the sky suddenly shined around me, a light like a spotlight consisting of a continuous lightning flash. %u@7I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me,%vn~
      %r@“%r@‘%R@S%r@a%r@u%r@l%r@,%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@u%r@l%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@c%r@u%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@?%r@’%r@%vn~
          %u@8”I replied, ‘Who are you, sir?’%vn~
      “He told me, %r@‘%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %R@J%r@e%r@s%r@u%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@N%r@a%r@z%r@a%r@r%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@c%r@u%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@.%r@’%vn~
          %u@9”Now those who were accompanying me saw the light indeed, but didn’t hear the voice which was speaking to me.%vn~
          %u@1%u@0”I said, ‘What do you want me to do%u@[%u@h%u@], sir?’%vn~
      %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %R@D%r@a%r@m%r@a%r@s%r@c%r@u%r@s%r@;%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@r%r@a%r@n%r@g%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@p%r@l%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@.%r@’%r@%vn~
          %u@1%u@1”As I had lost my sight due to the glory of that %i@m%i@a%i@g%i@n%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@t light, I was led about by the hand %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ by my colleagues and arrived in Damascus.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2”Now someone named Ananias, a devout man according to %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s, his devoutness affirmed by all the Jews living %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e,%i@ %u@1%u@3went up to me, stood over me, and said, ‘Comrade Saul, regain your sight,’ and that very moment I looked up at him and was able to see again. %u@1%u@4He said, ‘God of our ancestors appointed you to know His will and to see the One Who’s Right and to hear the sound of words coming from His mouth, %u@1%u@5because you will give an official account%u@[%u@i%u@] to all sorts of people all over the place%u@[%u@j%u@] %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t what you’ve seen and heard. %u@1%u@6And what are you going to do now? %I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ get up and get ready to be baptized and have your sins washed away, after you’ve asked him to do for you what he’s best known for%u@[%u@k%u@].’%vn~
          %u@1%u@7”What happened to me after returning to Jerusalem and was praying in the temple is that I found myself in a trance. %u@1%u@8I saw him telling me, %r@‘%R@H%r@u%r@r%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@J%r@e%r@r%r@u%r@s%r@a%r@l%r@e%r@m%r@—%r@q%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@k%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@—%r@b%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@’ %u@1%u@9I said, ‘Lord, they know that I was going from synagogue to synagogue imprisoning and beating those who believe in you. %u@2%u@0And when the blood of your advocate and representative%u@[%u@l%u@] Stephen started to be shed, I was right there too off to the side, heartily approving and keeping an eye on the jackets that the ones who were killing him %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f.’ %u@2%u@1He said to me, %r@‘%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@r%r@-%r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@n%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@…%r@’”%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Now they were listening to him %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@y up to the previous statement, and they %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n raised their voice singularly and said, “Wipe him off %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f the earth—a guy like this doesn’t deserve to live!”, %u@2%u@3and screamed and went absolutely ballistic%u@[%u@m%u@]. %u@2%u@4The colonel ordered that he be brought into the base, and said %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@w%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s for him to be whipped as part of an interrogation, in order to ascertain the reason he was being shouted at like this. %u@2%u@5As he stretched him out with the leather straps %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@,%i@ Paul said to the centurion standing there,%vn~
      “Is it legal for you all to whip a Roman citizen who hasn’t been convicted in a court of law?%u@[%U@B%u@]”%vn~
          %u@2%u@6Upon hearing this, the centurion went over to the colonel and reported %i@i%i@t, “What %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@l%i@d are you about to do? This here man’s a Roman citizen.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@7The colonel came over and said, “Tell me—are you a Roman citizen?”%vn~
      Paul said, “Yes.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@8The Centurion answered, “I acquired this citizenship %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ with a large sum of money.”%vn~
      Paul said, “But as for me—I was born into mine.%u@[%u@n%u@]” %u@2%u@9As a result, those who were about to interrogate him immediately backed away. The centurion became frightened knowing beyond a shadow of doubt that he’s a Roman citizen and that he had been tied up %i@i%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@g%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@.%i@%vn~
          %u@3%u@0A council was convened the following day to ascertain the facts of what he was being accused of by the Jews. He let him out, summoned the high priest and the councilmen%u@[%u@o%u@] to attendance, brought Paul down %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@,%i@ and had him stand before them.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@w…Lit: %i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@-%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@-%i@n%i@o%i@w%i@-%i@a%i@p%i@o%i@l%i@o%i@g%i@y [%i@r%i@e%i@b%i@u%i@t%i@t%i@a%i@l] %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@u%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@a%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@l…Lit: %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@a%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@l. An expression.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%I@I%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@c%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %I@W%i@a%i@y …Or: %I@I%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@t%i@h [%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e]. The text is ambiguous; the context favors the first over the second.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@s%i@u%i@b%i@d%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@j%i@a%i@i%i@l…Lit: %i@b%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@j%i@a%i@i%i@l. The word %i@b%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ is used frequently in the NT as a combined statement of fact and at times a metonymy for the word %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@d%i@u%i@e%i@.%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n…Or: %i@h%i@u%i@s%i@b%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@m%i@e%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s. This would be the Sanhedrin.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@d%i@o%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t…Or: %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@l%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n. Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e…Lit: %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n. A figure of speech. Ref. note of Matt. 3:5.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@a%i@s%i@k%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@k%i@n%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r…Lit: %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@a%i@d%i@v%i@o%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@s%i@o%i@l%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@c…Lit: %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@a%i@k%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@i%i@r. Idioms. Liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%I@B%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@—%I@I%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@e…The Gk. text expresses something stronger than a simple antithesis here.%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@m%i@e%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]Continued from chapter 21%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@I%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@g%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@p%i@ %i@a%i@ %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@v%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@w%i@?…An indication that the Roman Empire of Paul’s time hadn’t yet descended into decadence and immorality, in spite of the feuding and turnover of emperors. It’s doubtful that, had this situation occurred in the Roman Empire of the fourth century or later, the soldiers would have had any qualms about whipping Paul. This statement by Paul, similar circumstances as 16:37, refutes certain preconceived ideas connected with “turning the other cheek” (Matt. 5:39). Namely, when Jesus said to turn the other cheek, he didn’t mean that a person should not press for what’s rightfully his when being walked over.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 23%hb~
          %u@1Paul looked intently at the council%u@[%u@a%u@] and said, “Men, comrades, with a good conscience in every respect I have lived my life for God%u@[%u@b%u@] up to this day.” %u@2The high priest Ananias had the ones standing next to him hit him in the mouth. %u@3Paul then said to him, “God’s going to hit you %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%u@[%u@c%u@], you bogus %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%u@[%u@d%u@]. And %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ you presume to sit in judgment over me according to the Law%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ but you hit me illegally.” %u@4The attendants who were standing nearby said, “You’re insulting God’s high priest,” %u@5and so Paul goes on to say, “I didn’t know, comrades, that he’s a high priest. You see, it’s written in Scripture, ‘You shall refrain from speaking ill of a ruler of the people.’”%vn~
          %u@6Realizing that one part %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@ consisted of Pharisees but the other part consisted of Sadducees, Paul shouted to the council, “Men, comrades, I myself am a Pharisee, the very product%u@[%u@e%u@] of Pharisees—I’m on trial for the hope that life after death offers%u@[%u@f%u@]!” %u@7Once he said this, a disagreement broke out between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the majority were split %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@s%i@u%i@e. %u@8(On the one side of the dispute, Sadducees assert that there is no life after death, nor are there angels or spirits%u@[%U@A%u@]; whereas Pharisees profess the opposite.) %u@9Heavy back-and-forth shouting took place, and %i@s%i@o some of the designated teachers%u@[%u@g%u@] who were on the Pharisees’ side stood up and said in hot contention, “We find that this man has done no wrong. If a spirit spoke to him, or %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@h%i@a%i@p%i@s%i@ an angel, …” %u@1%u@0With quite a quarrel breaking out, the colonel was growing anxious %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@f%i@e%i@t%i@y%i@ lest Paul be torn to pieces by them and ordered a company of soldiers to come down %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ and snatch him from their midst and bring him to the base.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1That night%u@[%u@h%u@] the Lord stood over %I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@d%i@ and said, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@w%r@e%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@.%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@k%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@w%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@w%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@y%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@J%r@e%r@r%r@u%r@s%r@a%r@l%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@l%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@R%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@2When day came, the Judeans formed a cabal and swore an oath amongst themselves promising not to eat or drink until they killed Paul. %u@1%u@3There were more than forty who took this oath %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@b%i@a%i@l, %u@1%u@4and these men approached the high priest and the council and said, “We took an oath amongst ourselves, swearing that we would be cursed if we break it%u@[%u@i%u@], not to enjoy even a morsel of food%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@ until we kill Paul. %u@1%u@5So have an audience before the colonel now, you and the council with you, %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@t%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ to bring %I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l down %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ as though %i@y%i@o%i@u’ll be investigating his case in detail. We’ll be ready to bump him off before he %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ gets close to you.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@6Paul’s nephew (his sister’s son) heard about the ambush, was escorted to the base, was granted access, and informed Paul. %u@1%u@7Paul called one of the centurions over and said, “Send this young man to the colonel, as he has something to tell him.” %u@1%u@8He did indeed take the young man into his custody and brought him to the colonel and said, “The prisoner Paul called me over and asked me to bring this young man who has something to tell you.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@9The colonel clasped his hand and took him aside %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@l%i@k in private, and proceeded to inquire, “What is it that you have to tell me?” %u@2%u@0He said, “The Judeans concocted %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@o%i@t to ask that you bring Paul down tomorrow to %i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ the council as though some detail about %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e is being examined. %u@2%u@1So then don’t let them talk you into this, as more than forty of their men are in on the plot %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@m%i@p%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m, and these men swore amongst themselves to not eat or drink until they bump him off, and they’re ready to go as of this moment, waiting for you to give the word.” %u@2%u@2So the colonel released the young man and ordered him not to tell anyone that he had an audience with him.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3He summoned two of his centurions and said, “Get two hundred soldiers ready to march all the way to Caesarea, plus seventy cavalrymen and two hundred javelin-throwers%u@[%U@C%u@], with a departure time of nine in the evening, %u@2%u@4and saddle up a mule so that Paul will be delivered safely to Governor Felix, %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e mounted.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@5He dictated a letter which reads,%vn~
%si~
%u@2%u@6%I@F%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ Claudius Lysias, to his excellency Governor Felix: Greetings!%vp~
%u@2%u@7The Jews got ahold of this man and were about to kill him, but I came to the rescue%i@ with my soldiers. Having learned he was a Roman citizen %u@2%u@8and wanting to get to know the grounds on which they were accusing him, I took him to their council. %u@2%u@9I discovered that he was being charged for an issue involving their law, but nothing that he was being charged with was worthy of death or imprisonment. %u@3%u@0Now%i@ after I received a report that a conspiracy to take this man%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ was about to be hatched, I immediately sent him to you, commanding his accusers to present their case before you.%vp~
%si~
          %u@3%u@1So then the soldiers, following the orders they were given, took Paul and brought him to Antipatris over the course of the night. %u@3%u@2The next day %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@f%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y allowed the cavalrymen to part ways and continue on with him %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@C%i@a%i@e%i@s%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@a, while they returned to base. %u@3%u@3Those %i@c%i@a%i@v%i@a%i@l%i@r%i@y%i@m%i@e%i@n entered Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor and presented Paul to him. %u@3%u@4He read it, asked what province he’s from, and found out that he’s from Cilicia. %u@3%u@5”I’ll give you a hearing,” he said, “when your accusers show up.” He ordered that he be placed under guard in Herod’s palace.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@h%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u. The Gk. verb tense used in the word %i@h%i@i%i@t%i@ insinuates an open-ended retaliation rather than a tit-for-tat retaliation.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@b%i@o%i@g%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@w%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@l%i@l. Liberties taken. A commonly-used idiom used in Israel at that time. Ref. Matt. 23:27, Luke 11:44.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@t…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e. %I@H%i@o%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ is a hendiadys (ref. note of Matt. 3:11). %I@R%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d is an idiom meaning %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %I@S%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@n%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t. As the Jewish day starts at sundown, for them it would be the next day.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@s%i@w%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@ %i@i%i@t…In Gk. reads %i@a%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@v%i@ (Ἀναθέματι ἀνεθεματίσαμεν), (Ἀναθέματι/Strong’s 332), (ἀνεθεματίσαμεν/Strong’s 331), which shares the same root as the word %i@a%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@;%i@ and the words are repeated as a figure of speech.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@s…Or perhaps: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t. The GT is somewhat ambiguous. The word %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ here is singular in the GT, just as the word %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@s%i@ is actually singular (%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l). Since angels is singular but the intent is plural, logic suggests that the intent for %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ is plural as well. This also is consistent with the usage in v. 9.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@j%i@o%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@o%i@d…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e. This is an expression, as the text simply says %i@t%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@ with no predicate supplied. The word %i@t%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@ is used as a metonymy; the entire thing is a figure of speech. This helps explains what Jesus said in Matt. 26:29; Mark 14:25; Luke 20:10 about drinking of the fruit of the vine: he meant enjoying the fruit of the vine.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@t%i@w%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@i%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@C%i@a%i@e%i@s%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@,%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@v%i@a%i@l%i@r%i@y%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@w%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@j%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@-%i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@s…Scholars are uncertain what %i@j%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@-%i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@s (Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@-%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@-%i@g%i@r%i@a%i@s%i@p%i@-%i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@-%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@-%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@-%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d) refers to. Perhaps they were Roman velites, younger, less experienced men who served as the light infantrymen who threw javelins. By the size of the contingency, the colonel feared a confrontation which would escalate into a large skirmish, which might even trigger a revolt. Both the cavalry and the velites are fast-moving troops. Apparently, the strategy was to have some troops outrun any opposition, getting him on horseback to Caesarea quickly if the need arose.%i@%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 24%hb~
          %u@1Five days later the high priest Ananias arrived with some councilmen%u@[%u@a%u@] and with this attorney named Tertullus. They appeared before the governor %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ against Paul. %u@2After being called on, Tertullus began the prosecution of the case saying, “A good deal of peace has been obtained because of you and the reforms which—owing to your foresight—you’ve introduced into this nation %u@3and which have been whole-heartedly accepted by everyone everywhere, your excellency Felix, with overwhelming%u@[%u@b%u@] gratitude. %u@4But in order to not waste any more of your time, I beg you by the kindness you’re %i@k%i@n%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r to listen for a moment. %u@5You see, we find that this plague-of-a-man: %i@#%i@1%i@—is%i@ instigating rebellions among all the Jews across the civilized world plus is a ringleader of the Nazarene faction; %u@6%i@#%i@2%i@—attempted to desecrate the temple; %i@#%i@3%i@—has been arrested.%u@[%u@c%u@]%u@7%u@[%U@A%u@] %u@8In regard to all of these %i@a%i@f%i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@s, you might want to%u@[%u@d%u@] examine them yourself to ascertain what it is we’re accusing him of.” %u@9The Jews piled in alleging that this is so.%vn~
          %u@1%u@0And Paul, given the nod from the governor to speak %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@b%i@u%i@t%i@t%i@a%i@l, replied, “From many years of being a judge for this nation, all the while being good-natured about getting to know the background material of my rebuttal, %u@1%u@1you have the wherewithal to%i@ come to the realization that, from the time I left to travel to Jerusalem to worship there, no more than twelve days have gone by. %u@1%u@2%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@w%i@s have not found me wrangling%u@[%u@e%u@] with anyone in the temple or exerting pressure which I fomented out of a group of people in the temple, nor %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e in the synagogues, nor going from city to city %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e, %u@1%u@3neither can they present %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ to you pertinent to the accusations they’re leveling against me at the moment. %u@1%u@4I hereby state the following to you: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@g%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@f%i@s%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d worship the Father-God with are in accordance with ‘the Way’%u@[%u@f%u@] (which they say is a sect %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@J%i@u%i@d%i@a%i@i%i@s%i@m), in every respect exercising faith consistent with the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s and believing in what’s written in the rest of the Old Testament%u@[%u@g%u@], %u@1%u@5having hope in God, a hope which they too entertain for themselves, a soon-to-be afterlife%u@[%u@h%u@] of the righteous and—well—the unrighteous too. %u@1%u@6I apply myself to this as well, %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ to maintain a blameless conscience through it all towards God and towards %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w comrades.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7”%I@A%i@s%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@l%i@y%i@ over many, many years%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ gave donations to the poor among my fellow-countrymen, I arrived in the temple bringing offerings and donations. %u@1%u@8They found me in the temple with these %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ and in a state of %i@r%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@ purification—%i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ not%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@e with a crowd or with rioters. %u@1%u@9Some of the Jews from %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f Asia—who ought to have to appear before you %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ and submit accusations if they have some sort of %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@ against me— %u@2%u@0or should be made to state in person %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u that they found some misconduct %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ standing me before the council%u@[%u@i%u@]— %u@2%u@1unless %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@ it’s %i@a%i@l%i@l about this one squawk which I shouted out while I stood in their midst, ‘I’m on trial before you today over %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@c%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f life after death!’—”%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Felix adjourned the proceedings, knowing in detail the ins-and-outs of the Way from observation, and said, “When Colonel Lysias manages to get here, I’ll get to the bottom of your claims,” %u@2%u@3while ordering the centurion to keep an eye on Paul while he let him relax and ordering him not to prevent any of his personal attendants%i@ from attending to %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@s.%vn~
          %u@2%u@4A few days later Felix appeared with his wife Drusilla (who was Jewish), summoned Paul, and listened to him talk about faith in Christ Jesus. %u@2%u@5While he was making the case for%u@[%u@e%u@] righteousness, self-control, and the Coming Judgment, Felix became frightened and responded, “You’ll have to go now, but when I get the chance, I’ll call for you to come %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k.” %u@2%u@6All the while too, he was hoping that he was going to get money from Paul; for that reason too, he kept on conversing with him, summoning him frequently.%vn~
          %u@2%u@7Now his two-year term as governor ended, and Felix was replaced by a successor %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@d Porcius Festus, and wishing for the Jews to owe him a favor%u@[%U@B%u@], %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n Felix kept Paul imprisoned.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@m%i@e%i@n…Lit: %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@w%i@h%i@e%i@l%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]The GT indicates that items #1, #2, #3 are a comprehensive list of accusations, as indicated by the Gk. word %i@k%i@a%i@i%i@ (καὶ /Strong’s 2532)and the uses of the relative pronouns.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o…Or: %i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@r; %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d. Lit: %i@c%i@a%i@n [in the subjunctive mood]. Like in many languages, the use of the subjunctive is out of politeness and respect and avoids the effrontery of being too direct when speaking to one in authority.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@w%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g…%i@m%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r…Or: %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g. This word covers the gamut from discussing, reasoning, making the case for, debating, arguing, and wrangling.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@’%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@W%i@a%i@y%i@’…Ref. 9:2%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e…Lit: %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]Verse 7 is spurious%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@v%i@o%i@r…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@v%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@w%i@s. This is expression is also used in Acts 25:9. The exchange of favors was part what maintained the delicate political equilibrium between the Romans and the Jews.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 25%hb~
          %u@1So Festus assumed %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@n%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@o%i@r over the region and went from Caesarea down to Jerusalem three days later, %u@2and the chief priests and the leading Judeans informed him %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@u%i@s%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s against Paul and proceeded to ask him to step in %u@3and do a favor for them in their %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ against %I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l, that he be extradited to Jerusalem, as they were preparing an ambush to bump him off while on the way down. %u@4As a result Festus decided to keep Paul in Caesarea, while he himself was planning to leave %I@J%i@e%i@r%i@u%i@s%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@m soon. %u@5So he %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ says, “Let those of you who can make things happen%u@[%u@a%u@] accompany %i@m%i@e%i@ and indict him of crimes%u@[%u@b%u@] if there turns out to be some discrepancy with this man.”%vn~
          %u@6He spent no more than eight to ten days with them and went down to Caesarea. The next day he convened court as the presiding judge%u@[%u@c%u@] and called for Paul to be brought forth. %u@7When he showed up %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@t, the Judeans who had come up from Jerusalem brought lots of severe%u@[%u@d%u@] charges against him, but the case for any of them was not strong enough to stick, %u@8while Paul, speaking in his own defense, said, “I have not committed any infraction%u@[%u@e%u@] with respect to the Jews’ Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s, nor with respect to the temple %i@r%i@u%i@l%i@e%i@s, nor with respect to Roman law%u@[%u@f%u@].”%vn~
          %u@9But Festus, wanting to do a favor for the Judeans so they would owe him one%u@[%u@g%u@], replied to Paul, “Do you want to go down to Jerusalem and hold the trial for all of this down there with me as judge?” %u@1%u@0Paul said, “I have taken a stand in the Roman court of law, where my trial must be held.%u@[%u@h%u@] I have done no wrong to the Jews, as you have come to know so well. %u@1%u@1So now, if I am indeed guilty of doing something worthy of death, I won’t make excuses for getting the death penalty. But if nothing comes of what they’ve charged me with, nothing’s going to make them happy. I appeal %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ to Caesar.” %u@1%u@2After conferring with %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ council, Festus then replied, “You have appealed to Caesar, to Caesar you shall go.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Several days went by and King Agrippa and Bernice arrived in Caesarea and greeted Festus %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. %u@1%u@4In the course of spending a lot of days there, Festus went over the charges against Paul with the king from top to bottom, “There’s this man who was left imprisoned by Felix, %u@1%u@5concerning whom the Jewish chief priests and councilmen%u@[%u@i%u@] tendered a request to me while I was there in Jerusalem, asking me to sentence him %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@v%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@i%i@m%i@e. %u@1%u@6To which I replied that to surrender and hand over%u@[%u@j%u@] a given person before the defendant faces his prosecutors%u@[%u@k%u@] in %i@t%i@h%i@e %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ physical location and submits testimony in his own defense against the charges is not the Roman way of doing things.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7”So they came up here, and without delay I convened court the following day, sat in the judge’s chair, and called for the man to be brought in. %u@1%u@8When it was the prosecution’s turn to present evidence, they kept on accusing him %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@o%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@w, while I kept on suspecting that not a single one of the charges was a %i@l%i@e%i@g%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@e felony. %u@1%u@9They kept on having issues with his religious beliefs and with this certain fellow who died named Jesus, %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l. %u@2%u@0I was perplexed about this %i@o%i@n%i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ debate of theirs and kept on asking him if he would like to go to Jerusalem and be put on trial down there for these things. %u@2%u@1But when Paul appealed %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e and asked that he be held in custody for the purpose of having the emperor decide %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e, I ordered that he be held prisoner until I send him over to Caesar.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Agrippa %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ to Festus, “I’ve been wanting to hear what this man has to say myself.”%vn~
      “Tomorrow,” he said, “You shall hear what he has to say.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@3The next day Agrippa and Bernice—with much fanfare—went and entered the audience hall accompanied by a colonel and by prominent men of the city, and Festus called to have Paul brought out. %u@2%u@4Festus said, “King Agrippa and all the men who are joining us: see this fellow whom the overwhelming majority of Jews keep hitting me up about in Jerusalem and here as well, shouting that he must no longer live? %u@2%u@5I’ve been floored by the fact that nothing that he’s done deserves the death penalty, but this fellow %i@n%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s %i@i%i@n%i@v%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ appeal to the emperor, to have his case transferred there for trial. %u@2%u@6I don’t have anything definite to write down on this subject for the head-honcho; therefore I brought him before us and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that the inquiry which will take place now would result in something I can write %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@m%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e. %u@2%u@7The fact of the matter is, I think that sending a prisoner %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@m%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@o%i@r%i@ and not specifying the accusations against him is absurd.”%vn~
%sf~

%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@e…Lit: %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@y. An hendiadys; probably an expression too.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@f%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@s%i@i%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@w…Lit: %I@C%i@a%i@e%i@s%i@a%i@r. A metonymy.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@d%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@v%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@J%i@u%i@d%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@v%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n. Same expression in 24:27; ref. note there.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%I@I%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@w%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@l%i@d…Lit: %I@A%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@C%i@a%i@e%i@s%i@a%i@r%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@l%i@m%i@e%i@n…Lit: %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@l%i@y%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@c%i@u%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@s. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 26%hb~
          %u@1Agrippa said to Paul, “Are you allowed to speak for yourself?” Paul then put his hand up%u@[%u@a%u@] and proceeded to issue a rebuttal: %u@2“In regard to everything I’m accused of by the Jews, King Agrippa, I consider myself fortunate%u@[%u@b%u@] that I’m going to be giving a rebuttal before you today, %u@3especially with you being an expert in anything that has to do with the Jewish people and in their issues and disputes as well. Therefore, I ask %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ to patiently listen to me.%vn~
          %u@4”So now, all the Judeans have known firsthand the way I lived from the time I was a youth, %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@y what happened from the time it all started %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ among my fellow countrymen and %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ in Jerusalem, %u@5knowing me the entire time then. %I@W%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@ about it%i@ if they were put on the stand to testify is that I lived %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f a Pharisee, adhering to the strictness of our religion sect. %u@6At the moment I’m on trial standing %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@f%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f for the hope of our ancestors’ promises, which God %i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o come into being; %u@7for%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e%i@ which our %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@-%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@y%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ twelve tribes %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@, are hoping to attain, earnestly performing rituals of worship day and night; for a hope for which I’m defending myself from charges which the Jews are pressing, Your Highness%u@[%u@c%u@].%vn~
          %u@8”Why have you all decided that it’s too far-fetched to believe that there’s life after death, %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@i%i@s%i@s%u@[%u@d%u@]? %u@9Now—yes—I deemed it necessary to get personally involved in and actively participate in opposing everything Jesus of Nazareth stands for%u@[%u@e%u@], and I did this a lot. %u@1%u@0I did this in Jerusalem and had many of God’s very people%u@[%u@f%u@] locked up in prison, once I obtained the authority to do so from the chief priests, and I cast my vote for them to receive the death penalty. %u@1%u@1Going through all the synagogues one after another punishing them on many occasions, I kept trying to force them to renounce their faith, and, fuming with rage against them, I continuing persecuting them %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o neighboring cities.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2”Engaged in such affairs%u@[%u@g%u@], walking to Damascus with the authorization and permission of the chief priests with me, %u@1%u@3while on the road at noon, I saw, Your Highness, a light coming from the sky overhead—a light brighter than the sun—shine around me and around my fellow travellers. %u@1%u@4All of us fell flat on the ground, and I heard a voice say to me in Aramaic%u@[%u@h%u@], %r@“%R@S%r@a%r@u%r@l%r@,%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@u%r@l%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@c%r@u%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@?%r@ %R@I%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@w%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@A%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@.%r@” %u@1%u@5I said, “Who are you, sir?” The Lord said, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %R@J%r@e%r@s%r@u%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@c%r@u%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@E%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@—%r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@e%r@t%r@.%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@v%r@i%r@s%r@i%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@r%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@p%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@:%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@p%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@s%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@p%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@r%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@f%r@u%r@l%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@ %r@b%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@c%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@w%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@h%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@a%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%R@I%r@@%R@I%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@d%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@y%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@u%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@G%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@y%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@-%r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@r%r@k%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@g%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@b%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@n%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@g%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@B%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@c%r@e%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@p%r@i%r@e%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@i%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@m%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@p%r@a%r@r%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@%%r@i%r@@%r@t%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@o%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@ %r@%%R@I%r@@%R@H%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@i%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@m%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@s%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@e%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@l%r@%%r@i%r@@%r@f%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@[%r@%%R@U%r@@%R@C%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@]%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@a%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@9”As a result, King Agrippa, I was not left in a state of disobedience or disbelief by the heavenly vision. %u@2%u@0On the contrary—I proceeded to tell everyone %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ be changing %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r hearts and %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r ways%u@[%u@m%u@] and be turning to%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e close to God%u@[%U@B%u@] and to perform deeds reflective of%u@[%u@n%u@] a change of heart and of ways, first %i@t%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ to those in Damascus but not only to them but to those in Jerusalem, to the entire Judean countryside, and to the Gentiles. %u@2%u@1Because of all of this, the Judeans seized me when I was in the temple and proceeded to try to have me killed. %u@2%u@2So getting the help of %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@s%i@ from God up until this moment, I have taken a stand%u@[%u@o%u@] and am testifying in court today, letting the insignificant and the great as well know the truthfulness of what was going to happen, telling them nothing apart from what the prophets (and Moses too) spoke, %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s: %u@2%u@3#1%i@—The Messiah is capable of experiencing suffering; %i@#%i@2—A prototype of those who come back from the dead%u@[%u@p%u@] is going to announce to the %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@i folk-people and to the Gentiles%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ a light.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@4While he was %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@l making his rebuttal, Festus said loudly, “You’re crazy, Paul! All of that studying you’ve done reading all those books has driven you insane!”%vn~
          %u@2%u@5Paul said, “I’m not crazy, Your Excellency Festus, rather I’m uttering sentences consisting of the honest truth and of sanity. %u@2%u@6You see, the king, whom I’m speaking freely and in a straightforward way to, understands these %i@t%i@o%i@p%i@i%i@c%i@s. In fact I don’t believe that any of these %i@t%i@o%i@p%i@i%i@c%i@s are over his head; the fact is, this %i@n%i@e%i@w%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@g%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@‘%I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@’%i@ hasn’t been practiced in a way that it’s been kept in the closet.%u@[%u@q%u@] %u@2%u@7Do you believe, King Agrippa, in the Bible%u@[%u@r%u@]? From what I’ve seen, I know that you believe.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@8Agrippa %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ to Paul, “In a little %i@w%i@a%i@y%u@[%U@D%u@] you’re talking me into making %i@m%i@y%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ a Christian.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@9Paul %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@, “Would to God %I@I%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@u%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ in both a little %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ and in a big %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@,%i@ and not just you only but everyone who’s listening to me today, to become like me except for the shackles,” %u@3%u@0and the king, the governor & Bernice, and those seated with them got up, %u@3%u@1withdrew somewhere private, and proceeded to talk to one another saying that this man has committed nothing worthy of the death penalty or imprisonment. %u@3%u@2Agrippa said to Festus, “That fellow would’ve walked free had he not appealed %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ to Caesar.”%vn~

%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@k%i@-%i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e. Assumption is that %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ are Israelites, as the word is used this way in many places in the NT.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@i%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@i%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k…Lit: %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s…%i@a%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g…%i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@f%i@l%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@l%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@,%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d…Or: %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@l%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@,%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y. The text is ambiguous; both are true.%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@o%i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f [%i@t%i@h%i@e] %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@w%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@g%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@‘%I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@’%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@t…Lit: %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@r. Some liberties taken. Guessing that the %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ Paul’s refers to is Christianity.%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@B%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@s. Technically, the OT not including the Law.%fn~
%fn~
