%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@I%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@w%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@d%i@e…Lit: %I@I%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@t [or %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t] %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@d. Liberties taken. This is spuriously (but not erroneously) inserted in 9:5 in the Textus Receptus. The metaphor is of a steer or some other cattle being jabbed with a cattle prod: the more forceful the prod, the more it hurts the steer. When the steer kicks the prod, he hurts himself even more but doesn’t accomplish anything.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@c%i@l%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d…Lit: %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d. The appearance of the word %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ (%i@e%i@p%i@i%i@,%i@ ἐπί/Strong’s 1909)%i@ seems a bit idiomatic. The usage of %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n is the same as 25:9,26 where Festus asks Paul if he’d like to have the trial held “before me” (lit: %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@e), and%i@ where the word %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ (%i@e%i@p%i@i)%i@ is used twice in v. 26: “I brought him %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e us and especially %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e you%i@.” Other usages, however, like Luke 1:17, “to turn the hearts of the fathers to [epi] the children,” suggest exact proximity, as the base definition of %i@e%i@p%i@i%i@ suggests. Therefore, %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o is the chosen rendering.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@m%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f…Lit: %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@s [%i@s%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@-%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s]. Though this is somewhat ambiguous, the assumption is that by the context, the people separated to God refers to the Israelites.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y…Or: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e…Lit: %i@i%i@n [%i@a] %i@l%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@l%i@e, or, %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@l%i@e. Many scholars take this as a figure of speech or reject it in lieu of a different interpretation, one which isn’t obvious. Some render it %i@a%i@l%i@m%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@,%i@ while others render it %i@h%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@l%i@y. I see no reason not to render the remark literally, however.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 27%hb~
          %u@1As it was decided that we would sail to Italy%u@[%u@a%u@], they proceeded to transfer custody of Paul and some other prisoners to a centurion named Julius, a member of the Imperial Battalion%u@[%u@b%u@]. %u@2We boarded a ship in Adramyttium which was about to sail down the Turkish%u@[%u@c%u@] coast and hoisted sail, while Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica, accompanied us. %u@3The next day we stopped at Sidon. Julius did a kind deed for Paul and permitted him to go to his friends and receive care for his health. %u@4From there we set out to sea and sailed the long way, on the eastern side of Cyprus, because the winds were against us, %u@5sailed through the deep water off the coast of Cilicia and Pamphylia, and arrived at %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ Myra in Lycia. %u@6There, the centurion found an Alexandrian ship sailing to Italy, and we boarded it. %u@7After several days of making slow headway, we showed up over in Cnidus. Because the wind wasn’t in our favor, we sailed the long way around Crete down the coast of Salmone %u@8and with difficulty sailed along the coast and came to some place called Fair Havens, which is near a town called Lasea.%vn~
          %u@9As a good amount of time had gone by, and it being dangerous to travel %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@M%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@ %I@S%i@e%i@a%i@ because the Day of Atonement was already past (%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@, %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s %i@a%i@l%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l), Paul kept on urging, %u@1%u@0“Men, I’m looking at %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@n%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@,%i@ that there’s going to be damage and much loss—not only to the cargo and the ship but of our lives—on the voyage.” %u@1%u@1But the centurion was persuaded more by %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t the helmsman and the captain %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ than by what Paul was saying. %u@1%u@2Now since the harbor there was unsuitable for passing the winter, the majority decided to hoist sail and leave, if perchance they could make it to Phoenix and pass the winter there, which is a harbor in Crete which faces southwest and has a northwesterly wind.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3The south wind blew gently; thinking that they had a window of opportunity, they lifted anchor and proceeded to sail along the coast of Crete. %u@1%u@4But not long after, a hurricane called a “Northeasterly” came down from %I@C%i@r%i@e%i@t%i@e and plowed into them. %u@1%u@5As the ship was caught in the wind%i@ and couldn’t withstand it, they %i@l%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@l%i@s%i@ and drifted. %u@1%u@6Running under the protection of a small island called Cauda, we were just barely able to get the ship under control %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@s%i@m%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@c%i@k%i@s%i@.%i@ %u@1%u@7When they raised the waterline of the hull, they used cables to support the %i@w%i@e%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e ship and hold it together. Afraid that they might run aground on the banks of Syrtis, they lowered the anchor and were driven about while configured this way.%vn~
          %u@1%u@8Battered by the storm, the next day we proceeded to jettison boxes, jars, and cargo containers overboard, %u@1%u@9and on the third day we pitched gear and tackle. %u@2%u@0With neither the sun nor the stars shining for many days and %i@a%i@s%i@ no small hurricane was raging, we abandoned%u@[%u@d%u@] all hope of survival, %u@2%u@1and having gone without food for a long time, Paul stood up, had them gather around, and said, “Oh you guys%u@[%u@e%u@]—you really should’ve listened to me and done as I told you and not put out to sea in Crete, and none of this damage and loss would’ve happened. %u@2%u@2But now I advise you to cheer up; the fact is, none of you is going to lose his life—but the ship will be lost. %u@2%u@3You see, last night an angel of God%u@[%U@B%u@], whose I am and whom I serve and worship, stood by me %u@2%u@4saying, ‘Don’t be afraid%u@[%u@f%u@], Paul. You must appear before Caesar. And—get ahold of this%u@[%u@g%u@]—God has graciously and freely given a gift to you: %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f all those sailing with you.’ %u@2%u@5With this in mind, cheer up, men. You see, I believe in God, that %I@H%i@e%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ it turn out just the way the angel has spoken when he spoke to me. %u@2%u@6But we’ll have to run aground on some island.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@7Now as the fourteenth night came around, we were drifting about the Adriatic Sea, and about midnight the sailors began to suspect that they were nearing land. %u@2%u@8After sounding the depth by dropping a line with a lead weight, we measured a depth of twenty fathoms (120ft/37m). A short while later, we measured fifteen (90ft/27m), %u@2%u@9and fearing that we’d smash against the rocks, we cast four anchors off the ship’s stern and began to %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d pray for day to come. %u@3%u@0Trying to flee the ship, the sailors lowered the ship’s utility boat into the water, pretending that they were going to extend the bow’s anchor %i@l%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@s. %u@3%u@1Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, “If those guys don’t stay in the ship, you won’t survive.” %u@3%u@2The soldiers then cut the utility boat’s ropes and let it be driven away.%vn~
          %u@3%u@3Up until daylight was about to appear, Paul kept on encouraging everyone to have something to eat saying, “It’s been fourteen days of waiting it out now, and we haven’t eaten anything. %u@3%u@4With this in mind, I encourage you all to put some food in your stomach, as this is for your own well-being and could save your life. Fact is, not a single one of the hairs on your head will be lost%u@[%U@C%u@].” %u@3%u@5After he said this, he took a loaf of bread, offered thanks to God in front of everyone %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@,%i@ broke it, and began to eat. %u@3%u@6Everyone cheered up and partook of food. %u@3%u@7All totaled, there were 276 of us onboard the ship. %u@3%u@8After they’d eaten, they lightened the ship by throwing the %i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f wheat %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@b%i@o%i@a%i@r%i@d into the water.%vn~
          %u@3%u@9When daylight broke, they %i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ weren’t making out any land %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@c%i@k%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@e, but they started to notice a bay which had a %i@s%i@u%i@i%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ beach, and they got together and decided that it might be possible to run the ship aground on it. %u@4%u@0They cut the anchors loose and let them %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@t%i@t%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ sea and at the same time disconnected the rudder controls from the rudder, hoisted the foresail to utilize the wind, and headed for the beach. %u@4%u@1They encountered a place where two bodies of water converge and ran the ship aground. While the bow stayed firmly planted, the aft on the other hand began to break off %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p%i@ due to the force of the waves. %u@4%u@2A plan was put together by the soldiers to kill the prisoners, lest any one of them escape by swimming away, %u@4%u@3but wanting Paul to survive, the centurion thwarted their plan by first of all ordering those who are able to swim to the shore to jump overboard and get away, %u@4%u@4and for the others to get on a plank or something-or-another from the ship %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@d%i@d%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@e. And this was the way that everyone made it to dry ground and survived.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%I@I%i@t%i@a%i@l%i@y…Lit: %I@I%i@t%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@a. The Roman province of Italia, as there was no “Italy” at that time.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@B%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@c%i@o%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@T%i@u%i@r%i@k%i@i%i@s%i@h…Lit: %I@A%i@s%i@i%i@a%i@n. The Roman province of Asia.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@a%i@b%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@d…Same word as used in v. 40 to describe the cutting loose of the anchors%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%I@O%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@g%i@u%i@y%i@s…Lit: %i@o%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%I@D%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@d…The Gk. verb tense insinuates that Paul was not afraid at the time the angel spoke to him, but is being encouraged not to fall into it.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@d; %i@l%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@d%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@t %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@n…Lit: %i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@t; %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@d. The common Gk. word %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ō%i@r%i@e%i@ō%i@ (θεωρέω /Strong’s 2334) is used here but in an uncommon way.%i@ Since the voyage had not yet taken place and since Paul had seen something, one may deduce that Paul had some sort of premonition in which he saw what was going to take place.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d…Generally speaking, the GT of the NT refers to an angel as an “angel of the Lord,” “angel of God,” etc., instead of simply “angel.” This is done to clarify the ambiguity between an angel and a messenger, as the word means either. But in English, we simply say “angel” instead of the word-for-word rendering “angel of the Lord.” But in v. 23, Paul takes opportunity of the word %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ to add appositives to which describe his relationship with Him.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@s%i@t…Seeing that there were over two hundred who had to endure the storm and swim to shore, the likelihood that none of them lost a single strand of hair is slim. Therefore, Paul’s remark here is an expression, a figure of speech, and not to be taken literally. From the sounds of it, this is the same expression as is found in Matt. 10:30; Luke 12:7; what Jesus said there can also be understood as an expression and is not to be taken literally.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Acts Chapter 28%hb~
          %u@1Once we were safe, we came to the understanding that the island’s called Malta, %u@2and the natives began to shower us with an inordinate amount of kindness: you see, on account of the sudden rain coming down on us and the cold, they lit a fire and welcomed every one of us. %u@3When Paul gathered a bunch of sticks and put them on the fire, a viper fled the heat, %i@s%i@u%i@n%i@k%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@,%i@ and%i@ latched onto his hand. %u@4As the natives saw the viper hanging off his hand, they began to say to one another, “This guy definitely was a murderer. He escaped the sea but justice didn’t allow him to live.” %u@5So then he shook the viper off into the fire and nothing bad happened to him. %u@6They kept waiting for him to swell up soon or drop dead suddenly. While they were waiting and looking, nothing unusual happened to him, and they changed their minds and began to say that he’s a god.%vn~
          %u@7In the area that surrounds that place that they were at was a piece of property that belonged to the most prominent person%u@[%u@a%u@] on the island, a man by the name of Publius. He took us into his house for three days, extending hospitality to us strangers. %u@8Publius’s father came down with %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@ fever and dysentery which kept forcing%u@[%u@b%u@] him to lie down. Paul went over to him, became acquainted with him%u@[%u@c%u@], prayed, laid his hands on him, and healed him. %u@9When this happened, everyone else on the island who was run down with maladies of some sort%u@[%u@d%u@] started coming to him and was being healed or otherwise treated%u@[%u@e%u@]. %u@1%u@0They gave us many donatives as an allowance%u@[%U@A%u@], and while we were putting out to sea, they put necessities on %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1Three months later we put out to sea in a ship that had wintered on the island of Alexandrian, a ship called “Gemini%u@[%u@f%u@].” %u@1%u@2After we went up to Syracuse, we stayed there for three days. %u@1%u@3From there we sailed the circuit%u@[%U@B%u@] and arrived in Rhegium. After one day elapsed, a wind came up from the south, and after a second day, we went to Puteoli, %u@1%u@4where we found fellow-comrades%u@[%u@g%u@], and they cordially invited us%u@[%u@h%u@] to stay for seven days. This is the way we arrived in Rome: %u@1%u@5The comrades then heard what happened to us and went all the way down to the Forum of Appius and the Three Taverns to meet us. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and strengthened his nerve and stiffened his composure%u@[%u@i%u@]. %u@1%u@6Now when we entered Rome, Paul was given permission to live by himself and with his guard-soldier.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7What occurred three days later is that he summoned the leading Jews together. Once they got together, he proceeded to tell them, “Men, comrades, I, a prisoner who was handed over to the Romans back in Jerusalem, did nothing which was against the %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@i folk-people or the customs of our forefathers. %u@1%u@8The very people who examined me kept wishing to set me free because there was no charge which I was inherently guilty of which warranted death. %u@1%u@9Facing opposition from the Judeans, I was forced to appeal %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ to Caesar—not that I had any charges to press against my fellow countrymen. %u@2%u@0So I made the request to see you and to talk to you for this reason: you see, it’s because of the hope of Israel I’m wearing these chains.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@1They said, “We have neither received anything in writing about you from the Judeans, nor have any one of the comrades showed up informing us of anything %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@ or saying something bad about you. %u@2%u@2We would like to hear from you, %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@u%i@s what your thoughts are; for we certainly do know that this sect %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ is spoken against by everyone.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@3They reserved a day for him, and many went to visit him and were treated to his hospitality, guests to whom he kept on expounding %i@a%i@n%i@d solemnly stating the truthfulness of%u@[%u@j%u@] God’s interaction with mankind (God’s kingdom) and making persuasive arguments for them %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n %i@v%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ about%i@ Jesus and %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@v%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s from the Old Testament%u@[%u@k%u@] from early %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%i@ until evening. %u@2%u@4With %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g logical arguments, they indeed kept being agreeable to his propositions and conceding his points%u@[%u@l%u@], but %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ they refused to act in faith and believe. %u@2%u@5While in a state of disagreement with one another, they were %i@p%i@o%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@y told it was time to leave%u@[%u@m%u@] after Paul made a remark in which he said that the Holy Spirit put it beautifully when he spoke to our ancestors through the prophet Isaiah,%vn~
%si~
%u@2%u@6“Go to this people and say,%vp~
‘You will hear news of %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@,%vp~
But there’s no way at all that you’ll understand it,%vp~
And while looking at %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g, you will see it,%vp~
But there’s no way at all that you’ll gaze %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@.%vp~
%u@2%u@7The fact is, this people’s %i@c%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ heart became lethargic,%vp~
And with difficulty they heard %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ with their ears,%vp~
And they’ve closed their eyes,%vp~
Lest they, while using %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r eyes, might gaze %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%vp~
And, while using %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r ears, might hear %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@,%vp~
And would understand in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r heart %vp~
And would redirect their lives in the right way%u@[%u@n%u@],%vp~
And I will heal them %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@o.’%vp~
%si~
%u@2%u@8”So let it be known to you all that this rescue program%u@[%u@o%u@] of God’s was sent to the Gentiles; they especially will listen to it.” %u@2%u@9%u@[%U@C%u@]%nn~
          %u@3%u@0He lived on his own in a rented house for an entire two years, and welcomed as guests%u@[%u@p%u@] anyone coming to interact with him in a friendly visit%u@[%u@q%u@], %u@3%u@1preaching how God interacts with mankind (God’s kingdom) and teaching various things about the Lord Jesus Christ, preaching and teaching unhindered with total boldness and confidence.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@m%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@l%i@a%i@n%i@d. Perhaps specific to Malta only, or used when a place has no name for the office their leaders occupy.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@,%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@q%i@u%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m…Lit: %I@P%i@a%i@u%i@l%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. An idiom; ref. note of 19:8.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@r%i@u%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@l%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t…Lit: %i@w%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@s. Ref. note of Matt. 4:23%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@w%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d…Or: %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@d. Ref. note of Matt. 4:23 (a different note than previous ref.).%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@“%I@G%i@e%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@”…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@g%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ %I@D%i@i%i@o%i@s%i@c%i@u%i@r%i@i. Dioscuri is another name for Castor and Pollux, the Gemini twins.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@-%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@v%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@s…Lit: %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@g%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@g%i@e. The word %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@g%i@e here is derived from the same verb Jesus used when he encountered the disciples while walking on water (Mark 6:50) and has the same meaning.%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@m%i@n%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@a%i@g%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@u%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y…Lit: %i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@w%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@g%i@r%i@a%i@m…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@l%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@l%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@s…Lit: %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@t…Lit: %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m. This is an idiom; ref. note of Acts 19:8.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e…Lit: %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@s. In this context, the Gk. words %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@ and %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@ draws on a secondary definition which the lexicon says is “a reward, present” (the multi-faceted meaning propagated to the English %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r vs. %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@u%i@m). This is in the form of a monetary obligation, pay, or entitlement. That the usage here of %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@ refers to contributing financially is supported by these three facts: First, the words %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@ insinuate something which is quantitative (cash or items) rather than qualitative (honor or respect). Second, the latter half of v. 10 (“put necessities on the ship”) also concerns itself with giving material goods. Third, the word %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@ is also used this way in 1 Tim. 5:17.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@s%i@a%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@i%i@t…Some disagreement in the wording of various Gk. manuscripts here, and some conjecture from bible scholars as to what exactly Luke means. I’m guessing that this refers to ships that shuttled from town to town on short hops which were on a fixed and repeated schedule, competing with one another one prices, etc., sort of like how airlines offer flights and compete with one another.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]Verse 29 omitted from the better manuscripts%fn~
%i@%sb~

Romans%ha~
       Paul, the great pioneer of Christianity, the great theologian of Christian doctrine, makes a treatise out of the first half of this long letter to the Romans. %nv~
       The combination of Paul’s mastery of Greek., the customizing of his writing to a non-Jewish audience, and his lucid prose make it easy on the translator, as his works can be translated nearly word-for-word and the result be intelligible enough to serve as the final rendering. Therefore, if one compares various works of translations, even the ones which deviate from the traditional, literal rendering, one finds that the translations are similar. Paul uses his powerful vocabulary and understanding of the grammar to pack nuances into a pithy text, rather than relying on figures of speech like a few of the other NT writers do.%nv~
       Reasoning, philosophy, and the ability to look at various aspects of difficult questions are Paul’s bread & butter. Whereas Jesus’s teachings are remarkably insightful, Paul’s teachings are remarkably philosophical—and the first half of Romans is the pinnacle of this. Paul takes the reader on a long, single thread until the ninth chapter, when he finally segues to another.%nv~
       Since Romans delves into such thought-provoking theological and philosophical topics, the approach in translation is akin to the Amplified Bible, a compromise between preserving the literal wording and clarifying the end-result. As an analogy, scholars say that the writings of the philosopher Immanuel Kant should not be read directly by someone unschooled in the philosophical terminology Kant uses, as they will not understand it. This is partly the case with Romans also, as Paul’s multi-faceted meaning of his use of, for example, the word %i@l%i@a%i@w%i@ in conjunction with his inclusion or omission of the definite article is over the head of the unschooled reader, compounded by the fact that most translations don’t propagate through to the rendered version the inclusion or exclusion the definite article on a word-for-word basis anyways, as the final product in English would be awkward at best.%nv~
       To ameliorate this, I’ve preferred a word-for-word rendering of the definite article before %i@l%i@a%i@w%i@ and %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@ in particular and before other words as well because I believe that this is valuable information that Paul is communicating, that it has a large impact on what he’s trying to convey, and that it’s essential that the reader get this “unfiltered.” But by doing so, I must sacrifice some readability for clarity. To compensate and to fully explain the meaning of the preceding word in conjunction with its optionally-included article, immediately following, I add an explanation inside of parenthesis and set off by %i@i%i@.%i@e. Generally speaking, if the next occurrence of the word in the same chapter merits the same explanatory phrase, I omit the parenthetical note for brevity’s sake, assuming that the reader will understand that it’s the same as the previous.%nv~
%i@%sb~
Romans Chapter 1%hb~
          %u@1Paul, servant of Christ Jesus, called as a missionary%u@[%u@a%u@], designated to God’s good news—the Gospel, %u@2what He promised before over and over through His prophets in the Old Testament%u@[%u@b%u@] %u@3about His son, who—physically speaking—came into being through the lineage of David, %u@4who was declared in a powerful way to be God’s son according to the Holy Spirit due to the resurrection from the dead, %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@y Jesus Christ our Lord, %u@5through whom we’ve received grace and have received a missionary assignment that has the end-goal of obedience—a consequence of faith—among all the Gentiles and the far-off nations on behalf of all he stands for%u@[%u@c%u@], %u@6by which you too are called by Jesus Christ:%vn~
          %u@7To God’s beloved who are holy and called %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ who are in Rome: Grace %i@b%i@e%i@ to you—and peace—from the Father-God and the Lord Jesus Christ.%vn~
          %u@8First and foremost, concerning you I thank my God through Jesus Christ, that the word is being spread about your faith throughout the entire world. %u@9In fact, God is my witness, whom I offer a service of worship to in my spirit in the evangelization of his son, as I’m constantly making mention of you %u@1%u@0every time I offer up prayers, asking if somehow, sometime, I will have succeeded by the will of God in visiting you. %u@1%u@1The fact of the matter is that I long to see you so that I might bestow on you a spiritual gift, a gift whose goal is to establish you. %u@1%u@2This %i@b%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@f%i@t%i@ is %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ to take comfort together with you through the faith shared between you and me.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3I don’t want you to be left in the dark, comrades%u@[%u@d%u@], that I purposed many times to come to you, but I was prevented %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ up until now, so that I would %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@u%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ to observe the germination and growth of tangible signs of maturity%u@[%u@e%u@] among you as well just I observed it in the other Gentiles— %u@1%u@4I’m in debt not just to the civilized but to the uncivilized%u@[%u@f%u@] also, to not just the wise but to the foolish also. %u@1%u@5This is what motivates me to evangelize to you too who are in Rome.%vn~
          %u@1%u@6The fact of the matter is, I’m not ashamed of the Gospel, for it’s God’s power in all those who believe for them to end up with salvation (i.e., the state of being kept from from spiritual, moral, mental, and physical calamity)—and not just the Jews but the non-Jewish Westerners%u@[%u@g%u@] as well. %u@1%u@7For in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@l%i@ God’s righteousness (i.e., God’s requirements of how a person must lead his life in order to please Him and be approved by Him) is revealed out of faith and %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k into faith, just as it’s been written %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@,%i@ “The one who’s righteous (i.e., the one whose life is to be approved by God) shall live out of faith.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@8You see, God’s wrath is unfurled from up in the sky, up in heaven, upon ungodliness and unrighteousness %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ people who withhold the truth in and by their unrighteousness, %u@1%u@9%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@f%i@u%i@r%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ because the knowledge of God has appeared and been made known to them. %u@2%u@0To this point, from the inception of human society, His invisible aspects (that is, His everlasting power and divine nature) have been clearly seen and understood by means of the things which were created, resulting in %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@ being without excuse. %u@2%u@1Therefore, while knowing and understanding God, they didn’t glorify or thank %I@H%i@i%i@m%i@ as God, but became empty-headed in their reasonings instead, and their non-understanding heart darkened. %u@2%u@2Asserting to be wise, they became idiots %u@2%u@3and exchanged the glory of the Immortal God for the facsimile of a Mortal Human and of animals%u@[%u@h%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@4So for the aforementioned reasons, %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ in the desires of their hearts, God handed them over to dirty and disgusting unholy things%u@[%u@i%u@] in dishonoring and disgracing their bodies among themselves, %u@2%u@5the very people who, %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ in the %i@a%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ lie, swapped the truth of God and worshipped and held religious services for the creature, circumventing the Creator, the One who is forever blessed (and let us pause a moment for that to sink in%u@[%u@j%u@]).%vn~
          %u@2%u@6On account of this, God handed them over to an unnatural, disgraceful, excruciating passion %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@.%i@ In this regard, both the women%u@[%U@A%u@] swapped the Natural Function for that which circumvents what comes naturally; %u@2%u@7and the men%u@[%U@A%u@] too—and in the same manner—leaving the Natural Function of the woman, burning in their longing for one another, men perpetrating the disgraceful deed with%u@[%u@k%u@] men and receiving the corresponding reward which they have coming to them and which they were bound to receive due to their error, %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@r%i@r%i@o%i@r %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o among themselves.%vn~
          %u@2%u@8And just as they did not approve of retaining the accumulated knowledge and understanding of God, God handed them over to an unapproved mind, to do what is not fitting to do, %u@2%u@9having been filled to the brim with every kind of unrighteousness: with wickedness, greed, malice, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e full of envy, murder, strife, Machiavellian-styled rivalry, malevolence; %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ gossips and slanderers, %u@3%u@0trash-talkers, God-haters; %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ insolent people, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ arrogant, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ braggarts, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ dream up evil, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ rebel against %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ parents, %u@3%u@1%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ dull-witted, treacherous, without the natural affection one has for parents, children, nation, etc.; %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e unmerciful— %u@3%u@2The very people who know and understand God’s righteous precepts exactly, that those who practice such things deserve to die—not only do they do these things, but they’re in lockstep-agreement and think highly of those who practice them.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@m%i@i%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@r%i@y…Lit: %i@a%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@l%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@p%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r…Lit: %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@u%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@b%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@r%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y…Lit: %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@u%i@i%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@B%i@a%i@r%i@b%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@n%i@o%i@n%i@-%I@J%i@e%i@w%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@ %I@W%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %I@G%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@i%i@r%i@d%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@-%i@l%i@e%i@g%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@s. The NT writers enumerated categories that we simply place under the umbrella of %i@a%i@n%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@s%i@.%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@d%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@g%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s…Lit: %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@ %i@i%i@n…Lit: %i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@.%i@ Ref. note of Rev. 19:4.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h…Also: %i@i%i@n. The word ordering was also moved, as the GT reads %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ or %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@.%i@%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n…%i@m%i@e%i@n…In the GT, Paul uses the archaic versions of these words, the versions found in the LXX quotation of Gen. 5:2, “He made them man and woman, husband and wife.” These are the same words used in the embedded Gen. 5:2 quotations in Matt. 19:4 an Mark 6:6. By selecting the same words as found in Gen. 5:2, instead of choosing the more commonly used Gk. words for %i@m%i@e%i@n and %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n, Paul is signaling that the statements he makes in vv. 26,27 are based on Gen. 5:2.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Romans Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1…Which leads to this: who do you think you are, you who%u@[%u@a%u@] pronounces judgment %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s (i.e., draws conclusions about others for the purpose of writing them off)%u@[%u@b%u@]?—There’s no excuse %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s. The fact is, in the %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@a in which you judge another, you condemn yourself, for the one who’s doing the judging practices the same thing%u@[%U@A%u@]. %u@2Now we know for a fact that God renders a %i@g%i@u%i@i%i@l%i@t%i@y verdict in line with the truth against those who practice such things. %u@3You rascal%u@[%u@c%u@], you who commits %i@s%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@s and practices such things—do you figure that you’ll evade God’s judgment? %u@4Or while despising the riches of His goodness, forbearance and patience, you’re unaware that the goodness of God leads one to repentance (i.e., to change one’s heart and one’s ways)? %u@5But in accordance with your hard—%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t unrepentant—heart, you’re accumulating your own %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d-wrath %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@g%i@u%i@r%i@g%i@i%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d on that date when wrath is unveiled and readily distributed, the day of God’s righteous judgment, %u@6Who “will repay every person according to what that person’s done.” %u@7On the one hand to those who, in accordance with a consistent pattern of good works, seek after glory, honor, and immortality, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@y%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ eternal life. %u@8But on the other hand, to those who, out of %i@a%i@n %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@ to%i@ promote themselves by buying influence %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ and out of not being persuaded and being disobedience to the Truth but are convinced %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ unrighteousness %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@y%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ wrath and an outburst of rage— %u@9Distress and anguish for every last person%u@[%u@d%u@] who leads a life of evil, Jews at a higher level and non-Jewish Westerners %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m.%u@[%U@B%u@] %u@1%u@0But glory, honor, and peace to all who lead a life of good, Jews at a higher level and Westerners %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m. %u@1%u@1The fact of the matter is that God shows no favoritism.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2You see, anyone at all%u@[%u@e%u@] who sinned without the benefit of possessing a law (i.e., a list of God’s rules) will perish; and anyone at all who sins while %i@i%i@m%i@m%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@d in a law will be judged by %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ law. %u@1%u@3To be clear, it’s not the ones who have heard a law %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@ who are right with God, but the ones who put a law into practice will be pronounced righteous %i@b%i@y%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4To this point, when the Gentiles who don’t have a law (i.e., a list of God’s rules) instinctively do the things of the Law%i@ (i.e., the definitive, comprehensive list of God’s rules, which is the Law of Moses), they, %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ not possessing the Law, are a law (i.e., a set of God-given rules) for%u@[%u@f%u@] themselves. %u@1%u@5These particular people point out what the law written in their hearts (i.e., their particular list of God’s rules written in their hearts) has accomplished—%i@a%i@n%i@d while %i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ their consciences join in and testify even %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@b%i@i%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ between the various differing rationales condemning or defending— %u@1%u@6on whatever day it happens to be when God judges the hidden things of mankind through Christ Jesus according to my positive message—my Gospel.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7Now if you call yourself a Jew and are fixated on law (i.e., mankind possessing and putting into practice the definitive list of God’s rules), boast over (i.e., take pride in; swagger over; loudly extol the virtues of; defend vociferously) %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ God, %u@1%u@8know the will %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d,%i@ and accept or reject the differing oral traditions %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ from%i@ the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%u@[%U@C%u@]— %u@1%u@9and all these to the extent that you’ve convinced yourself that you’ve reached the point where you’re a guide to the blind, a light in darkness, %u@2%u@0a trainer to the foolish, a teacher to the young, possessing in the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s the embodiment of the knowledge and the truth %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d— %u@2%u@1so now, does the one who’s teaching someone else teach himself %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g? Does the one who preaches %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ not to steal steal %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f? %u@2%u@2Does the one who says “don’t commit adultery” commit adultery? Is the one who abhors idols a temple robber? %u@2%u@3Does the one who boasts in law (i.e., takes pride in—to the point of bragging about—his ability to follow the list of God’s rules) dishonor God by the transgression of the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s? %u@2%u@4In fact, “God’s reputation%u@[%u@g%u@] is slandered among the Gentiles because of you,” like it says in the Bible%u@[%u@h%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@5The fact of the matter is that—yes—circumcision (i.e., committing one’s life to following the Law of Moses) is beneficial if one were to put %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ into practice, but if one were to transgress the Law, his circumcision will have become uncircumcision (i.e., as though he never committed himself to follow the Law of Moses). %u@2%u@6So if the %i@a%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@y%i@p%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@ circumcised man were to keep the edicts of the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s, wouldn’t his uncircumcision count as circumcision? %u@2%u@7And the physically-uncircumcised man who satisfies %i@t%i@h%i@e %i@r%i@e%i@q%i@u%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ will judge you, the %i@q%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@l transgressor of law (i.e., one who doesn’t fulfill the requirements of the list of edicts given by God), a transgressor in the midst of having a verbatim copy of God’s edicts and by having signed up to comply with those edicts%u@[%u@i%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@8You see, a person is not Jewish because he appears Jewish on the outside, nor is circumcision a physical characteristic, %u@2%u@9but rather one is Jewish by virtue of what’s on the inside, and circumcision is of the heart %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ by %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Spirit not by the letter (i.e., by the rigid interpretation and application of God’s edicts); that person’s praise is not from people but from God.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o…Lit: %i@o%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@(%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@a%i@w%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@)…Also: %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@s. Ref. note of Matt. 7:1.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@s%i@c%i@a%i@l…Lit: %i@o%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@ [%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n]%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n. The word %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@ means %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ in this context.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l…In the GT this is actually plural, not singular%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@r…Or: %i@i%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@u%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@B%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@d%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@b%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@p%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@m%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g…Paul’s referring to a curious psychological condition I’ll call “The Jimmy Swaggert Phenomenon.” The TV evangelist in his heyday in the ‘80’s was calling out other ministers for their sexual sins while at the same time visiting prostitutes. What Paul is saying here is that, generally speaking, people tend to judge others in the same areas they are guilty of themselves.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@J%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@n%i@-%I@J%i@e%i@w%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@ %I@W%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m…Lit: %I@J%i@e%i@w%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@G%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@k. Since Jews were God’s chosen people and since they were given the word of God, Paul’s saying that judgment will be harsher on them. But on the flip side, v. 10 says that Jews will receive a higher level of glory, honor, and peace for the same reason.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@a%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@-%i@b%i@y%i@-%i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@-%i@o%i@f%i@-%i@m%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w. This might be a reference to the Oral Torah, which evolved into the Mishnah.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Romans Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1So what’s so much better about being Jewish? Put another way,%i@ what’s the advantage of being circumcised (i.e., being in a covenant to obey the Law of Moses)? %u@2Much and in many ways. First—certainly first—is that they were entrusted with %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@f%i@e%i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ God’s words%u@[%U@A%u@]. %u@3So now, what if some of them refused to have faith and believe? Does their refusal to believe cancel God’s faithfulness?— %u@4Don’t even think about it; think this instead%u@[%U@B%u@]: God is true, but every person is a liar, just like it’s written,%vn~
%si~
…So You’d be absolutely right in Your words%vp~
And come out on top in Your judgments%vp~
%si~
          %u@5Now if our unrighteousness causes us to become aligned with the righteousness of God, what’s the takeaway%u@[%u@a%u@]? It isn’t that God, Who brings the wrath %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h %I@H%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ upon %i@s%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@s,%i@ is unfair? (I’m talking %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@“%i@u%i@n%i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@” in terms of human standards %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r.%u@[%u@b%u@]) %u@6Don’t even think about it%u@[%u@c%u@]—otherwise, how will God judge the world (i.e., those who are a part of the ungodly society which mankind formed)? %u@7But if in the My Fraud Falsehood the truth of God proliferates to His glory, why am I still being judged like %I@I%i@’%i@m a sinner, %u@8and not %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@ according to the way in which we’re being slandered, in which some people are saying that our position is: let’s do these things here which are%i@ evil%u@[%u@d%u@] in order that these things here which are good will come? Their condemnation %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@-%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n is justified.%vn~
          %u@9What then? Do we have an advantage? Not entirely. The fact is, we Jews—and throw in all Westerners%u@[%u@e%u@] too—have been pre-indicted%u@[%u@f%u@] for being dominated%u@[%u@g%u@] by sin, %u@1%u@0just like it’s recorded in Scripture:%vn~
%si~
There is no person who’s righteous—not one.%vp~
%u@1%u@1There’s no person who understands.%vp~
No one seeks out God.%vp~
%u@1%u@2All of them veered off %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n;%vp~
The whole lot of them is useless.%vp~
There’s no one who does good%vp~
—Not even a single person.%vp~
%u@1%u@3Their throat is an open grave.%vp~
They deceive %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ with their tongues.%vp~
Cobra venom is under their lips, %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@p%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@%vp~
%u@1%u@4Whose mouth cusses and has a bitter taste in it.%vp~
%u@1%u@5Their feet are keen to shed blood%vp~
(i.e., they are acutely prone to shed blood).%vp~
%u@1%u@6Ruin and misery is in their paths%vp~
(i.e., for them, ruin and misery is inevitable and unavoidable),%vp~
%u@1%u@7And they haven’t discerned a path of peace,%vp~
%u@1%u@8There is no fear of God directly in front of their eyes%vp~
(i.e., their hearts’ desire is not fascinated%vp~
by a deep reverence for God).%vp~
%si~
%u@1%u@9Now we know that, to the extent to which the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ touches on points, it addresses those who’re %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@c%i@k%i@ in the Law, so that everyone would be left with nothing to say%u@[%u@h%u@] and the entire world (i.e., the entire established order of humanity) would become accountable to God. %u@2%u@0Therefore, what comes out of works of law (i.e., an attempt to perform the deeds which satisfy the requirements mandated by a list of God-given rules) is that not a single living being%u@[%u@i%u@] will be justified before Him (i.e., declared “not guilty” in a court of law presided over by God as judge); the fact is, through law comes a%i@ recognition and a precise knowledge and understanding of sin.%nn~
          %u@2%u@1But as it turns out, righteousness of God (i.e., a venue whereby God will approve of how one conducts his life) has been manifested apart from law (i.e., the reliance on pleasing God solely based on obeying His list of rules), %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ is showcased%u@[%u@j%u@] by the Old Testament%u@[%u@k%u@], %u@2%u@2a righteousness of God through Jesus Christ-faith to all who believe: there is no distinction, you see: %u@2%u@3For all have sinned and come up short of the glory of God, %u@2%u@4while %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d a gift of being justified by His grace through the redemption (i.e., the restoring of a person to his original, proper, and designated place) in Christ Jesus, %u@2%u@5whom God determined before it all started to be a propitiation (i.e., a means of redemption) through faith in his blood resulting in a demonstration of His righteousness by the overlooking of the previously-committed sins %u@2%u@6by the forbearance of God coupled with the demonstration of His righteousness in the present time, resulting in Him being just and justifying a given person out of and as a byproduct of Jesus-faith.%vn~
          %u@2%u@7So where is the boaster (i.e., the one who brags about his own accomplishments)?—he’s been shut out. Through what sort of law (i.e., method of attaining righteousness with God)? %I@T%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h the works%i@-%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@d?—No, but rather through a law (i.e. method) of faith. %u@2%u@8You see, we figure that a person’s justified by faith apart from works of law (i.e. a method of works). %u@2%u@9Is God the Jews’ God only? Isn’t He the Gentiles’ God too—Yes, %I@H%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ the Gentiles’ God too, %u@3%u@0if one assumes that there is only one true God and that this God is of one mind and has His own will, and there is no other being comparable to Him%u@[%u@l%u@], a God who will justify a circumcised man (i.e., a person who’s in a covenant to obey the Law of Moses) as a result of%u@[%u@m%u@] faith and an uncircumcised man by means of the %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ faith. %u@3%u@1Is law (i.e., the expectation of having to obey the list of God’s rules) preempted through faith? Don’t even think about it—on the contrary: law is established.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@l%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@“%i@u%i@n%i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@”%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@r%i@m%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@…Lit: %I@I%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@D%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@t…Ref. note of v. 4%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@/%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@/%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %I@W%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: all %I@G%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@-%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y…Lit: %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@s%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@…Lit: %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@h. A figure of speech. Also used in Matt. 24:22.%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@s%i@h%i@o%i@w%i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@d%u@ %u@%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@P%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@m…Lit: %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %I@O%i@n%i@e. Ref. note of James 2:19.%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@f%i@e%i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d. For all the sins of nation of Israel that we read about in the OT, they got a couple of things right, one of which is the Masoretic Text—the culmination of their careful keeping of God’s words.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@D%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@;%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@a%i@d…Lit: %i@m%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@-%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@-%i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@;%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@-%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@-%i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@e. Paul’s uses the Gk. verb %i@g%i@i%i@n%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@i%i@ (γίνομαι/Strong’s 1096) [%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@-%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@-%i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g] twice here. The first usage is in an expression (“may it never %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@-%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@-%i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g”); the second usage (“but let God %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@-%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@-%i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g true”) is a play on that expression.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Romans Chapter 4%hb~
          %u@1So what’ll we say about what we’ve discovered about Abraham, our forefather physically-speaking%u@[%U@A%u@]? %u@2You see, if Abraham was justified (i.e., examined by a judge and declared to be in the right) by%u@[%u@a%u@] works, he has bragging-rights (i.e., he has the right to be proud of and brag about his personal achievements); but no—not with God. %u@3Taking a closer look, what does the Scripture say?%vn~
%si~
Abraham had faith in God%u@[%U@B%u@], and it was credited to him as righteousness%vp~
%si~
%u@4The agreed-upon pay which the average worker earns is not awarded to him as a favor or as a gift to charity but as a debt which is owed and which he must be compensated for. %u@5Contrast that to the average worker who instead %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ believes in the justification of the ungodly %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@a%i@d: his faith is credited to him as righteousness, %u@6just as David too describes the blessings on the person whom God credits righteousness independent of works:%nn~
%si~
%u@7Blessed are they whose lawless deeds have been forgiven%vp~
And whose sins have been covered over.%vp~
%u@8Blessed is a man to whom the Lord%vp~
Will definitely not impute sin.%vp~
%si~
%u@9So is this blessing upon the circumcised (i.e., those who’ve made a covenant to obey the Law of Moses) or the uncircumcised? The fact of the matter is that we say, “The faith %i@p%i@e%i@c%i@u%i@l%i@i%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@A%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@ was credited to him as righteousness.” %u@1%u@0So how was it credited? While circumcised or uncircumcised? No—not while circumcised but while uncircumcised, %u@1%u@1and %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s, he had the actual circumcision operation done to him%u@[%u@b%u@], a certification of the righteousness of the faith which he had while uncircumcised, resulting in him being the progenitor of every believer who traverses from uncircumcision (i.e., them being Gentiles and consequently having no covenant with God) to their being credited with righteous, %u@1%u@2and a progenitor of a circumcised person (i.e., a person who’s Jewish and consequently follows the Law of Moses) %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s is not derived from circumcision alone but is a result of following in the footsteps of the faith that our patriarch Abraham had while uncircumcised.%nn~
          %u@1%u@3You see, the promise to Abraham or to his offspring, the promise to be the world’s heir, was not by means of law (i.e., a method where one follows a list of rules, with the implication of obtaining righteousness from it) but rather through faith-%i@b%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@d-righteousness. %u@1%u@4To that point, if a law-based methodology is the means by which one lays claim %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ and takes possession of it, faith has been made null and void, and the promise %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@A%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@ has been nullified. %u@1%u@5The Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s brings about wrath, you see, but where there is no law (i.e., God-originated list of right and wrong), there’s no transgression %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@w%i@ either.%vn~
          %u@1%u@6By this%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ comes out of faith, so that %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ in accordance to grace, resulting in the certainty of the promise to all the descendants %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@A%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@h%i@a%i@m, not only to those who are based out of the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ but also to those who are based out of Abraham’s faith, who is the progenitor of us all, %u@1%u@7just like it’s written in Scripture, “I have positioned you to be a father (i.e., patriarch, progenitor) of every nation and of all Gentiles”…%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ in plain sight of (%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@u%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f)%i@ the One whom he believed: God, the One who makes the dead alive and calls things which be not as being. %u@1%u@8Contrary to hope %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ upon hope%u@[%u@c%u@], Abraham believed, resulting in him becoming “a father of many nations” according to the quotation, “This is the way your offspring will be.” %u@1%u@9Not weakened in faith after fully noticing his own already-lifeless%u@[%u@d%u@] body, which %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ had existed for a hundred years or so, and the lifelessness%u@[%u@d%u@] of Sarah’s womb, %u@2%u@0he didn’t doubt the promise%u@[%u@e%u@] of God by %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ unbelief but was strengthened in faith instead, after giving glory to God, %u@2%u@1convinced that He who promised is able also to do %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@d. %u@2%u@2This is why “it was credited to him as righteousness.” %u@2%u@3Now %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %I@S%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@p%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@s—that %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ was credited to him—was not written for his sake only, %u@2%u@4but for our sake too, those to whom it’s going to be credited, %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ to those believing and laying their trust upon the resurrected-Jesus—our Lord raised from the dead, %u@2%u@5who was handed over and delivered %i@t%i@o %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ by our sins and was raised by our justification (i.e., the process of getting us to where we are acquitted of our sins before God).%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@b%i@y…Lit: %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@m%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@-%i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@m%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@C%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e%i@.%i@ Contrary to any hope in the natural world but resting on hope in the promise of God.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s…%i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s…Lit: %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d…%i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@s%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@s%i@e%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %I@A%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@f%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@h%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@-%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g…Or: %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %I@A%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@f%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@h [%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@s]. The text is ambiguous.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d. Paul, quoting from the LXX, uses the dative case for the word %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@,%i@ and the dative case when applied to a person after the verb %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@ is rendered %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n; a few examples of this are Matt. 21:25; 21:32; Mark 11:31; Luke 20:5. The literal rendering, though correct, is misleading and doesn’t agree with the rendering from Hebrew of Gen. 15:4.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Romans Chapter 5%hb~
          %u@1So having been justified (i.e., examined by God the judge and declared to be righteous) as a result of faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ, %u@2through whom we’ve also arrived at the point where we have the access by faith to this grace in which we’ve come to stand and boast (i.e., take pride, bask, exult) in a hope%u@[%u@a%u@] of the glory of God.%vn~
          %u@3Not only that, but we also boast in our affliction, knowing that the affliction %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ accomplishes perseverance, %u@4the%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@s%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@g perseverance approval (i.e., deemed sound as a result of having passed tests), the %i@e%i@n%i@s%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ approval hope, %u@5and the %i@e%i@n%i@s%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ hope won’t disappoint%u@[%u@b%u@], since the love of God has been poured out in our hearts through the Holy Spirit who was given to us.%vn~
          %u@6You see, while we were still weak, even still at the appointed time Christ died on behalf of ungodly people. %u@7You see, there’s hardly a person who will die on behalf of a person who’s righteous; and maybe someone will muster the courage to die on behalf of a good person. %u@8But God’s own love is endorsed to us%u@[%u@c%u@] %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@t that Christ died on our behalf while we were still sinners. %u@9So now that we’ve been justified by his blood, we’ll all the more be spared from the wrath %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ through him. %u@1%u@0You see, if we were reconciled to God through the death of His son while we were enemies, now that we’ve been reconciled, we’ll all the more be spared, preserved, and kept intact by his life. %u@1%u@1Not only that but we’ll also boast (i.e., take pride, bask, exult) in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we at this time have received the %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ reconciliation.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Throughout this %i@a%i@l%i@l, just as sin entered the world through one man and death (i.e., stagnation of waste, joylessness, futility, and destruction) through the sin %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d, and in this way death propagated to all men, seeing that%u@[%u@d%u@] everybody has sinned— %u@1%u@3the fact is, up until law (i.e., an enumeration of God’s commandments) %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@,%i@ sin was in the world (i.e., the established order of human beings), but sin is not transacted and counted against a person%u@[%U@A%u@] when law doesn’t exist. %u@1%u@4That aside, death reigned from Adam until Moses%u@[%U@B%u@] and %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@s%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ over those who didn’t sin by committing the same transgression that Adam committed, who is a prototype of and symbolic of %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ human beings who come after him.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5But put that aside. The gift %i@o%i@f %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ doesn’t operate the same way as the %i@i%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ transgression: for if the many died (i.e., were transformed into a state of spiritual death, resulting in their lives becoming a stagnation of waste, joylessness, futility, and destruction—culminating in physical death itself) by the single transgression, all the more did the grace of God and the unrequited-gift overflow%u@[%u@e%u@] to the many by grace, by the one man Jesus Christ. %u@1%u@6But the unrequited-gift doesn’t operate the same way as %i@t%i@h%i@e %i@a%i@f%i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ the lone person who sinned: on the one hand the judicial review which came out of %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@v%i@o%i@l%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ a single person resulted in condemnation, but on the other hand the grace%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ came out of many transgressions resulted in an act of righteousness.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7Put another way, if by the transgression of the singular person death reigned through the singular person, all the more will they who receive the abundance of the grace %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ and the gift of righteousness reign in life through the singular person Jesus Christ. %u@1%u@8So then, just as condemnation came to every person as the result of one transgression, in the same way one act of righteousness resulted in making available to every person the %i@a%i@b%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f to have the slate of his %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@e life wiped clean%u@[%u@f%u@]. %u@1%u@9For just as through the disobedience of the singular person the many were declared by imposition to be sinners, in the same way too through the obedience of the singular person the many are declared by imposition to be righteous. %u@2%u@0But law (i.e., the expectation of living up to the standards imposed by a list of right and wrong) slipped in, sneaking in unplanned as though crashing a party, in order that the transgression %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %I@A%i@d%i@a%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@a%i@g%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@c%i@e would multiply; but if the sin %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ multiplied, grace multiplied even more so, %u@2%u@1so that just as the sin %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ reigned by the death %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@a%i@w%i@n%i@e%i@d, in the same way grace would reign through righteousness resulting in eternal life (i.e., that special fullness of life, one which begins in this lifetime) through our Lord Jesus Christ.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@b%i@o%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@(%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@s%i@k%i@,%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@)%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e…Lit: %i@b%i@o%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@w%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@d%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@u%i@s…Lit: %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@u%i@s. The Gk. word for %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ was in ancient times used when someone introduced a person whom he recommends to someone else, with the intention of the two becoming friends or joining together in a common cause.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@s%i@e%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t…Lit: %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@l%i@o%i@w…Also: %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@p%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n…Lit: %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@;%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@p%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@d. Paul says here and elsewhere that sin cannot take place without God having published a list of His commandments. God doesn’t count deeds done in ignorance as sin. This is why when toddlers die, they don’t face condemnation: toddlers aren’t old enough to comprehend the commandments. It also explains Gen. 4:15, where God didn’t kill Cain for killing Abel but said he’d kill anyone who killed Cain.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %I@A%i@d%i@a%i@m%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s…Paul is referring to the timeframe before the ultimate law, the Law of Moses, was delivered to the people. Even without the Law, which is the ultimate, definitive list compiled by God of what sin is, sin managed to wreak its devastation (i.e., death) during that time. Paul said a verse earlier that sin is not transacted (imputed) where law doesn’t exist; but he’s clarifying that remark by saying that sin indeed reigned in spite of the Law of Moses not existing.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Romans Chapter 6%hb~
          %u@1So what’s there to say about this%u@[%u@a%u@]? Shall we dwell in the sin %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@ so that more and more grace %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@t?— %u@2Don’t even think about it%u@[%u@b%u@].
