Given a skill, profession, or some area of knowledge, the “outsider” is a novice, is unskilled, or is ignorant when it comes to the matter at hand.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@ %i@(%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@u%i@b%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@) %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@f%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ [%i@i%i@n]%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@f. A puzzling verse. J.B. Phillips, author of %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@N%i@e%i@w%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@ %I@E%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@ (1958 version), wrote, “This is the sole instance of the translator’s departing from the accepted text. He felt bound to conclude, from the sense of the next three verses, that we have here either a slip of the pen on the part of Paul, or, more probably, a copyist’s error.” In other words, Phillips is justifying the fact that he swapped a couple words to make sense of this verse. I disagree with Phillips; however, this verse must be supplied with interpolations to make sense of it. Verse 22 begins with the Gk. word %i@h%i@ō%i@s%i@t%i@e [%i@s%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@o (ὥστε/Strong’s 5620)]. Hōste connects two thoughts, and an interpolation has been added to beginning of the verse to make this more apparent (Matt. 12:12 is an example). Verse 22 is tightly coupled with v. 21, being linked to the quotation from Is. 28:11–12. What this means is that tongues is a sign that the prophecy from Isaiah has been fulfilled, so that those who don’t believe should recognize it as the fulfillment of this prophecy.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%I@S%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@w%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e…As Paul left a few key words to one’s imagination, it’s not quite clear which of a couple different things he meant. It seems that these verses here are referring to one person speaking, as the words %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ in %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@;%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ in %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@;%i@ and %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ in %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ are all singular.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d…Lit: %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d. The interpolation %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@ is justifiable based on the context and is affirmed by v. 2, which says that a person who speaks in tongues speaks to God. Many have taken the first half of v. 28, “Now if there’s no interpreter, have him remain silent in church,” to mean that there should be no speaking in tongues in church whatsoever unaccompanied by an interpretation. For this reason, Paul added the second half of v. 28 to allow speaking in tongues done without interpretation, as long as it’s done quietly (i.e. %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f).%fn~
Many claim that the Bible commands that all speaking in tongues must be followed by an interpretation, but there’s not a single example of a message in tongues followed by an interpretation when one closely examines every instance of speaking in tongues in Acts. In fact, in each of those instances, not only was there no interpretation given, but everyone was speaking in tongues at the same time. None of those who were speaking in tongues in Acts are “outsiders” (see above note), so it’s alright for them all to speak in tongues at the same time since they’ll all be self-edified.%fn~
Furthermore, as v. 28 says “…have him remain silent in church…” but also says “…let him speak to himself and to God,” we should infer that what Paul meant by “remain silent in the church” is actually a command to not speak in a loud voice so as to address the congregation rather than a command to not speak at all—otherwise, how can such a person simultaneously remain silent and speak to himself? This observation gains importance later on in this chapter when Paul talks about women keeping silent in church. The same applies in that case for women: he’s not saying that women can’t talk at all in church, rather he’s saying women shouldn’t talk out loud in a way that they address the entire congregation. This observation makes sense, as the problem in the Corinthian church was multiple parties trying to speak to the entire congregation at the same time, talking over top of each other—one speaking to himself or speaking in a subdued voice was not the problem.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@t%i@s…Regardless of whether prophets have been given the unction from the Holy Spirit to prophecy, the may choose not to, and this is not a slight against the Holy Spirit. This passage insinuates that a prophet will receive such unction but will have to wait his turn to deliver it. Put another way, the Holy Spirit will at times give unctions to multiple people at the same time, but it’s up to them to deliver these messages serially. An unction from the Holy Spirit can be held for a period of time—it doesn’t have to be blurted out the moment it’s received.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@u%i@d %i@a%i@d%i@d%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@r%i@e%i@g%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k. Ref. note of v. 27 for justification for adding %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@u%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@d%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@r%i@e%i@g%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@.%i@ Paul is not forbidding women to engage in normal conversation while at church; that notion is preposterous.%fn~
Continuing on in vv. 35–36, Paul says it’s disgraceful for a woman to speak in church. Paul’s statement “If they want to learn something in particular, let them ask their husbands at home” implies that the women were disrupting the entire church by interrupting the speaker with a question. Not only were they interrupting the speaker, Paul’s remark, “did the word of God issue forth from you (etc),” indicates that their questions did not come from a sincere, humble desire to learn but from a position of arrogance, from a know-it-all attitude. These reasons are why Paul said it was disgraceful for the women (these women) to speak in church.%fn~
But we know that women were permitted to speak in church at that time, since Acts 21:9 mentions four young women who prophesied. In order to prophesy, these women would have to do so in a church setting, and doing so meant that they were addressing the congregation while prophesying. This fourteenth chapter plus the ancient treatise called the %I@D%i@i%i@d%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@ indicate that the first century church had prophets stand up and address the congregation in prophesies on a regular basis—something which is radically different than even what Pentecostals do nowadays. I imagine that the four daughters of Acts 21:9 took their turn at the pulpit.%fn~
%i@%sb~
1 Cor. Chapter 15%hb~
          %u@1I’m making you understand, comrades%u@[%u@a%u@], the Gospel (i.e., the good-news message) which was evangelized to you, which in addition you received (i.e., took hold of in your hearts and applied to your own selves), and in which you stand (i.e., in this you are established, you remain stable and steadfast, and in this you withstand the pressures of life), %u@2and through which you are being saved (i.e., time after time being rescued from life’s calamities) by some concept%u@[%u@b%u@] evangelized to you if you keep a tight grip %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d, unless of course you weren’t serious when you %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ to believe (i.e., you frivolously, heedlessly, inconsiderately, without purpose, without just cause, without careful thought, without due consideration, or haphazardly made the decision).%vn~
          %u@3You see, I gave the highest priority to putting into you what I too received, %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ that Christ died on behalf of us sinners according to the Scriptures, %u@4that he was buried, that he rose on the Third Day, %u@5and that he was seen by Peter%u@[%u@c%u@], and then after that by the twelve %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@s. %u@6After that he was seen by over five-hundred people at the same time, the majority of whom have stayed alive until now, but some of them have passed away%u@[%u@d%u@]. %u@7After that, he was seen by James and then by all of the apostles. %u@8Last of all he was seen by me too, the bastard-stepchild%u@[%u@e%u@] sort of.%vn~
          %u@9You see, I am the most insignificant of the apostles, one who is not worthy enough to be called an apostle because I persecuted God’s church. %u@1%u@0By the grace of God I am what I am, but His grace wasn’t wasted on me; instead I worked harder than all of them, not me personally but rather the grace of God in conjunction with me. %u@1%u@1So whether I’m %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ or those %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r %i@a%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@t, we preach this same message in the same fashion, and you believed this same message in the same fashion%u@[%u@f%u@].%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Now if %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t Christ was raised from the dead is being preached, how is it that certain individuals among you claim that there is no resurrection from the dead%u@[%u@g%u@] (i.e., once a person dies, his total existence ceases; there is no life after death, nor can a person return from the dead since the moment he dies he ceases to exist)? %u@1%u@3If there’s no resurrection from the dead, not even Christ has been raised from the dead. %u@1%u@4If Christ hasn’t been raised, then our preaching %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ is a waste of time and your faith is a waste of time— %u@1%u@5And it’ll be obvious to everyone that we lie under oath, since we swore by God under oath that He raised Christ—whom He didn’t raise—%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d, since the dead %i@s%i@u%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@l%i@y%i@ aren’t raised. %u@1%u@6You see, if the dead aren’t raised, not even Christ has been raised. %u@1%u@7But if Christ hasn’t been raised, your faith is pointless; you are still %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@d%i@ in your sins— %u@1%u@8and those who’ve passed away in Christ have perished too. %u@1%u@9If we who in this life have hoped in Christ have been stranded%u@[%u@h%u@], we are the most pathetic people of all.%vn~
          %u@2%u@0But it turns out that Christ has been raised from the dead, a premier%u@[%u@i%u@] of those who’ve passed away. %u@2%u@1You see, since death %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ through a %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@ person, resurrection from the dead (i.e., hope of existing after death; life after death; blissful existence in the afterlife) also %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e through a %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@ person. %u@2%u@2To this point, just as everyone died (i.e., died spiritually: underwent a stagnation of waste, joylessness, futility, and destruction; eventually died physically) by means of Adam, likewise everyone in Christ shall be made alive by means of Christ too. %u@2%u@3But %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@c%i@c%i@u%i@r%i@ by each person’s ranking: Christ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ premier %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t, then %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ those who are affiliated with Christ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ at his coming, %u@2%u@4then comes the End, when the kingdom of God the Father%u@[%u@j%u@] will be transferred into %i@h%i@i%i@s hands, entrusted %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m for %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ to do as %i@h%i@e%i@ wills, when He’ll abolish every ruler, every authority, and every power%u@[%U@A%u@]; %u@2%u@5you see, it’s absolutely necessary%u@[%u@k%u@] that he reign and reign until such a time that all of his enemies be put under his feet (i.e., all his enemies be subjected to him: totally subdued and under his absolute control). %u@2%u@6Death will be the last enemy to be destroyed; %u@2%u@7you see, %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@,%i@ “He put all things under his feet.” When the circumstances arise in which He happens to say “all things have been subjected%u@[%u@l%u@],” it goes without saying that the Father’s not included in the “all things.” %u@2%u@8But when those circumstances arise when He subjects all things to him, then in addition the son himself will be subjected to the One Who subjected all things to him, so that God would become every little piece of everything%u@[%u@m%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@9But if all this is not the case, what are they going to do, they who are getting themselves baptized as a symbol of their resurrection from the dead%u@[%U@B%u@]? If the dead are definitely not resurrected, why are they being baptized as a symbol of them not being dead? %u@3%u@0Why do we take risks %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ every moment? %u@3%u@1Day after day I die by the lofty oath sworn to look after you, comrades, which I keep in Christ Jesus our Lord.%u@[%u@n%u@] %u@3%u@2That I had my back against the wall and was fighting for my life%u@[%u@o%u@] in Ephesus, what’s the point of doing it all if the dead aren’t resurrected. %I@W%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@a%i@i%i@a%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@?%i@—%i@%vn~
%si~
Let us eat and drink%u@[%u@p%u@] %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@,%i@%vp~
For tomorrow we shall die%vp~
%si~
%u@3%u@3Don’t be fooled %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@;%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@a%i@d:%i@%nn~
%si~
The wrong crowd corrupts good conduct%vp~
%si~
%u@3%u@4Snap out of it and don’t continue in sin. In fact, some %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ don’t have a knowing, recognition, or understanding of God. Shame on you%u@[%u@q%u@].%nn~
          %u@3%u@5Moving on though, someone’s bound to say%u@[%u@r%u@], “How will the dead be resurrected (i.e., how’s it possible for a dead person to obtain a new body)?” What kind of body will they get %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e? %u@3%u@6%I@H%i@o%i@w brainless you %i@a%i@r%i@e! What someone sows doesn’t spring to life unless it happens to die, %u@3%u@7and what one sows isn’t the body (i.e., the same biological form) of what it will become. No—you sow a bare seed…perhaps it’s wheat…perhaps it’s some other %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@n… %u@3%u@8But God gives it a body (i.e., a plant form) the way He wanted and %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ a unique, peculiar body to each type of seed sown. %u@3%u@9Not all flesh (i.e., cell and tissue composition) is the same flesh (i.e., consists of the same kind of tissues, skeleton, muscle, skin, etc.). No—there’s one %i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@h%i@ which corresponds to humans, another %i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f flesh which corresponds to farm animals, another %i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f flesh to birds, another %i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f flesh to fish. %u@4%u@0%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ bodies (i.e., unique physical entities) in outer-space%u@[%u@s%u@] and bodies on Earth, but no,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e: there’s one %i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f glory (i.e., wonder, splendor, awe, something spectacular) %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@e%i@s in space vs. another %i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@e%i@s on Earth; %u@4%u@1the uniqueness of glory that the sun has is a different glory than the type that the moon has, and there’s a different, unique type for the stars %i@t%i@o%i@o: in fact one star differs in its glory from that of another star.%vn~
          %u@4%u@2The resurrection from the dead works the same way. %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s sown is a mortal, decaying %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ tainted with moral corruption; it’s resurrected an immortal, non-decayable %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ untainted by moral corruption. %u@4%u@3It’s sown in dishonor, it’s resurrected in glory; sown in weakness, raised in power; %u@4%u@4sown a soul-body (i.e., a body having all the quintessential human elements: one that has a thirst for the things of this life, that thinks and feels as humans do, has human frailties), raised a spiritual-body. If it is a soul-body, it is also a spiritual-body: %u@4%u@5this is also the way it’s written %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t,%vn~
%si~
The first man Adam became%u@[%u@t%u@] a living-soul%vp~
%si~
…The Last Adam %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e a sprung-to-life-spirit. %u@4%u@6No, the first %I@A%i@d%i@a%i@m%i@ wasn’t the spiritual-%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@o%i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@-%i@m%i@a%i@n rather the soul-%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@o%i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@-%i@m%i@a%i@n, then %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ the spiritual%i@-%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@o%i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@-%i@m%i@a%i@n. %u@4%u@7The first man %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ out of the %i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@’%i@s dirt%i@,%i@ the second man %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ out of the spiritual world%u@[%u@u%u@]. %u@4%u@8As the dirt is, so too are the dirt%i@-%i@c%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s; as the spiritual world is, so too are the spiritual%i@-%i@c%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s. %u@4%u@9And just as we bore the image of the dirt, let us bear the image of the spiritual as well.%nn~
          %u@5%u@0I’ll say this, comrades, that flesh and blood%u@[%u@v%u@] (i.e., the best that human ability can muster) cannot inherit the kingdom of God (i.e., cannot put you in a place where you have a relationship with God; where God works in and through your life); neither does decayable mortality tainted with moral corruption inherit non-decayable immortality untainted by moral corruption.%vn~
          %u@5%u@1Hey—I’ll tell you a mystery: we all shall not sleep (i.e., stay dead forever), but we all shall be changed %u@5%u@2in a split-second, in the time it takes to blink an eye, at the last bugle call: the bugle shall sound off, and the dead will be raised %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ non-decayable immortals untainted by moral corruption. %I@Y%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ we ourselves shall be changed. %u@5%u@3You see, this decayable mortality must put on non-decayable immortality, and this mortal nature must put on an immortal nature. %u@5%u@4When this decayable mortality shall have put on non-decayable immortality, and this mortal nature shall have put on an immortal nature, then the verses will come to pass which say,%vn~
%si~
Death is engulfed by victory.%vp~
%si~
%u@5%u@5Death, where is your victory?%vp~
Death, where is your sting%u@[%u@w%u@]?%vp~
%si~
%u@5%u@6The sting of death is sin, and the power of sin is the Law (i.e., the Law of Moses; the set of commandments given by God)— %u@5%u@7But thank-you God, Who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.%nn~
          %u@5%u@8So then, my dear comrades, get to where you’re%u@[%u@x%u@] unshakeable, un-moveable, and un-perturbable, abounding and proliferating in the Lord’s work at all times, knowing for certain that your work in the Lord is not for nothing, is not going to waste.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@p%i@t…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@;%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@p%i@t. Ref. note of John 1:1.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@P%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r…Lit: %I@C%i@e%i@p%i@h%i@a%i@s. Ref. note of 1:12.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@p%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y…Lit: %i@s%i@l%i@e%i@p%i@t. Ref. 7:39.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@-%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@p%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d…Lit: %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@h; %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n. Some liberties taken, as Paul is speaking figuratively here.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d…In other places translated “life after death.” Ref. notes of Mark 12:18, Luke 10:25 and other places.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@m%i@i%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@u%i@i%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@F%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r…Lit: %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@F%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@s%i@o%i@l%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@r%i@y…Lit: %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@s%i@t [%i@b%i@e]. A figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@j%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d…This is a paraphrase of the prior quotation, “all things have been put under his feet.”%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@i%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l. Ref. 1 Cor. 12:6.%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%I@D%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@f%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@w%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@,%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d…Lit%i@:%i@ %I@D%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@w%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@,%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d. I’m guessing this is what Paul meant here.%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@s. An idiom. It appears that Paul added %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ [%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e] to indicate that he’s applying an idiom to a human experience and that one should not take his words literally. Ref. note of Mark 1:13.%fn~
%u@[%u@p%u@]%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k…A NT expression; in addition to the obvious—eating and drinking—it means to celebrate, party, feast.%fn~
%u@[%u@q%u@]%I@S%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u…Lit: %I@I%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@r%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%fn~
%u@[%u@s%u@]%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@-%i@s%i@p%i@a%i@c%i@e…Lit: %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@-%i@s%i@k%i@y. Ref. note of 1 Pet. 1:4.%fn~
%u@[%u@t%u@]%i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@o. Seems to indicate something he arrived at.%fn~
%u@[%u@u%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@l%i@d…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@v%u@]%i@f%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d…A NT idiom%fn~
%u@[%u@w%u@]%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g…Also: %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@d [%i@a%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@p]. Same word used in Acts 26:14 for %i@g%i@o%i@a%i@d%i@.%i@ %fn~
%u@[%u@x%u@]%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@r%i@u%i@l%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r…An explanation of the Gk. words for positions of authority and the like. The first three correspond to what’s quoted here:%fn~
Ruler [archōn, (ἄρχων/Strong’s 758)]—When referring to people, the very top of a hierarchy; the one who has the ultimate power over the entire hierarchy. It refers to a person or the people who are at the top of the pyramid, whatever that pyramid may be. It’s translated %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ in Eph. 6:12 (KJV), and in that case does not refer to people but refers to demons, demons who are at the top of some demonic hierarchy. When referring to time, it’s the very start or beginning of an epoch of time, sometimes spoken of abstractly when the start of time isn’t known (John 1:1). The KJV translates this as %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ instead of the NASB’s %i@r%i@u%i@l%i@e%i@r%i@ in places such as John 16:11, etc. See below for more on %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e.%fn~
Authority [eksousia, (ἐξουσία/Strong’s 1849)]—The literal meaning is %i@e%i@x%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@.%i@ Power which is given to a person to act on behalf of a hierarchy, government, etc. which has the ultimate power. Also, one who’s given the legitimate right to exercise power. Also, the power itself, with the understanding that it was granted in such a way and not simply usurped; the position, the seat itself.%fn~
Power [dunamis, (δύναμις/Strong’s 1411)]—The natural, inherent capability to exercise control over others. The ability may or may not be legitimate or have been granted by the government or hierarchy. The word %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@ simply states the capability to exercise power, but does not specify where this ability comes from, whether the power is transferrable, or what the nature of it is; whereas the word %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y, while in certain contexts simply refers to power, is, in its essence, power which is derived from the main body; power delegated; legitimate power; non-usurped power. Therefore, dunamis may refer to usurped power or illegitimate power.%fn~
Leader [haegemon, (ἡγεμών/Strong’s 2232)]—This has two similar meanings. First is the Latin %i@d%i@u%i@x: it’s the one who’s the leader; who takes charge and leads the way for others to follow; the commander, the one who not only makes the decisions everyone follows but is responsible for those decisions, whom everyone relies on to ensure that the decisions are intelligently made. The second is the Latin %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@p%i@s: the one who does a thing first. The princeps is the person who’s the most eminent, most distinguished, the first person; the leading citizen of the country; the person who’s the best at something and therefore has taken the lead; the person everyone relies on the most to lead the way when facing difficulties. In modern terms, the captain of a sports team is a princeps: the best player, and as the best takes the initiative the most, and as a result of taking the initiative, he’s the one who leads and drives the others to victory.%fn~
Dominion [kuriotās, (κυριότης/Strong’s 2963)]—The literal meaning is %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p. It is “the majestic power that a lord wields, ruling power, lordship, dominion” (Danker & Bauer). The nature of lordship is the assumption that the expected order of things is for there to be a lord and that this lord will rule over others, and that there are guidelines by which this is done, either codified in law or in an unspoken understanding. As this word is derived from %i@l%i@o%i@r%i@d, it follows that it refers to the powers a lord has and the way that he obtained them. Unlike the word %i@a%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@,%i@ a lord is not a ruler who derives his power from the government, but rather is like the owner of a large private estate, say, somewhere out in a remote rural area. In a feudal system this would include a dukedom or earldom, but a lordship can be much smaller also. Those who live in remote, rural areas are in many respects autonomous from the rest of society, including the government. While the lord rules like an authority (eksousia), his sphere of power doesn’t fall under the authority to another, so within his sphere he’s not answerable to anyone else. As expected, this also refers to a lordship seat which is transferrable, like from father to son, etc.%fn~
Throne[(thronos, (θρόνος/Strong’s 2362)]—A ruler whose powers extend to sitting on a judgment seat: arbitrating disputes, acting as a judge in a civil or criminal proceeding; receiving emissaries; forming policy, including do so with the advice of a counsel. The throne is not an ad-hoc judgment seat, but is a persistent seat, passed from person to person. As is apparent, there’s overlap in these terms for rulers.%fn~
Pastor/shepherd [poimān, (ποιμήν/Strong’s 4166)]—(Ref. note of 1 Pet. 5:2). This Old Testament word means %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@r, but the implication is that this person is leading ordinary people (sheep) and not soldiers under his chain of command. The sheep-analogy means that such a leader will have to deal with problems that are eradicated in an army due to the discipline instilled into that army. The problems Moses had to deal with when leading Israel in the wilderness are analogous to a shepherd over sheep. Since poimān has its roots in the Old Testament, the word is only used in conjunction with ecclesiastical leadership.%fn~
To come forward as a leader [proistāmi,(προΐστημι/Strong’s 4291)]—This appears in the NT as a verb but is also used substantively as a noun. It literally means %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@w%i@a%i@r%i@d, and appears in Rom. 12:8; 1 Thess. 5:12; 1 Tim. 5:17. Danker & Bauer defines it first, “to exercise a position of leadership, rule direct, be at the head of,” and second, “to have an interest in, show concern for, care for, give aid.” There are only three occurrences in the NT and all are in relation to church leadership. %fn~
Steward [oikonomos, (οἰκονόμος/Strong’s 3623)]—Someone whom a lord (the ruler of a sizeable estate) puts in charge of the affairs of the estate. Luke 12:42; 16:1; Titus 1:7 are examples.%fn~
Overseer, bishop [episkopos, (ἐπίσκοπος/Strong’s 1985)]—The Gk. word means “one who visits,” more specifically, “one who checks up on things to ensure that things are in order”; hence the NASB rendering %i@e%i@p%i@i%i@s%i@k%i@o%i@p%i@o%i@s as %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@e%i@r. What we nowadays call a “head pastor.” Someone who’s the single individual who’s the head over a congregation. This position didn’t exist in the early days of the church, as the early church was ruled by elder councils, probably imitating the way that synagogues were ruled by elders. Apparently, as Christianity diverged more and more from Judaism, the forms of church government diverged as well, with churches replacing elder councils with bishops. %fn~
Deacon [diakonos, (διάκονος/Strong’s 1249)]—A deacon is a leader (a poiman) in the church who has oversight over a specific area in the church, but does not have total oversight like a bishop does. Deacons existed in both elder-ruled and bishop-ruled churches. Nowadays, we call a deacon an associate pastor or a ministry director. A deacon is similar to a steward (see how these two words are used together in Col 1:25) but applied to a church context, as the word’s used in the NT. Deacon appears in Rom. 12:7; 1 Cor. 16:15; Eph. 6:21; 1 Tim 3:10.%fn~
Slave or servant [doulos, (δοῦλος/Strong’s 1401)]—This word is translated either servant or slave. As slavery was pervasive in the ancient world, most of the times a %i@d%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@o%i@s is a slave, but since the slavery-mindset is absent from us in modern times, we must make distinctions in this word. This word means a servant, a menial servant, one who takes orders and is not entrusted with any significant responsibilities. This word means a slave, someone who’s owned by another person; someone who’s locked into this position; forced servitude. Doulos as appears in the NT can refer to one or multiple of these definitions, and the most appropriate rendering is dictated by context. In the NT, a doulos can be a menial servant without specifically or explicitly referring to someone who’s locked into slavery, i.e. owned by another person. In this respect, a person who’s “locked into” a nine-to-five job is a doulos of a sort, even though he’s not a bona fide slave.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@m%i@b%i@o%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ [%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@]%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d. Translators and commentators are puzzled at the meaning of this. Some guess-work is required. A good explanation from one of the commentators is that an interpolation was intended, one which changes %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ to %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@.%i@ Also, the prepositional phrase usually translated %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ has been bent from its traditional meaning to mean something that symbolizes something else. Also, the verb %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@ seems to acquire some middle voice usage, but that’s speculative. Those who disagree with these explanations—and there are several good reasons to do so—are welcome to explain how their interpretation makes better sense.%i@%fn~
%i@%sb~
1 Cor. Chapter 16%hb~
          %u@1Concerning the matter of taking up a collection for the poor%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ to God’s people%u@[%u@a%u@] %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@r%i@u%i@s%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@m, do the same thing that I commanded the churches in Galatia to do: %u@2Let each of you in private stash away %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@y every Sunday%u@[%u@b%u@]—whatever you can afford—so that when I come, there won’t be any collection-taking going on then. %u@3When I make it over to your place, whomever you happen to decide upon to write letters of recommendation for, I’ll dispatch as couriers to take your gift to Jerusalem. %u@4If there happens to be %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@s%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ respect%u@[%U@A%u@], they’ll come with me %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t.%vn~
          %u@5I’ll come your way when I pass through Macedonia; I’ll be passing through Macedonia, you see. %u@6Perhaps I’ll stay with you %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ or even spend the winter, so that you’ll send me on my way %i@r%i@e%i@f%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@y%u@[%U@B%u@] wherever I happen to go; %u@7you see, at the moment I don’t want to %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ stop by for a short visit while passing through the area; you see, I hope to stay a while with you, if the Lord permits. %u@8I’ll stay in Ephesus until Pentecost (i.e., until late May to early June). %u@9In fact, a great door (i.e., a tremendous opportunity) has been opened for me and it looks promising, but %I@I%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e many adversaries.%vn~
          %u@1%u@0If Timothy happens to show up, see to it that he doesn’t get to where he’s intimidated by you%u@[%u@c%u@]; he’s doing the Lord’s work like I’m doing, you see, %u@1%u@1so don’t let anyone treat him disrespectfully or despise him. Send him forth to his next destination in peace (i.e., take care of him, treat him well, and send him out prepared for the journey), so that he manages to come to me, for I expect him with the %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ comrades%u@[%u@d%u@] %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Concerning Comrade Apollos…I’ve encouraged him an awful lot to pay you a visit, doing so by travelling with the comrades %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g, and it wasn’t his desire altogether to go at this time, but he’ll go in good time.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Stay focused%u@[%u@e%u@], take a firm stand in the faith, man up, seize control and hold on tightly. %u@1%u@4Let everything you do manifest itself in love.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5I appeal to you, comrades…you know first-hand Stephanas’s household, since they’re the crème de la crème %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@s%u@[%u@f%u@] of Achaia and have been put in positions of deacons for God’s people, the saints…%u@1%u@6%I@I%i@ %i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u that you too would submit to such %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@s%i@ as these and to all the fellow-workers and laborers. %u@1%u@7I’m so glad that Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus showed up, that these fellows filled in the pieces that you’re missing%u@[%u@g%u@]: %u@1%u@8they gave rest to my spirit and to yours, so recognize %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f men such as these.%vn~
          %u@1%u@9The churches in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ Asia send their greetings to you. Aquila and Priscilla send many greetings to you in the Lord and are joined in their greetings with the group of Christians who meet in their house. %u@2%u@0All the comrades greet you. Give each other a hearty handshake and an affectionate hug—holy ones—%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@.%u@[%u@h%u@]%vn~
          %u@2%u@1The greeting %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ is in my own handwriting, that of Paul’s. %u@2%u@2If anyone doesn’t like the Lord a lot%u@[%u@i%u@], let him be accursed. Maranatha (Do come Lord).%vn~
          %u@2%u@3The grace of the Lord Jesus %i@b%i@e%i@ with you all. %u@2%u@4%I@M%i@a%i@y%i@ my love %i@b%i@e with all of you in Christ Jesus.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@S%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@y…Lit: %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@b%i@b%i@a%i@t%i@h. As they didn’t have names for the days of the weeks, they referred to each day by how many days past the Sabbath it is.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@d%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@i%i@d%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@w%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@c%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@w%i@a%i@t%i@c%i@h%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@c%i@r%i@è%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@è%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@s…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@-%i@f%i@r%i@u%i@i%i@t. Ref. note of Rom. 8:23.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@f%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@i%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@f%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@c%i@k%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%I@G%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@h%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@g%i@—%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@—%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@e…Lit: %I@G%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@s%i@s. Liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@t…Lit: %i@l%i@o%i@v%i@e [%i@p%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@o] %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d. Note the Gk. word %i@p%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ō%i@ (φιλέω/Strong’s 5368) is used and not %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@p%i@a%i@ō%i@ (ἀγαπάω/Strong’s 25)%i@.%i@ Ref. note of Matt. 10:37.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@s%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@t …Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@y. Same word used similarly in Rom. 16:2. Guessing that Paul was referring to the respect the Jewish believers in Jerusalem would give to Gentile couriers—although this is very much a guess on my part.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y %i@r%i@e%i@f%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@y…Lit: %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h. Based on the usage in the NT of the Gk. word for %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@-%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ (Acts. 15:3, 20:38, 21:5; Rom. 15:24; 1 Cor. 16:11; 2 Cor. 1:16; Titus 3:13; 3 John 1:6), the word appears to have an meaning beyond what its roots suggest of simply sending someone forth. Additionally, it appears to mean, “sending someone on a journey prepared for that journey; sending someone away one good terms after they’ve spent a long with you; sending someone away with sorrow at seeing them go, with gladness of the work they’ll do; sending someone out to accomplish a mission; sending someone with your support and blessings; recommending a person sent to the next party which will receive him.”%fn~

2 Corinthians%ha~
       If it wasn’t enough that Paul wrote his longest epistle (slightly longer than Romans by verse count), he writes a second—and not a short one either. How did the Corinthians merit two lengthy epistles, whereas the Ephesians or Philippians did not?%nv~
       And based on what Paul wrote in the first letter, does the second show any signs that the Corinthians improved? Is the second epistle a part II of the first? No, the tone that the letter begins in is completely different, as Paul repeatedly uses words like suffering, tribulation, and consolation in the first chapter. The second chapter finds Paul expressing sorrow; the sting from the first letter is apparent. Is the sting mutual, as the second epistles describes the anguish, sorrow, and even tears Paul underwent as he penned the first? But the end of the book is telling: Paul says “the more I love you, the less I’m loved” (12:15).%nv~
        Of all the churches Paul founded, the Corinthian was not the most spiritual, but as it is true of a parent of several children whose favorite child is not the one who’s the best behaved, so it is with Paul and the Corinthians, as the volume he wrote to this church, the extremes of emotion, surpass the other churches.%nv~
       In the first epistle to the Corinthians, Paul gives a hint here, a detail there, of the difficulties he faces. But in this second epistle, as Paul progresses through the letter, his allusions become sentences, then the sentences become paragraphs. This culminates in the twelfth chapter as he talks about his “thorn in the flesh”—an oft misinterpreted passage.%nv~
       The Greek text is from one who has full command of the language, unlike the Gospels or like John’s writing. The writer was educated, the recipients were as well. Many times a more uncommon word was chosen when a simple word would have sufficed. But there is none of the awkwardness one finds, for example, in James or in the Gospels. The writing is fluid, howbeit with words and phrases omitted for brevity, like one does when texting on a phone. This is one of the more challenging NT books translate, ranking alongside Jude, but that also makes it one of the most satisfying.%nv~
%i@%sb~
2 Cor. Chapter 1%hb~
          %u@1Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by God’s will, and %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ comrade%u@[%u@a%u@] Timothy—%vn~
      To the church of God that is in Corinth, joined by the saints (i.e., God’s people) who are all over Achaia:%vn~
          %u@2Grace and peace to you from God our Father and %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Lord Jesus Christ.%vn~
          %u@3%I@G%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ praise %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Originator%u@[%u@b%u@] of all sorts of%u@[%u@c%u@] compassion and of advice, encouragement, and consolation, %u@4which consoles, etc. us in all of our distresses%u@[%u@d%u@], resulting in our ability to console those in all kinds of distresses%i@ with the same consolation with which we’re being consoled by God. %u@5Just as Christ’s sufferings proliferate to us, in the same way through Christ the consolation we %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e proliferates as well. %u@6Whether we’re being pressured, %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ for the sake of your consolation and salvation (i.e., your being rescued from spiritual, moral, mental, and physical calamity); whether we’re being consoled, %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ for the sake of your consolation, a consolation which is accomplished by enduring the same sufferings which we too suffer. %u@7And the hope which we have for you—our hope %i@i%i@s%i@ firm, fixed in the observation that as you are joint participants of the sufferings %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r, in the same way %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@j%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ of the consolation as well.%vn~
          %u@8In this regard, we don’t want you to be left in the dark, comrades, about the extreme difficulties we experienced in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ Asia, that we were overloaded and overwhelmed to the point that we lost the will to live. %u@9Anyways, %i@d%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ inside ourselves we concluded that we were doomed to die%u@[%u@e%u@], so we reached the point where we couldn’t be convinced that our own abilities %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s, but %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@d that the God who raises the dead %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ instead: %u@1%u@0He Who rescued us from a narrow brush with death%u@[%u@f%u@]—and rescues us %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@u%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@l%i@y—we set our hope in Him that He’ll rescue %i@u%i@s%i@ yet again, %u@1%u@1while you too were joining in lending a helping hand by the prayers that you prayed for us, so that the outcome of the stances, disposition, and full attention of many people%u@[%u@g%u@] is that the mercy and kindness shown to us would be thanked by many on our behalf.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2You see, our proud talk and bold claims%u@[%u@h%u@] are on par with the solemn declaration of our conscience, since the lifestyle we led in the world (i.e., among those who aren’t believers) was by God’s simplicity and sincerity, not by the wisdom of flesh (i.e., by the cunning shrewdness of our own ability apart from God tainted by the carnal nature) but by God’s grace instead—%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@y%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ all the more %i@s%i@o%i@ with you. %u@1%u@3In fact we’re writing to you nothing other than what you’re reading %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@r%i@e%i@g%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ or what you’re coming to understand, but I hope that you continue to gain an exact understanding until it’s all said and done%u@[%u@i%u@], %u@1%u@4just as you also gained an understanding of us, at least%i@ partially, that we are %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ your proud talk and bold claims just as you too %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ ours in the Day of the Lord Jesus (i.e., when he’s revealed in the fullness of his might).%vn~
          %u@1%u@5We formed a long-term desire for this, for what we’ve reached the point where we’re convinced is%i@ the thing that we want to do more than anything else, %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ to go visit you, so that you would get a second grace (i.e., a second impartation of our face-to-face ministry), %u@1%u@6and to continue on our journey through your %i@c%i@i%i@t%i@y to Macedonia, to %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@m%i@e%i@ the journey going from Macedonia %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ to your %i@c%i@i%i@t%i@y again, and to be sent forth by you (i.e., depart fully rested, provisioned, and in good spirits—all on account of the your generosity and hospitality) to the Jews in Judea.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7So then, was this plan treated with a nonchalant thought-process? Or what I’m planning, I’m planning according to flesh (i.e., from my own self apart from God, according to my own needs, and somewhat tainted to feed my carnal appetite), so that it would be “the yes-yes and the no-no” with me (i.e., I’d vacillate or renege on what I planned or promised to do)? %u@1%u@8But—by God—trust me%u@[%u@j%u@] that the statements we made to you aren’t “%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@e%i@s-yes and %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o-no.” %u@1%u@9To this point, God’s son Jesus Christ, who through us has been preached among you—through me, Siloam, and Timothy—hasn’t wound up being “%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@e%i@s-yes and %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o-no,” but rather has wound up being “yes” in him. %u@2%u@0For as many promises as there are from God, in him they are %i@a%i@l%i@l “yes” (i.e., no vacillating or reneging on them), and in light of this through him %i@i%i@s%i@ also the Amen (i.e., the acknowledgement of the finality of a matter; the familiar profession to God of “Let it be so”) to God with glory through us. %u@2%u@1God’s establishing us together with you in Christ and anointed us. %u@2%u@2He also stamped us with His seal of approval%u@[%U@A%u@] and gave us the down payment%u@[%U@B%u@] of the Spirit in our hearts.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3I swear to God—cross my heart and hope to die%u@[%u@k%u@]—that it was to spare you that I no longer went to Corinth— %u@2%u@4not that we act in a domineering manner towards you of the Faith—no—we work together as helpers%u@[%u@l%u@] of your grace: for you have stood by faith.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%I@O%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@r…Lit: %I@F%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r. This has a dual meaning: both God the Father and Someone who creates.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@a%i@l%i@l. A figure of speech. Use of the word %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ figuratively also occurs 1 Tim. 6:10.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@d%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@s…Also: %i@t%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s; %i@e%i@x%i@t%i@r%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@m%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@u%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e [or %i@d%i@i%i@a%i@g%i@n%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@s] %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@.%i@ Appears to be an expression or idiom.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@r%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@u%i@s%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h…Lit: %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h. Appears to be an expression.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@u%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@l%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@a%i@i%i@m%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@o%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e…Lit: %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l [%i@t%i@h%i@e] %i@e%i@n%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@b%i@y%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@—%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@e…Lit: %I@G%i@o%i@d [%i@b%i@e] %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@f%i@u%i@l. This appears to be an idiom.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%I@I%i@ %i@s%i@w%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@—%i@c%i@r%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@e…Lit: %I@I%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@-%I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@l%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@p%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@p%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@a%i@l…Lit: %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@.%i@ Seals were used in ancient times the same way they are today, howbeit for the occasional different application. A messenger who was assigned the task of delivering a papyrus scroll with a message written on it to a remote destination was handed a scroll which was sealed. The sealing more than likely was a hot wax dripped across the overlapping edges of the scroll, so that when the wax cooled and hardened, the scroll couldn’t be opened and read without irreparably breaking the wax seal—similar to how an envelope, once opened, cannot be closed again and how, if it was opened, it would be apparent. In addition, the wax, while still hot, was stamped with a stamp or a signet ring which had a detailed image etched into it which became imprinted into the wax, so that the cooled wax retained this image. The receiver would inspect the image to make sure it was genuine, as only a limited set of stamps or signet rings would be made. The receiver would be ensured that the document was genuine, not a forgery from an imposter, as a potential imposter, though capable of writing a forgery, could not (at least easily) make a duplicate of the stamp or signet ring.%fn~
So now, as Paul uses the word %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@l a few times in his epistles, what he’s referring to is this:%fn~
1. God has placed his stamp of approval on something%fn~
2. The thing God stamped is genuine, valuable, and special%fn~
3. Any third party, someone other than God the stamper and the person being sealed, upon examination will be able to recognize that such a stamp is indeed from God%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@y%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t…Also: %i@c%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@l…Lit: %i@s%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@t%i@y%i@;%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@.%i@ As seen in the OT (one example is Prov. 6:1–5), loans were secured with collateral, so a person who needed to borrow a small amount of cash for a day or two could leave his cloak with the person who lends him the money as collateral. Now on a few occasions Paul in his epistles states that the Holy Spirit is given to us like collateral for a loan. What he means is:%fn~
1. God hands us something immediately with the promise He’ll “repay” us with something greater in the future. In other words, the Holy Spirit is God’s guarantee to us that He’ll give us something greater in the future%fn~
2. The Holy Spirit is something we get to hold onto and make use of in the meantime%fn~
3. The Holy Spirit will never—can never—be taken away from us, as he is “surety”%fn~
%i@%sb~
2 Cor. Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1Getting to the point, I made up my mind that I wouldn’t visit you again while laden with the pains of sorrow. %u@2In fact, if I’m making you feel sorry, who in particular will cheer me up apart from the one I made feel sorry? %u@3The very thing I wrote, I wrote so that I wouldn’t come for a visit and wind up being made sorry%u@[%u@a%u@] by the ones I ought to rejoice over, as my nearness to you all has convinced me that my joy is derived from you all. %u@4In fact, what I wrote to you through many tears came out of a great deal of distress and heart-felt anguish, not so that it would cause you sorrow, but so that you’d understand the abundant love which I have for you.%vn~
          %u@5If a certain person has caused sorrow, he hasn’t caused me sorrow (%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ no, %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ partially), so I won’t dump%u@[%u@b%u@] %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s on you all. %u@6The very punishment %i@i%i@n%i@f%i@l%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ by the many is enough for such a person, %u@7so that on the flip-side, you %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e all the more kind and merciful %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ and comfort and encourage %i@h%i@i%i@m, %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t such a person not somehow be deluged with even more sorrow. %u@8In light of this I advise you to broadcast%u@[%u@c%u@] love to him. %u@9In fact, another reason I wrote is so that I could discern if you live up to my standards, %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ if you obey everything you’re told. %u@1%u@0Now if you forgive %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ something, so do I; you see, if in addition %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ I %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@g%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g, what I’ve forgiven (assuming there’s something I’m forgiving), %I@I%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ through you under the scrutiny%u@[%u@d%u@] of Christ, %u@1%u@1so that we won’t be swindled by Satan: we are not ignorant of his intentions, you see.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Now that I’ve arrived at Troas for the purpose of spreading the Gospel of Christ (i.e., the good news about Christ), a door has been opened to me in the Lord (i.e., in regard to the things of the Lord, a tremendous opportunity has presented itself to me), %u@1%u@3I was uncomfortable%u@[%u@e%u@] in my spirit not finding my fellow-comrade%u@[%u@f%u@] Titus, so instead I excused myself, said goodbye to them, and left for Macedonia.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4But thank-you God, Who always makes us roadies on Christ’s victory tour%u@[%U@A%u@], and Who’s propagating the fragrance of his knowledge%u@[%u@g%u@] through us in all regions, %u@1%u@5since in God we are a pleasant%u@[%u@h%u@] aroma (%i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g) of Christ among those being saved (i.e., those being rescued from calamity) and among those perishing; %u@1%u@6we who on the one hand %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ a whiff %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ from death to %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ death%u@[%U@B%u@], and on the other hand %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ a whiff %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ from life to %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ life—and that’s not good enough for some people? %u@1%u@7You see, we’re not like so many %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ who hustle%u@[%u@i%u@] the word of God—no—%i@w%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@l%i@ like it’s coming from someone who’s sincere through-and-through%u@[%u@j%u@]—no—we speak %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ in Christ like it’s coming directly from God %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e %i@w%i@e %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d before God%u@[%u@k%u@].%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@r%i@y…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@r%i@o%i@w%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@d%i@u%i@m%i@p…%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u…Lit: %i@b%i@u%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@b%i@r%i@o%i@a%i@d%i@c%i@a%i@s%i@t…Lit: %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@c%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%I@I%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e…Also: %I@I%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@s%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@m%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@-%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e…Lit: %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@f%i@r%i@a%i@g%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@k%i@n%i@o%i@w%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@g%i@e…A well-crafted metaphor, one which is continued in the next couple of verses%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@a%i@n%i@t…Or%i@:%i@ %i@s%i@w%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@-%i@s%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@h%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@l%i@e…The meaning of this Gk. word is “trade in, peddle, huckster.” It refers to “the tricks of small tradesmen,” so “…the word almost comes to mean %i@a%i@d%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@”%i@ (Danker & Bauer).%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@-%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h…Lit: %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y. An idiom.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d…Lit: %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k. Same idiom as before.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@u%i@r…Or: %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@i%i@u%i@m%i@p%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t. Some liberties taken. The single Gk. word used here refers to the following: In Roman times, generals returned from a battlefield victory in a procession and led the procession through the capitol. The triumphal general and his lieutenants formed the vanguard of the procession; those in the defeated enemy’s army, including women and children, were bound and formed the rear of the procession, being led to the city to be sold as slaves. The analogy is that we are a part of the procession, though I prefer to believe that we’re part of the vanguard and not the rear, but that’s open to debate.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@f%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h…%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h…%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e. Same Gk. wording as is used in in Paul’s statement %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ (Rom. 1:17), as this is the same expression. Similar to the English usage of %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@f%i@f%i@,%i@ the usage here means %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@a%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@;%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@i%i@m%i@p%i@s%i@e. Paul’s life and his companions’ lives exemplify a life of death and, even more, of life and even more life. Paul goes into detail about the death he’s referring to in the eleventh and twelfth chapters; but in the midst of this Paul experiences more and more of the life of God.%fn~
%i@%sb~
2 Cor. Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1Are %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@I starting over again in doing self-promotion %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@l%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@u%i@s? Put another way, we’re not in need of letters of recommendation %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@nt to you or %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d from you, like some people do, are we? %u@2You are our letter %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n, written in our hearts, understood and read by all people. %u@3It’s plain for all to see that you are a letter of Christ transcribed and delivered%u@[%u@a%u@] by us; not written with ink, but with the Spirit of the Living God; not %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ in stone but %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ in a flesh-heart.%vn~
          %u@4We’re convinced that we have such a thing through Christ with God— %u@5Not that we’re up-to-par in and of ourselves to %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ figure that something in particular %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d was self-generated, but rather that our adequacy %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@s out of God, %u@6Who also made us up-to-par ministers of a new covenant, not of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ letter (i.e., the literal, exacting listing of rules, compliance with those rules, and consequences for breaking them) but of %i@t%i@h%i@e Spirit: for the letter kills, but the Spirit causes things to spring into life.%vn~
          %u@7Now if the administering of death, %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@d in letters etched%i@ in stone, occurred in glory to the point that it wasn’t possible for the run-of-the-mill Israelite%u@[%u@b%u@] to gaze at Moses’s face because of the glory of his face—a glory that was deteriorating %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s— %u@8how much more will the administering of the Spirit be accompanied by%u@[%u@c%u@] glory? %u@9Furthermore, if %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s glory in the administering of condemnation, how much more does the administering of righteousness exceed it in glory? %u@1%u@0And furthermore, that which has been made glorious hasn’t been made glorious relative to%u@[%u@d%u@] the glory which surpasses it. %u@1%u@1In fact, if %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@ which has been nullified has been nullified by glory, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@ which remains does so all the more in glory.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2So having such hope, in our outspokenness and boldness we conceal nothing, %u@1%u@3unlike Moses who placed a veil over his face so that the run-of-the-mill Israelites couldn’t gaze at the vestige of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@ that was deteriorating— %u@1%u@4not a chance—their minds were dead-set against it%u@[%u@e%u@]. In fact to this very day the same veil remains uncovered at the reading of the Old Testament%u@[%u@f%u@], since it’s done away with in Christ. %u@1%u@5No—to this day whenever the Old Testament%u@[%u@f%u@] happens to be read aloud a veil lies over their heart, %u@1%u@6but, if they were to turn to the Lord, the moment they do so, the veil gets taken off.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7Now the Lord is %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@c%i@k%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ the Spirit, and there’s freedom where the Spirit of the Lord %i@i%i@s. %u@1%u@8While gazing at the glory of the Lord with an uncovered face as though we’re looking intently in a mirror, we all are transformed into the same image %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ from %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@z%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ glory to %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@z%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ glory%u@[%u@g%u@], just as %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ from %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@z%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ the Spirit of the Lord %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@z%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@r%i@u%i@n%i@-%i@o%i@f%i@-%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@-%i@m%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y…Or: %i@i%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@-%i@s%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@t…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@t…%I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@z%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@z%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@y…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@l%i@o%i@r%i@y. Ref. note of 2:16.%fn~
%i@%sb~
2 Cor. Chapter 4%hb~
          %u@1On account of this, %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ having this administering %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s, to the degree that we’ve been shown mercy, we don’t lose heart— %u@2on the contrary, we quit for good doing those things that we’re ashamed of that we keep hidden%u@[%u@a%u@], not going here and there playing games with people%u@[%u@b%u@], nor putting a spin on%u@[%u@c%u@] the word of God, rather by means of the propagation of the truth we leave a good impression deep inside of everyone else%u@[%u@d%u@] %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ under God’s scrutiny%u@[%u@e%u@]. %u@3But even if our Gospel, our Good News Message, is veiled, it’s veiled among those who are perishing, %u@4among whom the god of this age (i.e., this current era of mankind’s history) blinded the minds of those who refuse to believe to where they don’t see the light of the Gospel of the glory of Christ, who is a spitting image of God. %u@5You see, we don’t preach %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ we%i@ ourselves %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@r%i@s but rather %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ Jesus Christ %i@i%i@s%i@ Lord, and %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ we ourselves %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ your humble servants%u@[%u@f%u@] on account of Jesus, %u@6since the God Who said, “Light shall shine out of darkness,” %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@n%i@e%i@ Who shined in our hearts with %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ light of the knowledge and understanding of the glory of God by means of the direct attention of%u@[%u@g%u@] Jesus Christ.%vn~
          %u@7We have this treasure in clay storage vessels (i.e., physical bodies) so that the over-and-above power would be of God and not from ourselves. %u@8%I@W%i@e%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ pressured from every direction and in trouble, but no—we’re not at the end of our rope%u@[%u@h%u@]; confused as to what to do—but not totally confused; %u@9persecuted but not abandoned; knocked off our feet but not destroyed; %u@1%u@0always carrying around in our body the death of Jesus, so that the life of Jesus would also be manifested in our body. %u@1%u@1You see, we the living are forever being forced into a position where death has control over us because of Jesus, so that the life of Jesus would also be manifested in our mortal body.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2So then, the death %I@I%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@d%i@ is at work in us, but the life %I@I%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@w%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k in you. %u@1%u@3Having a spirit of (i.e., a prevailing attitude of) faith that’s the same as what’s written %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t, “I believed, and in light of it all%i@ I spoke,” we too believe, and in light of it all we too speak, %u@1%u@4knowing for a fact that He who raised the Lord Jesus will also raise us together with Jesus and together with him cast us in a favorable light %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%u@[%u@i%u@]. %u@1%u@5You see, all %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ things are for your sake, so that the grace %i@b%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@s, having proliferated through the thanksgiving of the many, would abound to God’s glory.%vn~
          %u@1%u@6In light of this we’re not losing heart; on the contrary, even though our outer-person is deteriorating, yet our inner-person is being renewed day-in, day-out%u@[%u@j%u@]. %u@1%u@7To this point, the light weight of our affliction is incomparable to the heavy weight of glory at work in us, %u@1%u@8while we’re not looking at the things which are seen but the things that are not seen: for the things which are seen are transient, but the things which are not seen are eternal.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@d%i@d%i@e%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@d%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@e. A figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@p%i@l%i@a%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@a%i@f%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@p%i@u%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@s%i@i%i@f%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g. Comes from root meaning %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@t%i@;%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@.%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@l%i@s%i@e…Lit: %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@c%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@y…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@h%i@u%i@m%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@l%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@s. A figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: [%i@t%i@h%i@e] %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@p%i@e…Or: %i@b%i@o%i@x%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%fn~
