          %u@1%u@2We ask you, comrades, to know from first-hand observation those among you who do hard work and who have stepped forward to stand in leadership positions%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@ in %i@t%i@h%i@e Lord and who advise, warn, admonish, and instruct you, %u@1%u@3and to have a superabundant%u@[%u@e%u@] high regard for them in love on account of their work.%vn~
      Keep the peace among yourselves.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4We plead with you, comrades, that you advice, warn, admonish, and instruct the disorderly and insubordinate.%vn~
      Cheer up those who are discouraged.%vn~
      Take a strong interest in and help those who are weak (i.e., those who are unwell; worn out with a sickness; too physically weak to take care of themselves; powerless to do anything about their circumstances).%vn~
      Exercise patience with everyone.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5See that no one, when somebody does something bad to them, retaliates by doing something bad back to them%u@[%u@f%u@], but instead pursues the common good and the general good%u@[%u@g%u@] at all times.%vn~
          %u@1%u@6Rejoice all the time.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7Pray incessantly.%vn~
          %u@1%u@8Give thanks in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@d%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ all %i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@m%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@s%u@[%u@h%u@]; you see, this is the will of God for you in Christ Jesus.%vn~
          %u@1%u@9Do not extinguish or put out the Holy Spirit %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g. Do not quench, stifle, or suppress the %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ Spirit.%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Do not despise, treat with contempt, or have utter disdain for prophesy, %u@2%u@1but examine all things %i@i%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@u%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@e%i@s instead %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@j%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@d and hold onto the good.%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Stay away from any appearance of evil or wrong-doing.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3Now %i@m%i@a%i@y the God of peace Himself set you apart %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e complete in all respects and %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ meet all expectations; %i@m%i@a%i@y your spirit, soul, and body%u@[%U@A%u@] %i@b%i@e%i@ blameless at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.%vn~
          %u@2%u@4Faithful is He Who calls us; He will do %i@i%i@t.%vn~
          %u@2%u@5Comrades, pray for us too.%vn~
          %u@2%u@6Greet all the comrades with a holy hug%u@[%u@i%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@7Make a promise to the Lord to have %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s letter read aloud to all the comrades, %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@t.%vn~
          %u@2%u@8The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ %i@b%i@e%i@ with you.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@w%i@h%i@e%i@l%i@m%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u…Also: %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@p%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@w%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@h…Lit: %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@h%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@e%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@w%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s…The Gk. word %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ā%i@m%i@i%i@ (προΐστημι/Strong’s 4291). This is defined in note of 1 Cor. 15:24.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@s%i@u%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@b%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t…Also: %i@b%i@e%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@s…Lit: %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@-%i@a%i@b%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@n%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@,%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@t%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m…Lit: %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@d%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@m%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@s…Also: %i@a%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@m%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@i%i@n [or %i@a%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@g] %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@.%i@ %I@A%i@l%i@l%i@ can refer to things, events, circumstances, etc.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@g…Lit: %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@s%i@s. Liberties taken.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y…This verse is key in specifying the three components of every human being. The listing is ordered from most important to least important.%fn~
Spirit—man is a spiritual being, and as such has commonality with all spiritual beings: God, angels, and demons. Sin causes the spirit to die; receiving Christ causes the spirit to be born again. The Holy Spirit dwells in a believer’s human spirit. Man’s spirit guides him through the course of life.%fn~
Soul—the soul is the mind, will, emotions. It’s the peculiar things that give a person personality and vitality.%fn~
Body—the obvious of course, but it also has man’s carnal nature strapped to it
2 Thessalonians%ha~
       The Thessalonians’ curiosity about end-time prophecy has made them a favorite by all those down to our present age who pine for answers to eschatology questions. It’s as though this is a follow-up letter to Paul’s response to the first letter, or perhaps another one. Though the second chapter has these answers, from our perspective the answers are cryptic and need second-guessing since we aren’t privy to all the letters exchanged. Perhaps that makes it even more tantalizing and enticing to pore over.%nv~
       In the meantime, though, the Thessalonians had fallen on hard times and suffered persecutions. Unlike some of his other epistles, Paul is quick to point out that the wrath of God will come upon those who incite persecution—not the “turn the other cheek” stereotype. Paul closes with a defense of his conduct among them, particularly how hard he worked to earn his keep, and that others must do the same.%nv~
       The text is typical of Paul’s epistles. Paul uses a wider range of vocabulary than one finds in the Gospels, to put things in perspective.%nv~
%i@%sb~
2 Thess. Chapter 1%hb~
          %u@1%I@F%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ Paul, Silas, and Timothy:%vn~
      To the church in Thessalonica in God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ:%vn~
          %u@2Grace to you and peace from God our Father and from the Lord Jesus Christ.%vn~
          %u@3We ought to thank God for you all the time, comrades%u@[%u@a%u@]—as it’s worth %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g—because your faith is growing off the charts, and the love which every one of you has towards each other is proliferating, %u@4so much so that we personally are speaking with pride about you in the churches of God because of your perseverance and faith during all the persecutions and extreme difficulties which you endure, %u@5evidence of the just and fair deliberation%u@[%u@b%u@] of God in deeming you worthy of the kingdom of God, which—incidentally—you suffer for. %u@6At the end of the day, it’s right in God’s view to pay back those who’re causing you extreme difficulties%u@[%u@c%u@] %u@7and for%i@ you who are on the receiving end of these extreme difficulties %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@y%i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ relief (%i@a%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ with us) in the revelation of the Lord Jesus from heaven with his almighty angels%u@[%u@d%u@] %u@8with a %i@s%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ flame of fire%u@[%u@e%u@] meting out%u@[%u@f%u@] vengeance on those who don’t know God and to those who don’t obey the Gospel (i.e., the message) of our Lord Jesus; %u@9%i@a%i@n%i@d—%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@e%i@d—those very people will pay for it in a punishment of doom and destruction %i@i%i@s%i@s%i@u%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@ from %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ face (i.e., scrutinized closely and as a result of that scrutiny issued forth) of the Lord and from the glory of his might (i.e., issued forth by his power manifested in all its magnificent splendor), %u@1%u@0when he happens to come to be vested in glory among%u@[%u@g%u@] his saints (i.e., his people) and to be beheld, marveled, and admired among all those who have believed—since what we told you to be true in a dead-serious manner was believed—on that day.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1We also pray all the time for you with this goal %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@d: so that our God would deem you worthy of the calling %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ and would cause all sorts of goodness’s good-will and all sorts of deeds of faith in power to proliferate, %u@1%u@2so that the name (i.e., the reputation) of the our Lord Jesus would be glorified among you, and you in him, according to the grace of our God and %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ Lord Jesus Christ.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Also: %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@t%i@r%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@i%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n. The repetition of %i@t%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ as a verb followed by a noun is a figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@s…Lit: %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t. A figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@a%i@m%i@e. A figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t…Lit: %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g. As it is the shortened form of the word %i@p%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ used in v. 6, it refers to the same thing: the delivering of a payback.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@a%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@g…Or: %i@i%i@n; %i@b%i@y. The exact rendering is ambiguous.%fn~
%i@%sb~
2 Thess. Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1Now we’re asking you, comrades%u@[%u@a%u@], on behalf of the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ and our being rallied to him, %u@2for you not to be jarred from the frame of mind %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@ nor be inwardly disturbed or troubled either because of a strong, prevailing attitude%u@[%u@b%u@], a concept, a piece of information, or a letter %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d like %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ you would %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ from us, claiming%i@ that the day of the Lord has arrived already. %u@3Don’t %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ anyone delude you in any way, because it won’t come unless the “apostasy%u@[%U@A%u@]” (i.e., the great falling away from the faith) comes first and the Man of Lawlessness (i.e., the man who’s completely unconstrained by any law, any moral principle, or any godly code defining right and wrong), the Son of Destruction-Causing (i.e., the one who takes it as his personal mission to destroy), is revealed, %u@4the adversary to and the one who raises himself above everything which is said to be God-related or is an object of worship or devotion, so much so that he takes a seat (i.e., he sets up his court, his courtroom, his office) in the temple of God, advertising himself to everyone %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t he is a god.%vn~
          %u@5Don’t you remember that when I was still staying with you I kept telling you these things? %u@6And now you know for a fact the thing that restrains him from being revealed in his own time%u@[%U@B%u@]. %u@7In fact the mystery of %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ lawlessness%u@[%u@c%u@] is already in action, it’s just that he who restrains%u@[%u@d%u@] %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ at the moment %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ until he happens to disappear from the middle %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l; %u@8and then the Lawless-One will be revealed, whom the Lord Jesus will put to death by blowing %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%u@[%u@e%u@] and will annihilate %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ by the outward show of the brilliant splendor of his coming, %u@9%i@h%i@e whose coming is a reflection of Satan in action with all %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ phony power, signs, and wonders (i.e., miracles; miracles for the purpose of proving one’s legitimacy; awe-inspiring miracles) %u@1%u@0and with every kind of self-delusion%u@[%u@f%u@] which has unrighteousness as its source by those following a trajectory of perdition, because they didn’t receive the love of the truth resulting in their being saved (i.e., spared damnation). %u@1%u@1And because of this God will send them an activity of deception with the goal of and resulting in their believing in the lie, %u@1%u@2so that he would %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@u%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ judge every person who hasn’t believed in the truth but has preferred %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@ in the unrighteousness %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@e instead.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3But we ought to thank God for you all the time, comrades, %i@y%i@o%i@u who are loved by the Lord, because God chose you, %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ crème de la crème%u@[%u@g%u@], to salvation (i.e., being spared spiritual and physical destruction) in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Holy Spirit and in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ true faith. %u@1%u@4With this ends in mind, he called you through our Gospel (i.e. our message) to %i@t%i@h%i@e acquisition of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ glory %i@a%i@s our Lord Jesus Christ %i@h%i@a%i@s. %u@1%u@5So then, comrades, stand and keep standing in and get ahold of and keep holding onto the bylaws, code of conduct, and best-practices established in perpetuity%u@[%u@h%u@], which you received whether by a message %i@s%i@p%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ or through %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ our letters. %u@1%u@6But our Lord Jesus Christ himself and God our Father, Who loved us and gave %i@u%i@s everlasting comfort, consolation, and good hope by means of grace, %u@1%u@7will comfort and console your hearts and cause you to stand in every action and in %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ good affair.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@,%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@v%i@a%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@d%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@w%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@w%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ (ἀνομία/Strong’s 458). Gk: %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@a (feminine). Note that the Gk. word for Lawless-One in v. 7 is %i@a%i@n%i@o%i@m%i@o%i@s%i@ (masculine). Paul’s making a distinction by using these slightly different words: anomia refers to a quality, whereas anomos (ἄνομος/Strong’s 459) refers to a person, the embodiment of these qualities.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s…Gk. %i@o%i@ %i@k%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@x%i@ō%i@n%i@ [ὁ κατέχων, (κατέχων/Strong’s 2722)]. This is not quite the same as what’s in v. 6, which is %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@k%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@x%i@o%i@n%i@ (τὸ κατέχον, (κατέχον/Strong’s 2722)]%i@.%i@ Although the definite articles are both neuter/masculine, the substantive of the first is masculine while the second in neuter. This suggest that it’s “he who restrains” not “the thing that restrains.” Ref. note of v. 7.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@b%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m…Lit: %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@h%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@-%i@d%i@e%i@l%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n…Also: %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@t. Same word used in Mark 4:19; ref. note there.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@c%i@r%i@è%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@è%i@m%i@e…Lit: %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@-%i@f%i@r%i@u%i@i%i@t%i@s. Ref. note of Rom. 8:23.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@b%i@y%i@l%i@a%i@w%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@-%i@p%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@e%i@t%i@u%i@i%i@t%i@y…Lit: %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@a%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@s%i@y…The Gk. word %i@a%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@s%i@i%i@a%i@ (ἀποστασία/Strong’s 646)%i@.%i@ The NASB defines this as “a falling away from the faith.” Some Gk. scholars disagree with this and claim that it means “departure” instead, citing sources such as the %I@G%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@v%i@a%i@ %I@B%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@,%i@ Tyndale’s translation, the %I@G%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %I@B%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@e, Kenneth Wuest, and John Lineberry. Their reasoning for choosing “departure” over “a falling away” is that %i@a%i@p%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ā%i@m%i@i%i@ (ἀφίστημι/Strong’s 868)%i@,%i@ the root verb from which apostasia is derived, means %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@.%i@ Furthermore, they say that %i@a%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@s%i@i%i@a%i@ (the noun form) only occurs twice in the NT, here in 1 Thess. 2:3 and over in Acts 21:21. Although the context of Acts 21:21 suggests that apostasia means “falling away” rather than “departure,” the critics claim that this isn’t sufficient evidence to negate the core meaning of aphistāmi. However, what these dissenters fail to take into consideration is the use of apostasia in the LXX. Apostasia is found in Josh. 22:22; 2 Chron. 29:19; 2 Chron. 33:19; Jer. 2:19. In all four cases, apostasia means “rebellion, unfaithfulness, backsliding.” In other words, it means the same thing as “a falling away from the faith.” Paul read from the LXX frequently and extensively (it might’ve even been his primary study-Bible), and he was familiar with the occurrences and usages of apostasia in these passages and was mimicking its usage here in v. 3. But in any case, between the LXX and Acts. 21:21, there are five occurrences of apostasia in the Bible apart from 2:3 here. In five of the five occurrences—100% of the time—the meaning of apostasia is “a falling away from the faith.” The sixth must mean the same also, the one here in v. 3.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s [or %i@i%i@t%i@s] %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@.%i@ The “thing that restrains” in v. 7 is the Gk. %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@k%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@x%i@o%i@n%i@ (a form of %i@o%i@ %i@k%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@x%i@o%i@n), where %i@t%i@o%i@ is the neuter definite article and %i@k%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@x%i@o%i@n%i@ is the neuter participle form of the verb %i@k%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@x%i@ō%i@ (κατέχω/Strong’s 2722)%i@,%i@ which literally means %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@.%fn~
%i@%sb~
2 Thess. Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1In conclusion, pray for us, comrades%u@[%u@a%u@], so that the word of the Lord would spread rapidly%u@[%u@b%u@] and would be glorified just as it did with you %u@2and that we would be rescued from the perverse%u@[%u@c%u@] and wicked people %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@s: not everyone %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@s%i@ the Faith, you see. %u@3But the Lord is faithful, who will cause us to stand and will guard us from the Evil One. %u@4I’ve reached the point where I’m convinced in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Lord %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ where you’re concerned, because you are doing and will do what we charged you with. %u@5May the Lord direct your hearts to the love of God and to the steadfastness and endurance of Christ.%vn~
          %u@6Now we charge you, comrades, in %i@t%i@h%i@e name of our Lord Jesus Christ (i.e., by the authority given to us by Jesus Christ) to stay away from all comrades who conduct themselves with a blatant disregard for the rules which have been set in place and not according to the bylaws, code of conduct, and best-practices established in perpetuity%u@[%u@d%u@] which you received from us. %u@7In this regard you know in yourselves from first-hand experience how necessary it is for you to follow our example, since we didn’t disregard the rules %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e among you, %u@8nor did we mooch any meals from anyone%u@[%u@e%u@]—uh-uh—we were toiling day and night doing back-breaking labor so we wouldn’t be a burden on any of you— %u@9Not that we don’t have the right %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@u%i@s, but %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@o%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d instead so that we could offer ourselves to you as an example for you to imitate.%vn~
          %u@1%u@0And in fact, when we were with you, we kept telling you to obey this rule: If a given person doesn’t want to work %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ don’t let him have a meal at mealtime%u@[%U@A%u@]. %u@1%u@1In fact we hear that there are some people among you going about not following the rules, not doing any work but goofing off%u@[%U@B%u@] instead. %u@1%u@2To such people we charge and advise in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Lord Jesus Christ %i@c%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ so that by keeping quiet while working they would eat their own meal (i.e., would be entitled to receive a meal).%vn~
          %u@1%u@3But you, comrades—don’t get tired of doing good. %u@1%u@4But if someone won’t obey the message %i@w%i@e%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ by %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ letter %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g, take note of this %i@g%i@u%i@y: don’t associate with or get mixed up with him, so that he’ll be put to shame. %u@1%u@5And don’t think of %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ as an enemy, but warn and admonish %i@h%i@i%i@m as a comrade instead.%vn~
          %u@1%u@6May the Lord of Peace himself grant you the peace throughout every %i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@m%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ in every place%u@[%u@f%u@].%vn~
      %I@M%i@a%i@y%i@ the Lord %i@b%i@e%i@ with you all.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7The greeting %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ Paul’s%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g, which is a distinguishing feature of every letter %I@I%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@e:%vn~
        %C@T%C@H%C@I%C@S%c@ %C@I%C@S%c@ %C@T%C@H%C@E%c@ %C@W%C@A%C@Y%c@ %C@I%c@ %C@W%C@R%C@I%C@T%C@E%u@[%U@C%u@].%vn~
          %u@1%u@8The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ %i@b%i@e%i@ with you all.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@s%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@p%i@i%i@d%i@l%i@y…Lit: %i@r%i@u%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e…Lit: %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@b%i@y%i@l%i@a%i@w%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@-%i@p%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@e%i@t%i@u%i@i%i@t%i@y…Lit: traditions%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@m%i@o%i@o%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@f%i@t%i@-%i@b%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@m%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e. The GT is more poetic.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e…Lit: %i@e%i@a%i@t. When people congregated, they had a couple people cook for the entire group, because that was the most efficient way of handling food preparation up until modern times. Everyone would sit down at a table together at the same time, the food would be passed around, and it would all be shared. This proscription is to forbid a person from having a seat at the table and share in the meal if he didn’t share in the common work also.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@g%i@o%i@o%i@f%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@s%i@y%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@;%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@d%i@d%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g. The Gk. word literally means “to go around the periphery of work.” The picture is of someone going here or there when working—or supposedly working. Instead, he’s bothering other people who are working, striking up non-work-related conversations, instead of getting his own work done. The assertion that this is what this Gk. means is confirmed by the statement in v. 12 which says to “keeping quiet while working.” Nothing has changed since ancient times!%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%I@T%I@H%I@I%I@S%i@ %I@I%I@S%i@ %I@T%I@H%I@E%i@ %I@W%I@A%I@Y%i@ %I@I%i@ %I@W%I@R%I@I%I@T%I@E…With this remark, Paul is demonstrating what is handwriting looks like, so they can tell if a forger sent a forgery. Also, it’s a personal touch, sort of like signing one’s signature at the bottom of a typed letter.
1 Timothy%ha~
       Paul’s instructions to one of his closest assistants, his “dear son” Timothy, has been broadened into guidelines which all Christian churches should follow. Paul doesn’t just give sterile rules to do this, that, and the other, but gets into the details of what’s going on inside the hearts and minds of various people—especially the nefarious ones, adding a lot of color to the epistles he sent to Timothy.%nv~
       The text is typical of Paul: mastery of Greek, an extensive vocabulary, Western thought, ambiguous in parts due to its brevity or to knowledge privy to the writer and the reader.%nv~
%i@%sb~
1 Timothy Chapter 1%hb~
          %u@1Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus according to the command of God our savior and Christ Jesus our hope:%vn~
          %u@2To Timothy, a genuine son%u@[%u@a%u@] in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Faith:%vn~
      Grace, mercy, peace—from God %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Father and from Christ Jesus our Lord.%vn~
          %u@3Just as I advised you to remain in Ephesus while on %i@m%i@y way to Macedonia so that you would impress upon certain individuals not to go about teaching things which are…shall we say…different%u@[%u@b%u@] %u@4or to take myths or endless genealogies seriously (the very things which generate a lot of %i@s%i@t%i@u%i@p%i@i%i@d%i@ questions), more %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@l%i@y than %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@s%i@ godly stewardship, a stewardship which is by means of%i@ faith%u@[%u@c%u@]. %u@5But the bottom line of the command %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h is love from a clean heart and a good conscience, %u@6of which a few people in particular have veered off into a ditch of senseless discussion, %u@7wanting to be instructors in the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s, not understanding what they’re saying or the implications of what they insist is true.%vn~
          %u@8Now we know that the Law is just fine if someone were to use it legitimately, %u@9knowing this for certain: law (i.e., the Law of Moses in particular or any code of right and wrong for that matter) was put in place for a reason, not for someone who lives right but for the lawless, for those who refuse to submit to authority, for those who aren’t pious, for those who murder their fathers, their mothers, their brothers, %u@1%u@0for fornicators (i.e., those who indulge in gross sexual immorality), for homosexuals, kidnappers, liars, perjurers, and %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ anyone who supplants what’s been put into place with something different than healthy doctrine, %u@1%u@1%i@d%i@o%i@c%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ which is in line with the glorious Gospel of the God Who is blessed, %i@d%i@o%i@c%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ that I’ve been entrusted with.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2I have grace for my empowerment in Christ Jesus our Lord, since he trusted me enough to make me a minister%u@[%u@d%u@], %u@1%u@3%i@m%i@e who used to be a blasphemer, a persecutor, and one who was insolent and violent—but no—He showed mercy since I did these things when I didn’t know better %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ in unbelief, %u@1%u@4and the grace of our Lord proliferated out of bounds with faith and love which is in Christ Jesus.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5This statement is trustworthy and from any point of view is worth being accepted: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners, I myself being the foremost. %u@1%u@6In spite of this I was shown mercy, so that in me foremost Christ Jesus would demonstrate every kind of patience imaginable, with a view towards those in the future who will be believing in%u@[%u@e%u@] him resulting in eternal life.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7Now to the King of the eternities—to the Incorruptible, Invisible, Singular God—%i@b%i@e%i@ honor and glory forever and ever. Amen (i.e., let us pause a moment for that remark to sink in).%vn~
          %u@1%u@8These things I’m charging you with, I entrust to you, Timothy %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ son, according to the prophesies over you which were given beforehand to lead you on your way, so that you would “serve in the army” %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k among them and be a fine soldier, %u@1%u@9having faith and a good conscience, which some, having shoved aside things pertaining to the Faith, are shipwrecked (i.e., their lives have been devastated), %u@2%u@0among whom are Hymenaeus and Alexander, whom I’ve handed over to Satan so that he would train them (train them like one trains a child) not to talk trash or blaspheme.%i@%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@n…Or: %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@s%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y…%i@d%i@i%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@t…Same word used in 6:3; ref. note there%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@b%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h…Or: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@F%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@o%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@i%i@n…Lit: %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@%fn~
%i@%sb~
1 Timothy Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1I urge %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ first above all %i@e%i@l%i@s%i@e %i@y%i@o%i@u offer supplications (i.e., urgent requests), prayers (i.e., generic prayers), intercessions (i.e., a two-way exchange in prayer), and giving of thanks%u@[%U@A%u@]%u@ for all people, %u@2for kings and for every high-ranking official, so that we may spend our time leading a quiet (i.e., free of disturbances, crises, unrest, etc.) and tranquil life in piety and dignity in every respect. %u@3This is a good thing to do, is acceptable, pleasing, and welcomed when examined by%u@[%u@a%u@] God our Savior, %u@4Who wants all people to be saved and to come to the knowledge and understanding of the truth. %u@5The fact of the matter is that there is one God %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ one mediator between God and mankind, %i@t%i@h%i@e man Christ Jesus, %u@6who gave himself %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e an atonement%u@[%u@b%u@]—the price of redemption; the price to buy someone back—for everyone, %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ that which serves as proof or makes a solemn statement in every individual period of human history%u@[%u@c%u@]— %u@7For which I was appointed a preacher and an apostle (i.e., a missionary)—I’m telling you the truth—no lie—an instructor of Gentiles in what true faith really is%u@[%u@d%u@].%vn~
          %u@8After some careful thought, I desire that men in every place pray and pray, lifting up holy hands, keeping a distance from anger and plotting. %u@9Likewise, %I@I%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t women dress themselves in good taste%u@[%u@e%u@] %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@o%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ with modesty and good judgment combined with self-control, not %i@d%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ in an %i@e%i@x%i@o%i@t%i@i%i@c hairstyle%u@[%u@f%u@] and with %i@u%i@l%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@-%i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ gold %i@j%i@e%i@w%i@e%i@l%i@r%i@y or pearls or expensive clothing%u@[%U@B%u@], %u@1%u@0but instead %I@I%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@a%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@ (which is befitting to women sworn to a life of piety to God) by good works.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1Have a woman%u@[%U@C%u@] learn in silence with total submissiveness%u@[%U@D%u@]; %u@1%u@2I don’t permit a woman to give instructions %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@o%u@[%U@E%u@], dominate, or give orders to a man, but rather %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ to be in silence. %u@1%u@3The fact of the matter is that Adam was first formed %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@E%i@d%i@e%i@n, then Eve %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@e%i@d. %u@1%u@4Plus Adam was not deceived %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ but the woman %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d, %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ once deceived, found herself%u@[%u@g%u@] in transgression%u@[%U@F%u@]. %u@1%u@5But she will be spared calamity%u@[%U@G%u@] through the childbearing %i@y%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@s%i@ if she were to continue in faith, love, and holiness with good judgment combined with self-control%u@[%u@h%u@].%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@a%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t…Also: %i@r%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@o%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@m%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@y…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@s…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@h. A hendiadys. Ref. note of Matt. 3:11.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@o%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@e%i@x%i@o%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@y%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@i%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@b%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@-%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@l…Same phrase used in v. 9.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@s%i@u%i@p%i@p%i@l%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@(%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@,%i@ %i@u%i@r%i@g%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@q%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@s%i@)%i@,%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@y%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@(%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@,%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@y%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@)%i@,%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@(%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@w%i@o%i@-%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@y%i@e%i@r%i@)%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@k%i@s …Gk. words %i@d%i@e%i@ā%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ā%i@,%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@u%i@k%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@e%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@a.%fn~
Deāsis (δέησις/Strong’s 1162)—a prayer which asks for wants or needs; urgent requests%fn~
Proseuchā (προσευχή/Strong’s 4335)—lit: %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o. This is the general word for prayer. Since a secondary meaning is a place of prayer, it insinuates prayers done in that setting, hence: formal prayers; structured prayers; prayers done at a set time.%fn~
Enteuksis (ἔντευξις/Strong’s 1783)—lit: %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@;%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@;%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@;%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n. The word is rendered %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@.%i@ This kind of prayer insinuates a back-and-forth exchange between two parties; some sort of negotiation. The negotiations can be to suspend a judgment incurred because of a violation of the rules or other just circumstances, such as when Abraham negotiated with God to spare Sodom and Gomorrah. In Abraham’s case, the intercession was done on behalf of another party, but intercession can be done for one’s own self.%fn~
Eucharistia (εὐχαριστία/Strong’s 2169)—The giving of thanks to God, which is a kind of prayer.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@o%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@y%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@u%i@l%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@-%i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@j%i@e%i@w%i@e%i@l%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@l%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@l%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g. As what Paul writes here is identical to what Peter writes in 1 Pet. 3:3, this implies that this was a problem in the early church. Since Paul precedes this by saying that women should dress in good taste, modestly, and exercise good judgment and self-control, it stands to reason that these hairstyling, jewelry, and expensive clothes were not considered to be good taste, modest, or indicative of one exercising good judgment. Since we in modern times don’t consider the use of hairstyling, jewelry, etc. to be bad taste or indicative of a lack of judgment (except for a few very conservative denominations, most of which have reversed their position), this warrants closer examination. %fn~
Let’s assume that the amount of gold in piece a jewelry is equivalent to the gold in a Roman Aureus (8g of gold), which was valued at 25 Denarii, and let’s assume each Denarius represented a day’s labor. If there are 312 working days in a years, this represents around 8% of a laborer’s annual income. So from the perspective of us in modern times, if a person earns $50,000 a year, an 8g piece of gold jewelry would cost around $5000 in today’s money (and the same 8g of gold goes for around $500 nowadays). This means that gold jewelry was more expensive for them back then that it is for us, as this hypothetical example shows an 8-to-1 difference then to now.%fn~
So it was more expensive, in terms of purchasing power, for the average woman to dress in the way that Peter and Paul admonish them not to than it is for a woman to dress herself today in the same way. It may be that these women were spending outrageous amounts of money on their dress, and from the remarks Peter and Paul made, were investing their self-image in their ability to dress lavishly and were trying to imitate the world, including the lasciviousness of worldly women.%fn~
The lesson that modern-day Christian women should learn is to recognize the root-problems here and not be so concerned about the letter of the law. Women shouldn’t be obsessed with dressing in clothing that they can’t afford, trying to imitate those in the world who live an ungodly life, or base their self-image on the way they look. Being beautiful on the inside is more important than trying to make oneself beautiful on the outside.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@w%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n…The Gk. words rendered %i@m%i@a%i@n and %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n are %i@a%i@n%i@ā%i@r (ἀνήρ/Strong’s 435) and %i@g%i@u%i@n%i@a%i@i%i@k%i@a%i@ (γυνή/Strong’s 1135), which are also the same words rendered %i@h%i@u%i@s%i@b%i@a%i@n%i@d and %i@w%i@i%i@f%i@e. The ambiguity (ambiguity…I thought Gk. was this ultra-specific language?) is resolved by context. When Paul leaves instructions for the anār and the gunaika in Ephesians and Colossians, the context is obvious: the rendering is husband and wife. Here also the rendering is context-dependent. Is Paul talking about husbands and wives or men and women? Most translations choose men and women. To justify it being husbands and wives, there must be something in the context that indicates that this is the case. The evidence in that favor is that vv. 11,12 are similar to 1 Cor. 14:33–36, which we know was addressed to wives. Also, v. 15 talks about bearing children, which means that it’s addressed to wives. The subject is omitted from the sentence of v. 15, relying on the verb conjugation in conjunction with the context to insinuate that the subject is %i@s%i@h%i@e%i@.%i@ It Gk., it’s not common to have the subject omitted entirely. In lieu of its total omission, a definite article is used as a pronoun, as a definite article is short, perhaps is even a proclitic. But by omitting the subject entirely, the writer assumes that the reader knows beyond any doubt that the subject to be used is easily insinuated by the context. Such is the case. Through this insinuation, v. 15 is tightly bound to the context. Therefore, since v. 15 addresses wives, not women, coupled with the similarity between this passage and 1 Cor. 14:33–36, one may put forth a weighty argument that the entire context of vv. 11–15 is of wives specifically, not of women in general.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@t%i@o%i@t%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@m%i@i%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s…Lit: %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@m%i@i%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n. Ref. notes of Eph. 5:22; 1 Pet. 2:18 which explain the difference between %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@ and %i@o%i@b%i@e%i@y%i@.%i@%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@o…Also: %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h. The Gk. word %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@a%i@s%i@k%i@ō (διδάσκω/Strong’s ). The meaning of this word extends beyond mere definition of the English word %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h, and includes giving instruction as to what rules a person must follow. It’s used this way in Acts 15:1 (ref. note there). Since what follows the word didaskō here in v. 12 is “dominate” and “give orders,” it stands to reason that didaskō is used in this context to refer to giving instructions on what rules one should follow more so than meaning teaching (explaining).%fn~
Now, in vv. 13, 14, Paul gives the reasons why a woman shouldn’t be giving instruction. First is the fact that Adam was created before Eve and is therefore receives the leadership position. Second, women are more easily deceived, more so than men (cults usually have more women than men, for example), and for this reason are less qualified to be instructors. In spite of this, Titus 1:3 allows women to be teachers.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%I@P%i@l%i@u%i@s%i@ %I@A%i@d%i@a%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@g%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n…We must keep in mind that Paul credits Adam—not Eve—with the original sin (Rom. 5:14), in spite of centuries of Christian teaching to the contrary. Though both Adam and Eve sinned in the garden, Adam was not deceived when he partook of the forbidden fruit, and this makes his sin more heinous than Eve’s, as—according to this verse here—he knew exactly what he was doing when he bit the fruit. It was bold-faced disobedience in light of the full understanding and recollection of God’s commandment.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%i@s%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@a%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@b%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g %i@y%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@s …Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@b%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g. The Gk. word %i@s%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ rendered %i@s%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@a%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ here is not in reference to her receiving Christ. Some that this is a promise for a woman escape death or harm when giving birth, which up until modern times was a serious threat to a woman’s well-being.%fn~
%i@%sb~
1 Timothy Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1You can count on this statement being true: if someone aspires to be a bishop%u@[%u@a%u@] (i.e., a head pastor), he desires to do something excellent%u@[%u@b%u@]. %u@2So a bishop candidate must have no moral character flaws%u@[%u@c%u@]; must be the husband of one woman%u@[%U@A%u@] (i.e., not divorced and remarried); self-controlled and exercise moderation in vices such as drinking; be sensible, serious, and level-headed; be respected, held in high esteem, and honorable; be hospitable, able to reach out to others, and likes and can work with people who are different than himself; be capable of giving instructions to others or teaching them; %u@3not be a heavy drinker or have a drinking problem; not a bully, a brawler, or someone who gets into fights, but yielding, gentle, courteous, and tolerant instead, and avoids fights; not fondly attached to money; %u@4does a good job of presiding over his household; keeps his children in obedience with %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ respectful in all respects (%u@5but if someone can’t preside over his own household, how will he look after God’s household?); %u@6not a newbie, so that he won’t become full of himself or conceited and fall to %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Accuser’s (the Devil’s) true accusations of guilt. %u@7Outsiders must have a good report to give about him, so that he won’t fall into disgrace: the Accuser’s trap%u@[%u@d%u@].%vn~
          %u@8Likewise, deacons%u@[%u@a%u@] (i.e., associate pastors and ministry directors) %i@m%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e honorable and respectable; not insincere or say one thing one moment and contradict it another; not consumed with drinking%u@[%u@e%u@]; not always trying to make a fast buck through shady business practices; %u@9possessing the mystery of the Faith in a clean conscience. %u@1%u@0Let these %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@d%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@s%i@ first be examined and approved, then let them serve as deacons %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ being %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ to have no moral character flaws.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@’ wives must be honorable and respectable as well; not slanderers; self-controlled and exercising moderation in vices such as drinking; faithful in all respects. %u@1%u@2Make sure%u@[%u@f%u@] deacons are the husbands of one wife (i.e., have not been divorced and remarried); do a good job of presiding over their children and over their household. %u@1%u@3In fact, those who have done a good job serving as a deacon take a big step forward in their own lives%u@[%u@g%u@] and acquire much boldness and confidence in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Faith which is in Christ Jesus.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4I’m writing these things to you and hoping to visit you post-haste. %u@1%u@5But in case I’m delayed, %I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@w%i@ so that you would know for a fact how %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ house of God, which very thing is the church of the Living God, a pillar and a chief supporting base of the truth, must be run%u@[%u@h%u@]. %u@1%u@6And great, admittedly, is the mystery%u@[%U@B%u@] of piety:%vn~
%si~
%I@H%i@e who appeared in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ flesh%vp~
Was declared righteous in spirit%u@[%u@i%u@]%vp~
Was seen by angels%vp~
Was preached to the Gentiles%vp~
Was believed by the world%vp~
Was taken up in glory%vp~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@b%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@o%i@p%i@s…%i@d%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s…Ref. note of 1 Cor. 15:24%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@m%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@a%i@w%i@s…Or: %i@u%i@n%i@i%i@m%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e. The NASB renders this “beyond reproach.”%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@d%i@i%i@s%i@g%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@:%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@A%i@c%i@c%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@p…Lit: %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@g%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@n%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@D%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l. A hendiadys; ref. note of Matt. 3:11.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@u%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@c%i@c%i@u%i@p%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ [%i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g] %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@n%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@r%i@e…Lit: %i@l%i@e%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@w%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@a%i@c%i@q%i@u%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@r%i@u%i@n…Also: %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d; %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@y%i@l%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t…Or: %i@i%i@n [%i@t%i@h%i@e] %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t. Though the GT is ambiguous, the preceding stanza’s “in the flesh” skews the resolution to %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ rather than %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@.%i@%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@s%i@b%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n…This covers both polygamy (incidentally) and marriage, divorce, then remarriage (primarily). Many interpret this proscription as applying to polygamy, but polygamy wasn’t practiced in the parts of the Roman Empire where Paul’s churches were. Furthermore, in 5:9 when Paul is talking about widows, he says that she should be “the wife of one man.” This is the same wording in GT as “husband of one woman,” except in reverse. If “husband of one woman” were talking about polygamy—in this case, a single man having multiple wives at the same time—then “wife of one man” would have to be talking about a single woman having multiple husbands at the same time—something which is unheard of.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@m%i@y%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@y…The “mystery of piety” here and the mystery of “Christ in you, the hope of glory” (Col. 1:27) refines the definition of %i@m%i@y%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ as used in the NT: a “mystery” is something which is profound.%fn~
%i@%sb~
1 Timothy Chapter 4%hb~
          %u@1The Spirit says explicitly that in later periods of human history%u@[%u@a%u@] some will revolt%u@[%u@b%u@] from the Faith, their attention occupied by deceiving spirits and doctrines or teachings of demons, %u@2telling lies in hypocrisy, having reached the point where they’ve seared their own conscience, %u@3hindering or preventing getting married, abstaining from foods that God created to be taken %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@u%i@m%i@e%i@d with thanksgiving by those who believe and have perceived, recognized, and understood the truth. %u@4%I@A%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ because God’s entire creation is excellent, and nothing which is received with thanksgiving is to be rejected, %u@5for %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ is designated holy on account of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ word of God and %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ a request offered in prayer.%vn~
          %u@6By teaching the comrades%u@[%u@c%u@] these things until they’re built into them, you’ll be a fine minister%u@[%u@d%u@] of Christ Jesus, firming up the words of the Faith and of the quality teaching which you have closely followed. %u@7Refuse to receive %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ profane and desecrated, %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ old wives’ tales. Put yourself on a training program (like you do at the gym) towards %i@b%i@u%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ piety. %u@8Physical training, you see, is beneficial to a small degree, but piety is beneficial in every respect, holding a promise of life (i.e., that special fullness of life) in the present time and in the time to come.%vn~
          %u@9You can count on %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t statement %I@I%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ being true, and it deserves to be accepted any way you look at it. %u@1%u@0In fact we work hard and strive for this, since we have set our hope on %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Living God, Who is %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Savior of all people, especially those who believe.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1Charge %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h these things and instruct %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m. %u@1%u@2Don’t let anyone think less of you or treat you disrespectfully because you’re young, but instead become an example for the believers %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w in speech, in manner, in love, in faith, in purity (%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n).%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Stay busy with %I@S%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@p%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ reading, with exhortation and encouragement, with teaching (%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n) until I get there. %u@1%u@4Don’t neglect the %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ gift%u@[%u@e%u@] in you which was given to you through prophecy and accompanied by the laying on of hands by the elders (i.e., the church board). %u@1%u@5Put these things %I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ into practice; be in them (i.e., be totally into them), so that your progress will be quite noticeable to everyone. %u@1%u@6Pay close attention to yourself—how you are and what you do—and to your doctrine and teaching. Immerse yourself in them. You see, by so doing, you’ll be preserving yourself, protecting yourself, and keeping yourself from harm, you and those who listen to you.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@y…Lit: %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@v%i@o%i@l%i@t…Lit: [%i@g%i@o] %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@o%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@f%i@t…same wording as what’s found in 1 Cor. 12; refers to the same%fn~
%i@%sb~
1 Timothy Chapter 5%hb~
          %u@1Don’t chide an older man, speaking to him condescendingly, but address him as though he goes by “Mr.”%u@[%u@a%u@], %u@2an older woman like she’s “Mrs.”, an older teen to twenties male like he’s your comrade%u@[%u@b%u@], an older teens to twenties female like she’s your woman-comrade %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ with purity in every respect.%vn~
          %u@3Give financial support to a widow%u@[%u@c%u@] who really%i@ is a widow, %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@l%i@p%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r. %u@4But if a given widow has children or grandchildren, let %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@r%i@e%i@n learn that their highest priority duty is to their household (i.e., those in their immediate family, the ones they currently or used to live with) and %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ pay those who were their parents %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@p back with financial compensation; this is pleasing when put to the close scrutiny of%u@[%u@d%u@] God, you see.%vn~
          %u@5Now the widow who’s truly destitute and has reached the point where she’s all alone %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r—%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ has set her hope on God, and that she continuously, consistently prays day and night offering up supplications and prayers%u@[%u@e%u@]; %u@6but the self-indulgent, luxury-seeking, pleasure-loving woman, %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h living %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@r%i@m%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@f%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@,%i@ has %i@a%i@l%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y died.%vn~
          %u@7Give the order that these%i@ %i@r%i@u%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@d, so that there’d be no way anyone could point a finger at %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m. %u@8But if someone won’t provide for his own %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s, especially those of his own household, he’s denied the Faith and is worse than an unbeliever.%vn~
          %u@9Enroll a widow %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@g%i@r%i@a%i@m if she’s not less than sixty years old, the wife of one husband (i.e., not married, divorced, then remarried before being a widow); %u@1%u@0%i@e%i@n%i@r%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%u@ %i@i%i@f there are eyewitness accounts and testimonies of her good deeds; %i@e%i@n%i@r%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r if she raised children; if she shows hospitality; if she washed the saints’ feet (i.e., done demeaning chores for the church and its members); if she helped those in distress; if she’s devoted herself to good works of every sort.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1But deny %i@r%i@e%i@q%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@r%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@ widows who are young: you see, when they become overpowered with physical, sensual desires contrary to %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@v%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@o Christ%u@[%U@A%u@] in their wanting to get married, %u@1%u@2they’ll be “guilty as charged” (so to speak) because they abandoned their previous obligation. %u@1%u@3At the same time they learn to be lazy, making the rounds from house to house—not just lazy but they also run at the mouth and stick their noses where they’re not wanted, saying things that shouldn’t be said.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4So, after thinking about it, I want young %i@w%i@i%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@s to get married, have children, and take responsibility for their house and for those in it, so they won’t give the Opponent any opportunity to verbally abuse them, scolding and insulting them. %u@1%u@5The fact of the matter is that some have already gone in a different direction to become ardent followers of Satan%u@[%u@f%u@]. %u@1%u@6If a particular woman who is a believer has widows %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@e%u@[%u@g%u@], have her help them and not be a burden on the church, so that the ones who really are widows %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@c%i@h may be helped.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7Let the elders (i.e., those on the church board) who do a good job of running things be entitled to twice their pay%u@[%u@h%u@], especially those who work hard at speaking and teaching. %u@1%u@8You see, the Scripture says “do not muzzle the ox while threshing” and “the worker is entitled to his paycheck.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@9Don’t accept an accusation of wrongdoing against an elder except if %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ by two or three people who solemnly swear that it’s true.%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Expose those who are sinners in front of everyone, so that everyone will become afraid %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g.%vn~
          %u@2%u@1I solemnly affirm these things and declare them to be true before God, Christ Jesus, and the special angels%u@[%u@j%u@], so that you would guard these things without prejudice, doing nothing out of favoritism.%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Don’t be too eager to lay hands on anyone %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@b%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r nor %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u participate in others’ sins: keep yourself unsullied.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3Don’t %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t drink water %i@o%i@n%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e, but use a little wine %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@d%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ because of %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r stomach and your frequent ailments%u@[%u@k%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@4For some people, their sins are obvious, paraded before them with much fanfare for everyone to see in front of them on their way to judgment; but some come right behind them, quietly, unannounced, and unexpected by everyone%u@[%U@B%u@]. %u@2%u@5Deeds %i@o%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@e the same way %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n: the deeds which are exemplary are obvious %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e, but the ones which are otherwise can’t be kept hidden.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@a%i@d%i@d%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@“%I@M%i@r%i@.%i@”…Lit: %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@d%i@o%i@w…Lit: %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r [%i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@u%i@m%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o] %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@d%i@o%i@w%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@c%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@s%i@u%i@p%i@p%i@l%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@y%i@e%i@r%i@s…Ref. note of 2:1%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@b%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@t%i@a%i@n…Or: %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@t%i@a%i@n…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@S%i@a%i@t%i@a%i@n. A NT expression; ref. note of Matt. 4:19.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%I@I%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@s %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@e…I’m unsure whether this is correct%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@t%i@w%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@y…Lit: %i@d%i@o%i@u%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r [%i@h%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@u%i@m]%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@c%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@n…Or: %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@s…Lit: %i@c%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@s. This might be a reference to the seraphim and cherubim.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@a%i@i%i@l%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s…Lit: %i@w%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@e%i@s. Ref. note of John 5:3.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@p%i@h%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@v%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t…The single Gk. word rendered %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@p%i@h%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@s is a word Paul coins here, not found anywhere else. Paul may be referring to sexual desire, or he may be referring to the desire of a woman to become more affluent through marriage, which would bring those extra creature-comforts she misses in her poverty (or both perhaps.) To this second point, the root for this Gk. word appears in Rev. 18:7,9, and is rendered %i@l%i@u%i@x%i@u%i@r%i@y%i@ there.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@n%i@f%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@;%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@,%i@ %i@q%i@u%i@i%i@e%i@t%i@l%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@a%i@n%i@n%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e…Lit: %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@;%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@d. A metaphor of the victory parade of a general who’s won a great victory and wishes to flaunt his victory when he marches into the city. The procession is orchestrated so that, when arriving in the city, the spoils of war, the glitz, the glamor go first. This is done to attract attention and applause and to drum up awe and excitement. Then comes the general. After him comes the slaves he’s captured, etc. They get little attention. In the metaphor, the sins of some people are well-known, everyone has talked and talked about them, dissecting every bit of the evil deed. But the sins of some people are a well-kept secret, but they will make their way to judgment.%fn~
%i@%sb~
1 Timothy Chapter 6%hb~
          %u@1Anyone at all who’s forced to be a slave%u@[%u@a%u@], let him esteem his master worthy of total honor, so that God’s reputation and the things %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@h believes in not be bad-mouthed. %u@2They who have masters who are believers mustn’t despise them because they’re fellow-comrades%u@[%u@b%u@], but should serve them all the more, because they are faithful and beloved, they who are having a surrogate take their place in assisting them in what’s beneficial.%vn~
      Give instructions in these %i@m%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@s and exhort and encourage %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@.%i@ %u@3If anyone teaches things which are…shall we say…different%u@[%U@A%u@], and isn’t headed in the direction %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g sound messages, %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ messages of our Lord Jesus Christ and teaching in line with godliness, %u@4then he’s become conceited, understanding nothing, but has a sick desire for debates and controversies instead, out of which he becomes envious, engages in quarrelling and strife, he slanders, becomes paranoid, %u@5constantly arguing with people who are morally depraved whose mind is also deprived of the truth, of the opinion that godliness is a means of gain—%vn~
          %u@6—But godliness with contentment alongside it %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ is a means of great gain. %u@7We brought nothing %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@u%i@s into the world %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@r%i@n, you see, and we sure can’t%u@[%u@c%u@] take anything out %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@t. %u@8Regular meals and %i@a%i@d%i@e%i@q%i@u%i@a%i@t%i@e clothing—we’ll be satisfied with these things. %u@9But those who want and plan to get richer and richer%u@[%U@B%u@] fall into temptation, into a trap, and into many strong desires which are unintelligent, dull-witted, and harmful. %u@1%u@0The fact of the matter is that a %i@p%i@o%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ root-%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e of every type of the evils %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@l%i@d%i@ is the love of money, which some who’ve made it their goal %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ have veered off from the Faith and have skewered themselves through with a spit (like when roasting meat), skewering themselves all over with a lot of misery, with many mental pains, and with a tremendous amount of %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@u%i@e%i@ suffering.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1Now you, oh man of God—run away as fast as you can from these things. Pursue righteousness, piety, faith, love, patience, gentleness, %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@.%i@ %u@1%u@2Fight the good fight of the Faith. Grab and hold onto that special fullness of life, eternal life, to which ends you were called and for which you confessed the Good Confession before many witnesses.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3I charge you before God the Life-Causer of everything and Christ Jesus who submitted the Good Confession as testimony to Pontius Pilate %u@1%u@4to keep the%i@ commandment %I@I%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@e%i@ spotless and blameless until the appearance of our Lord Jesus Christ, %u@1%u@5which %i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ he will indicate in separate eras of time, he the blessed and singular authority, the King of the kings and Lord of the lords, %u@1%u@6the one having immortality, whose resides %i@i%i@n unapproachable light which no one has seen or is able to stare at: to him %i@b%i@e%i@ honor and might forever. Amen (i.e., let us pause a moment for that remark to sink in).%vn~
          %u@1%u@7Charge those who are rich in %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s present age not to be high-minded or to set their hope on the uncertainty of wealth, but to instead %i@s%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ on God the One Who richly makes available to us all %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ things for %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ enjoyment, %u@1%u@8%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@v%i@a%i@i%i@l%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n be doing good things to others, %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ become richer in top-notch works, %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ be generous, willing to share, %u@1%u@9storing away for themselves a good nest egg%u@[%u@d%u@] for the future, so that they would grab and hold onto what life really is.%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Oh, Timothy, guard what’s been entrusted to you, avoid the desecrated, profane kind of useless chatter and the contradictions of so-called knowledge and understanding, %u@2%u@1which some, %i@b%i@y%i@ professing %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s, have veered off into a ditch with respect to the Faith.%vn~
      The grace %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ with you all.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@l%i@a%i@v%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@k%i@e. The Gk. word %i@d%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@o%i@s%i@ (δοῦλος/Strong’s 1401)%i@,%i@ which is either servant or slave, is narrowed in scope to mean %i@s%i@l%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ and not %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@ by the phrase %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@.%i@ Also, plural words in this verse changed to singular for readability.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@-%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@’%i@t…Lit: %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@’%i@t. Various manuscripts differ here, and probably because what’s in several of the better manuscripts makes little sense.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@g%i@g…Lit: %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@…%i@s%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@…%i@d%i@i%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@t…All these are the single Gk. verb %i@h%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@d%i@s%i@a%i@k%i@ō%i@ (ἑτεροδιδασκαλέω/Strong’s 2085), “to different-teach.” This word only appears twice in the NT; Paul appears to have coined it. From the sound of it, he’s describing those who teach things which are perhaps novel, appealing, and sound good on the surface. Paul isn’t saying they are necessarily false teachings, they’re just different and warrant keeping a close eye on, because there may be a false doctrine lurking under the guise of a new, welcoming message.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r…The tense of the Gk. verb insinuates continual action; in other words, Paul’s not talking about someone who simply wants to become wealthy, and once they attain that goal are satisfied and quit, but he’s talking about someone who continually wants to get richer and richer with no end in sight.
2 Timothy%ha~
       The strong emotions which Paul had while in prison are put in this second letter to Timothy, Paul’s final letter. One can feel the intensity when reading it, feeling something in the air, feeling that things are getting serious, that events have taken a turn for the worse, that the end is near. He breaks out into poem in the second chapter an prayer in the fourth.%nv~
       Paul’s attachment to his son in the Faith Timothy is one of the few things which gives him the inner strength to persevere; except for Luke he is alone.%nv~
%i@%sb~
2 Timothy Chapter 1%hb~
          %u@1Paul, %i@a%i@n%i@ apostle of Christ Jesus because of God’s will according to %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ promise of life which is in Christ Jesus:%vn~
          %u@2To Timothy, a dear son%u@[%u@a%u@]:%vn~
      Grace, Mercy, Peace, %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ from God the Father and our Lord Christ Jesus.%vn~
          %u@3I thank God and have gracious %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@s for Him, Whom I serve with a clean conscience in a worship %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ from my ancestors, as I constantly rehash memories of you all day and all night while I’m chained up in prison, %u@4yearning so much to see you (now that I’ve remembered %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ of your tears) so that I could be filled with joy, %u@5now that I’ve taken in a memory of the sincere faith in you: the very %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ which first resided in your grandmother Lois and your mother Eunice—and I am convinced is in you too. %u@6It’s for this reason that I’m reminding you to stir up the gift of God, a gift which is in you through my laying on of hands. %u@7You see, God didn’t give us a deep, intense, overriding attitude%u@[%u@b%u@] of cowardliness, but of power, love, and a self-control which results in us being sensible and sound-minded.%vn~
