          %u@8So don’t be ashamed of us telling others in a serious manner what the truth is about%u@[%u@c%u@] our Lord nor %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ me his prisoner, but rather participate in the evil-generated sufferings %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@t to the Gospel (God’s message of love and forgiveness) in lockstep with %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ power of God, %u@9Who saved us and called us (i.e., summoned us to be believers) by a holy calling, not according to our works but rather according to the intention which He decided beforehand and according to His grace instead, which was given to us in Christ Jesus before time immemorial%u@[%u@d%u@], %u@1%u@0but has been made visible for everyone to see through the manifestation of our savior Christ Jesus, now that he on the one hand abolished the death %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ while he shined %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %I@E%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@h, but on the other hand %i@g%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ life and immortality through the Gospel. %u@1%u@1Towards that goal I have been given the positions of preacher, apostle (i.e., missionary), and teacher.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2That’s also the reason I suffer the things I suffer, but—no—I’m not ashamed %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@t, for I know whom I have believed in and am convinced that he’s capable of guarding what I’ve been entrusted with until that day %i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Keep a %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@l picture%u@[%u@e%u@] of wholesome words which you heard from me in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ faith and love which is in Christ Jesus. %u@1%u@4Guard the %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d thing which has been entrusted %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u through %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Holy Spirit who resides in us.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5Know this to be a fact: everyone in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ Asia (included among them are Phygelus and Hermogenes) have rejected me. %u@1%u@6May the Lord shower his mercy and goodness on Onesiphorus and his entire family%u@[%U@A%u@], because he rejuvenated me many a time and wasn’t ashamed of me being chained up in prison— %u@1%u@7uh-uh—he quickly showed up in Rome, went looking for me, and found me. %u@1%u@8May the Lord grant that he find mercy from the Lord on that day—And he helped out in so many ways in Ephesus, as you are keenly aware of.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@n…Or: %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@,%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@d%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@m%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@a%i@l…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%I@K%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@e…Lit: %I@H%i@a%i@v%i@e [or %i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p] %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@k%i@e%i@t%i@c%i@h%i@%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@O%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@p%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@m%i@i%i@l%i@y…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@O%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@p%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@u%i@s. This is everyone who lives in his home: wife, children, domestic servants (maybe even slaves), and perhaps relatives who live with him out of necessity.%fn~
%i@%sb~
2 Timothy Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1So you, my son, empower yourself by the grace which is in Christ Jesus, %u@2and what you heard from me throughout the many%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@s I solemnly declared %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u, entrust these things to people who are faithful, ones in particular who will become competent to teach others too.%vn~
          %u@3Participate in the evil-generated sufferings as a fine soldier of Christ Jesus’s %i@a%i@r%i@m%i@y%i@.%i@ %u@4No one who serves in the military is bogged down%u@[%u@a%u@] in the everyday affairs of life, %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ so that he pleases the one who enlisted him. %u@5But if a given person were to compete %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@t, he won’t take first place%u@[%u@b%u@] unless he follows the rules when competing. %u@6The hard-working farmer must be the first one to partake of what’s raised on the farm.%u@[%U@A%u@] %u@7Think about what I’m saying; you see, the Lord will give you understanding in every respect.%vn~
          %u@8Remember—Jesus Christ was raised from the dead, was a direct-descendant of David, according to the message of love and forgiveness I’m personally spreading%u@[%u@c%u@], %u@9for which I suffer bad things to the point of being put in chains like a criminal—but no—the word of God has not been bound %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s. %u@1%u@0Because of this I endure all these things for the sake of the chosen-ones (i.e., Christians), so that these very same people would also obtain salvation of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@y%i@p%i@e which is in Christ Jesus along with eternal glory.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1You can count on this passage%u@[%u@d%u@] being true:%vn~
%si~
For if we died together, we shall also live together.%vp~
%u@1%u@2If we endure, we shall also reign together.%vp~
If we’re going to deny %i@h%i@i%i@m,%vp~
That’s %i@t%i@h%i@e %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n who’ll deny us.%vp~
%u@1%u@3If we refuse to believe %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@,%vp~
That’s %i@t%i@h%i@e %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n who’ll remain true to his word;%vp~
He can’t deny himself, you see.%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@4Remind %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ these things while solemnly declaring %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ before God as the sworn truth; %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m to not fight over words that serve no useful purpose and at their core cause disarray to the listeners.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5Be fanatical about having God examine you and giving you His approval%u@[%u@e%u@], a laborer who has nothing to be ashamed of, competently handling%u@[%U@B%u@] the truth of the word %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%u@[%u@f%u@]. %u@1%u@6But avoid the desecrated, profane kind of chattering; you see, when %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r proliferates, irreverence and ungodliness will make progress— %u@1%u@7and their message will eat through you like gangrene, among whom are Hymenaeus and Philetus, %u@1%u@8particular individuals who’ve veered off into a ditch with respect to the truth, saying that we’re already living in the afterlife%u@[%u@g%u@] and %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ subvert some people’s faith. %u@1%u@9Nevertheless, God’s firm foundation %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@f%i@t%i@ standing %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@c%i@t, having this distinguishing identification mark: “The Lord knows those who are His,” and, “Let everyone who names the name of the Lord (i.e., who acknowledges the greatness that the Lord is known to be) depart from unrighteousness.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Now in a large estate’s manor there are not just jars, pots, and vases %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ of gold and silver but also %i@j%i@a%i@r%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@t%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@v%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ of wood and clay, and some made for honorable %i@u%i@s%i@e (i.e., decorative pieces, serving dishes, etc.) and some for dishonorable %i@u%i@s%i@e (i.e., wash basins, chamber pots, etc.). %u@2%u@1Now if someone were to purge these things%i@ %I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t from himself, he will be a jar, pot, or vessel for honorable %i@u%i@s%i@e, reserved %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@l%i@y, quite useful for the master %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@e, ready to be used for something good on any special occasion%u@[%U@C%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Now run away as fast as you can from strong desires (including sexual) characteristic of teenagers and young adults; pursue righteousness, faith, love, peace, %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n with those who call upon the Lord (i.e., invite the Lord into their lives) from a clean heart. %u@2%u@3But avoid the stupid, foolish, uninformed, uneducated questions %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@r%i@c%i@u%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@e, knowing from firsthand experience that they generate strife. %vn~
          %u@2%u@4Now the Lord’s servant mustn’t quarrel but instead %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e kind, teachable, endure injuries, %u@2%u@5schooling %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r opponents in a gentleness rooted in self-restraint, if perchance God grant them %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ to change their minds resulting in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m recognizing the truth, %u@2%u@6and they come to their senses%u@[%u@h%u@] %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@e%i@e %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ from the devil’s trap, having had been captured alive and taken prisoner by him for the purpose of %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ that%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@s%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@’%i@s will.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@b%i@o%i@g%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n…Lit: %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@l%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@e%i@d. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@m%i@y%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@p%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d. %I@W%i@o%i@r%i@d might simply be a short for %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d, meaning that what follows is a message of prophecy which was given to Paul.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%I@B%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@a%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@p%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@a%i@l…Lit: %I@B%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@p%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@h. A figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@u%i@p%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@-%i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@r%i@m%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@r%i@m…What this means is that a person who teaches others what to do must be the foremost practitioner of what he teaches.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@c%i@u%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n. Refers to the skill of a laborer. This together with the word %i@l%i@a%i@b%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@r%i@ is a metaphor, comparing how skilled a laborer is with his tools to how skilled a teacher should be with the word of God.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@c%i@c%i@a%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k. The Gk. word for %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ is not the word %i@k%i@a%i@l%i@o%i@s%i@ (καλῶς /Strong’s 2773)which Paul uses frequently in such cases, and, based on that, one expects to use here, but the word %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@ (ἀγαθός/Strong’s 18)instead. Agathos means that the nature of the function the pot is to be used for is good itself; hence, it refers to a special occasion or the like.%fn~
%i@%sb~
2 Timothy Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1Now understand this: in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ last days, difficult periods of time will come with their difficult conditions. %u@2In connection to this, the people %i@d%i@u%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@d%i@s will be selfish; money-loving; they’ll be braggarts; arrogant; they’ll be slanderous, blasphemous, bad-mouthing people; they’ll be disobedient to %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ parents; unforgiving, unkind, and ungrateful; they’ll have no piety or religious devotion; %u@3they won’t have the love one naturally has for family, for kin, for nation, etc.; they’ll be irreconcilable and incapable of negotiating solutions to problems; %u@4they’ll be traitors and will betray others; they’ll be rash, impulsive, and reckless; puffed up and conceited; they’ll be pleasure-loving more than God-loving; %u@5they’ll have an outward appearance of godliness but will have rejected %i@g%i@o%i@d%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@’%i@s%i@ power. Go out of your way to avoid those %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e.%vn~
          %u@6Furthermore, included with these %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ are those who sneak into the houses%u@[%U@A%u@] %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n and utterly captivate%u@[%u@a%u@] silly women%u@[%U@B%u@] who have a pile of sins %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@g%i@h, %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e led%u@[%u@b%u@] by various intense and impulsive desires (including sexual desire), %u@7always learning but never arriving at the recognition and precise understanding of the truth. %u@8Now the manner in which Jannes and Jambres opposed Moses is the same way that these %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ oppose the truth, people of depraved minds, failing to make the grade where the Faith is concerned. %u@9But never mind that—they won’t get very far; the fact is, their folly will be perfectly clear to everyone, as %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ of those guys %I@J%i@a%i@n%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@J%i@a%i@m%i@b%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@ also became %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e.%vn~
          %u@1%u@0But you now—stick close to my doctrine, my way of life, my plan, my love, my perseverance, %u@1%u@1to %i@m%i@y persecutions, %i@m%i@y%i@ sufferings, such as what happened to me in Antioch, in Iconium, in Lystra—%i@o%i@h%i@,%i@ what persecutions I endured—and the Lord rescued me from all of them. %u@1%u@2Everyone who wants to live a life of godliness in Christ Jesus will be persecuted.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Evil people and charlatans will make progress for the worse, leading %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ astray and being led astray %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@s. %u@1%u@4You, though, dwell in the things which you learned and came to trust, knowing whom you learned them from, %u@1%u@5and that you have known%u@[%u@c%u@] the sacred Scriptures from the time you were a wee child, the things that have the power to make you wise in the ways of%u@[%u@d%u@] salvation (i.e., ways of preventing being overtaken by calamity) through %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ faith which is in Christ Jesus. %u@1%u@6All %i@o%i@f Scripture has the breath of God (i.e., is inspired by God) and is useful for teaching, for reproof or cross-examination, for improvement, for training in righteousness, %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@,%i@ %u@1%u@7so that God’s man %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n would be capable, proficient, and properly equipped for the purpose %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ any kind of good work imaginable.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@u%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@r. A metaphor.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@s%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@d…The noun for %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@ is neuter, the participle %i@l%i@e%i@d is also neuter, like the participle for %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@s; therefore the antecedent of %i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ is %i@s%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@. For that matter %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ in v. 7 is also neuter.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@n%i@o%i@w%i@n…Lit: %i@k%i@n%i@o%i@w%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@o%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@s…If one thinks about this more closely, the men described here who sneak into these women’s homes must do so with the cooperation and consent of the women. In other words, they cannot be burglars breaking into a house, as the door would be kept locked at night, the woman would scream (Deut. 22:24, though these are Gentiles), the man of the house (and there certainly would have been) would rescue her, etc. But the woman could find a time when nobody else was home, a time for the man to enter the house for a romantic rendezvous, adulterous or just consensual. Naturally, the man would have to be careful not to be seen entering the house, hence Paul’s use of the word %i@s%i@n%i@e%i@a%i@k.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@s%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n…Lit: %i@l%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@;%i@ more precisely %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@-%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@s [the diminutive form of the word %i@w%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n]. This word only appears once in the NT, and the lexicons provide little information about it, except to say that it’s pejorative. The fact that it’s a diminutive leads one to speculate that it’s slang of a sort. The closest equivalent might be the word %i@b%i@i%i@m%i@b%i@o%i@,%i@ though that might be too strong a word. We can only guess what the exact meaning is.%fn~
%i@%sb~
2 Timothy Chapter 4%hb~
          %u@1I’m telling you the truth—I solemnly charge you before God and before Christ Jesus, who’s going to judge the living and the dead at his appearance, and is going to reign as king: %u@2preach the word %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d: stay on top of it when the conditions are favorable and when they’re not%u@[%u@a%u@]; correct %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@c%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@o%i@r; chide, admonish, and rebuke; exhort, encourage, and entreat; %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s with the utmost perseverance and with every possible explanation.%vn~
          %u@3In fact a time will come when the conditions are such that they won’t tolerate sound doctrine, but will accumulate teachers who’ll tickle%u@[%u@b%u@] their ears in line with their own strong desires instead. %u@4%I@T%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s will turn the listeners from the truth and turn them to fables in their place. %u@5But keep a clear head%u@[%u@c%u@] in every way, endure infliction perpetrated against you, do the job of an evangelist, get the maximum amount out of%u@[%u@d%u@] your ministry.%vn~
          %u@6The fact of the matter is that I’m already being poured out %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@b%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@;%i@ and the time for me to be set free in death is bearing down on me. %u@7I have fought the good fight, I have finished my race, I have kept the Faith. %u@8What remains %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ is that the trophy%u@[%u@e%u@] of righteousness has been placed before me, which the Lord will give me when that day arrives%u@[%u@f%u@], the just judge—not only %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ to me but also to everyone who has come to love his making an appearance.%vn~
          %u@9Try as hard as you can to visit me as soon as possible. %u@1%u@0Demas, you see, has deserted me, %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e loved the present age (i.e., loved how life can be lived in the world as it exists in the times we live in) %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e, and went to Thessalonica; Crescans %i@w%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ to Galatia, Titus to Dalmatia. %u@1%u@1Only Luke is still here with me.%u@[%U@A%u@]%vn~
      Pick up Mark and take him with you, since he’s useful for being an assistant to %i@m%i@e. %vn~
          %u@1%u@2I sent Tychicus to Ephesus.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3That jacket%u@[%u@g%u@] I left in Troas—bring it with you when you come—and the scrolls, especially%i@ the ones which are parchments.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4Alexander the coppersmith did really bad things to me; the Lord will repay him in line with the things he’s done.%u@[%U@B%u@] %u@1%u@5And speaking of him, you should be on the lookout and protect yourself from him; he tremendously opposed what we have to say%u@[%u@h%u@]. %u@1%u@6During the first defense %i@p%i@h%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ my%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@i%i@a%i@l, no one showed up and stood by me; everyone abandoned me instead. May it not be counted against them. %u@1%u@7But the Lord stood by me and put power in me, so that, because of me, the preaching %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ would reach its maximum extent%u@[%u@d%u@] and all the Gentiles would hear %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@l and %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ he snatched me%u@[%u@i%u@] out of %i@t%i@h%i@e lion’s mouth. %vn~
%si~
%u@1%u@8The Lord will rescue me%vp~
From all the things the evil one does%u@[%u@j%u@]%vp~
And %i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p rescuing me%vp~
Until %I@I%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o His kingdom in heaven%u@[%u@k%u@].%vp~
To Him be the glory forever and ever.%vp~
Amen (i.e., let it be so).%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@9Greet Priscilla and Aquila and %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ in Onesiphorus’s house.%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Erastus stayed %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ in Corinth, and Trophimus was left behind%i@ in Miletus, %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ ill and couldn’t continue%u@[%u@l%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@1Eubulus says hello to you, and so does Pudens, Linus, Claudia and all the comrades%u@[%u@m%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@2%I@M%i@a%i@y%i@ the Lord %i@b%i@e%i@ with your spirit. %I@M%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ grace %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ be with you all.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@v%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@l%i@e…Or: %i@s%i@c%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@b%i@e%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@x%i@i%i@m%i@u%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@m%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f…%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@x%i@i%i@m%i@u%i@m%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@f%i@u%i@l%i@f%i@i%i@l%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@y…Lit: %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@n. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@j%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@e%i@t…Lit: %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@a%i@k. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y…Lit: %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@s%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@d [%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@u%i@e%i@d] %i@m%i@e%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@k%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@%fn~
%i@s%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@n%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@n…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@d%i@o%i@m. The literal is poetic and is worded like something from the OT.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@u%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@e%i@a%i@k%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@O%i@n%i@l%i@y%i@ %I@L%i@u%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@e…Speculation entirely, but this supports the theory that Luke was formerly a slave of Theophilus but assigned by him to be Paul’s servant. This is the reason he was still with Paul.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e…However you choose to interpret “turn the other cheek” (Matt. 5:39), weigh this remark against it.
Titus%ha~
       Titus, though not mentioned by name much in the NT, was nevertheless an assistant Paul relied heavily on. The amount Paul relied on such assistants (“deacons” in fact) becomes apparent from reading this epistle and Paul’s epistles to Timothy, as his churches were spread out through the Roman Empire. What Paul tells Titus is similar—almost exactly the same in points—to what he tells Timothy, and from this we can deduce that the guidelines Paul established for running the churches were uniform.%nv~
       Though Titus is not quoted as much as other books, it is a hidden gem lying in the rough, waiting for the curious treasure-seeker to spot it, pick it up, wipe the dirt off it, and place it amongst his collection.%nv~
%i@%sb~
Titus Chapter 1%hb~
          %u@1Paul, a menial servant of God but %i@y%i@e%i@t an apostle (i.e., a missionary) of Jesus Christ according to %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Faith of God’s chosen %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ and %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ recognition of the truth which is reflective of godliness %u@2%i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@s%i@ upon a living hope of eternal life, which the God Who Won’t Lie promised before time immemorial%u@[%u@a%u@]— %u@3But He manifested His word in individual periods of human history%u@[%u@b%u@] by means of preaching, preaching that I was entrusted with according to the commandment of God our Savior:%vn~
          %u@4To Titus, a real son%u@[%u@c%u@] according to %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ common Faith:%vn~
      Grace and peace from %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Father God and Christ Jesus our savior.%vn~
          %u@5The reason I left you behind in Crete is so that you would tidy up the remaining items and would %i@g%i@o%i@ from city to city and appoint elders (i.e., church board members) like I told you to do. %u@6If a given %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@d%i@a%i@t%i@e is without moral flaws, the husband of one wife (i.e., not divorced and remarried), %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ children %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ are trustworthy, not ones who can be fairly accused of having a reckless disregard for their own self-preservation or of being rebellious, %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@m%i@u%i@m%i@ %i@q%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@.%i@%vn~
          %u@7The fact is, a bishop%u@[%U@A%u@] (i.e., a head pastor), as the steward of God’s house, must be without moral flaws; not stubborn or self-willed; not hot-tempered; not a heavy drinker; not pugnacious or a bully; not always trying to make a fast buck through shady business practices; %u@8but instead hospitable, able to reach out to others, one who likes and can work with people who are different than himself; a lover of all things good; sensible, serious, and level-headed; just and fair; holy; self-controlled, disciplined, and having one’s impulses under control; %u@9clinging to the tried-and-true message%u@[%u@d%u@] reflective of the doctrine %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h, so that he’d be capable of both exhorting and encouraging %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s in the Sound Doctrine and correcting those who oppose it.%vn~
          %u@1%u@0The fact of the matter is that there are those who refuse to submit to authority, those who say nothing when they speak and who are deceivers, especially those%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@e out of the circumcision (i.e., those whose background was that they were following the Law of Moses), %u@1%u@1who must be silenced, people in particular who subvert entire households, teaching things they mustn’t for morally unacceptable gain. %u@1%u@2One of their own prophets said, “Cretans %i@a%i@r%i@e always liars, vicious brutes%u@[%u@e%u@], %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ fat blimps%u@[%u@f%u@].”%u@[%U@B%u@] %u@1%u@3I’m quoting a reliable source%u@[%u@g%u@]. You%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ severely correct them for this reason: so that they’ll be healthy in the Faith; %u@1%u@4so they won’t pay any attention to Jewish fables and to the commandments of people who are turning them away from the truth.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5All things %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ clean%u@[%U@C%u@] (i.e., according to the Law of Moses, eligible to be touched, handled, and used; absent any defilement) to those who are clean; but to those who have been defiled%u@ (i.e., who’ve become tainted and are no longer clean) and who refuse to believe, nothing is pure—no, not a chance—both their minds and their consciences have come to be defiled. %u@1%u@6They profess to know God, but %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@f%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n is repudiated by %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r actions, %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ are detestable, disobedient, and failures when comes to any good deed.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@m%i@e%i@m%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@a%i@l…Lit: %i@e%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@y…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@s. Same phrase used in 1 Tim. 2:6;6:15.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@n…Or: %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@-%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@w%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@v%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@f%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@i%i@m%i@p%i@s…Lit: %i@f%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@-%i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@-%i@l%i@a%i@b%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@s. Some liberties taken. The %I@E%i@x%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@ %I@G%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@k%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t says, “He [the poet] has in his mind the belly, as it obtrudes on the beholder and is a burden to the possessor.”%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@q%i@u%i@o%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@e%i@%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@b%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@o%i@p…Ref. note of 1 Cor. 15:24. As vv. 5–6 address qualifications for elders and v. 7 begins with a coordinating conjunction, it stands to reason that, at least for the churches Titus was dealing with, elders were bishops and vice-versa. This supports the theory that the ancient church was originally run by elders but later on transitioned to one which was run by bishops instead.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@”%I@C%i@r%i@e%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@a%i@r%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@i%i@m%i@p%i@s%i@”…From the sounds of it, this prophet was parroting an outrageously false, negative ethnic stereotype about Cretans, which the prophet categorically applies to all Cretans. Paul is vehemently condemning that kind of language.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n…Also: %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@e. Paul’s usage of clean and defiled here is a metaphor to the OT concepts of clean and unclean, concepts which are deeply rooted in the Law of Moses and touch all the temple rituals and quite a lot of other things. Once something was defiled (tainted), it could no longer be used in the temple service. Care had to be taken to keep or maintain people or things in a state of cleanness.%fn~
The metaphor presented here is that a person who’s clean is one who’s pure in mind and spirit, and everything that person handles is automatically clean. A person who’s pure will look at any fact, teaching, philosophy, etc. and come up with practical applications, anecdotes, life-lessons, analogies, etc. which are pure, meaning they’ll support or complement Christian truths, principles, and values. But anyone who’s defiled, any fact, teaching, philosophy, etc. will ultimately lead to something twisted, to the point of contradicting Christian truths, principles, and values.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Titus Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1Now talk %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ that makes sound doctrine more pronounced and more palatable%u@[%u@a%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%I@I%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@c%i@t the older men%u@[%u@b%u@] to be self-controlled and to exercise moderation in vices such as drinking; to be honorable and respectable; to be sensible, serious, and level-headed; healthy in faith, love, perseverance. %u@3Likewise, older women should behave in a reverent manner; not be slanderers; not have reached the point where they have a compulsion to drink a lot%u@[%u@c%u@]; be ones who teach others to strive for excellence%u@[%u@d%u@], %u@4so that they could train the young women to maintain a discipline of sensibility and self-control which causes them to have a strong friendship with their husbands and enjoy their companionship%u@[%U@A%u@], and train them to do the same for their children; %u@5to be sensible, serious, and level-headed; to be chaste%u@[%U@B%u@]; to be good housekeepers and homemakers, submitting%u@[%u@e%u@] to their husbands, so that the word of God not be spoken badly of.%vn~
          %u@6Likewise, I exhort and encourage the young men to be sensible, serious, and level-headed %u@7in every aspect %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e, putting yourself out there as an example of %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@y%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@z%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ fine deeds; to be incorruptible in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ the teaching %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@y; to be dignified; %u@8to have wholesome speech which is unassailable to accusation, so the opposition camp would be humiliated by not having anything bad to say about %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m.%vn~
          %u@9%I@I%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ slaves to submit to their masters in all respects; to be pleasing and to not give %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ any backtalk; %u@1%u@0to not go around stealing things, but to instead demonstrate that they’re good people and can be trusted in every regard, so that %i@s%i@l%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y would in every regard be a feather in the cap (so to speak)%u@[%u@f%u@] of the teaching of God our Savior.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1In fact, the grace of God, %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s salvation, shined to all people, %u@1%u@2training us to deny%u@[%u@g%u@] the ungodliness and the strong, worldly desires, so we would live in the present age sensibly, with self-control, justly, and godly, %u@1%u@3awaiting the blessed hope and the appearance of the glory of our Great God and of our savior Christ Jesus, %u@1%u@4who gave himself for us so that he would redeem us (i.e., recover for us what we once had) from any sort of wickedness and lawlessness (i.e., a refusal to be restrained by the rules of God or of man) and clean and purify for himself a special people, ones who have a zeal for doing good works.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5Communicate these things and encourage, exhort, and correct while staying in full control of the situation: don’t let anyone look down on you.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@t%i@a%i@l%i@k%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@c%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@c%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t [or %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g]. Uncertain of the correctness of the rendering.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n…Or: %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s. The GT is ambiguous.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@u%i@l%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@t…Also: %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@y%i@-%i@d%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@c%i@o%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@i%i@c%i@s…Lit: having been enslaved to much wine. %fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@b%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e…Lit: %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@-%i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@s%i@u%i@b%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g…Ref. note of 1 Pet. 2:18%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@p%i@ %i@(%i@s%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@)…Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@o%i@r%i@n. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@y…Also: %i@r%i@e%i@n%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@c%i@e. Unexpected verb tense used here.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@s%i@b%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@j%i@o%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p…Lit: %i@h%i@u%i@s%i@b%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@l%i@o%i@v%i@e. Note the root word for %i@l%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@ used here is not %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@p%i@ā%i@ (ἀγάπη/Strong’s 26) but %i@p%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@o%i@.%i@ Ref. note of John 12:25 and other places for differences in these words. One of the few places in the NT where women are told to love their husband, and the love is a %i@p%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@o%i@-love not and agapā%i@ %i@-love. Contrast that to Ephesians where husbands are commanded to %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@p%i@ā%i@ their wives. Philo-love is an enjoyment of the fellowship and companionship two people have, like when David loved Jonathan. Agapā%i@ -love is a love that sees value in the other person, sometimes in spite of what they’re doing, or (and this is in contrast to philo-love) to love them without them reciprocating. Philo-love is a reciprocating love; agapā%i@ -love is not necessarily reciprocal. In the NT, the same root-word %i@p%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@o%i@ also means %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@s%i@s%i@.%i@ In ancient times (and even a bit in modern times), kisses were not a token of romantic love, but tokens of friendship, fellowship, and personal connection. Women must be taught to philo-love their husbands, because the alternative is to become bored with them. When they do, they sometimes go looking for another man to bring excitement into their lives.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@c%i@h%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e…Also: %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@; %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y. The Gk. word %i@h%i@a%i@g%i@n%i@o%i@s%i@ (ἁγνός/Strong’s 53), which is derived from the usual word for %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y and the word for %i@s%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@.%i@ Note that Paul used a different word for %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ [%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@s%i@,%i@ (ὅσιος/Strong’s 3741)]in 1 Tim. 2:8, in “lifting up holy hands.” Hosios also appears in 1:8 as a characteristic for bishops. One expects to find hosios used in 2:5 here, not hagnos. So the words should be more closely examined. The root-meaning of hagnos is separation. In the OT, things which were holy were separated from the unclean in order to preserve their holiness. This is hagnos. So when hagnos is used in reference to women, it’s talking about a separation—a separation even from men in a sexual way. This is how it’s acquired the means of %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@ (meaning kept sexually separate) in this verse here. Paul might’ve meant chaste exclusively and not pure or holy—we don’t know.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Titus Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1Keep reminding them to submit to and comply with rulers who have %i@l%i@e%i@g%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@m%i@a%i@t%i@e authority %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u and to be prepared to do any sort of good deed %u@2without saying bad things %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@,%i@ not being quarrelsome %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@,%i@ not being inflexible about every little detail—in every way possible demonstrating a gentleness towards people borne out of self-restraint.%vn~
          %u@3The fact is, we were mindless back then, disobedient, deceived, enslaved to a variety of strong desires (including sexual desires) and pleasures, spending our lives in malice, in envy, detestable people hating each other. %u@4But when the goodness and benevolence of God our Savior shined on us, %u@5%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ out of things we did in %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ righteousness, but He saved us instead according to His mercy on account of a%i@ washing of %i@t%i@h%i@e new birth and a renewal of %i@t%i@h%i@e Holy Spirit, %u@6which He poured out on us copiously through Jesus Christ our savior, %u@7so that, having been made righteous in that grace, we heirs would be born to a hope of eternal life (i.e., that special fullness of life).%vn~
          %u@8You can count on %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s statement being true%u@[%u@a%u@]: I’ve thought about these things, and what I want you to do is to emphasize them, so that those who have come to believe in God would be intent on prioritizing good works. These things %I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ are good and benefit the people. %u@9But do your best to avoid stupid debates, %i@o%i@b%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ genealogies, and conflicts and fights over law (i.e., from a conceptual perspective, over a codified list of God’s commandments, in particular the Law of Moses), for they are useless and pointless. %u@1%u@0Shun a heretic (i.e., a person who breaks people off from the accepted doctrine or school of thought and forms a sect out of them) after giving him two clear warnings%u@[%u@b%u@], %u@1%u@1knowing from firsthand experience that that kind of person is twisted, has no morals%u@[%u@c%u@], and is sinning, being condemned for what’s going on inside of himself%u@[%u@d%u@].%vn~
          %u@1%u@2When I do send Artemis to you or %i@m%i@a%i@y%i@b%i@e%i@ Tychicus, as fast as you can come visit me in Nicopolis, since I’ve decided to spend the winter there. %u@1%u@3Send Zenas the lawyer and Apollos on their journey as soon as you can, %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@e%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@ so that %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g they need.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4But let our own people also learn to emphasize good works that have the goal of meeting the needs %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s, so that they’re not unproductive %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@e%i@s.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5Everyone with me sends their greetings. Greet those who love us in faith.%vn~
      The grace %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ with you all.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%I@Y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@e…Lit: %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@f%i@u%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@w%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@w%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@t%i@w%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@,%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t. Danker and Bauer says, “to turn aside from what is considered true or morally proper.”%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@m%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f…Lit: %i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@-%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@m%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@
The Epistle of Philemon%ha~
       When Paul sat down to write this letter to Philemon, he was not conscious of the fact that he was adding another book to the Bible; he simply sat down to write a letter—a spontaneous one, not a thought-out treatise like some of his other letters—on behalf of a runaway slave of Philemon’s named Onesimus, whom Paul wants the help of in his ministry. Though unintentional, this letter captures the message of the Gospel in a true story.%nv~
       If one views the Bible from a literary perspective, this short story is one of the best fragments of literature found in the Bible, one that should be read and enjoyed like any other great work of literature.%nv~
       This story flows fluidly from Greek into English, guided by the feelings it carries.%nv~
%i@%sb~
Philemon%hb~
          %u@1Paul, a slave of Christ Jesus, and Comrade%u@[%u@a%u@] Timothy:%vn~
      To Philemon, our dear fellow worker, %u@2to Apphia our female comrade, to Archippus our fellow soldier, and to the church that meets in your house%u@[%U@A%u@].%vn~
          %u@3Grace %i@b%i@e%i@ to you and peace from our Father God and %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Lord Jesus Christ.%vn~
          %u@4I’m always thanking my God %i@a%i@s%i@ %I@I%i@ bring you up in prayer%u@[%u@b%u@], %u@5hearing about your love and faith which you have towards the Lord Jesus and for all the saints (i.e., those who are believers), %u@6to the ends that the sharing and participation of your faith—a sharing and participation which is in operation—should manifest itself in a recognition and better understanding of all %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ good which is in you%u@[%u@c%u@] with Christ as the goal. %u@7In fact, I got a lot of joy and encouragement out of%u@[%u@d%u@] your love, because the saints have been refreshed deep down on the inside because of you, comrade.%vn~
          %u@8With this in mind, I have the audacity%u@[%u@e%u@] in Christ to order you to do your duty by doing what’s right— %u@9Through the love %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ I appeal to you all the more%i@ in such a personage as %i@a%i@n%i@ old man %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@d Paul %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ is%i@ also now but a slave of Christ Jesus— %u@1%u@0I appeal to you concerning my son%u@[%u@f%u@], who was born into slavery as Onesimus, %u@1%u@1who used to be of no use to you but is quite useful to me at this time, %u@1%u@2who is the same person I sent back to you (in other words%u@[%u@g%u@], %I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@l%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ those things which are nearest and dearest to my heart), %u@1%u@3whom I was planning on retaining for myself so that he could serve me under your sponsorship%u@[%u@h%u@] while I’m imprisoned because of the Gospel%u@[%u@i%u@].%vn~
          %u@1%u@4I didn’t want to do anything without your consent, so that your %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f goodness %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d as though you had no choice%u@[%u@j%u@] but because you authorized it. %u@1%u@5Because of this, in fact, without delay he was sent away %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@m%i@e for a short period of time so that you would send him away from you forever, %u@1%u@6%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ as %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@’%i@s%i@ no longer a slave but %i@s%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ for the benefit of %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@i%i@s a slave, dear comrade, especially for my %i@b%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@f%i@i%i@t%i@,%i@ but how much more %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@f%i@i%i@t%i@ both in the flesh (i.e., from a natural perspective) and in %i@t%i@h%i@e Lord?%vn~
          %u@1%u@7So if you’re all in with me%u@[%u@k%u@], welcome him %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ as you would me. %u@1%u@8If he did something wrong to you or owes %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@y, put it on my tab. %u@1%u@9I Paul personally wrote this in my own handwriting %i@s%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@m%i@e%u@[%U@B%u@]: I’ll pay %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ back whatever he owes—But don’t get me going about how%u@[%u@l%u@] you owe me your very life%u@[%u@m%u@]. %u@2%u@0Yes, comrade, do me this favor%u@[%u@n%u@] in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Lord: In Christ bring to rest what is churning deep inside my heart.%vn~
          %u@2%u@1I wrote %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ convinced of your obedience, having come to know firsthand that you will even do for me what I tell you. %u@2%u@2But at the same time, prepare a guest room for me; you see, I’m also hoping that I’ll be the beneficiary of your generosity %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ on account of your %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ requests %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%u@[%u@o%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@3Epaphras, my fellow prisoner in Christ Jesus, says hello, %u@2%u@4along with my coworkers Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke.%vn~
          %u@2%u@5The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ %i@b%i@e%i@ with you all’s spirit.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@b%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@y%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@m%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@y%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u…Or: %i@u%i@s. The manuscripts disagree as to which is correct.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@a%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@u%i@d%i@a%i@c%i@i%i@t%i@y…Also: %i@m%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@f%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@n…Also: %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d. Has a dual meaning. First, it’s the closeness Paul had to him, as he used the same word with Timothy. But based on the context, it’s similar to the word %i@b%i@o%i@y%i@s%i@ used in John 21:5 (ref. note there).%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y. This phrase also appears in Matt. 26:46; Mark 7:2; Acts 1:19; Heb. 9:11,10:20.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p…Lit: %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@h%i@a%i@l%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@p%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@l…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@e%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@o%i@i%i@c%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@y%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@i%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@e…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@i%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%I@B%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@w…Also: %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e…Lit: %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@d%i@o%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@v%i@o%i@r…Lit: %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%fn~
%u@[%u@o%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@q%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r…Or: %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@y%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ [%i@t%i@o%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d]%i@.%i@ I’m uncertain about this.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@e%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e…Embedded in this quotation is the Gk. phrase %i@k%i@a%i@t%i@’%i@ %i@o%i@i%i@k%i@o%i@n%i@ [κατ' οἶκόν, (κατ'/Strong’s 2596), (οἶκόν/Strong’s3624)], which means %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@e. This same phrase is found in Acts 2:46, where’s it’s used to describe the disciples meeting from house to house. Here in v. 2 it may imply that Archipus’s church was one of many that met from house to house.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@s%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@…Ref. Gal. 6:11. Paul might’ve signed the letter in his own handwriting so it would hold up in court—for the same reason someone signs a check nowadays.
Hebrews%ha~
       The Book of Hebrews is a treatise. The subject matter is the comparison between the Old and New Testaments, proving that the new covenant is better than the old covenant. Though veering off into many subjects, it returns to its principal subject.%nv~
       Because of the intensity, a translator must concentrate intensely while translating, juggling both the translation and following the thread of reasoning. Interpolations must be supplied at critical junctures, otherwise the meaning risks being lost.%nv~
       Speculations will forever abound as to who wrote this book, and the only evidence we can use to support any theory is from an analysis of the text itself and a comparison to the other writings of the New Testament. One piece of such evidence is that whoever wrote Hebrews had a mastery of Greek, it being probable that it was his native tongue. Also, he had studied the Septuagint extensively. Although his peculiar writing style isn’t immediately recognizable as what we find in Paul’s epistles, one should keep in mind that Hebrews is not a letter but an essay, and that the same writer will use one style when writing a letter and another when writing an essay. Furthermore, the author says in 13:23 that he’ll take Timothy with him when he travels: that sounds like Paul.%nv~
       On the other hand, a simple word such as %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ [%i@h%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@,%i@ (ὅθεν/Strong’s 3606)] is found in Hebrews in 2:17, 3:1, 7:25, 8:3, 9:18, 11:19, but is nowhere to be found in any of Paul’s writing. One would a simple word like that to be independent of whether what’s being written is an essay or an epistle.%nv~
       Studying the entire book, we come to the conclusion that the writer was influenced by Paul’s teachings. As the last part of the last chapter talks about Timothy, he had to be a close associate of Paul’s, at the bare minimum; but whether it was actually Paul who wrote it, we’ll never know.%nv~
%i@%sb~
Hebrews Chapter 1%hb~
          %u@1%U@I%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ one piece at a time%u@[%u@a%u@] and %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ in many ways%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t God spoke long ago to the Ancestors%u@[%u@c%u@] by means of the prophets, %u@2but during this time—a time in which we see His long-awaited promises coming to pass%u@[%u@d%u@]—He spoke to us in %i@a%u@[%U@A%u@] son whom He positioned to be %i@t%i@h%i@e heir of everything, through whom He also made the ages (i.e., the epochs of time; the periods of history); %u@3%i@a%i@n%i@d who is the brightness and radiance which is emitted and beams forth from His glory and is a carbon-copy%u@[%u@e%u@] of His being, His undergirding reality%u@[%u@f%u@], and who carries any and every thing %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ by the word %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ spoken into action and having His power as its instrument%u@[%U@B%u@]. After he performed an act of cleansing for the sins %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d, he sat at the right hand (i.e., he assumed the position of chief executive officer) of the Majesty in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ Highest%u@[%u@g%u@], %u@4having become so much better than the angels %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ he has inherited a name (i.e., a title; a position of authority; a statement of who he is; a reputation) which %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ more excellent, more distinguished than they. %u@5Furthermore, to which of the angels did He say:%vn~
%si~
You are my son,%vp~
Today I have begotten you%vp~
%si~
Plus another %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@,%nn~
%si~
I will be a Father to him,%vp~
And he will be a son to Me%vp~
%si~

Have all the angels%u@[%u@h%u@] worship him%vp~
%si~

%si~
The One Who makes His angels spirits,%vp~
And %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@s%i@ those who serve Him%vp~
%I@A%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p%i@%vp~
A flame of fire%vp~
%si~
%u@8And contrast that to this: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@g%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@ to the son %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@s,%nn~
%si~
Your throne, God, %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@ out%i@ to forever and ever,%vp~

%si~

(i.e., You hated those who refuse to be restrained%vp~
By the laws of God and of man).%vp~
Because of this God—your God—anointed%u@[%u@i%u@] you%vp~

Which picks you out from among your peers%vp~
And elevates you from them.%vp~

%u@1%u@0And %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@o:%nn~

In reference to the beginning,%vp~
You, Lord, laid the foundation of the Earth,%vp~
And the sky, the atmosphere, and outer space%u@[%u@j%u@]%vp~
Are Your handiwork.%vp~

You, though, will still be there.%vp~
Everything will grow old %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@%vp~
Like shirts, pants, and capes do.%vp~
%u@1%u@2Like You would do to a cape%vp~
%I@W%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@m%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@,%i@%vp~
You will roll them up or fold them,%vp~

And Your years %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@u%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@%vp~
Won’t come to an end.%vp~

%u@1%u@3To which of the angels did He direct %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ He has spoken in the past:%nn~

%u@1%u@4Are not all of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@s spirits which serve %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ who are being dispatched for the purpose of being an assistant to those who are about to be receiving the relief which is rightfully theirs%u@[%U@C%u@]?%nn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@i%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e…Also: %i@b%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@t; %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@i%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s…Lit: %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@-%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@-%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@s…Gk: %i@p%i@o%i@l%i@u%i@m%i@e%i@r%i@ō%i@s%i@ %i@k%i@a%i@i%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@l%i@u%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@ō%i@s%i@ [Πολυμερῶς καὶ πολυτρόπως, (Πολυμερῶς/Strong’s 4181), (πολυτρόπως/Strong’s4187)]. An alliteration, pun, assonance, or rhyme; these words may have formed a common expression.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@A%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@f%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@u%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@—%i@a%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@-%i@a%i@w%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@s…Lit: %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%i@s. Ref. note of John 6:39.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@c%i@a%i@r%i@b%i@o%i@n%i@-%i@c%i@o%i@p%i@y…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@b%i@j%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@p%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@p%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@;%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@l%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@g%i@i%i@r%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@y…Also: %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e;%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n;%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@e…Lit: %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@-%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@-%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r; %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%I@H%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@t…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@g%i@h. Meaning is superlative, although the form is not.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@s…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d. When rendered, the qualifying words %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ aren’t needed. Ref. note of Col. 2:18.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@a%i@n%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@d…Ref. note of 1 John 2:20%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@k%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@m%i@o%i@s%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@a%i@c%i@e…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@s. Ref. note of 2 Cor. 12:2.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%I@A%i@s%i@s%i@u%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %I@M%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@e%i@f%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@e%i@c%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@v%i@e…Lit: %I@S%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f [%i@a%i@t] %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@t%i@e%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@q%i@u%i@a%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@s%i@l%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@o%i@t%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@o%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@e%i@t. A common idiom.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@n…Or: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@s%i@o%i@n. Whether we render this %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ or %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@n, in either choice the article is an interpolation. There are many instances in the NT where the definite article %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ is assumed after a preposition, and this may well be but another instance. However, there are instances also where the definite article is added, added apparently to prevent ambiguity. On the other hand, the omission of the definite article may be just that: the equivalent of (Gk. has none) an indefinite article (or perhaps none at all) is what was intended and what’s being conveyed; the definite was not intended. Though I’m not insisting that this is correct, I do favor the latter, the deciding factor being the context as usual.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r. The Gk. for word here is %i@r%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@ (ῥῆμα/Strong’s 4487)not %i@l%i@o%i@g%i@o%i@s%i@ (λόγος/Strong’s 3056)%i@.%i@ Also, with respect to %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r, in Bullinger’s %I@F%i@i%i@g%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@S%i@p%i@e%i@e%i@c%i@h%i@ %I@U%i@s%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@B%i@i%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@,%i@ Appendix B, since this phrase uses the genitive case, “This is hardly his powerful word; but the word which is the instrument, by which His power is carried out.”%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@l%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Or: %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@l%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Or: %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@l%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Some notes on the GT. The Gk. verb %i@m%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ō%i@ (μέλλω/Strong’s 3195)can mean %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e, %i@g%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e, or perhaps %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e. Naturally, its meaning is decided by context. Something else which is noteworthy is that the infinite %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@ has a verb tense which insinuates ongoing action, as opposed to a one-time action. So the heirs are about to be inheriting, going to be inheriting, or destined to be inheriting salvation on an ongoing basis. This begs the question, what does %i@s%i@a%i@l%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ mean in this context? Many Christians, scholars, and translators assume it means “receiving Christ in the new birth” or something similar. When applying this definition to this verse, the dilemma is that the angels are sent to assist only those who are about to or are going to inherit salvation, not those who already have inherited it, as the word %i@m%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@ō%i@ refers to something which is going to happen in the future but hasn’t happened yet. For this reason, in this verse the word %i@s%i@a%i@l%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ does not mean receiving Christ in the new birth, but it means being rescued from catastrophe. This is its core meaning anyways, so the only surprise should be that Christian scholars failed to apply it properly in the first place. The last piece to the puzzle is the meaning of %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@.%i@ The Gk. and English meanings are essentially the same: it means coming and actually possessing what’s been set aside as yours, what’s rightfully yours. Inheriting salvation here is not being born-again some time in the future, but it means coming into the relief in a dire situation of that which is rightfully yours, a person who is already a Christ-follower. Angels are sent to assist Christ-followers with coming into the relief which is rightfully theirs, and to come into this relief on an ongoing basis.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Hebrews Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1Because of this %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@f%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@t%i@w%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@l%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@S%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d, it’s even more necessary for us to pay attention to, follow, concern ourselves with, and devote ourselves to what we heard,%i@ lest those things slip through the cracks%u@[%u@a%u@]. %u@2The fact is, if the word %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d spoken %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ by angels was enforced%u@[%u@b%u@], and every infraction, violation%u@[%u@c%u@], and act of willful disobedience got a just punishment as a payback, %u@3how will we evade %i@a%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@n%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ after neglecting so great a salvation (i.e., an entire program of keeping all dimensions of calamity and disaster away from us) %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@l%i@v%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@C%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@t? A salvation which was accepted and wholeheartedly embraced way back then by those who listened to it as it was being spoken by the Lord resulting in us making it effective and enforcing it%u@[%u@d%u@], %u@4%i@a%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ which was accompanied by a conformational-attestation to its truthfulness consisting of signs (i.e., miracles whose purpose is to confirm that the one performing them is authentic) and not just by signs but by wonders (i.e., awe-inspiring miracles), by a variety of miracles, and by bits and pieces of %i@s%i@u%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ of%i@ the Holy Spirit %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ according to His will.%vn~
          %u@5%I@B%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s topic%i@ about angels we’ve been talking about here:%i@ the fact of the matter is that He didn’t subordinate to angels the civilized world which was to come, %u@6but somebody somewhere solemnly delivered a truthful statement %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@r%i@y%i@ saying,%vn~
%si~
What is man, that You would remember him,%vp~
(i.e., give a hoot about him)%vp~
Or the son of man%u@[%U@A%u@]%vp~
(i.e., the ultimate human being)%vp~

(i.e., check on him with a purpose in mind)%vp~

everything to him).%vp~
%si~
In this regard, in the process of subordinating all things to him, nothing evaded%u@[%u@f%u@] him %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@q%i@u%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@l%i@y%i@ has not been subordinated to him. But at the present time we do not yet see that all things have been subordinated to him. %u@9But we see him who’s been “demoted somewhat lower than the angels” (%i@w%i@e%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ Jesus %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e) because of the suffering of death “crowned in glory and honor,” so that by the grace of God he would taste death for everyone.%nn~
          %u@1%u@0You see, it was appropriate for Him—Whom all things %i@a%i@r%i@e because of and Whom all things %i@a%i@r%i@e by—after leading many sons to glory, to complete %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ the originator of their salvation by %i@v%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ sufferings. %u@1%u@1And, you see, the one who’s making others holy and those who are being made holy %i@b%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e out of one %I@G%i@o%i@d; for this reason he’s not ashamed to call %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y “brothers” (i.e., comrades), %u@1%u@2saying,%vn~
%si~
I’ll spread the word about Your %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ title%u@[%u@g%u@]%vp~
To my brothers.%vp~
