%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@j%i@a%i@i%i@l…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@s. A NT synecdoche.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@f%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s…Lit: %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@r%i@k%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h…Also: %i@s%i@h%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k; %i@a%i@v%i@o%i@i%i@d; %i@d%i@r%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k; %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@a%i@p%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@r%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@r%i@u%i@m%i@m%i@a%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@c%i@r%i@o%i@l%i@l…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@n%i@o%i@b%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@c%i@r%i@o%i@l%i@l. Without being certain what this means, the assumption is that this is a figure of speech similar to Gal. 3:10, but here it refers to the turning of the knob which advances the place in the scroll. This is indicative of the reader browsing through the scroll to locate a passage which is about to be read aloud.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%I@H%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@H%i@o%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@s. Looking at the precise wording of the GT, the term “Holy of Holies” is introduced in 9:3, and the GT literally reads “holy of holies.” Thenceforth, however, the author of Hebrews shortens the literal phrase from %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ to %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ (9:8); %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ (9:12,25); and simply %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ (9:24). So the phrase %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ which appears in 10:19 is yet another usage of a shortened form of Holy of Holies, a repetition of the wording which appeared in 9:8 when you get right down to it.%i@%fn~
%i@%sb~
Hebrews Chapter 11%hb~
          %u@1Faith is%u@[%U@A%u@] the undergirding of what’s hoped for, the proof of things not seen (which includes all things for which there is no physical evidence); %u@2by this, you see, those we hold in esteem from long ago%u@[%u@a%u@] had an official account, a favorable mention, of their actions recorded for posterity.%vn~
          %u@3By faith our mind understands that the world was set in order by a sentence spoken by God, resulting in what we see coming into being out of what hasn’t been manifested.%vn~
          %u@4By faith Abel offered God a much %i@b%i@e%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ sacrifice than Cain, through which an attestation to him being righteous was entered %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@r%i@d, the record specifying the gifts he offered to God, and through %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h, %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h he’s dead he’s still speaking.%vn~
          %u@5By faith Enoch was instantaneously transported from one place to another for the purpose of not experiencing%u@[%u@b%u@] death; “There was no trace of him to be found%u@[%u@c%u@] because God had transported him.” You see, before he was transported, it had been stated for the record that he had pleased God quite well.%vn~
          %u@6Now apart from faith it’s impossible to be well-pleasing to God, for he who approaches God must believe (and have already believed ahead of time)%u@[%u@d%u@] that He is %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %I@I%i@ %I@A%i@m and that a reward manifests itself %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ to those who seek Him out.%vn~
          %u@7By faith Noah, having been warned by God about things that had not yet been seen, in piety and in the fear of God built and provisioned an ark for the purpose of preserving his family and keeping it safe, through which %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h he condemned the world (i.e., consigned the world to punishment) and became an heir of the righteousness which comes from faith.%vn~
          %u@8By faith Abraham obeyed when he was summoned to leave %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ go to %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ which he was going to receive as an inheritance (i.e., a place which was reserved for him exclusively and in perpetuity), and he departed having no idea where he was going. %u@9By faith he emigrated and became a foreign resident in the land of promise, living in tents with Isaac and Jacob, joint-heirs of the same promise. %u@1%u@0You see, he anticipated, expected, and was eagerly awaiting the city which is not a rickety-rackety, makeshift one but is built to last%u@[%u@e%u@], whose builder and architect is God.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1By faith, even Sarah, who couldn’t have children, got the ability to conceive in her old age, since she considered the One Who had promised to be faithful. %u@1%u@2As this was the case, one man (and this fellow was debilitated%u@[%u@f%u@]) sired %i@a%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ as innumerable as the stars in the sky and the grains of sand on the beach.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3All these %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ died in sync with%i@ faith, not having received the promises, but having seen and greeted them from afar instead, and having confessed that they were foreigners on this planet. %u@1%u@4The fact is, those who say such things make it evident that they seek their native country. %u@1%u@5If they kept on rehashing memories of%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r that %i@u%i@n%i@g%i@o%i@d%i@l%i@y%i@ place they ventured forth from, they would have found%u@[%u@g%u@] an opportunity %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@u%i@s%i@e to return; %u@1%u@6but as it stands, they aspire for better, that is to say, for %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g from the spiritual domain or from heaven. In light of this, God is not ashamed to be called their God, for He has prepared a city for them.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7By faith Abraham, while being tested, offered up Isaac—he who gladly received the promises offered up his one and only %i@s%i@o%i@n, %u@1%u@8to whom it was spoken, “The descendants who will perpetuate your family tree will be designated as coming through Isaac.%u@[%u@h%u@]” %u@1%u@9%I@A%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@ figured that, in addition %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@s%i@ %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@, God is able to raise %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ from the dead. As a result of this, he recovered %I@I%i@s%i@a%i@a%i@c%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d in an analogous fashion.%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Also by faith Isaac pronounced blessings over Jacob and Esau in regard to what would happen %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ in the future.%vn~
          %u@2%u@1By faith Jacob while on his death bed pronounced blessings over the sons of Joseph, and “bowed down %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g on top of his staff%u@[%U@B%u@].”%vn~
          %u@2%u@2By faith Joseph, nearing the end, left a reminder about the Exodus with the descendants of Israel and left orders about his bones (i.e., orders that they take his bones with them when they leave).%vn~
          %u@2%u@3By faith Moses was hidden by his parents after he was born out of a reverential fear because they saw that the boy had charisma%u@[%u@i%u@], and they didn’t fear the king’s decree. %u@2%u@4By faith Moses %i@g%i@r%i@e%i@w%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d became a great man and renounced his claim of being the son of Pharaoh’s daughter, %u@2%u@5having chosen to endure the hardship with God’s folk rather than to retain the pleasures of sin for a brief span of time, %u@2%u@6considering the vilification and reviling of Christ to be greater riches than the treasures of Egypt; for he was focused on the reward.%vn~
          %u@2%u@7By faith he left Egypt, unafraid of the wrath of %I@P%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@o%i@h the king, for he endured as %i@o%i@n%i@e seeing the Unseen-One. %u@2%u@8By faith he observed the Passover and the marking of the blood, %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e so that the Destroyer wouldn’t touch any of their firstborn %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@s. %u@2%u@9By faith he crossed the Red Sea as if it was dry land; when the Egyptians tried %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@s%i@s%i@ it, they were drowned.%vn~
          %u@3%u@0By faith the walls of Jericho fell after being %i@m%i@a%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@ in a circle for seven days.%vn~
          %u@3%u@1By faith, the prostitute Rahab wasn’t wiped out with those who were disobedient after extending a welcome to the spies and taking them in%u@[%u@j%u@].%vn~
          %u@3%u@2And what more will I say? For there’s not enough time to go into detail about Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, David, plus Solomon and the prophets, %u@3%u@3who through faith conquered kingdoms, put into practice standards of fairness %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@u%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g, obtained promises, shut the mouths of lions, %u@3%u@4extinguished intense heat-generating fires%u@[%u@k%u@], escaped %i@t%i@h%i@e sword’s edge, got their strength back from weakness, became mighty men in war, routed foreign armies in battle. %u@3%u@5Women got %i@m%i@e%i@m%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f their %i@f%i@a%i@m%i@i%i@l%i@y who died to come back to life. Others were tortured but refused the chance to get out of it, so that they would be better off in their life after death%u@[%u@l%u@]. %u@3%u@6Others experienced jeering and whipping; still others %i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@d%i@ being chained up and locked up. %u@3%u@7They were stoned to death, they were sawn %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@w%i@o, they were tempted and brought to the breaking point, they were slain by the sword, they wandered about in sheepskins, in goatskins, while being impoverished, afflicted, distressed, mistreated— %u@3%u@8%i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e whom the world is not worthy of—%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ deserts, on mountains, in caves, in underground tunnels—%vn~
          %u@3%u@9Because of their faith all of these people had a favorable account of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@p%i@l%i@o%i@i%i@t%i@s recorded for posterity’s sake but did not obtain the promise, %u@4%u@0God having provided something better for us, so that %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@n%i@k%i@s would not be complete without us %i@a%i@d%i@d%i@e%i@d.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@o…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@(%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@h%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@m%i@e%i@)…Lit: %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e, but with a verb tense which insinuates a one-time believing, one that occurred in the past.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@e%i@t%i@y%i@-%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@e%i@t%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@i%i@l%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@s%i@t…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@b%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d …Lit: %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@p%i@e%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@m%i@i%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@a%i@a%i@c…Lit: %i@b%i@y%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@a%i@a%i@c%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@m%i@a…Also: %i@s%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@;%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@-%i@b%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@;%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@;%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@p%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e. The Gk. word used here at its core refers to the splendor of cities in contrast to the lack of such splendor one finds in the countryside.%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@e%i@x%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@l%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@ %i@i%i@n…Lit: %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@e. An expression; ref. note of Matt. 10:13.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@-%i@g%i@e%i@n%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h…Lit: %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@r%i@r%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@F%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s…Some translations render this ”now faith is,” which is also correct. However, the Gk. word for %i@n%i@o%i@w%i@ is the conjunction %i@d%i@e%i@,%i@ one of the most common words in the NT%i@.%i@ %I@D%i@e does not mean “at this moment in time.” Some ministers, however, take the word “now” to mean “faith is now” in other words “faith by nature exists at this moment in time.” They then go on to explain how a principle of faith is that it exists in the here-and-now, not some time in the future. While this is true about faith, this is not what the GT of 11:1 is saying. Other translations’ use of “now” should not be taken to mean “at the present time.”%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@b%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@h%i@i%i@p%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@f%i@f…The GT of this is a verbatim quotation of Gen. 47:31 in the LXX. As Jacob’s blessings of Joseph’s sons is found in Gen. 48, not 47, it’s a mystery why these two seemingly disjointed accounts are linked together here.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Hebrews Chapter 12%hb~
          %u@1For this very reason, we too, surrounded by such a cluster%u@[%u@a%u@] of %i@t%i@r%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ witnesses, let us lay aside every burden and the sin which entangles us and run with endurance the up-and-coming race we’re entered in, %u@2setting our undivided attention on Jesus, the originator and perfector of our faith, who, instead of %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ the task he was assigned to do, endured the cross, disregarding and having contempt for the shame %i@a%i@s%i@s%i@o%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@t ,and has sat down at the right hand of God’s throne (i.e., he took up the position of God’s chief executive). %u@3Furthermore, consider for a moment that he has endured such %i@e%i@x%i@t%i@r%i@e%i@m%i@e opposition from sinners, so that you not grow weary in %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@h%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ your souls and capitulate— %u@4You have yet to resist to the point of bloodshed, %u@5and you’ve completely forgotten the encouragement which addresses you as sons:%vn~
%si~
My son, do not take lightly the discipline of the Lord%vp~
%I@A%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%u@[%u@b%u@]%vp~
Nor capitulate when corrected by Him.%vp~
%u@6You see, whom the Lord loves He disciplines,%vp~
And He thrashes every son%vp~
Whom He has whole-heartedly welcomed as His own%u@[%u@c%u@].%vp~
%si~
%u@7You endure for the purpose of %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y discipline%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%u@[%u@c%u@]: God treats you like %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ son. In this regard, %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ any son whom his father doesn’t discipline? %u@8But if you live in absence of%u@[%u@d%u@] discipline, which you all get your fair share of now, then you’re children some strange woman had out of wedlock and not sons %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@c%i@l%i@u%i@d%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@m%i@i%i@l%i@y.%nn~
          %u@9Furthermore, we had fathers in the natural who disciplined us time and time again, and we gave them our respect; how much more should we submit to the Father of %i@o%i@u%i@r spirits and live %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y? %u@1%u@0You see, while it’s true that for a brief period%u@[%u@e%u@] %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@t%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ disciplined %i@u%i@s%i@ the way they personally thought discipline ought to be done, but He, though, %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ for our own benefit, for the purpose of us %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ partake of His holiness on an ongoing basis. %u@1%u@1While any discipline at the time it’s occurring is not considered to be a bundle of joy, but instead is painful, later on it yields a peaceful result, namely righteousness, to those who have been trained by %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@e %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2In light of this, put the hands that lie idle at your side and the knees which have become weak back in the position where they’re poised for action, %u@1%u@3and clear out a straight path for your feet, so that %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ hip joint, knee joint, etc. which is preventing you from walking not be dislocated any more, but rather be healed.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4Pursue peace with all people, and %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@u%i@e%i@ holiness, without which no one will see the Lord. %u@1%u@5Check up on any person who might lack the grace of God (i.e., who needs to receive mercy, kindness, or forgiveness from God) and help them in whatever situation %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ which is causing this, lest some root of bitterness grow up%i@ and become a source of irritation, annoyance, or trouble, and many people would be tainted by %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@o%i@t; %u@1%u@6lest there be some fornicator %i@m%i@e%i@t%i@a%i@p%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@ (i.e., someone who’s immoral in a way which is analogous to sexually immorality) or someone who’s profane or has no piety like Esau, who sold what was rightfully his by birth for one meal. %u@1%u@7In fact, you know %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@y%i@,%i@ how afterwards, while wanting to receive %i@h%i@i%i@s inheritance %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h the blessing %i@b%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@a%i@a%i@c, he was rejected; the simple fact is that there was no way he could turn the situation around%u@[%u@f%u@], although with tears %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ he tried.%vn~
          %u@1%u@8The fact of the matter is that you haven’t come to a physically tangible %i@m%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@ %I@S%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@i, to one which is on fire, and to darkness and to gloom and to a whirlwind %u@1%u@9and to the sound of a trumpet and to a voice speaking words, a voice which those who heard it begged that not another word be spoken to them; %u@2%u@0you see, they couldn’t take it anymore, couldn’t stand the order, “If so much as an animal happens to touch the mountain, it will be stoned %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h.” %u@2%u@1The scene was so terrifying that Moses said, “I’m terrified and shaking all over”—%vn~
          %u@2%u@2—No, you’ve come to Mount Zion and to the city of the Living God, the Jerusalem in heaven, and to a myriad of angels, %u@2%u@3to the mother of all church gatherings%u@[%u@g%u@] of the firstborn who’s registered in heaven, and to God the judge of all, and to spirits of upright, decent people who’ve been made perfect, %u@2%u@4and to Jesus the mediator of a new covenant and to the %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@e%i@ sprinkling-blood, which calls for%u@[%u@h%u@] better things than %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ Abel %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d.%vn~
          %u@2%u@5See to it that no one disregards or rejects what’s being called for. You see, if those people who disregarded or rejected %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ couldn’t escape after He warned them %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ on the Earth, how much more will they not escape, they who refuse Him Who warns from heaven? %u@2%u@6That voice shook the Earth back then, but at the present time there’s a promise which He has given which says, “I will yet cause the Earth to shake one more time, and not just %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ the Earth but the sky, outer space, and the spirit-world too.” %u@2%u@7But the phrase “yet one more time” insinuates the removal of those things which are shaken, as %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h have been created, so that what would remain would be the things which can’t be shaken.%vn~
          %u@2%u@8In light of this, as we heartily embrace a kingdom which can’t be shaken, let us maintain %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ thankfulness%u@[%u@i%u@], one in which we serve God in a way that pleases Him, %i@k%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ with reverence and awe: %u@2%u@9For our God is a consuming fire.%i@%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@c%i@l%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@u%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e…Lit: %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@e. Ref. major note of v. 5.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@-%i@h%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@l%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n…Lit: %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@s%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f…Lit: %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@i%i@e%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@o%i@d…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@w%i@ %i@d%i@a%i@y%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@d…Lit: %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@i%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@h. A hendiadys; ref. note of Matt. 3:11.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r…Lit: %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@m%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@t%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@k%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ [%i@t%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@k%i@s]%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@A%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@s%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e…An interpolation based on the fact that the word %i@d%i@i%i@s%i@c%i@i%i@p%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ in this verse comes from a root word meaning %i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ or %i@c%i@h%i@i%i@l%i@d, and refers to the discipline, correction, and instruction that a son receives that will mature him into the man he needs to become. This discipline is done with this long-term goal in mind and is not a simple punishment.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@r %i@m%i@e%i@t%i@a%i@p%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@r. We know from the OT account of Esau and Jacob that Esau never committed fornication, which is any act of sexual immorality (not just sex out of wedlock). Therefore, the episode where he sold his birthright for a bowl of stew is a metaphor to fornication: it’s the same sin but minus the sexual component. Esau had convinced himself that he would die if he didn’t eat the meal Jacob prepared (this was not true; nobody dies for lack of a single meal, especially someone who can still walk). He exchanged something precious for a short-term gratification of the flesh.%fn~
%i@%sb~
Hebrews Chapter 13%hb~
          %u@1Continue in your love for your fellow comrade, loving the fellowship you have with them. %u@2Don’t neglect to extend a hearty friendship-welcome to those who are new to a church, new to the area, or who are just plain different than yourselves. In doing this, some have unwittingly welcomed angels.%vn~
          %u@3Remember those who are in prison%u@[%u@a%u@] as though you’re fellow inmates, and %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@m%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@ those who are ill-treated as though you have to live in their shoes%u@[%u@b%u@].%vn~
          %u@4%I@B%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o honor the institution of marriage and %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ in bed is morally pure; for God will judge fornicators and adulterers.%vn~
          %u@5Be sure that the kind of life you live is absent the love of money; He himself said, “There’s no way I’ll ever leave you or forsake you.” %u@6%I@T%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@f%i@i%i@d%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e so much so that we perk up and have the gumption%u@[%u@c%u@] to say,%vn~
%si~
The Lord is my helper; I will not fear.%vp~
What can a person do to me?%vp~
%si~
          %u@7Remember your leaders, the very people who spoke the word of God to you, closely observe on a continual basis the end-result of their manner of life—mimic their faith.%vn~
          %u@8Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever.%vn~
          %u@9Don’t get sidetracked by different and novel teachings; you see, it’s good that the heart be established by grace, not by %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t food %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@e%i@a%i@t. %I@T%i@h%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s haven’t benefited those who have changed their lifestyles %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m. %u@1%u@0We have a %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l altar, and they who serve by performing the religious rituals in the %i@p%i@h%i@y%i@s%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@ tabernacle are not entitled to eat %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@p%i@r%i@o%i@d%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@t. %u@1%u@1In fact, the carcasses of the animals whose blood is brought by the high priest into the Holy of Holies are incinerated outside the camp%u@[%U@A%u@], %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d. %u@1%u@2In light of this, Jesus also, so that through his own blood he would purify, sanctify, and make the folk-people holy, suffered outside of the gates of the city %i@a%i@w%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@.%i@ %u@1%u@3So then, let’s go outside the camp %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ and go to him, pick up his vilification, vituperation, and reviling, and carry it ourselves.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4You see, here %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@a%i@n%i@e%i@t%i@ we don’t have a city %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ which is going to last into eternity, but we’re seeking after %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@i%i@t%i@y to come instead. %u@1%u@5Through him let us continuously offer up to God a sacrificial offering consisting of praise%u@[%U@B%u@], in other words, the fruit of lips which confess %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@s%i@ in his name and to his name (i.e., by his authority and to his glory). %u@1%u@6And don’t neglect to do acts of kindness and to help others financially; for God is quite pleased with sacrificial offerings such as these.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7Be persuaded by your leaders to the point of obeying them and submit to them; you see, they keep watch over your very lives%u@[%u@d%u@], as they’ll be held accountable for them%u@[%u@e%u@]. %I@B%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@m%i@i%i@t%i@ so that they may do %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@j%i@o%i@b with joy and not %i@r%i@e%i@g%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ grumbling; it just isn’t worth it.%vn~
          %u@1%u@8Pray for us, and keep on praying for us. We believe that we have a good conscience (i.e., we’re not involved in any wrongdoing; there’s nothing we feel guilty about) in that we are wanting to maintain a lifestyle of excellence in every respect. %u@1%u@9But more %i@i%i@m%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@l%i@y, I encourage you %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@y%i@ so that I’ll be restored to you (i.e., be reinstated and continue doing with you what I was doing) as soon as possible.%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Now may the God of peace, Who brought the Great Shepherd%u@[%u@f%u@] of the Sheep back from the dead by means of %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ blood of the eternal covenant—our Lord Jesus Christ— %u@2%u@1in every good %i@w%i@a%i@y put you into proper order and prepare you for a purpose, doing this with the goal of accomplishing His will, working in us what from His point of view is very pleasing%u@[%u@g%u@] through Jesus Christ, to whom %i@b%i@e%i@ the glory forever and ever. Let us pause for a moment to let that sink in%u@[%u@h%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Bear with me, comrades%u@[%u@i%u@], as I encourage you with this word of encouragement. You see, I’ve only briefly written to you %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@f%i@f%i@a%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@.%i@ %u@2%u@3Just so you know, our fellow comrade Timothy has been let out of jail. If he can manage to come over %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %I@I%i@ %i@a%i@m in a hurry, I’ll take him with me when I visit you.%vn~
          %u@2%u@4Extend my greetings to all those in leadership positions and to all the saints (i.e., all the other believers). Those from %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@R%i@o%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ Italy greet you.%vn~
          %u@2%u@5%I@M%i@a%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e grace %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e with you all.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@i%i@s%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@n%i@d%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@s%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@k%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@u%i@m%i@p%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@a%i@g%i@e. Used this way in Mark 10:49; 15:43; ref. note of John 16:33.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@s %fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%I@S%i@h%i@e%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@d…Also: %i@p%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@e%i@w%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@p%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@w%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@-%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@a%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%I@L%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@ %i@i%i@n…Lit: %i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@.%i@ Ref. note of Rev. 19:4.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@r%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@b%i@r%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@m%i@p…This word and the word %i@t%i@a%i@b%i@e%i@r%i@n%i@a%i@c%i@l%i@e%i@ used in v. 10 are both references to the tabernacle used by the Israelites when the wandered in the Sinai desert for forty years. Where the people lived was called a “camp” because they had no buildings to live in since they could be commanded by God to pick up and leave any day.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@i%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@s%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@c%i@r%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@i%i@s%i@e. This is a metaphor which compares praise offered to God to OT sacrifices offered to God and incinerated on the altar of burnt offerings. Some have misinterpreted this to mean that it is a personal sacrifice on our part to praise God.%fn~
%i@
James%ha~
       James addresses his epistle to Jewish believers, as he was the leader of the Jewish faction of the church. His wisdom is in the Semitic style that his brother Jesus used rather than the Greek style that Paul uses, giving it an unusual flavor which complements the other epistles.%nv~
       Church tradition holds that James prayed so much that his knees were calloused. His dedication to prayer comes across in the letter.%nv~
       Looking at the Greek text, James’s writing style is straightforward, shying away from some of the exotic verb tenses and particles one finds Luke and Paul using, but he also displays a deep vocabulary, using words which are not found anywhere else in the NT. For example, the words %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ and %i@d%i@r%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@,%i@ both occurring in 1:6; or the word %i@d%i@e%i@c%i@l%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s (%i@b%i@o%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g) in 3:5; or the word %i@s%i@t%i@o%i@k%i@e%i@r%i@ in 3:6. James’s writing is rich in metaphors and other figures of speech and is seasoned with words and concepts which came directly from his brother, such as the “trophy of life” in 1:12. James’s generous use of metaphors (like “bridle his tongue” in 1:26) and other figures of speech makes this a rich piece of literature and should be high on the list of books in the Bible that should be read purely for literary content, such as English class readings.%nv~
       But it’s more important to get the gist of what James says rather than parse with a fine-toothed comb his writing looking for logical fallacies, as his writing is similar to John’s, not written like a science textbook. A fair amount of interpolations are necessary to prevent the book from being lost on the reader. An example of this is 4:5, where he cites the Old Testament and Bible scholars can’t find the exact verse he’s quoting from.%nv~
       But after granting this allowance and understanding who James is, one begins to see things from his point of view. He talks about the “perfect code” and “freedom’s code” being the Law of Moses on the surface, but underneath focuses on the more important aspects of the Law that Jesus emphasized, such as loving your neighbor and helping the poor. Unlike many of the strict Jews of the day, James isn’t caught up in the rituals of the Law; a keeper of the Law will act in love towards others—not like the rich, whom he disdains since they are oppressive.%nv~
       Speaking of the rich, James defines the Judeo-Christian perspective of oppressor vs. oppressed, telling the oppressive-rich to stop oppressing the poor, excoriating them morally. This is unlike the Marxist perspective which seeks to eliminate the rich and change the entire economic system.%nv~
       James pulls in concepts from the Old Testament and gives us continuity, taking the cue from Jesus, as both James and Jesus teach that these concepts have not changed but have been better defined. The Law of Moses is the most prominent example, but there are other concepts such as “God is One” (2:19; 4:12) and what the nature of faith is.%nv~
%i@%sb~
James Chapter 1%hb~
          %u@1James, a servant/slave of God and of %i@t%i@h%i@e Lord Jesus Christ:%vn~
      To %i@t%i@h%i@e %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@-%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ the%i@ twelve tribes %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l%u@[%U@A%u@] who are among the Diaspora (%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@c%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@J%i@e%i@w%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@l%i@d):%vn~
      I’m delighted to write to you%u@[%u@a%u@]:%vn~
          %u@2Consider it a joy, my %i@d%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@ comrades, when you %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ fall into various tests and trials which find out what you’re made of, %u@3knowing that the process of proving your faith produces perseverance. %u@4Let perseverance have %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@p%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@u%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ a mature, completed work, in order that you would become mature and that every part of you would become complete with nothing left out.%vn~
          %u@5But%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@…If someone is lacking in%u@[%u@b%u@] wisdom, advise him to%u@[%U@B%u@] simply ask %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@s%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@ from the giving-God %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@q%i@u%i@e%i@s%i@t without chewing the person out or demeaning him, and it will be given to him. %u@6But admonish him to%u@[%U@B%u@] ask in faith, nothing about him wavering in doubt: you see, a person who doubts is like the way that ocean waves are moved and tossed about by the wind. %u@7To this point, you should adjust%u@[%U@B%u@] that person’s expectations so that he does not expect to receive anything from the Lord, %u@8%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a double-minded man, irresolute in all his ways.%vn~
          %u@9Get%u@[%U@B%u@] the Humiliated, Abased Person to glory and take pride in his exaltation, %u@1%u@0and %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@w%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t the rich man %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@e humility and self-abasement%u@[%U@C%u@], because, like the wild flowers of the field%u@[%U@D%u@] which reach an apex when they blossom and then fade back into obscurity, he too will %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ pass away %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@b%i@s%i@c%i@u%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@y. %u@1%u@1You see, the sun rose and dried out the wild flower with its sweltering heat%u@[%u@c%u@], its flower-part fell off, and the lovely appearance it projected was destroyed—this is the same way that the rich man will waste away in his journey %i@t%i@h%i@r%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Blessed is %i@t%i@h%i@e man who perseveres %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ tests and trials, since, after he’s attained approval %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@, he’ll receive the trophy%u@[%u@d%u@] %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@f%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ life%u@[%U@E%u@], which is promised to those who love Him. %u@1%u@3Teach%u@[%U@B%u@] the person who’s being tested by some sort of trial or temptation not to say, “I’m being tested by God %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@m%i@e.” You see, God is un-tempt-able by any evil; He tempts no one. %u@1%u@4Each person is tempted when he’s lured and dragged off by the passions which are peculiar to him %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@e%i@x%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n. %u@1%u@5Then once passion or desire has conceived%u@[%U@F%u@], it gives birth to sin. When it’s finished running its course, sin produces death (%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@g%i@n%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@j%i@o%i@y%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@f%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n).%vn~
          %u@1%u@6Don’t get led down the primrose path, my dear comrades. %u@1%u@7Every good gift and every perfect present is from %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@k%i@y above, coming down from the Creator of Astronomical Objects (i.e. the sun, the moon, stars, etc.), with whom there is no deviation %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@b%i@j%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@s and no hint or suggestion of change %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m%u@[%U@G%u@]. %u@1%u@8Having planned and decided %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@o, he birthed us in%u@[%u@e%u@] a conceptualization%u@[%u@f%u@] of truth with the end-goal of us being the crème de la crème%u@[%u@g%u@] of His creation.%vn~
          %u@1%u@9Be sure you get this down pat, my dear comrades: Each person should see to it%u@[%U@B%u@] that he’s quick to listen, slow to speak, slow to anger%u@[%u@h%u@]. %u@2%u@0You see, a man’s anger won’t live up to God’s standards of right and wrong. %u@2%u@1In light of this, once you’ve rid yourself of any filthy residue%u@[%u@i%u@] of malice, with a soft-spoken, gentle self-restraint take to heart and fully embrace the implanted word %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d which is able to relieve, rescue, and preserve your mind and emotions%u@[%u@j%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@2But become practitioners of a given subject matter%u@[%u@k%u@] and not just students who hear it taught, deceiving themselves %i@b%i@e%i@c%i@a%i@u%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@,%i@ %u@2%u@3because if somebody hears a subject lectured to him but doesn’t put it into practice, that guy’s like a man %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@s at himself%u@[%u@l%u@] in a mirror and gets an idea of what he looks like— %u@2%u@4you see, he got an idea of what he looks likes, walked away, and immediately forgot what he looks like%u@[%U@H%u@]. %u@2%u@5But the fellow who crouched down and looked carefully at a perfect code, a freedom code, and stays put %i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ and didn’t become a forgetting-student but became a doing-practitioner, that fellow will be blessed in his doing.%vn~
          %u@2%u@6If anyone thinks that he %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f his religion%u@[%U@I%u@] %i@a%i@n%i@d isn’t reigning in%u@[%u@m%u@] his tongue but instead kids himself %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@g%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@l%i@y—this sort of religion is worthless. %u@2%u@7A pure set of religious do’s and don’ts—a set that’s untainted from the Father-God’s%u@[%u@n%u@] point of view—is to visit orphans and widows in dire need for the purpose of helping them, while keeping oneself unstained from the world, %i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%I@I%i@’%i@m%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u…Lit: %i@j%i@o%i@y. A common salutation found in the NT; same one in Matt. 26:49; ref. note there.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@l%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n…Lit: %i@l%i@e%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t. Same verb used in v. 4 %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@l%i@e%i@f%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t, and this verb is used in the same voice%i@.%i@ James is obviously using this as a transition.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@s%i@w%i@e%i@l%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@a%i@t…Lit: %i@b%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@n%i@d%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@y…Lit: %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@n [in this context, a %i@v%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h]. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@i%i@n…Or: %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@a%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@p%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@i%i@z%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d. Ref. John 1:1.%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@c%i@r%i@è%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@ %i@c%i@r%i@è%i@m%i@e…Lit: %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@s%i@t%i@-%i@f%i@r%i@u%i@i%i@t%i@s. Ref. note of Rom. 8:23.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@q%i@u%i@i%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@e%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@e%i@a%i@k%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@r…James’s use of the Gk. aorist tense here is a bit unexpected. It’s as though he’s picturing a single, hypothetical instance and not speaking in generalities.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@f%i@i%i@l%i@t%i@h%i@y%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@i%i@d%i@u%i@e…Lit: %i@d%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@r%i@p%i@l%i@u%i@s [or %i@s%i@u%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@l%i@u%i@o%i@u%i@s; %i@r%i@e%i@m%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g]. An hendiadys; ref. note of Matt. 3:11.%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@u%i@e%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@e%i@m%i@o%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@b%i@j%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@t%i@t%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d. James uses the definite article with%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@d%i@ in v. 21 but drops it in vv. 22, 23.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f…Lit: %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@n…Or: %i@b%i@r%i@i%i@d%i@l%i@i%i@n%i@g. A metaphor which compares taming the tongue to taming a horse.%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@F%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@-%I@G%i@o%i@d…Lit: %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@F%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r. A hendiadys.%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@l%i@o%i@o%i@d%i@-%i@d%i@e%i@s%i@c%i@e%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@w%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@r%i@a%i@e%i@l …Lit: %i@t%i@w%i@e%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@i%i@b%i@e%i@s. The phrase twelve tribes is a metonymy for all Israelites. By specifying the twelve tribes, James makes the distinction between the Jewish believers and the Gentile believers. Since James’s authority is over the church in Jerusalem, and perhaps all of Israel, he extends his pastoral care to all believing Israelites who for one reason or another are located outside of Israel but nevertheless are Jewish like those living in Israel. At the time this epistle was written, there were more Jews outside of Israel than there were in Israel. But the schism in the early church between the Jewish and the non-Jewish believers would naturally cause the Jewish believers living outside of Israel to gravitate towards and affiliate with James.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@a%i@d%i@v%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@o…%i@a%i@d%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@i%i@s%i@h%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@o…%i@a%i@d%i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t…%i@g%i@e%i@t…%i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t…etc…Lit: %i@h%i@a%i@v%i@e [or %i@l%i@e%i@t] %i@h%i@i%i@m. James uses this third-person imperative form of the Gk. verb in a parallel fashion as a figure of speech.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@w%i@i%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@t%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@l%i@f%i@-%i@a%i@b%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@i%i@l%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n. (The interpolations are justified by the parallel construction.) Before making generalizations about the wealthy based on this verse, one should first read James 2:6–7; 5:1–6 and understand that the “rich man” of that passage is the same “rich man” in v. 10,11 here. Though there’s a tendency for wealthy people to be abusive, not all of them are. But all of them are reminded to stay humble.%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%i@w%i@i%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@e%i@l%i@d…Lit: %i@g%i@r%i@a%i@s%i@s. Max and Mary claim that in this context this refers to wild flowers and not grass and that this is a picture of fragility from the OT (ref. Is. 40:6; Ps. 103:15%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@p%i@h%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@e%i@p%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@s%i@f%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ life…Lit: %i@c%i@r%i@o%i@w%i@n [%i@v%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@h] %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e. This is a metaphor where obtaining a deeply satisfying life by persevering through trials is compared to a victor being awarded the victor’s wreath. The word %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e leans on the definition Jesus put forth in John 6:53, “if you won’t eat the Man’s flesh and drink his blood, you don’t have life within you.” In the next verse Jesus goes on to talk about eternal life, which is that special fullness of life that God gives. By this reasoning, the word %i@l%i@i%i@f%i@e%i@ in v. 12 here does not refer to physical existence but rather is the same concept of life and eternal life which Jesus taught. What James is saying is that perseverance through trials and temptations results in a deep richness to one’s life.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%i@c%i@o%i@n%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@d…Same word used in Luke 1:24 when Elizabeth managed to become pregnant, insinuating a bit that this was only achieved after some difficulty. A few words later in this verse, James says %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@n, where the word %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@ is just that—a woman giving birth.%i@ This verse is a metaphor where temptation is compared to a man who impregnates a woman (i.e. a person) and she conceives a child sin and gives birth to it.%fn~
%u@[%U@G%u@]%I@C%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@A%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@ %I@O%i@b%i@j%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@(%i@i%i@.%i@e%i@.%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@o%i@n%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@r%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@e%i@t%i@c%i@.%i@)%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@o%i@v%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@b%i@j%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@g%i@g%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m…Lit: %I@F%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@L%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@s%i@,%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@v%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g. The same Gk. word for %i@l%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@s%i@ used here in v. 17 is the same Gk. word used in Gen. 1:16 in the LXX, “And God made the two great lights…”; therefore, the “lights” James refers to are the sun, the moon, and every other celestial object which emits light. The word %i@s%i@h%i@a%i@d%i@o%i@w%i@ used in this verse is similar in meaning to the way it’s used in Heb. 10:1; i.e., it’s not a physical shadow but rather an imperfect representation of another object. The Gk. words for%i@ %i@v%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ and %i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ are astronomical terms. In addition, it’s been known since ancient times that the movement of the planets, the rotation of the earth, etc. are extremely precise and entirely predictable. Therefore, James is saying that the same God who put into place such precision will apply the same precision to His gift-giving.%fn~
%u@[%U@H%u@]%i@f%i@o%i@r%i@g%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@o%i@o%i@k%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e…James is describing what we all experience on a daily basis. While you’re looking in the mirror, you know exactly what you look like, but the moment you step away, you immediately forget what that was no matter how long you were staring into the mirror. Let’s say a woman looks in a mirror to see how her hair looks. She’ll step away, worry that this lock or that braid doesn’t quite match her outfit, then step back up to the mirror and look at herself again. Why did she step back to the mirror a second time?—Because she forgot what she looked like.%fn~
%u@[%U@I%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@r%i@i%i@c%i@t%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@d%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@’%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@g%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@k%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@g%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s. Some liberties taken. The word %i@r%i@e%i@l%i@i%i@g%i@i%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ insinuates the rituals performed by the Jews. This insinuation is confirmed by the selection of words James uses in v. 27, namely %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ [%i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@f%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@d] and %i@u%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@d, which smack of Jewish religious purification rituals.%fn~
%i@%sb~
James Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1My comrades, don’t have a faith in our Lord of Glory Jesus Christ which shows favoritism. %u@2If a powerful businessman%u@[%u@a%u@] wearing an expensive suit%u@[%u@b%u@] were to join your synagogue%u@[%u@c%u@], and a poor man in ragged%u@[%u@d%u@] clothing were to join, %u@3you’d be naturally inclined to favor the fellow in the expensive suit and tell him, “Let’s make sure you’re seated up front in the reserved section where all the important people sit%u@[%U@A%u@],” and you would tell the poor guy, “Stand against the wall in the back or sit where the usher sits and be ready to fill in for him and run an errand when we call%u@[%U@A%u@].” %u@4Have you not shown bias towards those among you, preferring one person over another, and have you not become decision-makers%u@[%u@e%u@] whose thought process consists of really bad, downright evil, things?%vn~
          %u@5Listen, my dear comrades: Hasn’t God chosen the world’s poor to be rich in faith and to get their individual slice of God’s involvement with the human race%u@[%u@f%u@], which He promised to those who love Him? %u@6But you’ve treated the poor with contempt. Don’t the rich oppress you and drag you into court? %u@7Don’t they cuss at, slander, and revile your excellent, %i@h%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@-%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@d reputation%u@[%U@B%u@]? %u@8If there really is a perfect regal code %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@y and if the code is based on the Bible verse %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@s, “Love your neighbor as yourself,” %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n you’re on the right track%u@[%u@g%u@]. %u@9But if you show favoritism, you’re committing a sin and are incriminated by the Law %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@M%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@s. %u@1%u@0In fact, that particular individual who’s willingly trying to keep the Law but falls short%u@[%u@h%u@] in one area is guilty of violating it as a whole.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1Here’s an example: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %I@O%i@l%i@d%i@ %I@T%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ said “Don’t commit adultery” also said “Don’t commit murder.” Now if you didn’t commit adultery but committed murder, you %i@n%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@l%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ became a Law-violator, %i@v%i@i%i@o%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %I@L%i@a%i@w%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@o%i@u%i@g%i@h%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@v%i@i%i@o%i@l%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@a%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@t. %u@1%u@2Talk and behave as though as though you’re going to be held to a standard defined by freedom’s code and judged by it. %u@1%u@3You see, the judgment %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@c%i@e%i@ will be merciless towards those who won’t show mercy. Mercy trumps judgment.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4What benefit is it, my comrades, if (%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@g %i@s%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@p%i@o%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@i%i@l%i@l%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n) this person says he has faith but has no actions %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@t? That %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@-%i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@d faith%u@[%U@D%u@] won’t pull him out %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%u@[%u@i%u@], will it? %u@1%u@5If a comrade were to find himself or herself having no clothing whatsoever to protect his or her body with and lacking minimum-sustenance food, %u@1%u@6and if you were to tell him, “See you later, take care now%u@[%u@j%u@]. Stay warm and get plenty to eat,” but not provide physical necessities for him, what good is that? %u@1%u@7The %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ faith%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@l%i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ is the same way: if it were to not have actions %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@t, it would be%u@[%u@k%u@] void of life, being %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s consistent with itself.%vn~
          %u@1%u@8Putting that aside now—someone is bound to say, “You have faith %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@t and I have actions %i@b%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@m.” Show me your %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ faith apart from the actions %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@t, and I’ll show you the %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ faith from out of my actions. %u@1%u@9You believe that there is %i@o%i@n%i@l%i@y one %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@e God %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@m%u@[%U@E%u@]? Good job. The demons believe it as well and quiver in their boots over it%u@[%u@l%u@].%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Oh you nit-wit—were you interested in knowing that the %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f faith %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@s apart from %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ amounts to nothing%u@[%u@m%u@]? %u@2%u@1Wasn’t our patriarch Abraham made right in God’s sight%u@[%u@n%u@] from actions after offering his son Isaac upon the altar? %u@2%u@2%I@I%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@s%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@A%i@b%i@r%i@a%i@h%i@a%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@f%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %I@I%i@s%i@a%i@a%i@c,%u@ one sees that the %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f faith operates together with its %i@a%i@c%i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@n%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ actions and comes to fruition out of the actions. %u@2%u@3The verse of Scripture was fulfilled which says, “Abraham believed in God, and it wound up being credited to him as righteousness,” and he was called a friend and close-companion of God. %u@2%u@4Observe that a person is made right in God’s sight as the result of actions and not by faith on its own.%u@[%U@F%u@] %u@2%u@5Wasn’t the prostitute Rahab made right in God’s sight the same way—as the result of actions—cooperating with the agents and hurrying them out another way? %u@2%u@6For as the body is dead %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ apart from a spirit, in the same way the %i@g%i@e%i@n%i@u%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ faith apart from works is dead too.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@a%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@w%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@u%i@s%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@m%i@a%i@n…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@-%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n. %I@G%i@o%i@l%i@d%i@-%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@e%i@d is a synecdoche. The ring on the man’s finger is a signet ring, a ring used for making sizeable purchases or validating transactions.%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@p%i@e%i@n%i@s%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@i%i@t…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@c%i@l%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@s. Some liberties taken. Only the rich and noblemen wore bright clothing. %fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@j%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@n%i@a%i@g%i@o%i@g%i@u%i@e…Lit: %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@y%i@n%i@a%i@g%i@o%i@g%i@u%i@e. An idiom; ref. note of Acts 19:8.%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%i@r%i@a%i@g%i@g%i@e%i@d…Lit: %i@f%i@i%i@l%i@t%i@h%i@y%i@-%i@d%i@i%i@r%i@t%i@y%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]%i@d%i@e%i@c%i@i%i@s%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@-%i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@r%i@s…Lit: %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@e%i@s%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@i%i@v%i@i%i@d%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@l%i@i%i@c%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@v%i@o%i@l%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@r%i@a%i@c%i@e…Lit: %i@i%i@n%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@d%i@o%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@a%i@c%i@k…Lit: %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@l%i@l%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@t…Lit: %i@s%i@t%i@u%i@m%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@s. A less-common word for %i@s%i@t%i@u%i@m%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ [%i@p%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@ō,(πταίω/Strong’s 4417)] than the one usually used [%i@s%i@k%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@l%i@o%i@n, (σκάνδαλον/Strong’s 4625)], but both are Gk. renderings of the OT word %i@s%i@t%i@u%i@m%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@.%i@ Ref. note of Matt. 11:6.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@p%i@u%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@s%i@a%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%I@S%i@e%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@t%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@w…Lit: %I@G%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@e. A common parting remark.%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@w%i@o%i@u%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e…Lit: is. A grammatical error made by James, presumably.%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@q%i@u%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@i%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@o%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@i%i@t…Lit: %i@s%i@h%i@u%i@d%i@d%i@e%i@r. Some liberties taken.%fn~
%u@[%u@m%u@]%i@a%i@m%i@o%i@u%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@i%i@d%i@l%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@n%u@]%i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t…Lit: %i@j%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@i%i@e%i@d%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%I@L%i@e%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@’%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@p%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@o%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@t…%I@S%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@c%i@k%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@u%i@s%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@a%i@d%i@y%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@u%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@r%i@r%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@l%i@l…Lit: %I@S%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@o%i@d…%I@S%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@o%i@t%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@o%i@l. Liberties taken. Unlike modern times, in ancient times, people at an event were not seated randomly but were seated in seats that were arranged so that one could tell their importance at the function by the location of the seat in proximity to whatever is the center. Also, the phrase %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@m%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@o%i@t%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@o%i@l is a NT expression which means that such person is subordinate to whomever he’s seated under.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@c%i@u%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@s%i@l%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@r%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@v%i@i%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@,%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@r%i@d%i@-%i@e%i@a%i@r%i@n%i@e%i@d%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@u%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n…Lit: %i@b%i@l%i@a%i@s%i@p%i@h%i@e%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@a%i@u%i@t%i@i%i@f%i@u%i@l%i@ %i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e [or%i@ %i@e%i@x%i@c%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@p%i@u%i@t%i@a%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n]%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@g%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@s%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@y%i@o%i@u. Many scholars assume that James is talking about blaspheming God’s name, but a literal interpretation does not support this assumption.%fn~
%u@[%U@C%u@]%i@p%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@g%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@d%i@e…Lit: %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@f%i@e%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@o%i@y%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@w. James 1:25 “perfect law” refers to this same concept. The perfect law transcends the legalistic practice of the Law of Moses and lays down a better, perfect, and higher code of conduct, the same one that Jesus talked about in the Sermon on the Mount when he said, “It is written but I say.”%fn~
%u@[%U@D%u@]%I@T%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h…Lit%i@:%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h. In the Gk. James adds the definite article before the word %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ to indicate that he’s talking about a specific type of so-called faith. He adds a %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ before %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ in in various places in the passage of v. 14–17.%fn~
%u@[%U@E%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@l%i@y%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@.%i@ %I@H%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@,%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@a%i@r%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %I@H%i@i%i@m…Lit: %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e. Also appears in 1 Cor. 8:4; Rom. 3:29; Gal. 3:20: this is a quotation from Deut. 6:4. The brevity of the statement only enhances its profoundness, as it speaks to so many things about God. This one statement is the foundation for all Abrahamic religions.%fn~
%u@[%U@F%u@]%I@O%i@b%i@s%i@e%i@r%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@e%i@r%i@s%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@d%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@n%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@i%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@w%i@n…The passage consisting of vv. 14–26 has been misunderstood for years, even to the point where Martin Luther refused to include the book of James in his translation of the Bible, as he thought James is promoting a righteousness based on works. He’s not. The point James makes is that genuine faith is always accompanied by works (actions) which reflect it and are the result of it. Genuine faith cannot exist without these accompanying actions. This does not mean that if a person manufactures the actions they necessarily have the works, but it means that the two must go hand-in-hand.%fn~
%i@%sb~
James Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1There should not be a lot of you becoming instructors%u@[%U@A%u@], my comrades, knowing that we’ll be held to a higher standard%u@[%u@a%u@]. %u@2You see, we all mess up or fall short%u@[%u@b%u@] in many ways. If a given person doesn’t mess up in speech, that fellow has got his act together%u@[%u@c%u@], able to reign in his entire body%u@[%U@B%u@] as well. %u@3Now we%u@[%u@d%u@] stick bits in the mouths of horses in order to prevail upon them to do our bidding, and %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@ we guide their entire bodies. %u@4Ships too, for example, are gigantic and are propelled by stiff breezes, guided by the smallest %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@a%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e—a rudder—in whatever heading the helmsman selects. %u@5Analogous to this, the tongue is a small part %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@m%i@u%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@l%i@a%i@r%i@g%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@u%i@n%i@i%i@t and makes outrageous remarks%u@[%U@C%u@].%vn~
      I’m telling you what, %i@i%i@t%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@k%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@y%i@ %i@s%i@a%i@y%i@:%i@ “Just a tiny flame can set even an enormous forest on fire%u@[%u@e%u@].” %u@6And the tongue is a flame %i@i%i@n%i@d%i@e%i@e%i@d, an elaborate mechanism%u@[%u@f%u@] of wrong-doing—the tongue occupies a position of preeminence%u@[%u@g%u@] among our body parts—the defiler of the entire body and stoker of the Merry-go-round of Life%u@[%U@D%u@]—and is itself stoked by hell.%vn~
          %u@7In fact, human beings by nature tame wild animals. All sorts—land, aquatic, reptilian—are %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@o%i@c%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@f being tamed and have been tamed, %u@8but not a single person can tame the restless, unstable tongue, full of deadly poison. %u@9With it we thank the Father-God%u@[%u@h%u@] and with it we swear at %i@o%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w man, those who have been created in the image of God. %u@1%u@0Out of the same mouth come thanksgiving and cussing. This is not the way it’s supposed to be, my comrades. %u@1%u@1Non-contaminated and contaminated %i@w%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@r doesn’t pour out of the same spring, now does it? %u@1%u@2It’s not possible, my comrades, for a fig tree to yield olives or a grape vine figs, or for %i@a%i@ water%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@u%i@r%i@c%i@e to produce %i@b%i@o%i@t%i@h%i@ salt water %i@a%i@n%i@d fresh water, is it?%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Who among you is wise and understanding? Let him display his deeds which come from the good conduct %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@o%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@’%i@s%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@’%i@s%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@m%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%i@s%i@ in wisdom’s gentleness. %u@1%u@4But if you have bitter jealousy and rivalry in your heart, don’t distort the truth by bragging and lying%u@[%u@i%u@]. %u@1%u@5This is not the same wisdom which comes from the spiritual world where God lives%u@[%u@j%u@], but %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@u%i@n%i@n%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@-%i@s%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@s%i@d%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h is %i@a%i@m%i@o%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@o%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@s%i@ ruthlessly pragmatic, psychopathic, and diabolic%u@[%U@E%u@]. %u@1%u@6The fact is, where jealousy and rivalry %i@e%i@x%i@i%i@s%i@t, there is turmoil, and every bad thing imaginable is done%u@[%u@k%u@]. %u@1%u@7But the wisdom from the spiritual world where God lives is pure and innocent, then %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ peaceful, considerate, reasonable, full of mercy, and without pretense. %u@1%u@8The end-result where everything turns out right has its origins%u@[%u@i%u@] in peace by those who put peace into practice.%vn~
%sf~
%u@[%u@a%u@]%i@w%i@e%i@’%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@e%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@s%i@t%i@a%i@n%i@d%i@a%i@r%i@d…Lit: %i@w%i@e%i@ %i@w%i@i%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@r%i@e%i@c%i@e%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@r%i@ %i@j%i@u%i@d%i@g%i@m%i@e%i@n%i@t%fn~
%u@[%u@b%u@]%i@m%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@u%i@p%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@ %i@f%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@s%i@h%i@o%i@r%i@t…Lit: %i@s%i@t%i@u%i@m%i@b%i@l%i@e. Same word used in James 2:10, see note there.%fn~
%u@[%u@c%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@f%i@e%i@l%i@l%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@g%i@o%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@c%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@g%i@e%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@m%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@p%i@l%i@e%i@t%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@d%u@]%I@N%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@w%i@e…Lit: %I@N%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@i%i@f. Appears to be a mistake in the autograph; some early manuscripts have redacted it out.%fn~
%u@[%u@e%u@]J%i@u%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@t%i@i%i@n%i@y%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@c%i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@n%i@ %i@s%i@e%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@o%i@r%i@m%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@i%i@r%i@e…Lit: %I@H%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@s%i@m%i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@l%i@a%i@m%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@o%i@w%i@ %i@g%i@r%i@e%i@a%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@f%i@o%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@k%i@i%i@n%i@d%i@l%i@e%i@s. In the GT this is: %i@h%i@ā%i@l%i@i%i@k%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@p%i@u%i@r%i@ %i@h%i@ā%i@l%i@i%i@k%i@ā%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@u%i@l%i@ā%i@n%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@a%i@p%i@t%i@e%i@i%i@ (ἡλίκον πῦρ ἡλίκην ὕλην ἀνάπτει). An obvious alliteration/assonance and presumably a commonly-used expression.%fn~
%u@[%u@f%u@]%i@e%i@l%i@a%i@b%i@o%i@r%i@a%i@t%i@e%i@ %i@m%i@e%i@c%i@h%i@a%i@n%i@i%i@s%i@m…Lit: %i@a%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@l%i@d. Keep in mind that %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@l%i@d%i@ refers to the established order of mankind more so than the physical planet.%i@%fn~
%u@[%u@g%u@]%i@o%i@c%i@c%i@u%i@p%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@a%i@ %i@p%i@o%i@s%i@i%i@t%i@i%i@o%i@n%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@p%i@r%i@e%i@e%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@e%i@n%i@c%i@e…Lit: %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@s. The meaning of the word %i@s%i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ as used in this verse is the same meaning as it’s used in Ps. 110:1.%fn~
%u@[%u@h%u@]%I@F%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@-%I@G%i@o%i@d…Lit: %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %I@F%i@a%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@r. A commonly-used NT hendiadys.%fn~
%u@[%u@i%u@]%i@d%i@i%i@s%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@h%i@ %i@b%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@a%i@g%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@y%i@i%i@n%i@g…Lit: %i@b%i@o%i@a%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@a%i@n%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@e%i@ %i@a%i@g%i@a%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@r%i@u%i@t%i@h. Assuming this is an idiom and guessing what the idiom means.%fn~
%u@[%u@j%u@]%i@w%i@h%i@i%i@c%i@h%i@ %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@e%i@s%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@s%i@p%i@i%i@r%i@i%i@t%i@u%i@a%i@l%i@ %i@w%i@o%i@r%i@l%i@d%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %I@G%i@o%i@d%i@ %i@l%i@i%i@v%i@e%i@s…Lit: %i@c%i@o%i@m%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@w%i@n%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@o%i@m%i@ %i@a%i@b%i@o%i@v%i@e%fn~
%u@[%u@k%u@]%i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@i%i@m%i@a%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@d%i@o%i@n%i@e…Lit: %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ %i@b%i@a%i@d%i@ %i@d%i@e%i@e%i@d%i@s. The word %i@a%i@l%i@l%i@ is used as a figure of speech, a hyperbole or metonymy of a sort. Same figure of speech used in 1 Tim. 6:10, “For the love of money is the root of all evil.”%fn~
%u@[%u@l%u@]%i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@d%i@-%i@r%i@e%i@s%i@u%i@l%i@t%i@ %i@w%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@e%i@v%i@e%i@r%i@y%i@t%i@h%i@i%i@n%i@g%i@ %i@t%i@u%i@r%i@n%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@u%i@t%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@ %i@h%i@a%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ %i@o%i@r%i@i%i@g%i@i%i@n%i@s…Lit: %i@t%i@h%i@e%i@ %i@f%i@r%i@u%i@i%i@t%i@ %i@o%i@f%i@ %i@r%i@i%i@g%i@h%i@t%i@e%i@o%i@u%i@s%i@n%i@e%i@s%i@s%i@ %i@i%i@s%i@ %i@s%i@o%i@w%i@n%fn~
%fn~
%u@[%U@A%u@]%i@i%i@n%i@s%i@t%i@r%i@u%i@c%i@t%i@o%i@r%i@s…Or: %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@s. The Gk. word for %i@t%i@e%i@a%i@c%i@h%i@e%i@r%i@ is both (or either) one who imparts insight and understanding and one who gives moral instruction (ref. note of Acts 15:1), telling the pupil how he should conduct his life. In relation to giving moral instruction, it becomes clear why the instructor must be held to a higher standard.%fn~
%u@[%U@B%u@]%i@r%i@e%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y…Lit: %i@a%i@b%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@t%i@o%i@ %i@b%i@r%i@i%i@d%i@l%i@e%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y. The word %i@b%i@i%i@t%i@s%i@ in v. 3 is derived from the %i@b%i@r%i@i%i@d%i@l%i@e%i@ in v. 2. This combined with the repetition of the word %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ in v. 2 and %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@i%i@e%i@s%i@ in v. 3 indicates that %i@r%i@e%i@i%i@g%i@n%i@ %i@i%i@n%i@ %i@h%i@i%i@s%i@ %i@e%i@n%i@t%i@i%i@r%i@e%i@ %i@b%i@o%i@d%i@y%i@ is a metaphor which compares controlling one’s body by controlling one’s tongue to controlling a horse’s body by the use of bits.
